description:
I thought I would be turned away for not wearing a retro hat or sporting expensive ear buds.

Cosy venue with limited seating indoors and only one person taking orders, making coffee and delivering. The constant line of 3-4 diners kept the poor girl busy. Kudos to her for remaining calm and polite. 

The lack of indoor seating means that you have to hit the street. Benches, tables and a wooden garden nook (?) plus an iron railing were eclectic but surprisingly comfortable and convenient. 

All I had was a flat white. It was good, real good. I overheard others commenting positively on crispy croissants, fruit topped toast and other dishes. 

The aforementioned hatted hipsters disappeared into an Uber. After the initial hipster shock the crowd became more diverse and I didn't feel so out of place. Cool spot.
author: Richard L.

description:
Cute store. It knows what it serves and does it well. The everyday toast is always beautiful and photographs well. My only gripe is that they took down the pricing on their wall menu so you get hit by a number where the toast costs closer to a meal than a snack. SF at its finest. However, I would come back. It makes me savor each bite. The quality in here feels high so the price matches. Simple yet good quality items. I've tried also the avocado toast and the matcha chai (why didn't I think of this before? My two favorite drinks in one!) and then the Milk and Honey. All were very great.

-1 Star for the pricing. It's so expensive for a piece of bread and fruit. But I will probably come back. Sigh haha
author: Josie W.

description:
I took a friend here for brunch before she left for the airport as it was right across the street from my apartment.  This place was always packed on the weekends so I assumed that it would be amazingly delicious.  That being said, it was not quite up to my expectations.  I ordered the following:

Salmon Toast: smoked salmon on a dill cream spread with sprouts
PROS:
- dill spread did not overwhelm me with the taste of ... all herb.  Dill in particular, can be very strong so the balance needs to be just right.
- toast was not soggy meaning it was fresh made and came out quick
- side salad was a nice refreshing touch given that the toast itself was on the heavier end of the meal
CONS: 
- it'd be nice to have a little more salmon.  I realize smoked salmon is expensive, but even the bagels in NYC have more salmon and that's a staple for the city.  Not to mention, the price for this salmon toast was equivalent if not more than what I would get for a similar item.  

The one thing that I didn't quite like was the limited seating.  Inside had one large table with wall seats (as in a bench built into the window).  Private seating was located outside with maybe three small tables.  If the weather is bad which, can actually happen in the Bay, it doesn't bode well for eating in (or out rather).  Given that I live across the street, my toast probably would be able to survive the soggy-test had I decided to take my order to-go.  

Overall, it's nice but I wouldn't wait in line here on the weekend for this.
author: Vera L.

description:
This place has become so disappointing. 
I went two days in a row after the morning crew decided to take a 20+ person order + custom espresso drinks, shutting down and selling out their morning menu. 
Second day the scattered, nervous counter girl took my order, off sold some random toast to me immediately, then I waited a very long time for my incorrect order drink while she fixed other missing items from other customers. 
Most importantly the daily toast was awful. The fruit was dirty, I could taste the soil, and still had bugs crawling on it. The mascarpone was hard, the fruit was haphazard, the grapes were past their prime and so is Farm:Table.
author: Frank A.

description:
The only thing I wish I could change about this place is their pricing. Holy cow I spent over $25 for some toast, a slice of quiche and coffee!!! It was friggin tasty though. 

DAILY TOAST - they don't have a typical fruit they top this with, but it's a thick slice of sweet breath topped with  mascarpone and fruit. I didn't want to like it, but by golly it was good!! Idk if it's $9 good, but it's up there. I'd give it a 8/10 mostly because of the price. It would be a splurge type of thing more than anything else.  

SAVORY PIE - I ordered the veggie + meat. It was great, but not for $12!!! It was yummy for a quiche, but not for that price. 7/10

Overall it's a super cute restaurant, but it wouldn't be a consistent breakfast place for me (I'd be broke!!). I also wasn't a huge fan that the prices weren't listed. Their pricing online is cheaper than what they charged me. They were a 3.5/5 for me.
author: Kyrsten S.

description:
Unfortunately after three tries, and an issue each time, I think I'll have to pass. 

Pros: The outside area is really pretty and great for a nice day. The service is also really fast. 

Cons: The line can be very long, it's not cheap, and the service can be hit or miss. I've had my order wrong twice and once they even forgot it. To the servers credit, they've been quick to rectify it every time. 

I don't know... I want to like this place. Sadly I just don't.
author: Capers B.

description:
Food: food was delivered quickly, very fresh ingredients with well put together flavors 


Ambiance: the restaurant has a very cozy feel with a community table as well as private outdoor patio tables 


Service: the service is also very welcoming as if you were at someone's home. the staff was very friendly and sweet. 

my only suggestion would be more menu options and display pricing for items.
author: Eva D.

description:
We thought this was more of a sit-down brunch place so were kind of disappointed to find it to be so small with not much seating and meant to be for quick-bites. 

However, don't be deterred by the lack of seating or feel you have to eat quickly. The service is very friendly and the food is really good. The Daily Toast is *chef kisses fingers* with quality brioche, mascarpone spread, lots of fruit (wide variety), and nuts. Yeah, I could maybe make it at home, but there was lots of fruit and honestly well-worth $8. Of course, it's very Instagrammable. 

My friend liked her egg on croissant. My Frank the Pug Honey Latte was warm and sweet, but not overly so. 

I'd be back but definitely plan to get your food to-go. The menu doesn't really have prices but it's pretty reasonable for San Francisco and something that looks so aesthetic.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
What a great place with even nicer people working there. You can enjoy beautiful outdoor tables while eating their delicious food. 

We tried egg sandwich on gluten free bread and royal monsieur. Both were delicious and the royal sandwich was so big that my BF will enjoy it later today. Egg sandwich was so fresh that we actually had a conversation about the taste of the eggs.

Their coffee was really good and smooth. I tried their hibiscus iced tea and hot dinosaur tea. Both were very good.

We will definitely visit Farm: table next time we are in SF. You should do it too.
author: Magda S.

description:
Small shop that serves one of the best toast and breakfast sandwich as well as unique lattes. 

Farm : Table is very small, casual shop. There is one large family table inside and outside there's a few small tables and counter seats. They also converted the parking spot into a planter with bench seating. Don't be afraid to sit with strangers with some seats are open. 

I usually order the daily toast and the breakfast sandwich. The daily toast is a thick slice of bread with their house marscapone spread and topped with a good helping of seasonal fruit. The presentation of the toast is also so very nice with the fruit topped very beautifully. Instagram worthy.
The breakfast sandwich is on a croissant with hardboild eggs, a greens, and ham. 

They also have interesting drinks. I wanted to try the charcoal latte but since it didn't have any caffeine I decided to try the chai and matcha. I love chai and I love matcha, why don't I try it together. The taste was fine but the I think the matcha made it really grainy to me. The color also wasn't a great color if you think green mixed with brown. My friend got the golden tumeric latte and like it. 

I just so happen to be driving to SF when I go to Farm : Table and parking isn't bad at all. I am always able to find something within 2 blocks on a weekend morning.
author: Avita S.

description:
You'll get simple food here prepared deliciously with fresh ingredients, at a rather expensive price that may be justified for the convenience.

There are quite a different open face sandwiches to get here. I prefer the daily toast, with fruit on mascarpone. I typically stay nearby whenever I'm in San Francisco, and I have to say that I find myself coming back no matter how apathetic I feel about it.

I wouldn't dine here if you're expecting to get a table, and I wouldn't wait through the lines on the weekends, but its certainly worth a try if you're hungry and you're walking by, provided that there isn't a long wait.
author: Stanley W.

description: More of a coffee house with some food. Very limited seating. Food was pretty good but it's no sqirrl. Skip the croissant sandwich, was pretty normal.
author: Mendel L.

description:
Farm:Table is almost too small to qualify as a hole-in-the-wall place, honestly! I expected it to be small but not quite so tiny. Very cute but you'd certainly be blessed to secure seating. Hoping they can expand the space somehow soon! 

Food was amazing; I ordered an Egg on Croissant and Pug n Honey Latte   (soy substitute #LactoseIntolerant anyone?) to go and was completely satisfied with both. Had high expectations and wasn't disappointed!

I'm determined to try the Daily Toast next time; it not only looks pretty but also very nutritious (:

Note that the prices and menu changes frequently to reflect current prices in the market (fresh fruit, veggies, etc).
author: Vivian S.

description: This is a great little place in the heart of the city but is a bit expensive. Lots of great selections, especially for brunch and great service overall. They have a little bit of indoor seating but quite a bit of outdoor seating. I got the Almond Hummus sandwich and was a bit surprised that it was an open-faced sandwich where all of the ingredients were stacked on the bread. The vegetables seemed super fresh, the avocado was quite good, and the almond hummus spread was excellent - better than any hummus I've ever had. It is great if you combined the ingredients in one bite, but it is a little difficult. Overall, a really good and filling breakfast!
author: Sampath D.

description: Small place easily overlooked.  Almost felt like you weren't in San Francisco when you were here, but in a good way.  Limited seating inside and outside, but again, in a good way.  The menu was not so large that I got lost but I felt like I had a good number of choices to ponder I still had trouble deciding cause much of it sounded good.  My croissant was yummy (I obviously told them no ham) and my wife got the incredibly delicious breakfast toast (the one loaded with fruits). The mascarpone was sweet and fluffy, almost ricotta like , and honestly one of the best toasts either of have had.  We both got coffee as well, I had a honey latte of some sort which was just a touch sweet and overall smooth, so no complaints here.  Would most likely hit again for the toast alone, would make the trip worth it
author: Yaser R.

description: Slightly pricey but I got the daily toast and some sort of latte and it was delightful. The daily toast was different both times I got it which is what I was hoping for.
author: Justine C.

description: This place was busy but well worth the wait... I just had the egg on croissant...  super flakey croissant and the filling was on point!  Sooo good!
author: Alphonse M N.

description:
My fiance and I stayed across the street in the Courtyard Marriot, so when we wanted breakfast on a lazy Sunday morning and this place popped up, we were surprised we happened to be literally on the opposite side of the street from such a well-reviewed place.  That's San Francisco for you.

After reading about the small interior and long lines I thought it best to just order the food to-go and eat in our room.  I tried to call but got only a recording, so I walked over to place an order there.

The inside is as small inside as everyone says, one four-top table with seating for six (figure that out).  So while I stood in line next to the table, in the only walkway there was, directly in the way of the server bringing food out to the folks outside, I didn't see the appeal.  It's cramped, small, and you're always in the way of someone...but they had some good looking breakfast options and gluten-free bread, so in line, I stood.

The guys working the counter were nice enough, though it's obvious it's a small space and they have to work to make it all work, which would drive me nuts.

I got the Daily Toast for my fiance, and it looked really good.  Not quite as good in the to-go box as it does on a plate (based on other Yelp photos) but she said it was really good nonetheless.

I had the salmon toast, which is essentially an open-faced sandwich with some cream cheese, salmon, onions and a side of arugula.  It was okay, but nothing I feel I need to get again or recommend you get.  I know gluten-free bread isn't the same, and I get that, it was fine, but I am glad I only waited about 10 minutes to get it.  I'd have been way bummed if we waited longer, or ate there, as I hate being in the way while I eat.  

When I got my boxes, the guy realized I had too much to carry and offered to get me a bag, which I accepted and he paced everything in for me which was a big help.

So if you get the food to-go, eat somewhere cozy, you'll be happy with your choice.  I can't speak to standing and waiting and sitting there and eating.  I think I'd just go somewhere else instead.

We also had americanos, which were served in tiny paper cups, maybe the size of a Tall from Starbucks, too small for me, but it was better than drip from the hotel.

All in all, I think the food was good, not great, though my fiance said hers was great, I would be willing to try something else in the future, though to be fair, most of those things involve croissants, which I don't eat, so I'll probably not be back.
author: Luke W.

description: A literal hole in the wall with smashingly good brunch options! We took the savory tart, egg croissants, matcha chai latte and the regular latte. Will definitely come back here when I come to SFO again. Seating is an issue so get there early! Also, they run out of their famous stuff pretty quickly, so again, get there early
author: Pranjali S.

description: Small quaint little coffee shop with a small, yet light and refreshing menu. I went with their daily toast and lavender latte. Delicious! The marscapone cheese spread was like whipped cream. They also have a selection of plain croissants, chocolate croissants and other pastries and muffins. Share one large community table with others or sit outside their small open window space with 4 barstools outside the shop. Lovely place. Will come again!
author: Stephany C.

description: The food was fresh and amazing! Coffee was just as great. The service was quick and team was friendly. Really enjoyed this little spot!
author: Ligia R.

description:
Yelp 100 Challenge: 63/100

Having been eating very heavily meals during my weekend in SF, I needed some cleanse in my system. My friend came across Farm : Table and decided that we wanted to give this place a try since it looked like a healthier option. 

Keep in mind that this place only has a communal table inside their store that can seat ~6-8 people depending on how close you'd like to get with strangers, and approx. 4-5 more 2-person table outside along the building. Other than that, good luck, and hope that you can balance eating your meal on an interesting piece of artwork by the curb!

I opted for the daily toast, which had lots of different fruits on a thick piece of toast spread with some custard cream. IT WAS AMAZING! I loved how refreshing it is, and that the toast itself is very crispy and it kept me full for a good part of the day. Not to mention it was very carefully put together and looked amazing!
author: Katherine L.

description:
Solid breakfast and coffee spot in the Tenderloin.

Great food, great service, but the space is so small / crowded it's hard to enjoy your meal here. Would come back but only if I was on the go.
author: Spencer H.

description: Decent fare for a little hole in the wall farm fresh goodies spot.  Wish there were a few more options.  The egg sandwich was just ok.  Nice folks inside and prompt service.  I'll return for lunch sometime in the near future and try something new out.
author: Adam P.

description:
Decent food, but the presentation is much more impressive than the execution. We got the egg crossaint sandwich, kale salad, and daily toast, which were all good, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it. The crossaint sandwich had a hard boiled egg, which was interesting. Salad was pretty solid; generous with the avocado, but nothing outstanding. Daily toast is a must try; they rotate seasonal fruits and nuts on top of thick brioche bread (which to be honest, tasted the exact same as the loaves of white bread you get in Asian bakeries). 

Their house specialty drinks were my favorite! The Nutella latte is thick and chocolatey, and I got the matcha chai latte, which I was able to sub almond milk for. The matcha/chai combo was surprisingly complementary and didn't overpower each other.
author: Denise L.

description: I live right by this spot and have walked by many times.  Decided to try it out the other day and was impressed.  Great service by friendly people and they food was so yummy!  Definitely recommend... it does get quite busy though.
author: Amy D.

description: Daily toast was SO good, and that's coming from someone who doesn't usually eat sweet breakfasts. Lavender latte was ok, they forgot to put lavender in it when they first gave it to me though but they found me and gave me a little cup of lavender syrup lol
author: Scott K.

description:
Had a great start to the day here. A simple breakfast place. And when I say little, I mean little! There is one communal style table of five. That's it. But they have tables and chairs set up outside as well. 

Had the matcha chai latte- that's not a mistake. It's a matcha latte with chai. And the egg croissant and the daily toast. The matcha chai tasted exactly the way you think it would taste- matcha with chai : p
As for the food, the egg croissant was good but the daily toast is what I really enjoyed! I want my daily toast to look and taste like that!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Their almond croissant is good. Not the best I've had but it's definitely acceptable and by itself would get four stars

Their breakfast cereal: good balance between yogurt, a dollop of jam, and cereal. Not sweetened cereal or granola which is always a turn-off for me.

Their breakfast toast: this is definitely the highlight of this place. The must get. The spread they put on top is spicy and sweet. Fresh fruit and a nice brioche bread that is just slightly toasted. This is definitely the thing to get when you come 

There Espresso Bar in cappuccino: cappuccino was roasted a bit dark but overall right where I would expect it to be

This is a great lightfair modern breakfast spot worth getting to if you're in the area 

I wish Yelp had a bit more variance on the score. This place is definitely better than A4 but not quite a perfect 5. So I'm going to give it an overall score of 4 but I would really prefer to get a 4.5
author: Zilla K.

description:
A cute little shop outside of Union Square.

I ordered:
- matcha chai tea latte (perfect for a cloudy day with just the right amount of spice that came with the chai)
- egg on croissant (seems ordinary but it was good - it's really not hard to screw up on breakfast food. there's egg, cheese, meat, and lettuce inside. the croissant comes warm, so at least you know it's made fresh to order)

My friend ordered the daily toast - definitely IG worthy with its fruit spread and mascarpone cream. 

Overall:
I'm glad my friend and I went on a weekday, otherwise we might have had to wait in line like other Yelpers mentioned. There is literally just one table inside and a sort of a counter set up outside, which really isn't ideal if it's anything but sunny outside. I'm glad I tried it out (partly for the Instagram), but I don't really think I'll come back.
author: Valerie T.

description:
The place is very tiny and seating is super limited so be aware of that when you visit this place. With that being said, I still thought the space was aesthetically pleasing. It can get pretty cramped because there is one table that can be shared among 4 people or so, but several seats are available outside. 

All of the staff members were friendly and helpful since it was my first visit and my friend and I had some questions and asked for recommendations. 

I ordered the daily toast because 1. It's beautiful 2. Mascarpone cheese. Need I say anymore? The second thing I ordered was a latte. The toast was as beautiful and as majestic as I imagined and also very hearty and decadent so it felt a bit more like a dessert than a breakfast but I was not complaining! It can be a bit difficult to eat but worth it. It is quite pricey for toast, but then again it's a pretty majestic toast, so I say, "Go on, treat yoself." It's not a place I would go often, but it is a nice little treat if you are in the area.
author: Christina C.

description:
seating situation: limited indoor seating (8 max to one picnic table), one picnic table outside, and two individual tables for two outside
food: the egg croissant sandwich was delicious; the salmon toast with a side salad was good as well
wait-time: about 10ish minutes - there was a slight wait as we were waiting for our food to be prepared 
price: pricey - none of the prices is displayed on the menu board, which is how they got us.
We ordered one salmon toast, one egg croissant, one nutella latte, and one charcoal latte and it totaled to approx. $35! Which is absolutely insane and unexpected. Honestly, the price of the food here is what turned me off and although the food was good, our breakfast didn't feel like it was worth $35.
author: Victoria X.

description:
I was wondering why this place gets such amazing reviews so went to finally try it and it was good, but I was a little underwhelmed.  But it's a cute spot so I'd still recommend checking it out but go as if you're going to a casual local small coffee shop.

Egg on croissant - very good. super flavorful. the avocado really added a little extra freshness to it.  Eggs are hard boiled eggs.  Super messy to eat but super enjoyable!  Add a touch of hot sauce and kick it up a notch too.

The croque royale (or whatever it was called) - super heavy.  Kind of one note and it looks a little one note too. I think it would have been better with ham, or an addition of a tomato or something.  It's thick white bread, with white turkey, with white cheese, with another piece of white bread.  It eats very heavy.  It does come with an arugula salad on the side to lighten it up but it's really hard to finish this sandwich.

Hot chocolate was super rich. Super yummy.

Chocolate croissant was also good. Chocolate is super deep flavored chocolate.

Bathrooms are across the street in the Courtyard by Marriott.

Street parking

Accepts credit cards.

Has one big square table with benches to fit 8 people inside; otherwise it's sidewalk tables or taking your food to go.  TINY inside!

I'm not sure I'd try this place on a weekend because I'd imagine the line is out the door and down the street with nowhere to sit, but if I'm around I would be open to trying it again.
author: Traci H.

description:
On 12/2/2017 when I was arriving in San Francisco, I visited to this beautiful place located in the Lower Nob Hill neighborhood called, "farm : table." This local cafe serves the customers to taste their extraordinary, eatable foods from breakfast to lunch every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is much laid back and elegant as I welcomed there. The concept is much like visiting to your local Starbucks, but it's much home living environment filled with country style decors and modern designs both inside and out despite the smaller sized room. Yes, it's very "farm-to-fork" feel, so you get the best naturally made foods right at your comfort zone without unwanted surprises!

The employees here from baristas and cookers are doing a great job for making the customers like me a wonderful and prodigious service! No cons at all.

Now onto the food! Since I'm new here coming from Sacramento, One of the employee recommended the breakfast croissant sandwich, so I ordered the Ham and Egg Croissant Breakfast sandwich as a recommendation. I also ordered a small cup of coffee too. As I ate it, it tasted sensational! The croissant baked perfectly and flaky to bite. The ingredients from seasoned eggs, smoked ham and garnishes all tasted delicious and mesmerizing! Delish!

Parking at farm : table can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

Bottom line, farm : table is the most incredible and outstanding local mini cafe that I've ever discovered it for the first time thanks to my trusty Yelp app! Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering! A well received visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: It was just what we were looking for in the morning! It's a small intimate space and we sat outside. The food was Fresh and light. We ordered their egg on croissant.
author: Lilly Z.

description:
After trying breakfast croissants and toasts for a few days we found the best around... A small location which offers homemade like food with delicious flavors and a welcoming atmosphere.

If you are around don't miss on trying their daily fruits toast or their egg croissant, both are breathtaking! 

The staff is well organized and very friendly, the place setup will make you feel like you're having breakfast at home with your family.
author: Christian M.

description:
Farm : Table's fruit toast is probably one of the best things I've ever eaten in my life. It's a nice thick slice of soft toast with freshly made mascarpone and an incredible variety of delicious fruit. It's pretty substantial for being fruit on toast. The fruit changes seasonally, too.

I've also had the croissant egg sandwich, which is also amazing, but more of a breakfast food, not a hearty lunch. 

The only reason I give Farm : Table 4 stars instead of 5 is for the lack of food variety and layout of the space. Although there are options for coffee beverages, they don't have much in terms of pastries. 

Also, the space isn't setup like a typical cafe. Instead of cafe tables, they have a large community table. The space is also cramped, whereas nice cafes are often open and airy, often flowing out into the sidewalk. The space is definitely no Blue Bottle or Sightglass Coffee. There is a nice parklet, but the street is typically windy, cold, and in shade due to the surrounding buildings. 

Overall, I highly recommend Farm : Table for breakfast, but would go somewhere else for brunch or lunch.
author: Joanna S.

description: Got food poisoning here from the croissant breakfast sandwich. I think the sauce in there was not fresh or kept in the fridge before serving.
author: Susan M.

description:
Decent and unique San Francisco breakfast experience. I stopped in for coffee and the daily toast (before yoga, naturally). The toast was a huge slice of brioche with a whipped marscapone topping and a variety of fruit. Each one seems different; I saw a few go out and I think mine was the only one with grapefruit. I would have preferred to know in advance what my topping would be, but I guess that's part of the fun. Coffee was ok, if a little burnt-tasting. A cheaper and similar alternative exists at Starbucks. 

Interior is tiny with just one communal table and a cream/sugar bar. There are a few tables and a window bar outside but this place is made for food and coffee on the go. 

Worth a try for a light but filling breakfast.
author: Kate D.

description:
I never write reviews but this place deserves one. 5/5 .. I feel cozy here. 

Isn't a large location which is fine, it's more a grab and go or if you're with someone else. 
Come check it out, you won't be disappointed with the Nutella Latte.
author: Scott A.

description:
This review is for one thing:

The Breakfast Croissant Sandwich except they ran out of Croissant and asked me if it was o.k. to have it on Brioche.

I think..think...this may have been a blessing in disguise b/c the sandwich was AMAZING.

If I go again I'll definitely get it on Brioche and probably convince whomever I'm with to get a Croissant one so we can taste test and if I'm by myself I just might mess around and order TWO to taste test on my own.  Nevertheless...a great ..cute little spot that I look forward to returning to.
author: Rod M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I'm drawn to small, hole in the wall atmospheres if they have amazing food, but the food and coffee just wasn't that great. I feel a little bad writing this since the service was quick and everyone working there is super nice.. but here's our experience:

As noted in other reviews there are only a couple tables so we ended up on barstools next to each other on a tilted sidewalk, positioned a foot above a larger table, looking down on a group eating, and staring into the sun. 

I ordered the egg sandwich and it was a hard boiled egg cut in half, which was a surprise. Don't usually expect that in a Breakfast sammy. My partner ordered the tuna melt which was open face and not the tastiest, with undressed greens.

An overall meh experience, but you may fare better ordering the toasts/cereals and at a different table. We were in and out of there and already talking about how we'd redeem ourselves with a good lunch.
author: Laura G.

description:
This place is tiny, tidy, super fast and perfect!  It is so good, I would go back every single day!  

I had the toast of the day (a thick Texas-style-like slice of brioche topped with mascarpone and assorted fruits - - teardrop grapes and lovely figs includes.  yes, for real!!!) and a croissant sandwich (it was kind of like an eggs Benedict sandwich ... but better).  

I drank both the Nutella coffee and the cold brew - - breakfast perfection!!! The place was packed so I took everything to go, and it all travelled well!  No excuses!  Try this place!
author: Maria S.

description:
I would have liked to give it a 5 star but this place is just so pretentious.
First, being cool doesn't mean you have to be rude. When I say I want an oatmeal and a latte, don't tell me you are only taking my food order for now. There are only 2 of us. I hope my order of 4 items is not going to fry your brain of overcool guy.
When the kind lady behind me asks you if the tart is vegan, don't respond with the question "for here or to go?".
And oh, by the way we would not mind if you would display the prices on your menus. It is just a breakfast place.
Still 3 stars because the food is decent.
author: Adeline M.

description:
farm : table is a hole in the wall on Post Street. Be ready to wait in line. Yes, it's one of those hipster places.

It's a tiny little place, with very limited seating. Inside is only one large table, while outside is a bench and a couple small tables all on a slant. But it's the only restaurant with life in the Nob Hill area. 

I had the Egg on Croissant. There was an egg, cheese, meat and lettuce inside. It was good, but it's also hard to mess up breakfast food. The menu is written on a chalk board with no prices listed. It's not cheap, but it's hipster SF.
author: Vincent H.

description:
I like everything here. The service is great. The food is inventive. The environment is inspiring. The pricing is entirely reasonable. 

Because of this the place gets 5 stars.
author: Jack D.

description:
All I can say is Guy Fieri from Dinners Drive In's and Dives needs to make a visit!! The most unique breakfast/brunch joint I've ever been too. 
I would say this place is about 200 square feet (so plan on taking to go) they have a few tables out front but not much. 
These guys behind the food are creative artist putting their heart into fresh food for your sole. 
I got the egg on croissant and it was the best breast sandwich I've ever had. (local meat ham, farm fresh hard boiled eggs, mixed greens, American cheddar, house made creme fraiche) WOW!!!! Was fantastic :-)
The reason why you should stop by is because it's NOT a chain, it's San Fransisco at its finest and trendy.. 
thanks for a great experience 
Xo
author: Mel B.

description:
My fiance and I stayed across the street at the Marriot, so this review is not about me actually stepping foot in the doors of this place but eating the food to go. 

Since Yelpers review this place as being super tiny, my fiance and I decided we didn't need to eat at the restaurant and could just grab the food and bring it back to our hotel room. My fiance graciously said he would go order the food and wait for it. I was super excited to receive my food from all of the delicious reviews and pictures on Yelp.

I will say from the food brought back to me in my room, it was pretty darn delicious. Now would I wait an hour in line for it and then have no place to sit, probably not. I think my fiance was gone a whole 20 minutes total and that seemed to be a totally appropriate amount of time.

I ordered the daily toast on gluten free bread and it was BOMB DOT COM. I will say that when ordering gluten free bread you have to know what you are getting yourself into. It is usually not that great of bread to begin with so don't go expecting any different here. It tasted like Udis or Trader Joes gluten free, rumor has it, the bread is from Trader Joes. The mascarpone, fruit, and nuts on it were just superb though. Like I want to make this every day for breakfast now.

My fiance got the Salmon toast on gluten free bread and thought it was pretty delicious as well. We also ordered two americanos which I thought were great but a bit on the small side for me. 

I would definitely share my experience with this place and eat there again.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Nice spot to grab some breakfast. Good fresh food and great coffee.

Would definitely recommend the breakfast oatmeal. Comes with great marmalade and fresh fruit
author: Benjamin C.

description: Cute little cafe with amazing toast and super friendly, fun staff. My mom had the croissant and egg (which looked good) and I had the daily toast which was gorgeous and very much instagram worthy. Highly recommend the daily cereal or daily toast.
author: Lisa H.

description: The brunch here is very nice! We got Daily Toast and the Salmon Toast. Both are fresh and delicious :) This place is also very affordable. (~$14 per person) the downside is that the serving is a bit small, and the place does not have many tables. We came at a right time, so we were able to grab a seat, but it might get much more crowded during busy hours
author: Yifan L.

description: Nutella latte is good, but together with the egg croissant is $15. Not really worth the price for me. A bit disappointed. Cute place, but not as good as I thought it'd be.
author: Angela P.

description:
Ordered a fruit toast, which had walnuts, blackberries, strawberries, plums, pineapple chunks, apples, and persimmon slices. I got it for here, and it came on a paper plate (which was a surprise, I expected a real plate). 

The inside is very cozy, with one communal square table. With the name "farm : table", I expected more tables, but it was still a cute experience.
author: Rosey L.

description:
After trying the Charcoal Vanilla Latte at Red Bay Coffee in Oakland, I was so excited to see a place in SF serving it.   On my last trip to the bay, we stopped in to get it.   The cafe is super tiny.   Friendly and line moved pretty fast.   We were lucky enough to find a seat outside.  My drink came quickly.  It was super pretty, metallic like. However, the taste was blah.   It tasted like sweetened warm milk.   

I will most likely not be going back.
author: Shannon D.

description:
Totally tourist/instagrammer trap. I ordered a salmon toast and 'House pressed' orange juice. All together the bill was $23. 

The salmon toast was nothin special and the smoked salmon on it doesn't look fresh. The edge was dry. The 'house pressed' OJ was a joke. I saw the guy pouring out the OJ from a plastic-gallon-milk kind of bottle. It tastes like any generic brand you get from grocery. 

Also the worst thing is that they don't have price on the menu. I came to SF for an interview and I know I definitely don't look or sound like local. But the price is a rip off. One piece of smoked salmon on one slice of old toasted bread, 6 oz supermarket juice. Can you believe it's $23?

Oh, and one thing worse. I went in around 1 pm and as soon as I sit down start eating, the guy started to sweep floor with some chemical that smelled awful (chlorinated water I believe) totally disrespectful to customers.
author: T G.

description:
Come eat breakfast at farm:table if you have no plans for the rest of your day, want fresh ingredients, and creative lattes.

It's breakfast items, but the wait can be just as long as brunch in SF (30-45 mins). BUT I'd come back again for their turmeric latte (SO flavorful and beautifully crafted) and crispy croissant sandwich.

Veggie-eaters behold! This place has so many options for you, from salads, to veggie sandwiches, to yogurt bowls...farm:table is very accommodating. Yes, there is not a lot of seating indoors (just one giant communal square table) and outdoors isn't that much better...but the high-quality fresh breakfast is what you're coming for. 

The shop is literally like the smallest Harry Potter-closet-esque size I've ever been to eat breakfast, but if you order the right item it'll be totally worth it. The croissant sandwich is the best thing I think...since they have a veggie option without meat but added avocado! YAS. Their turmeric latte is delicious, and rare selections like charcoal and lavender totally piqued my interest. The service here is small...meaning, there's like literally the cashier dude who also runs out the food, and only one barista. However, they hustle and make it work. I'm sure they bring in a lot of revenue! 

I won't go out of my way to come back, especially since I tend to carry a lot of stuff with me...like my yoga mat, bag, tote bag...and that just creates so much chaos in this small space. But this is a great place to go get quick food if you're not in a rush. PLUS you can walk to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse around the corner to get more pastries to go.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Ended up here mid morning on a windy Saturday and it was just the thing we needed. They feature a small menu that is ever changing and even smaller seating. 

We lucked out and got a table outside on the sidewalk to enjoy our breakfast. The service was awesome and accommodating and the food came out so fast. I could see this being a really great to go option or a fast lunch spot. 

I enjoyed a crispy, perfect croissant topped with ham, cheese, greens, and boiled egg. It was tasty and filling and reasonably priced. My sister got a salad with boiled egg, sweet potatoes, pumpkin seeds, tomato and avocado. Both were great light options to keep us going on our day of walking around the city! 

The inside has a large, communal style table but I wouldn't bank on that if you're with a large party. I would definitely return here if I come back to San Fran!
author: Anne Louise B.

description: This is a tiny counter with an indoor table and outdoor cafe seating - great place for a quick bite but not to sit for hours doing brunch. The food is fresh and delicious. I enjoyed a tart made with in-season veggies and bacon with a dressed side salad. The staff is very personable and was making jokes with anyone that bothers to look up from their phones. I would recommend for vegetarians as well as most dishes were available without meat.
author: Mary F.

description: Over priced mediocre food that isn't actually farm to table. The tuna melts didn't taste like anything! The girl who took our order was really nice though.
author: Shea P.

description:
My friends and I absolutely loved this spot. We were looking for breakfast near the area and this was walkable distance which was perfect. And we were pleasantly surprised! It's a tiny little spot but they serve some great food. The coffee was okay, nothing special. They have a lot of specialty flavors including a nutella latte, so if you're into sweet lattes maybe try that one.

I ordered the breakfast quiche and it was so delicious. It came with a salad and was the perfect amount of food for the morning. My friends ordered the oatmeal, which according to some locals we talked with is THE thing to order here. It's basically a Greek yogurt, non-sweetened breakfast oatmeal with fruit and granola and is apparently wonderful.

I love the vibe here and how tiny and intimate it is, as well as the fact that it is one of those street cafes you can just pop in, grab a quick breakfast and be on your way. Lovely little place in San Fran and worth a visit.
author: Hanna J.

description:
--PARKING-- street parking

--SEATING-- one large table inside, small table outside, and small windowsill seating outside

--MENU-- pastries, salads, toasts, lemonade, coffees, eggs, croissant sandwich..

Salmon toast: thick slice of brioche bread (not toasted), sprouts, smoked salmon- I wish this was friendlier to eat. It's hard to keep everything from sliding off the brioche. Each ingredient was great individually but it wasn't spectacular together.

Super salad: swiss chard, kale, cubed tomatoes, avocado, seeds, boiled egg, light vinaigrette- not a very cohesive salad and the greens needed to be chopped way more finely. I found it difficult to eat.The tomatoes should have been a cherry tomato instead of a chunky tomato and there wasn't enough avocado for my liking.

Total- $24

*Takes Apple-Pay!

--SERVICE-- no complaints; friendly people

--OVERALL-- I feel deceived by the Yelp stars. I like the concept and usually enjoy places like this but it was incredibly underwhelming. It missed the mark for me.
author: Telena V.

description: My daughter & I genuinely liked our breakfast! We ordered the toast with the fruit... I forget what its called but its one of their infamous breakfast served. The overall quality of the fruit was good, the cream spread is a bit sweet like a dessert cream you'll find on a fruit tart pastry but I like sweet things so that didn't bother me. My daughter wasn't a fan of the sweetness. She did enjoy her matcha green tea and I enjoyed my hot honey lavender cappuccino. I'd come here again for breakfast. The line went fast and our order came out fast also. There's not much seating but there's a few chairs, stools and a bench on the sidewalk that's fine or take it to go and get a nice short walk into Union Square with breakfast in tow.
author: Alexia B.

description:
Arrived as soon as they opened & greeted with niceties by the gentleman who went on to prep my food order. There was no wait and semi-open seating. Although there's only 1 decent sized farm table inside, 2 bistro tables & a window ledge table that seats 3 comfortably outside; this place packed a crowd in less than 10 minutes of opening.

I gave the space a once-over & quickly decided on the Toast of the Day & the Lavender Latte w/Almond Milk. I had previously asked about the contents of another drink when the cashier guy gave me my total. I noticed it was low and asked had he added my drink. He basically argued that I had requested another drink...DUDE FIX THE TICKET & move on so I can procure my order! Which took excessively long considering we were 2 of 4 total customers at the time of ordering. 

Major turn off that a minor miscommunication would lead to a 2 star review & an I'll NEVER RETURN experience.

The toast was filling, thick, great balance of mascarpone & fresh fruit...simply delicious. The service was horrific. 

~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
Great little spot for a quick breakfast. Not somewhere you'd sit and relax to eat but there are some tables outside if needed and a larger communal table inside. Unique coffee menu and small but delicious food menu. 

Service was fantastic! They have a small outdoor "garden" that creates a space for you to sit and relax. It's a few blocks from union square but worth it to check out! 

- @foodieintraining_
author: Laurel K.

description:
What a place! This place is tiny but i would come early and get a seat in the window. They have one communal table inside but it gets cramped with the people ordering. 

We tried a couple of the different toasts. The one with the different fruit on top is to die for!! All fresh fruit! The mascerapone cheese layer adds a great touch and is almost the glue that holds everything together. The toast is the perfect texture for this dish. Soft and holds together at the same time.

Also got the egg croissant sandwich which was perfect as well.

The egg veggie tart was ok. Not my favorite but we will let them slide on that one. 

Coming from ny we were astounded by how good this place was.

What a great place. Definitely come
author: Nicholas G.

description: I ordered the daily toast and my husband got the oatmeal. Both were amazing. The only thing I would change is the toast-I would use a multi-grain bread instead of white bread, but it was still delicious. Very small inside so bring a jacket if you're there early am since you'll most likely have to eat outside.
author: Arissa C.

description: Nice place to stop by for a quick breakfast. It's small and busy. Only one table inside and a few small ones outside. I got the daily toast and it tasted as good as the presentation looked. I like how they keep a minimal menu, but good enough choices for everyone to enjoy. Self serve water available by the cash register. They will call your name and bring out your order for you. Definitely a small space to stand in line in.
author: Joanna P.

description:
Came here during Labor Day weekend.

There are not that many seats inside nor are there many seats outside.

We got the Egg on Croissant aka a croissant sandwich with egg and ham. We also got the Tuna Melt. While the Croque Royale is on their online menu, they didn't seem to be serving that anymore. I was super sad because I was excited to try that.

Overall, there will be a line but it goes by quick and the food is yummy and well-priced especially considering that it's in SF!
author: Carol L.

description: For such a small shop they churn out amazing food. Salmon toast was amazing with a tasty salad, daily toast made with a thick sweet cut bread topped with mascarpone and fresh fruit. Also, had a savory tart which was a quiche made with fresh veggies including cauliflower and sweet potatoes...all so very good. Coffee and lattes finished an amazing breakfast!
author: Joe D.

description: Pricey Yes. Delicious, yes. I enjoyed the salmon toast although the salmon was thin and toast was thick
author: Vicky T.

description:
Farm : Table has very high reviews, but so far I have had just an ok experience here. 

After visiting a few times I can say that the service can be hit or miss, the food is good but expensive, and the coffee is alright. 

I do agree with other reviewers that the staff seem a bit too eager to kick you out once it gets close to closing time. It's understandable to not want guests to linger for too long, but it is also acceptable to give a friendly reminder about the closing time. 

My favorite food item here is the fruit toast. I like that they change the fruits on it often, but it's not quite as exciting as I would like it to be. 

I may come back here for a quick to go snack, but it is not at the top of my list.
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Great breakfast!! 
I ordered the breakfast toast and it was a great combo of fruit and marscapone! Very filling and delicious. 
My family ordered a variety of other things on the menu and we enjoyed all of it. You can go wrong here. Also the coffee was very good. Would definitely recommend
author: Samantha M.

description:
This is cute little brunch joint in the heart of downtown San Francisco. There is limited seating so don't be surprised if you have to share space with a stranger. If you're able to sit outside, the upside is that it's like you're literally in the middle of an SF street taking in the glory of the city in the morning, looking at the tilting Millennium tower. The downside is that it's like you're literally in the middle of an SF street taking in the glory of the city in the morning, getting a good whiff of the homeless urine scent. See what I did there?

Anyway, like Jenn B. said, the portions here are not proportional to the amount you pay. I mean, unless the food actually is coming from a farm, that day, to your table, then the prices are on the high side. Then again, what do you expect in downtown SF?

My fiancé and I had the Daily Toast and the Egg Croissant. The toast had a delicious spread and the croissant was flaky bliss. I recommend both of these with a cup of coffee for a great meal to start the day.

This place is ideal if you work/live downtown and you're looking for a cafe to get a quick snack or a tasty drink to-go. It's not ideal for large groups.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Food: 4/5     Price: 3/5       Service: 3/5      Ambience: 5/5

Super cute and basic breakfast place that's made for your Instagram feed! Farm : table is quite small with 1 big table inside, and a handful of stools / high tables on the walkway. It's so comfortable sitting outside enjoying your beautiful breakfast with SF street view! 

Daily Toast is the best here - Pain De Mie Brioché lightly toasted and topped with house mixed mascarpone, and beautiful local seasonal farm fresh fruit, and pecans. The toast is thick cut, slightly oily, with a nice toasted crust. The mascarpone spread is super thick, slightly sweet and very delicious. Then comes the beautifully arranged fruits that are too good to eat!! They change up the fruit every day so it really depends on the chef that day for your toast design. However, $8 is a little too much for a simple toast with some fruits....

Latte? blah....I specifically asked for a latte art, but the latte came in a mess with no effort whatsoever of making a design. I soon found a hair in my latte, and the waiter went and made a new cup for me. I asked for latte art again, and he nodded. A minute later, an ugly plain latte appeared on my table again. Seriously???? Why is everyone's pic so beautiful and mine is just a mess:(

Favorites:
* Daily Toast ($7.99)

Others:
* Latte ($4)
author: Victoria L.

description:
Cute, cozy restaurant with decent toast. There's very limited seating so it's a bit of a gamble whether you'd be able to dine in. The communal table inside can sit about 6 and the tables outside can sit about 10. I think most people grab their orders to go. 

I ordered the lavender latte (1 star), daily toast (4 stars) and savory tart (5 stars). The lavender latte was really bland without a hint of lavender. They either got my order wrong or just have really terrible lavender lattes. 

Note: They don't have wifi and don't allow you to use a laptop at the table inside. It's a place for a quick bite.
author: Katherine Y.

description: Cute little hole in the wall type shop. I came here because few of my friends were raving abt it. I got the salmon toast, super salad & the croissant. the best part of the meal was the croissant, really delicious and would come back for that alone. The salmon toast was a little to fishy for my liking and the salad had a strange taste, I think it was just too earthy for me. Definitely try the croissant if you decide to come!
author: Ivy C.

description: I'm so in love with this little shop! It's very cute and charming and to top it all off, they have great food! I ordered the tuna melt with a mocha and everyone else got the daily toast or the egg croissant. The tuna melt was my favorite. The tuna was delicious and flavorful and came with a side salad. It came on a thick piece of toast and some melted cheese on top. The best part about the tuna was that there was small pieces of green apple which made it very fresh and light tasting. Overall, great place! Everyone loved their food and their service is great!
author: Nargis A.

description:
Despite the tiny seating area, farm: table is a great place for creative latte tasting & delicious eggs on croissant ... Yummm. 

Since toast is a part of San Francisco's culture. We like to wake up in the weekend & get in line for toasts . I got to Farm:table too late to grab those last 2 daily fruity toasts, had to settle for quiche (or they called it tart) 

Those two were delish though the black charcoal coffee is a bit sweet for my taste. I am def not a sweet person :(. It's delicious but I think I can only do 2 sips..  

The line is average 20 mins long & meanwhile you are at farm:table, Mr. Holmes bakery is only 3 blocks away. That's a great post breakfast spot
author: Thao P.

description: Got here a few minutes before opening to avoid any lines. The staff was super friendly. It took a few minutes to prepare my order (3 daily toasts, 4 egg croissants, 2 black coffees, 1 matcha latte, 1 milk and honey) and we chatted for a bit while it was being done. I brought it back to my hotel room a couple blocks away. My matcha was awesome and my mom and dad loved the toasts, croissants, and coffee. My husband didn't like croissant that much but he's a hater (lololol he's from belgium and he has a high standard for baked goods). The milk & honey was a bit too sweet for both of us. Would love to make it back here sometime soon for another toast!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Went here with a friend, and I almost mistaken the restaurant with another one. But when you come here, you will see why they are name farm:: table. The design of of the restaurant literally looks like a farm and inside, they only have 1 table. Genius! Haha! 

I ordered their egg croissant with avocado. That was so good, basic and delicious but I wish it didn't cost so much because I probably would have ordered more. But it's okay, you pay for the quality and service. 

But overall a very cute place for brunch and maybe a date with a friend or someone special.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Well-known place in San Francisco - there's space for like 5 people to sit outside and maybe 5 outside. 

The food is good though! We got:

-House cereal (Almonds, coconut, and seeds toasted to perfection, hand mixed with organic cereal and craisins served along side house made yogurt and side of house made Jam and fruit garnish). This was especially crunchy, and I liked the jam on the side.

-Egg on croissant (Local Prather Ranch Ham, Petaluma Cheese, local Farm fresh eggs, market greens, and house made crème fresh all on a buttery croissant). 

-Daily Toast Pain De Mie (lightly toasted and topped with house mixed mascarpone, and beautiful local seasonal farm fresh fruit, and nuts). This is probably their most famous dish because it's so aesthetically pleasing. It's also just really good bread/cheese with fresh fruit on top

-Tuna Melt Whole Grain Bread (house mixed tuna salad with red onion and apple, topped with fresh local tomato and Petaluma cheddar server open face with side salad). Very good as well.
author: Kimberly T.

description:
I can only give two stars because there isn't much to be excited about, sadly. The restaurant is so tiny to the point of being uncomfortable. You are always in someone's way and the large communal table takes up most of the floor space indoors. I can enjoy the quirkiness of a small space making do, but it honestly just felt annoying as there's no real counter and whoever is cashier has to step in or out of the kitchen to the restaurant at any given time depending on delivery of food. 

The menu is pretty straightforward but it's only written on the wall and boards so you can study it ahead of time (again without being in the way) and additionally, there are NO PRICES. We got two toasts, a drink, and a tart (its quiche) for $50. Are you kidding me? I respect that this is an expensive city but honestly it was not worth it. 

The famed daily toast that I see tons of photos of was good, salmon toast  was so so. The tart was ordered vegetarian but we got a bacon slice - when I brought this the their attention they were gracious and gave us a veggie slice. However when I ate the salad on my salmon toast, it didn't have dressing... its like the entire experience was if you get one thing right, there will be another thing wrong to cancel it out. It was a slightly exhausting experience because additionally, the staff were having their own conversations that were totally fine, but given their high volume and slightly less professional subject matter, i would have preferred to just have my orders right and not have to hear it. I think they could have had their conversations quieter or maybe out of the line of customers being able to hear. 

I know this all sounds harsh but I just did not love anything about the visit. I couldn't wait to leave because the whole experience felt like a hassle. 
2 stars for the food being good and them correcting whatever mistakes were made in the process, but overall, not worth going back again (or arguably, visiting in the first place)
author: Ashley G.

description:
This place had stellar reviews and I was definitely disappointed when I came in. It's just super overcrowded and small of a space. It's a tiny little space, they have one picnic table inside and some tables outside. The lines stretched outside the door and people try to cram in. 
The menu is limited. Very limited. 
We decided to forgo eating here and just grabbed some coffee here. I had a whole milk latte- they don't carry skim. My friend had a regular coffee, he said it was fine. My latte was burning hot and they handed it to me without a sleeve on. They have a communal spoon which is disgusting and also not sensitive to those with allergies. It's completely unsanitary and unappetizing. Not sure what the line is about, maybe it's just because they are so slow. 14 minute latte... needless to say won't be visiting again next time I am in town.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Classic "Yelp-bait" in that they have almost zero vegan options.  Avoid if you care about your health, the planet, or animals.

Actually, perhaps better to avoid the entire place:

1.  There's ONE table inside.  One.  For only four diners.

2.  Is dining on the sidewalk, with the aroma of urine, something you enjoy?  You'll feel right at home here!

3.   Also, an opportunity for panhandlers to chat you up while you dine.  Priceless.
author: Mark P.

description:
I make a point to visit farm:table whenever I'm in SF. I love how delicious and fresh their food is. I especially love the daily toast (loaded with mascarpone cream and seasonal fruit) and the milk and honey drink. 

They get very crowded, but if you get there early, you can be in and out before the rush. If the weather is warm and nice, there's actually a decent amount of seating outside (tables and benches), but it's probably better to take your food to go.

It's a bit pricey, but the ingredients are top notch.
author: Angela T.

description: I ordered the Egg on Croissant and the Frank the Pug n Honey Latte. I was very pleased. I guess I didn't read the description very well for the Egg on Croissant because I wasn't expecting the hard-boiled egg, but it was a good surprise. It was the most perfect hard-boiled egg I have ever had in my life. I really enjoyed the latte I ordered. I think it was sweetened with honey. It was the best latte I have ever had. I will definitely come back here again when I'm in the city.
author: Michaela N.

description: As Vegetarian, I love this place for breakfast. Good options available. Very delicious food and very elegant atmosphere.
author: Navneet S.

description:
We ate here for simple breakfast since Honey Honey Cafe  had long line. We are glad we had an opportunity to try Farm : Table , a very small place with just a few tables and small selections of entrees.
We had egg croissants with fresh micro greens, soy latte and  had Salmon open face sandwich with greens and pickled onion. Very simple but overall excellent food & experience!
author: Phil S.

description:
VERY small cafe/brunch place! Good for quick bite or break but not super filling and limited options...

+ daily toast was good and presented beautifully
+ egg croissant was perfect mix of flaky and soft! Egg was also soft but cooked well and the avocado was the cherry on top!
+ parklet concept was cool (open public seating)

- very little seating, was lucky enough to pull a few chairs and snag a table outside (only one table inside, 2 outside, countertop seating and the parklet)
- limited menu
author: Mahima D.

description: This place is too cute, a bit small but it works. Breakfast was delicious and they have outside seating. They were fast with our order and the presentation was nice. We had the croissant and the toast and both were on point. Wish they had more seating but somehow it worked out since people eat and go.
author: Gabby R.

description: Cute little breakfast spot, a little cramped, but the seating outside is nice. Coffee selections are great, had a croissant with eggs and fixings.
author: David C.

description:
So first off, this place is SMALL. Definitely ideal for an order-and-go situation, not to sit and eat. There's literally 1 table there that's a shared space. Secondly, the menu is very limited (but what they make, they do well).

Came here with a co-worker for a quick lunch and luckily the options available that day suited our palates. I ordered the daily toast and some golden tea. Across the board delicious -- fresh fruits, chunky slice of toast, delicious tea...

So again, manage your expectations here. This is not an app/entre type of place, but the options of food they do have are very thoughtful and well done.
author: Ariel J.

description:
This was one of those places where I'm excited to try for the first time, but not eager to return for many reasons:

1) Daily toast = can it really justify for $7? The egg croissant was better. 
2) Service = a hello? Hi? 
3) Forgetting your to go orders and not even apologetic. Then taking forever to make it...Priority?!?! 
4) Tiny space

What a screw up and I'm glad I won't ever be coming back here again. Kthanksbye!
author: Owie N.

description:
Farm to table is a fantastic little spot on Post street in San Francisco and I was extremely fortunate to visit this gem of an establishment. The guys behind the counter are friendly and positive. The menu is simple and easy however the food itself is anything but. This is not boring and bland. The items are fantastic and will absolutely bring your taste buds alive!!

Let's start with the Daily Toast! Sounds like a show or some theme music  should accompany the presentation and delivery of this side dish.  I ordered mine with fruit. This was not just fruit! The mascarpone cream on the toast is absolutely scrumptious and an incredible complement to the toast that is about 1.5-2 inches in height. Thick toast here! Also, the toast has a nice and complementary sweetness to it which is great with the cream and fruits. Ah, the fruits... grapes, berries, mandarin oranges, granola, and thinly sliced apples oh my!! What a presentation!

I also enjoyed the croissant egg  sandwich based on another yelper that had both and was very happy with the choice. This sandwich has delicious ham (not just any ham), mixed greens, hard boiled egg (halved) and some delicious spread on it that was simply tangy and something I'd want to bottle and take home to the family! BTW, this sandwich is not huge and while i went for the gusto with my order the sandwich alone might not have done it for me. I feel a little on the full side now but that's ok. I'm only here for a super short trip and wanted to experience these two fantastic menu items!!

The latte!!  while at most places, this drink costs a latte I would say in SF this is a fair price! I had the mocha which has a local chocolate  cocoa to it. This was great and so was the design. I sipped before taking the picture... sorry! 

Great job to the gang at Farm to Table!! Loving your concept and menu!! We will be back!! Cheers!!
author: LouCindy A.

description:
Absolutely loved Farm Table, which was suggested by a friend during a recent trip to San Francisco. It did not disappoint -- food was scrumptious, prices were reasonable, quite a variety of food and and coffees to choose from and good conversations with strangers at the farm table. 

- Food: Of course, I have to start off with the Daily Toast (Pain de Mie topped with a houseblende flavored marscapone topped with a variety of marker fruits and pistachios) ($7.95). It seems like this is one of Farm Table's most popular items, and it certainly did not disappoint. 

It comes on a thick slice of toast and is filling. Love the light sweetness that the marscapone adds, which compliments the fresh and tasty fruit atop it. If this is your first time visiting Farm Table, certainly get the Daily Toast. 

The other item I ordered was the Egg on Croissant (Petulma Cheese, Farmer's Market Boiled Egg, Topped with Market Greens, homemade creme fraiche and avocados) ($7.95). This was also absolutely delicious! It was a smaller portion, but the the Croissant and buttery, flaky and warm, and everything inside of it blended very well. 

This wasn't as filling as the Daily Toast, but definately recommend it nonetheless. Would recommend getting a latte or a complimentary item if you're going to order this. 

- Coffee: Farm Table has a good variety of coffees. I decided to go with the Matcha Tea Latte, which was came beautifully adorned with a design atop it, as well as a very large cup/ portion. I do have to say that it was a bit underwhelming and slightly bitter, however not bad. If I have a chance to go back, I might order the Nutella Latte or another drink next time. 

- Atmosphere: This place is tiny! However we went on a weekday for brunch so we found seating outside initially and then moved it when folks left. The only seating inside is a farm table, essentially one large table that sits about eight people. It seems like it's supposed to facilitate strangers sitting together for a meal, which happened with us. We got to meet two other groups of travelers during our meal and had a pleasant conversation. 

There's also seating outside with about two tables, as well as an artsy structure which I guess you can eat on as well. The staff were also friendly. 

I'd definitely like to go back to Farm Table, loved loved the food and it's fresh quality!
author: Amit J.

description:
Fruits on the daily toast was so fresh. I love the different assortments of fruits on there. Felt so healthy after eating it. 
Got the frank the pug latte because they ran out of the lavender. Tasted like regular latte to me, I couldn't tell if it had flavor or not. 
Seating outside is super cute. 
A bit pricey for the amount of food I got.
author: Emily P.

description:
Great atmosphere, friendly staff, but probably wouldn't come back.

Food wise very limited options, and not much seating. I chose to sit outside and was brought my coffee immediately, then they forgot about me and my food. Thirty minutes later when I went back they refunded me but at that point my expectations were very high for my sandwich. It was alright but after waiting that long I was wanting something more substantial then brunch.
author: Kelly M.

description: I ordered super salad and house cereal. Looks fancy but the taste is mediocre. They only have one table inside so we sat at a table on the street but the area smells like piss. The server is not very friendly and no one greeted us at the counter. Might be a good place for a quick breakfast but do not recommend if you are with a group or want above average dining experien
author: Moliang J.

description:
Excellent food, but the waitress was rude. One of our friends ordered after us and he got his food and we were puzzled why our food was not ready yet as time went by and our friends were almost done eating. Since other people who ordered after us got their food too, we politely asked to see where our food was. She rudely said there were a 20 people ahead and our food will be out. I understand that she is busy but that not how she should treat people. I hope the owner should have a talk with her about her attitude with her customers. Not coming back especially when I was kind. 

Update: they refunded me
author: HoaiMy T.

description:
The daily toast is a must get! It's probably the most visually appealing toast I've ever laid my eyes on - all that fruit! The mascarpone they put on it tastes exactly like a Creamy French from Andersen Bakery, well to me at least. Mmm so delicious and won't break the bank either! Perfect for a light breakfast or snack.

I've also had their salad, which was OK. The Nutella latte didn't taste very Nutella-y, I'd go with the matcha instead. 

It's a super small space where you order at the register and then find yourself a seat. There's one table inside and a few counter-top seats and tables outside. 

Service is kinda spotty. They forgot about our order during my last visit. If you notice people getting their food before you even though they showed up afterwards, say something! - or else you will be forever forgotten.
author: Laverne N.

description:
Little coffee shop  with some indoor seating and outdoor seating. Small menu but food taste great. 
Fast and easy. 
I had a lavender latte. Tasty.
author: Jolanda W.

description:
I didn't pay enough attention to the description of their salad to realize that it had sunflower seeds in it, and was a little dismayed to find the salmon covered in them when I opened the box (I have an allergy). Even though this was completely my fault for not reading the menu, they remade the salad right away. 

Also, the house-made almond milk is fantastic.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Farm:Table was all right, but I wasn't a fan of the whole operation overall.   From the extra-long line that mostly existed on the restaurant outside and the menu that had a bunch of stuff not in stock to the all-right food and lack of seating, I don't think I'll be spending my money here again.

We stood in line for about 20 minutes before finally making it indoors to a point that we could actually order. We ended up getting an egg sandwich ($8.25, no meat, really?), a $10 tuna melt (actually pretty decent!), a matcha chai (the one other stand-out item) and a rosemary iced tea (more watery than anything else). One of our party had to sit and reserve the one table inside while the others went to order. Thankfully the staff brought our food to us, so we didn't have to get up and lose our spot. 

All in all, Farm:table was cute but nothing special. The price and food quality weren't particularly appealing, and this ended up being just another hole-in-the-wall breakfast place. I'm happy I gave it a shot for myself but I don't think I'll be coming back or recommending it.
author: John B.

description:
My husband and I were in SF visiting my sister and brother-in-law and came out this afternoon for brunch at Farm:Table. The staff was very welcoming and the food was delicious. The whole atmosphere and patio decor was so nice. When our food came out, one of the workers saw we had our German Shepard with us and came back with a piece of ham for him. 

We had the egg croissant sandwich and the salmon toast. I had the milk and honey, and my husband had the macchiato. The macchiato was definitely strong, but the milk and honey was a nice chaser. The milk and honey was made with almond milk and the drink itself was lightly sweet and delicious! 
Definitely recommend this spot for its outdoor seating, pet friendliness, and delicious food options.
author: Serena Y.

description:
I've wanted to come here for a very long time and finally made the trip to SF a weekday morning to try the food and coffee here. The pictures all looked really cute so I was excited to try it out. I walked here from the Powell Bart station which took around 10-15 minutes. What I didn't realize about this place before I came is that it is SUPER TINY. When you walk inside, there is a huge communal table in the cafe and the cashier counter and that is it. Other than seating around the communal table, there are a couple bar stools and 2 little tables outside the venue, so seating is extremely limited. I think they could make use of their space a little better indoors in order to accommodate more people. Fortunately, on a weekday at 11AM, there weren't too many people here and there was no line so we could sit comfortable and enjoy our food. That is likely not the case on the weekends.

The food here is very pricey for the portion size. My friend ordered a daily toast, which was pretty loaded with fruits and nuts. I ordered the egg on a croissant which was however very tiny. For an $8 sandwich, I expected the croissant to be larger at least, but it was super small. The sandwich consisted of 2 hardboiled eggs that were cold (I would've preferred warm eggs and softboiled), mixed greens, some sauce, ham, and cheese. It tasted okay but definitely wasn't worth it. I also got the nutella latte which was pretty tasty and really sweet. The food here is pretty and make for a good picture to Instagram, but I probably wouldn't come back.
author: Catherine S.

description:
You'd find better service in a prison! The male waiter was rude, served us the wrong food, when we adressed it he swapped the paltes with another costomer (who had allready eate of it). And said in an intimidating manner "You don't want it?!"
The food wasn't fresh. I ordered a pesto-avocado sandwich. The avocado flesh was brown and the side of "salad" consisted of three saladleafs with balsamico on.
They had to dogs that the chef hand fed.
The small open kitchen was scruffy, with dirty and clean plates mixed together. I just cross my fingers that we will not get sick.
There are so many great palces for breakfast in SF. This is NOT one of them. I'd take my money elsewere.
author: Emir A.

description: This is my favor tiny breakfast cafe, despite the limited space inside. I was able to find a spot and enjoy my smoked salmon toast with a cup of latte. I was traveling to San Francisco for four days with my friend. We accidentally came across this cafe early in the morning and we waited outside for them to open. My friend ordered the toast with all the fruits on top - very eye catching and colorful. The food was great and had the reflective style in Europe. I will for sure come back and try other items on the menu.
author: Gloriaa S.

description: Limited menu (6-8 options; Croissant Egg Sandwich - delic.); Limited indoor seating, outside cafe tables. Great for small parties to stop by for casual quick bite or grab take away coffee or breakfast.
author: Jillian G.

description:
On my list to try for so long! We came on Super Bowl Sunday morning to have some delicious toast and coffee and was sadly disappointed. 

Food- The toast I received looked good, but it did not look amazing nor as pretty as the hundreds of photos on Yelp and the macchiato was lumpy. Toast tasted ok, but it wasn't anything particularly special. Husband got the breakfast tart/quiche which was decent. 

Service/Setting- Service was mediocre. It's a casual place so I didn't expect amazing service, but the cashier seemed annoyed when I asked if there was an alternative to the mascarpone cheese and then walked away without taking our order. Then when the other worker came by and found out we weren't helped yet, he joked with the first cashier about not helping us. I was not in the mood for joking at the time since we were pretty much left there waiting with no explanation. The place was tiny with some cute decorations, but it was not very clean. I understand that the mess was most likely left by previous customers, but someone's got to clean the stuff up before the next patron if it's so dirty! 

Overall the place is exactly OK. Not pressing to return but may give it another try if I'm in the area and feeling like fruit toast.
author: Iris H.

description: I ordered the fruit toast, but it is kind of pricey for how little you get. You're kind of paying for the aesthetics. I don't think I'd come back.
author: Allyson L.

description: This is one of my absolute favorite coffee/breakfast spots in SF. They have very good quality coffee and many types of lattes (honey lavender is my favorite) and all their drinks can come iced too if asked! Their pastries are good and I usually get either their egg crossiant sandwich or their toast with fruits and mascarpone cheese (daily toast). The line is usually long in weekend mornings but if you go during the weekdays, it's not too bad at all. Also, it's a small coffee shop so there isn't much seating inside so many people usually get everything to go. Union square is only a few blocks away and it's a perfect spot to enjoy some delicious coffee and breakfast from a lovely cafe that only uses organic products.
author: Piyali B.

description: Farm:Table is a quaint spot for brunch. There is only one large table inside and a few small tables outside, so go on a nice day because chances are you'll be eating outside. The line on the weekends can be a little long, but the food is served fairly quickly. I ordered a croissant sandwich and thought that it was pretty good.
author: Ceecee Y.

description:
I had wanted to try out Dottie's True Blue Cafe for brunch on a sunny Saturday, but they were closed! Luckily, I had a bunch of backup options, and the closest one happened to be farm:table, so I thought we could give this place a try. It's quite a tight and cozy space, with only 1 square common table inside, which can sit probably 8 people with a bit of a squeeze, and a few small tables on the outside. Anyways, we were able to get a seat just as others were leaving, so we were able to enjoy our little breakfast/brunch inside.

- Daily Toast: of course I consulted Yelp on this one and it was a great choice. I love bread, and it was nice and thick with mascarpone spread and assorted colourful fruit on top. The only thing was that the fruit wasn't exactly uniform, as in I didn't get strawberries, but my friend did. I thought I got some other kinds of fruit that my friend didn't get, but we checked out photos (because camera always eats first aha) and he had the same ones I had plus strawberries :P Oh well, the strawberries looked a bit raw anyways, and the fruit + mascarpone toast was good.
