As we approached the "counter" which really isn't a counter.. its an iPad with a credit card machine attached to it, we were not greeted by the man standing there taking our order. He just stared at us blankly until I said "Um, can we order from you?" Which his reply was "Um, yeah."
My sister and I both are dairy free (not allergy related) and asked for almond milk in our lattes. His response "We're all out." 
To which I said... "Ok, any coconut milk?"
Him: "Nope"
ALRIGHTY THEN.
So we just dealt with regular skim milk in our lattes. Whatever.
We ordered. He did not say thank you. He did not say have a nice day. He did not say a word. 
We sat down outside, maybe 5 minutes went by and he brought out our food. No silverware.
So I went in to ask for some silverware to which he POINTS (Yup you read that right) to the "picnic" table (if its even that) where I see a utensil holder and napkin holder in the middle of the table. 
I say thanks. Head to the table... and guess what? NO FORKS.
So I have to go up to this ass hat again. 
"Can I have a fork please? There aren't any in the communal utensil holder."
He looks at me, walks out back for two seconds and comes out with one fork.
He hands it to me. 
"I think you might want to go back out there and get a few more forks so no one bothers you again for one."
He smiled and walked away. 
Only smile I got from him in the 20 minutes we were there. 
The food was STELLAR. Really amazing. Homemade bread, lox spread. Just delicious. 
But I would never go back. Ever. Guy is a dick. And he's probably the owner too.
author: Meg N.

description: This place was very cute, I must say! If you are looking for a quick bite to eat with some coffee, id definitely come here. Don't expect to get full though. Seating is horrible. You have to stand and wait for people to get up. If you come here try the fruit on toast! It was amazing
author: Navita S.

description: This place is great, and I love it as a way to start the day off right. Although they have limited seating and a small menu, they make up for it in how they make those few items so well. I recommend taking it and enjoying it in the parklet or outdoor seating area in front! Check out some photos below and also see my favorite menu item.
author: Thom H.

description:
A small place with self service. Should give 15 mins prep time after placing the order as it is a busy place. 
Egg croissant with avocado, tomato and arugula in it - had to go twice there for the breakfast which explains it all how delicious it was. Bread toast with fresh fruits and nuts on it - very innovative , never tried before and I am glad I tried it. Perfect blend of cream and filled with fruits. Yummy!!
author: Bhavika P.

description: Omgggg I found this place on yelp...!! Sooo freaking good!! Parking wasn't so bad since it's a Sunday and meter was free. Very small place and the tables are first come first serve. When we got there all the table were taken up but one of the guy at the register got us a community table where we share with everyone. Super nice! Food was phenomenal!!! We had the tuna melt and it was delicious!! I also ordered the matcha green tea latte was incredible. The daily toast was fresh and light. And the egg on croissant was out of this world! Will definitely come back!! Worth the drive from San Jose to San Francisco!!
author: Loan N.

description: Had the toast sister had the cereal both were great!  Very helpful young lady at front that had a great attitude and was pleasant! Seating looked like it would lack but we got a seat quickly and it was comfy
author: Reza S.

description: We luckily were staying at courtyard marriot right across the street. Oh man did I thank my friend for finding out hotel because we had the best breakfast spot. Best egg and ham croissant on earth . It's not  just a breakfast sandwich , it's THE breakfast sandwich ! Yum!!!! Can't wait to get back to eat here again . Also very friendly employees .
author: Jamie T.

description:
Came here for breakfast, thy did not offer anything with eggs.  They say this place is for breakfast, but I beg to differ...
Walked a block away to a place that actually served breakfast....
author: Stephen H.

description: Tried the daily toast and milk with honey. It was delicious!!!! They were busy, so the folks were refilled when I almost finished my food. But I don't mind eating toast with a spoon at all because their toast was that good. Service was hand down excellent. I'd consider going back at least once before I leave.
author: Thuy T.

description: This place is dinky.  The staff are literally rubbing butts trying to prepare food and drinks in the kitchen.  Got the Daily Toast and it was good!!  The bread was nice, thick and toasted perfectly.  Lots of fruit layered on top of the mascarpone spread.  Pretty pricey for what it is, but it was filling.  I'll be back to try more of the menu the next time I'm in SF!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Maybe I'm too old and uncool for this spot. I'm not the biggest fan of these uber hole-in-the-wall, can't-even-find-a-seat, type businesses in the city. Hole-in-the-wall thing works only when the price matches the unassuming display.

Still wanted to give this place a try for my last breakfast in the city. The matcha chai latte was okay. A little light on the flavor, with a lot more matcha than chai. Weak on the caffeine. I also had the lemon coconut torte, which was okay. Not bad, but nothing to write home about either. 

Keep in mind, I'm writing this review from the viewpoint of a simple Houstonian who has been spoiled by cheaper things. But seriously, for the $ I'm paying for this light breakfast, I expect some study space and free wi-fi where I can plop down and leisurely enjoy my morning coffee. 

I walked out still feeling hungry.
author: Sung In K.

description: This place is awesome. It's super hip and has just one medium sized community table that you share with others. Usually you can grab a seat after a short wait. Their egg in croissant is outstanding. Super crunchy, freshly toasted croissant, ham, sour cream and green. Not salty or fatty at all - the real flavor really comes out. Their coffee is great too, serving Roast Co from Oakland. Love that hole in wall brunch spot.
author: Jonas G.

description:
Dear Mr. and Mrs Farm Table:

This is only for your service. I wish I could tell you myself but cannot since we were kicked to the curb with smokers and pee smell.

My opinion: Never be rude to a customer. Be polite. I am not a very smart person but I do know you never make a lady wait..especially an 8 year old little girl. My review will not matter much with your popularity on yelp. It will matter even less than  the $20 I would've spent.

We bookmarked your restaurant on Yelp  from Orange County and trying your daily toast was part of our itinerary.. We walked from our hotel at 730am. We arrived and were told we couldn't come in because it was 7:53 and you open at 8. Outside your shop,  the street smells like piss and people are smoking. At 8:01 am (by my phone) we left.

We arn't important enough to let us have a seat inside. If it were my business, I would simply say "we are not ready yet but please come inside." You upset an 8 year old and put us on the street to wait. In my book that is terrible service. 

You ruined a little girls morning and that means you ruined mine. I am sorry we got there 7 minutes early. It's your business decision and this is my opinion.  We had crummy customer service. We have had better.
author: Nick H.

description:
Solids 4 star breakfast place. Very quaint space for a nice, light farm fresh breakfast. Since I kept hearing so much hype about this place, I knew I couldn't just choose one thing (and yes, I tried almost everything on the menu...don't judge). I was a bit apprehensive about the daily toast, because I'm not usually one for creamy cheeses, but the flavor combination was really great. And the marscapone was made in-house and tasted like honey. Definitely a place to check out for a quick bite to eat, or just to hang out with a friend.

Likes:
-farm fresh options
-food cooked/prepared to perfection (I could actually feel the love in the food prep)
-daily toast is AMAZING
-cute outdoor seating (although limited)
-quaint place inside (note: probably only 6-8 people can fit inside. This place is SMALL!)
-pretty reasonable (everything less than $8)

Dislikes:
-limited menu
-limited seating
author: Tracy T.

description:
Farm:table is an interesting spot where you know you'll be getting some serious farm to table food, otherwise they wouldn't have that name!  I stopped over here with fellow yelper Merica S. to try their famous Daily (aka Everyday) Toast.  Just take a look at this beauty:

Daily (aka Everyday) Toast -- http://bit.ly/1Gj2lY7
Toasted brioche, spread with mascarpone cheese, topped with seasonal fruit and pistachios
It's pretty and tasted delicious!   Yeah I know, it's just fruit on toast, but I was pretty impressed with the presentation.  I'll say it's the most artistically impressive toast I've ever seen and eaten.  Granted, I could probably make this at home, but if you see the ingredients, I'd say it'll cost a lot of time and effort for me to gather up all that fruit, cheese, and other ingredients just to assemble it.  It's not something I'd make everyday so I'd gladly spend the $8 to get this at farm:table.

The place itself is really small.  They have one communal table inside that takes up most of the space, a couple of small tables outside, and a parklet.  I thought Merica and I were pretty lucky that we got space on the communal table inside.

Farm:table is not exactly a spot I'd go out of my way for, but I know if I'm in the area, I could stop by for some true farm to table fresh food.  I wouldn't mind going back to try their other breakfast items.  Their food definitely lives up to their name.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Four Solid Stars to something you should wake up very early for.

farm:table offers a small menu that suits every taste bud. I had of course had to try them all! 

Green Tea Latte's: Matcha, Cream and enough sugar to fulfill your sweetooth cravings. We ordered for here, so we can take cute photos of latte art. 

Croissant Sandwich: IS YO NAME YVONNEEE?!?!?!? IS THAT FRENCH OR SUM ISH?!?! If you get that reference, good on you! This was my favorite savory dish. The croissant was nice and toasty. Their bake goods comes fresh daily. So good. I wouldn't recommend sharing the sammy, since you I can eat 2 by myself. Greedy much? Yes. 

Savory Tart: This was in between a savory tart and quiche, nothing that blew me away, but I love eggs and cheese! 

Daily Toast: Fruit layed on top of a sweet cream, and then layered on top of a briohce(?) or challah(?) A bread that is very fluffy and sweet. It's definitely very instagram friendly. Check out my pics! I love the figs, and the cream, other fruits are more decorative in my opinion. 

All items ranges from 8-9 and drinks are 3-4. Very standard. We got here at 9:00AM and there was a wait. Definitely a must try!
author: Phuong V.

description: Hole on the wall place with some amazing organic food! The long line wait was worth it.
author: Sue M.

description:
A fabulous breakfast.

Egg on croissant.
Soy latte.
Coffee.

For less than 6 bucks.

What?!

Yes, it's just a sliver of a space.  One table inside that seats about 6 comfortably.  A parklet out front.  2 or 3 two tops on the sidewalk.

Thaz it baby.

The croissant was fresh & perfectly toasted.  
The ham was fresh, hot, & tasty.
The egg was hard boiled & split down the middle.
The greens were fresh.

Notice all the "fresh?"

This breakfast was so clean & delicious...
& yes, FRESH.

3 men were manning the operation.  All warm & friendly.

My soy latte went down smooth as silk.

They even make their own almond milk.  For chrisakes.

Great food.  Great coffee.  Great peeps.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: small and simple - miss this place a ton. definitely on the smaller side but if you get that table you are royalty
author: Bric B.

description:
Cute as a button! 

Love the farm-esque look to the joint, the girl who made my beverage was as sweet as pie, and they have a limited menu so you're not doing the "what should I get" dance for minutes on end.

The milk & honey is a top notch beverage. If you're not a huge dairy person, you can substitute for almond (made in house). The honey is also made in house and it's not as concentrated as regular honey (more syrup-y), so it blends nicely with the milk, as opposed to being a huge glob at the bottom of the drink. The touch of cardamom on top adds that beautiful smell. Iced on a hot day...it's pure perfection.

I was lured in the same day by a pic of their daily toast, which was a fruit masterpiece on a beautiful brick of bread. We were their last customers of the day, so not sure if we missed the stone fruit stash because our toast was mostly berries. Don't get me wrong...I love me some berries, but the ingredient that sold me on the pic, was the ripe peaches and that was definitely absent from ours. Still delightful, nonetheless!

We also got a savory tart and if we had eaten it on the spot, I think it would have been a red, hot winner. Sadly, we had quite a walk ahead of us before we sat down to munch, so it lost some of its luster on the trek back to the office.

One thing's for sure...their milk & honey does a body good!
author: Katie B.

description: When I arrived , I didn't know it was a really small cafe. There's one big community table inside where you sit with random people , which is cool. I ordered chai matcha latte and the special toast. The chai matcha was really good and it serve in a big o' cup! The toast was fruity, but too sweet for my taste... Overall I enjoyed the friendly staff and the nice environment :)
author: Judy M.

description: This little "hole in the wall" is very unassuming and quaintly sophisticated. I journeyed over to this restaurant because of its proximity to my hotel near Union Square and had the honey latte with the Salmon toast. AMAZING!!! It was the perfect light breakfast for a Sunday morning and the coffee was excellent too. There is very little seating so be prepared to take out your food or wait for one of the small tables available outside. There is only one large table inside so unless you get there early it likely won't be available. Totally worth it though! All of the food was very fresh and the toast makes it filling. I will definitely be stopping by this little gem the next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Ayanna H. M.

description:
Food on FLEEK! Lord have mercy, people this is what dreams are made of!! 
I came here on a whim with my friend one morning while we were combing the yelpisphere for something intriguing to eat. 
What we found was the most eye-opening, culturally enlightening, and iconic establishment known to the Bay Area. 

Everything from the unique take on the yogurt parfait, to the Substainability sourced fresh brewed iced-coffee, to the breakfast croissant was flawless. I haven't had an authentic croissant that was buttery, flaky, firm, and soft since I have visited France a few years ago. The communal seating was also cute too, and really set the vibe of the whole experience. I plan on coming back up here very soon to get my grub on! Hope they keep up the great work!
author: Ariel T.

description: I'm not much of a traditional breakfast person, so decided to try the open-faced tuna sandwich, and it was incredible - tuna, red onion, green apple, on a great slice of wheat bread, topped w/ cheddar cheese, and served with a lovely side salad in a tangy vinaigrette and slices of strawberry. Not much seating, but a great find!
author: Amber E.

description: Great breakfast options and one of my go-to coffee places when I visit SF. Limited indoor seating, but the outdoor chairs are nice when it's warm.
author: Dan Z.

description: Super tiny place with majority of the sitting outside but fabulous food! Loved all the dishes but my favorite was the daily toast.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Almost forgot to give this place a raving review. Although it's small its big on everything else from the coffee and beverages to the breakfast plates and to the wait staff.   We Found this place on Pinterest and have to give that Pinner a big shout out.  I love the sidewalk, city cafe feel and the fact that everything is fresh and farm to table. That is a big giant plus on my list (if I can find it)

The Avocado Toast is a must try and so is the deliciously fresh daily toast. I say chose both since they are on opposite ends of the palate..I accidentally ordered the milk and honey and while I'm not a milk drinker it was a perfect choice on a crisp San Francisco morning.  

The pug n' honey was just what I needed too (can't lie stole a few sips when my daughters back was turned) and just the right wake me up for an exhausted lost tourist trying to navigate the old fashioned way..,with a map
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Remember when $4 toast in SF was a joke? Farm:table took it one step further and created a $7.75 toast. Only in SF can you find food so extravagantly unique and indulgent with a designer brand price tags (perhaps NY will soon have $10 toast).

Ridiculously overpriced though it may seem, their sandos are surprisingly addicting. The menu changes daily according to what is fresh, seasonal, and local, so every visit is a surprise. (Thankfully farm:table is out of the way for us so we've only been once; otherwise my wallet would be bleeding organic, recycled twenty-dollar bills.) (Sorry I am having too much fun trolling... let me get to the review).

The DAILY TOAST is something you could make at home, but you do have to give them credit for the beautiful presentation and thoughtful combination of fresh fruit, mascarpone / some devilishly delicious spread, and a sprinkle of pistachio crumbs atop perfectly toasted focaccia. 

The EGG SANDWICH is also way more tasty than you'd expect from the banal name, but the soft-boiled runny egg in a buttery, flaky croissant is better than any stereotypical brunch fare. However I think they could have done better on presentation. The eggs look out of place in the middle of the coronal cross-section of the croissant, and a simple plate would have done wonders in comparison to the paper boat it's currently served in.

The richness of the croissant brings forth a dilemma; it is extremely filling, so I would recommend also ordering the daily toast and splitting half-and-half to simultaneously satisfy cravings for brunch food and a healthy (ish) fruit dish.

Seating can also be problematic because it's small and gets crowded quickly, so I suggest coming before 9 on weekends (or even earlier/on weekdays if you want to snag indoors for ideal food pictures, which is mandatory if you are paying this much).

It came out to ~$20 for a breakfast for 2, with no drinks or extras. Pastries look amazing and judging from the bombness of the croissant I would trust them to have serious baking skills, but the $20 had definitely evaporated my breakfast allowance for awhile.
author: Edna C.

description:
Walked here from The Opal hotel which was about a 12 minute walk. 
This is a petite Cafe with very friendly staff. Don't expect to sit down with a large party. Theres one table inside that seats 5-6 and about 4 tables outside that seats 1-3. Food and coffee came out very quickly. 

We ordered:
Egg on croissant sandwich and it was really good! The croissant was perfect size and crispy. 

Daily toast: highly recommended! The fruit on top were delicious and sweet. You can tell that it's homegrown or wherever they get it from, it wasn't store bought. We had a type of grape that we've never seen before. The bread was crispy and soft. It was pretty perfect. I wouldn't change one thing about it. 

Would definitely come back!
author: Mary C.

description:
5 stars most definitely for their starting player the DAILY TOAST. Made to perfection and crave worthy!! A thick piece of toasted focaccia, creamy marscapone cheese and the freshest, sweetest fruit sprinkled with pistachios! Ahhhhhh heaven!! A very hearty snack (at the whopping price of $7.50) which does not disappoint. While a part of me was telling myself, "7 BUCKS?!?!? You can totally make this yourself at home." The other part of me replied with, "Yeah but it won't be as pretty, and plus this is San Francisco..." 

Coffee was ok but sizes run small with the largest being 12 ounces. I have yet to try the other items on the menu but all seem delicious! 

Overall cute place, with fresh food....at a hefty price.
author: Caye Q.

description: First time in San Fran, and this place was an amazing place to hide away for a nice breakfast. The owner was very hospitable and the food was great! I had the smoked salmon toast with coffee and both were incredibly good. And everyone loves free coffee refills. Highly reccomended and kudos to hosting an amazing morning!
author: Mina A.

description:
I really wanted to like farm:table but I simply couldn't bc the prices are overwhelming for overrated toast. One toast with seasonal fruits is $7.75. It left me hungry for more so I had a croissant with egg and ham. Again, very small portion. I'm still hungry and a tad angry; heading towards another level of hangryyyyy! 

I decided that was it, but spending a penny more for empty calories. I spent over $24 bucks on toast and croissant + two drinks (coffee and milk with honey), yet I'm not satiated at all. 

Additionally, there was no space to sit. The outside patio smelled like urine. I won't be back any time soon.
author: Phoebe T.

description:
My friend and I stumbled on this place after a workout class and were famished. 

We had delicious breakfast sandwiches and coffees. For randomly coming across this place, the breakfast was pretty good. The egg on my sandwich was hard boiled though, and for someone who loves a good fried egg on their breakfast sandwiches, that was a bit of a bummer. Bread was the best part--fresh, slightly sweet, REALLY good. 

Only downside was that it was extremely small and it was hard to find a place to sit.
author: Lara K.

description: Great food and service. Love that their menu changes daily according to what's in season and available. A truly inspired and humble little spot in the heart of SF.
author: Lucy M.

description: Super cute hole in the wall place for breakfast, lunch, coffee, juice, and pastries! Love that most of the seating is outside; it's perfect for people watching. I ordered a white peach lemonade and egg on croissant -- so good !
author: Karen P.

description: This place is small but cute. Fruit toast was awesome. It came loaded with fresh fruits and tasty spread. The charcoal latte was visually interesting but the flavor was nothing special. Recommended for breakfast.
author: Dex Y.

description: Great food, pretty quick. Not a lot of seating but outside seating was great. Had the hard boil d egg croissant with avocado, very good.
author: Erik J.

description:
Cute place with fresh tasty food and nice service that's very popular. Even on a weekday afternoon there was a 20 minute wait. Not very much space inside or outside so don't necessarily expect to find any seating especially if you are in a group.

The menu is simple and only has a few items. We got the daily toast ($8) and egg croissant ($8). The toast had delicious mascarpone cheese and fresh fruit on top. Definitely not enough for a meal if you're hungry. It was good but I preferred the egg croissant much more. It was the perfect crunch and had a creamy flavorful sauce. Also not enough for a meal on its own for me. Coffee was good too but nothing too memorable.

Overall tasty fresh food but a bit overpriced for the serving size.
author: Linda X.

description:
I came here on a Saturday at 11 a.m. It's a cute place, but definitely way too small if you were hoping to dine here.

Expect to see the place packed with one cramped table inside and people spilling out into the street to either sit at two small outside tables, the public parklet across the way, or just straight up stand next to a ledge.

Despite the limitations of the location, this place is actually pretty adorable and hard not to like. They have a full coffee menu and different breakfast treats and baked goods to enjoy. I decided to order the House Cereal  which comes with mixed toasted flakes, coconut, almonds, seeds, dried fruit and served with housemate yogurt and seasonal jam for $7.75. It was tasty.

I would come back if I was already in the area.
author: Regina W.

description:
Farm to table was full of surprises for my friend and I, to say the least. The name itself is intriguing because you can expect some really fresh ingredients. We parked on the street a block down (SF you know, what else would ya expect?!) and we walked on over to find that this place is tiny. TINY. Like barely any standing room for 4 or so people and a small COMMUNAL table that takes up most of the rooms space. There's also some interesting bench area thing in front to fit some people and soak up some sun and 1 actual 2 person table in front as well, but that area was packed like crazy. Being my awkward self I kind of wanted to take our food to go, but at the same time I didn't want to walk down the block to our car with my egg sandwich thing in hand, taunting me to take a bite, but having to fight my urges for fear of spilling all over myself. I just have not mastered that whole walking and eating or drinking at the same time thing! If I had attempted that, then the name of this story would be, "Farm to Table to All over my shirt to Tears: A day in the life of Maleah." 

ANYWAY, that led us to sitting at that small communal table (that seats maybe 5-6 people) since a group of people had left and the table was up for grabs. So I squished my butt in and sat with the other strangers who were experiencing this with us. ONTO THE FOOD! The menu is VERY small but honestly, that's what's expected in farm to table type of places-it's about the quality not the quantity. We ordered the Egg on Croissant (hard cooked egg, melted cheese, baked ham, greens & creme fraiche), the Daily Toast (toasted focaccia, mascarpone, seasonal fruits, and pistachios), matcha chai latte, and mocha (60% tcho chocolate). My friends daily toast tasted awesome and looked beautifully instagram worthy, but NO DOUBT my plainer looking egg croissant was totally better, oh my goodness. I don't know what it was that made it so packed with flavor, but it was great. Take note that things may change a little by what's in store each season! If you ever have the chance, this place is a noteworthy hole in the wall type of thing to stop by!
author: Maleah M.

description:
Lovely food, my egg croissant was delicious, the cheddar and ham perfectly embraced the hard boiled egg and greens.  Angelica's cereal bowl was fresh and all things tasted natural. 
My latte was also really good.  The final star would have come from better or more seating options, it can be quite uncomfortable.
author: Juan G.

description:
Pros: Very yummy food, solid service (was luckily not crowded when I went), and wide selection of drinks.

Cons: Only 5 options for food, it's only cheap b/c they give very little quantity, odd staff.

I think the pros speak for themselves, but I want to expand upon the cons. As for quantity I personally got the egg on croissant and it was good, but it's a small croissant, so you might want to indulge in two dishes, which will bring you to a $16 meal. At that price, I've had much better quality brunch. Staff threw me off a bit because specifically one guy acted very weird, almost creepy, but people have their personalities and just because I might not like one on first glance does not mean they are bad. Service was quick and, but not outstanding.
author: Oviya A.

description:
Came around 8:30 am on a Sunday morning as a party of 4 and this place was already bustling! Was excited to try this place out and can say it is a definite hole in the wall. 

We ordered the Daily Toast, Tuna Melt, and Matcha Chai Latte. I would rank them as the following:

1. Matcha Chai Latte: This is a must!! I am a big fan of chai and this drink brings out the perfect blend in taste between matcha and chai. The matcha taste doesn't overtake the chai and vice versa. The drink was not super sweet as I had expected and overall, a really special drink that I am willing to come back again just for this. Rating: 5/5

2. Daily Toast: Really special and super fresh! The mascarpone spread with fresh fruits on top was a refreshing combo I haven't seen before. It's a relatively big piece of toast for 2 people to share. Would recommend this with the matcha chai latte! Rating: 4/5

3. Tuna Melt: I don't think this is on their permanent menu but was a great choice! It was delicious but it was not as special as the matcha chai latte and daily toast.  Came with a small salad on the side. Rating: 3/5

Cute atmosphere, friendly people, but the pricing was set slightly higher in correlation to its quality. Would say an average person would have to spend $10+ for breakfast here if you are ordering a toast (their main menu) and a drink.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Farm:table is tiny.  Teeny tiny.  Practically thimble-sized.  But it's fabulous.

In case you don't know, farm:table is a adorable little (very little) breakfast spot a hop, skip, and jump away from Union Square.  Did I mention that it was small?  Well, it is.  There's nothing more than a breakfast pastry display, a cashier, and a communal table that technically seats 8 but eliminates all pretense of personal space.  Be prepared to rub elbows with strangers.

I came in around 8:30am on a Sunday morning and there was already a line.  Luckily it moved quickly and gave me an opportunity to browse the mouthwatering menu.  I opted for a berry muffin, their "daily toast" (with raspberries, blueberries, peaches, strawberries, and cherries on mascarpone cheese), and a glass of their daily juice blend.  

Every single item was outstanding.  The toast was simply stunning to look at, and it tasted heavenly too, with lots of fresh berries in every bite.  And the muffin?  Warm, soft, sweet (but not too sweet!), and very flavorful.  The juice was the perfect thing to wash it down with.

At first, I was a little apprehensive about the cramped communal seating, but it ended up not being a big deal at all.  Everyone had a good sense of humor about having their breakfast on top of everyone else, and it seems like an easy environment to make some new friends...or just eavesdrop on some randoms.

Farm:table proves that amazing things can come in the smallest of packages.
author: David G.

description: Cutest little brunch spot. High emphasis on the LITTLE -- I think there's about 4 seating areas total that including inside and outside. However, the line is always long and the food is always fresh and yummy. You can't go wrong with anything on the bunch menu. Try it out if you're in nob hill/lower tenderloin area.
author: Jenn N.

description:
Latte (Frank the Pug) was excellent.
Food superb.  No frills service in disposable containers.  Seating is limited and communal.
Very quaint and appealing.
author: Bryan C.

description: This place is amazing. I definitely recommend it. The toast with all the fruit is so good and also the coffee. If you're in the area I highlight recommend checking it out. Long wait though so make sure you have enough time
author: Sanaz T.

description:
Came on a Sunday morning and the wait was not bad at all. You order at the counter and then find a seat. They do bus the tables so you don't have to bus your own. 

My friend and I shared the daily toast and the egg on croissant. I loved the soft brioche and the mascarpone on the toast. The egg on croissant was also really good, although simple. I feel like the egg should have been more soft boiled and sliced instead of halved. 

I'd probably visit again if I were in the area but I wouldn't make a special trip out.
author: Vivian H.

description: Pretentious hipster crap. We tried to order toast with eggs (which wasn't the daily special) and were promptly told we couldn't do that. So we ordered two house cereals with yogurt and a cappuccino, total cost $26 with tip. This is probably $1-2 worth of food and it honestly wasn't anything memorable or special. Skip this place. There are a lot more places to eat in the area that offer far more food for the same price range.
author: Heath P.

description: Oh I ALWAYS enjoy their cappuccino! Small but fantastic. The House Coffee and the plain croissant are also on point!
author: Yeseul S.

description:
If I lived in San Francisco, I would likely frequent farm:table. I loved that it was a small neighborhood place and served great food. I got their savory tart which was very delicious and my husband got their breakfast croissant. We were overall very satisfied with what we got even though the portions were a tad on the small size. 

I loved how small and intimate the location was and everyone who worked there seemed to take extreme pride in what they do which was wonderful. We didn't get coffee but their roast smelled great. We will probably stop by the next time we are in town.
author: Sarah Z.

description: Get the daily fruit toast! Fruit and mascarpone cheese on fluffy bread with crisp edges. Bomb. The Frank the Pug honey latte was also great. Small place, one communal table inside...would be better with just a little more space when it's cold out, but over all cute place. Very friendly staff.
author: Allison I.

description: Loved the presentation of the daily toast. Covered in coffee marscapone with a beautiful array of fruit. Cute and small cafe.
author: Jessica L.

description:
this place was pretty cool. It is a trendy breakfast/brunch spot in a nice San Francisco neighborhood. The ambiance and food is pretty much tailored for a good instagram picture. The service is really friendly and it is very easy to order. The building is a bit small and cramped, so perhaps you should prepare to order to go.

I got the tuna melt and it was definitely tasty. My one complaint is that it was overpriced and the quantity was not that filling.
author: Evan T.

description: I really enjoyed the food and coffee here. A tad bit expensive but that's true for anywhere in the city.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Get off of Yelp and just go here STAT! This breakfast was phenomenal! It's a gem in the midst of downtown blahhhhh. The menu is short and sweet, but too the point powerful. Highly recommend the lavender latte as it was just slightly sweet with the floral essence but balanced perfectly for the coffee. It had a smooth, silky finish, nothing overpowering. And then the Croissant Breakfast sandwich was BOMB. Fresh pastry and hard boiled eggs, maple bacon, Everything I wanted to start my morning. 

The place is super small though. Only about 6-7 seats inside at a shareable community table, and then about another 6 outside via counter and small table. Either plan to take out, or be ok with shacking up with close quarters and some other guests. 

100% recommend this as a SF go-to.
author: Alicia C.

description: If you're a foodie you must try this place! Amazing! My daughter and I had the daily toast and yogurt. It's a very good sized portion and really feels you up. The fruit is so fresh you can see them cutting it right in front of you! The inside is small but the outside eating area is a really cool spot to start your day. We got there 10 minutes after opening and it was already packed! We will definitely return when we are back in the city.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I came to check out the hype and was a little underwhelmed. 

This place is an extremely small (teeny tiny) cafe but with an impressive following. It only seats about 10 people inside, maybe less, with a couple chairs outside. There was a line out the door when I got there but it moved quite quickly.

I ended up getting the daily toast and my friend got the tuna melt. I also got a matcha latte. My daily toast was very pretty and photo worthy but taste was only 3.5/5, the latte was okay as well and my friend didn't quite enjoy her tuna melt. 

Overall, I would come back on a day that wasn't crowded for some daily toast but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Lisa S.

description: Nice filling bfast place for gluten free, dairy free folks.  I had the cereal with almond milk and ordered a black tea with honey.  Great way to start the day!   Communal table with some outside sidewalk seating available.
author: F. J.

description:
Pros: We came here because we were able to avoid crazy brunch lines. This is like a coffee shop - you order food first, and then find a place to sit. I got the daily toast and it was pretty good!

Cons: Unfortunately, this is not a brunch place to get a hearty meal, and more like a place to grab coffee and a quick bite. It's a super cute place, but overpriced for what it is.
author: Stephanie C.

description: food was great! And the match latte was to die for! However seating was extremely limited ): and we had to wait for a seat to open up which is the only reason this place isn't 5 stars for me.
author: Saori S.

description: The guy is so rude and the service is not good. Honestly I don't know why they have 4 stars.
author: Azadeh T.

description: Came for a quick bite, and got the daily toast with the mocha chi latte.  The toast was good but towards the end it was super sweet. I usually like chi lattes but didn't enjoy this one. The place is super cute and small.
author: Karen G.

description:
We came here 2 days in a row for a quick bite.

Loved the small setting and intimate vibe.

We split a croissant egg sandwich and had lattes.

Will be back!
author: Aidan V.

description: Took a walk thru the scummy Tenderloin to eat here.  It's even worse than I remembered when I live on Nob Hill many years ago.  Full of human garbage, piss and scat.  Yummy.  But, I wanted to try this place and had very high hopes and expectations.  Not fulfilled.  Coffee was weak and thin.  Egg Croissant was not properly seasoned and lacking in any enhancements to make it "special".  Salmon brioche was smothered in creme fraiche obliterating any other flavor.  Salad was nice.  In summary not bad but certainly not outstanding in any aspect.
author: Robert D.

description:
One of my favorite spots for breakfast in SF. The coffee, juices and the food is amazing. I literally crave for the everyday toast when I'm not in SF. Their croissant breakfast sandwiches are equally delicious.

Tuesdays - Fridays they open at 7:30am and all other days they open at 8am. Be the first through the door!!!
author: Adrian K.

description: Had a great breakfast here on a recent trip to San Francisco. Quick service and super fresh options. I'll try to get back to this place on a future visit!
author: Reno B.

description:
Really tiny cafe with really amazingly delicious food.  I'm a huge fan and want to bring it back to LA with me.

Don't come here expecting a ridiculously large, heavy breakfast one human being should not be consuming anyway.  Expect a fresh meal made from quality ingredients in a portion size that's reasonable.

I do wish they had more space and tables.  We were lucky to have gotten a space inside because it looked really cold where their few outside tables were.

I got the Daily Toast, which has pecan butter, apples and toasted coconut on whole wheat.  Yummalicious, beautifully presented and not nearly as expensive as I expected it to be (7.50) and a perfect latte.  I am one happy and satisfied customer!
author: Lucky S.

description:
I ordered the everyday toast. There's limited seating and it gets pretty packed. I got a mug of hot water to go with my toast. My cup was dirty (food bits stuck on it and there was something green stuck to the side). Not gonna lie, it killed my mood a little, but I just went back inside and got another mug.

The toast had a nice presentation but the fruit tends to fall off when you take a bite so I ate the fruit with a fork first then the toast. I liked how the toast, fruit, and cheese combo wasn't too sweet, but the $8 price tag had me cringe just a little considering it's something I can make myself in a snap with ingredients from my own garden. If you don't have a garden I'd recommend this though!

I had a sip of my friend's cappuccino and it was really good (that's coming from someone who normally doesn't even like it).

I'd say if you're looking for a simple breakfast and good cappuccino, come to Farm:table, otherwise I'd look elsewhere.
author: Sylvia Y.

description:
Cute and quirky. Good coffee and food. Haphazard limited seating so don't expect to be comfortable on a Saturday or Sunday. Rather expensive. $8 for a small bowl of cereal ? 

Go there once on a sunny weekend morning. You'll enjoy the novelty, but you'll find yourself not eager to return.
author: Eric L.

description: Great place for a hip brunch. The server/reg op was great! All of their espresso drinks are single origin. My husband and I had the French toast and croissant Sami.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
I came across this place on a warm November morning just before a long day at the deYoung museum. (I'm a little late to writing this) I was looking for a good brunch place that was walk-able from the Hilton Union Square, but I didn't want to go somewhere touristy or crowded.

I was very glad to find farm:Table with seating available. There was no line, as it was a weekday, and I was served right away. The staff was friendly and helpful. They have a small menu but the things they do make, they make really well. I ordered the Egg on Croissant and coffee and promptly took a seat on their cute sidewalk eating area. It has planters around it and juts out from the normal walking area of the sidewalk. Kind of a nifty idea.

Coming from Minneapolis, a very clean city, it can be a bit unappetizing to eat on a patio/outdoors in larger cities like SF that have a lot of cleanliness issues. I found that farm:Table's sidewalk seating (seems to be weird to call it a 'patio') really depended on the direction of the wind. In the end, I was still able to enjoy my food, strong coffee, the friendliness of the staff, and a good book.
author: Carrie W.

description: We came here for a Sunday brunch last week before dropping my friend off at the airport. After 1 week and all I could remember was how small this place is. Don't expect to find seating. So how this place works is that you order and pay for your food, then find your own seating. I mean, the food was average and the place has an SF vibe which is pretty cool. One thing that was kind of a turn off was the savory tart that I ordered. I am very sensitive to the taste and smell of goat cheese and they did not list goat cheese in the description which has all the ingredients for the savory tart. I just couldn't eat the savory tart. The other people I came with got a tuna melt, a chocolate croissant, and some sort of a croissant sandwich. They said the food was average. In conclusion, nothing special about this place. Just an average restaurant.
author: Tran N.

description:
Another weekly Sunday brunch date with Stef C. Somehow we ended up deciding on this place the weekend before. I woke up a bit late but this is place was SMALL. I didn't believe how small it was until we got there. There's only about room for 8 people to sit there. 

I ordered a regular latte and that wasn't anything special but Stef got the pug n honey latte. The sip that I had was delicious. Definitely recommend it. Might be too sweet for some people though. 

We shared the daily toast with fruit and the egg on croissant. The toast was topped with mascarpone cheese with different fruit (outs had strawberries, apple, orange, grapefruit, kiwi, blackberries). Healthy! The egg on croissant is good too. Hard boiled egg, arugula, and prosciutto on a croissant is a popular too. 

Protip: stake out a place at the community table and get some toast!
author: Nina Y.

description: Our first time eating at a table with random sweet & friendly people. The coffee is great and perfect portioned breakfast.
author: Michelle D.

description: Where can I start?! This was the best breakfast I have had in forever. I could eat here everyday if I could. The staff was great, the food was even better. Our waitress even gave me a to go cup for my drink. Like who does that besides awesome people. The food is definitely fresh!!!!
author: Lili M.

description:
Yum!! Super small space but love that it's a small list of options and all fresh and scrumptious. It makes it easier to pick.

The homemade cereal was good- nice balance of yogurt, fruit, and cereal. 
The egg croissant was toasty- perfect egg, sauce and toasted bread.
The daily toast was beautiful and delicious- in season fruits, marscapone and thick toast. What's better?  

Farm:table:Jenn's mouth.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Really poor customer service, to the extent of rudeness. No prices are displayed anywhere. If you can get over that, the food is decent.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Get their daily toast (mascarpone cheese with seasonal fruit) and the matcha chai latte with soy milk.

I've tried their croissant sandwich and the cauliflower tart and both were just okay -nothing too memorable. 

They have very limited seating (one communal table inside and a few small tables outside) so either get it to go or bring only ONE of your friends.
author: Jenn K.

description:
Great little breakfast spot in the heart of SF! Came here after a night at the Fremont hotel nearby. Arrived around 11am and to a line out the door, brunch goers on nearby benches and the small restaurant packed. 

Pros: 
-staff hustles and gets through the line quick 
- croissant egg sandwich and morning cereal were worth the wait. 
- latte served in large cup (soy / almond milk available ) 

Cons:
- tiny indoor seating - 8-10 people max
author: Sierra A.

description: A cute little hole in the wall with a line out the door, this place is a great stop for a quick breakfast (outside if you can find a table) or to go. I took mine to go and brought it down to Union Square. Based off of reviews I kind of expected this place to be spectacular, but it wasn't. It was good, but nothing special. I ordered the egg croissant with avocado instead of ham (maybe that's why it wasn't spectacular?) which comes with hard boiled egg, some kind of sauce, mixed greens and melted cheese. I felt that for $8 it wasn't really worth it. There weren't any special flavors, it was pretty generic. Good, but not great. The portion was decent, but I think it should be maybe more of a $5 breakfast sandwich. As for the cappuccino, it was tasty and beautiful. This is a good spot if you don't want table service and want something fresh on the go, but maybe try the daily toast instead of the egg croissant...I couldn't decide between the two but kind of wish I had tried the daily toast. Side note: the guy working the register was really pleasant and helpful.
author: amanda g.

description:
Came here for breakfast with some girlfriends. Place is cute, but line is long even at 9:30AM on a Sunday. It's more of a bakery than what I originally thought it would be - a sit down breakfast cafe. There is some standing space for 1 or 2 people groups outside along the sidewalk. 

The menu is limited with a few breakfast items.l, and between the four of us, we pretty much ordered the entire menu. The croissant looked good, but we thought it was weird that it came w/ a hard boiled egg. The house cereal and toast seemed decent. I got a blueberry kouign Amman and thought it was overly buttery sugary and decadent though tasty. I also tried to order a house juice, but they didn't have any juices today!! 

4 stars for decent food, but minus one star for no seating, and more important they had no juices from their menu today!
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Classic small cafe with limited options of what I would consider food that you could easily make at home. But that's the appeal of these hipster joints, and yes I caved too for that beautiful (and very simple) daily toast. Decked with fresh fruits and marscapone spread, the daily toast is more picture worthy than anything. For a whopping $7, you don't actually get a bang for your buck. 

The matcha chai latte was decent but I've had much better in NY. Seating inside is limited to one communal table, but I loved the high table seating and park-let they have outside. A smart design move!
author: K C.

description:
I like this place mostly for the good vibes and cute front. Came here for brunch with a friend. You order up at the register and pay, and then they bring your food out to you. Spaces are pretty limited--there's this one communal table inside and two smaller tables outside of the restaurant. There's also this funky seating arrangement thing right in front of the restaurant. From what I can gather, it's a memorial for someone, but it looks like an ergonomic approach to seating. It's a bit fun to try to figure out the best configuration for eating if you're up for it, but otherwise, I'd just go for the table.

I actually just got the breakfast cereal and a honey and milk. The breakfast cereal was surprisingly good given how simplistic it was. It was basically just cereal, raisins, jam, and yogurt mixed together. The honey and milk was lovely and warm and complemented my meal pretty well. I do agree with some other Yelper's reviews that the meals are a bit simplistic and look like things that you could make by yourself. I do still think that it's a pretty cute brunch place. I don't think you'll be mindblown by the food that you're eating, but it's good. 

tldr; cute brunch spot, don't overlook the breakfast cereal it's actually pretty good! definitely a small place though
author: Jasmine X.

description: This place is absolutely tiny and honestly it's not clear what's do farm to table about them. I had the daily toast which was good (4/5) and a cappuccino. Service left a lot to be desired since my coffee arrived 15 min after my toast. They handsomely forgotten about it and had to be reminded several times.
author: Neha M.

description: Pretty good spot. Warrants a return if I'm in the area, but I'd like to try out other spots. They got the job done with my breakfast tuna salad sandwich. I'd say give it a shot; know there is pretty limited seating here.
author: Justin W.

description:
While they are billed as a breakfast place, the menu was more like lunch. The muesli was good, but not that special. The egg croissant was a better choice. 

While they have speciality juices, it seems they buy the orange juice from the market done the street. 

Limited outdoor seating.
author: David J.

description: Great place for breakfast at SF. We stayed in a hotel near by and decided to check it out. Definitely nice cool place to visit. And they croissant  sandwich was AMAZINGLY!!! Definitely worth stopping by and getting some delicious breakfast!
author: Fashionista I.

description: I try to come here every time I visit SF. Short and sweet menu and you can't go wrong with any option! House cereal is my personal favorite.
author: Amanda I.

description: I've been here before, coffee is good food is ok but the service is terrible. Last time I went, after 5 minutes of waiting without being greeted and nobody in line, cashier was rude when she approached the register. When I thought she was going to take my order impolitely told me to wait without even raising her head to acknowledge my presence. Then after another time she just went out the door. So did I.
author: Lorely G.

description: Great breakfast choice! Toasts are delicious with fresh strawberries, pineapples, apples and blackberries. So tasty! Awesome to go with a cup of cappuccino!
author: Emily C.

description: Comically typical awesome San Francisco tiny breakfast coffee shop serving wholesome fresh simple large good coffees and breakfast items from a simple menu - with no prices listed. Three of us ate hearty toast and morning drinks for $39 - limited seating busy place - trendy hipster
author: Shaw J.

description: Very tiny place that was packed and a bit disorganized. However, the food was great for a quick breakfast on the go.
author: J D.

description: Love love love this place! Went here on a Thursday around 10:30am. There was a small line and all tables except one were taken, but service was very friendly and efficient. We ordered two lattes, the daily toast and the egg croissant with avocado- would recommend everything. So delicious I wanted more!
author: Joanna H.

description: The Daily Toast was delicious - a hearty slice of bread with sweet mascarpone cheese and fresh fruit. All of the flavors played really nicely together. I like how the fruits vary depending on the day you come. The Eggs on Croissant was good but nothing too special in my opinion. I liked the tangy sauce they used. There's only one table inside that can fit probably 8 people comfortably so you might have to wait a little depending on when you go.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Nothing too excited to rave about here.

Good service and mediocre beans and limited food selection.  Sandwiches is just ok and fruit with bread is overpriced in my opinion.
author: Nicolas N.

description:
We wanted to find a healthy breakfast to eat. Had the "daily toast" which was delicious! Hubby had the toast dry without the marscpone cheese. The coffee was on spot!

Only one big table inside and outside seating. Service was fast.
author: Karen S.

description:
Good spot for a breakfast snack to go, not so much a full-on hearty brunch. I came here on a Sunday morning where it was comfortably packed (it's a VERY small place. They only have one communal table, window seating, two little tables outside and the parklet) so my boyfriend and I were able to sit outside right under a balcony, which was helping us somehow avoid the rain.

We shared the Egg on Croissant and their Daily Toast accompanied with a latte & their Milk n Honey (basically a honey latte) drink. They accidentally made us a hot chocolate that we got to keep on the house! The Daily Toast reminded me of brick toast at some asian cafes, but way more refreshing with the fresh fruit on top (and I guess with the delicious homemade mascarpone of course....), as well as the Egg on Croissant being a very simple croissant sandwich with two eggs, meat and a sprinkle of greens in the middle. I was pretty content with what we got, but it could have been all the liquid that made us full afterwards.

I like the idea of this place and how they promote fresh, local and organic ingredients but I feel I can't ever dine comfortably here. I would suggest coming here if you want a healthy alternative to a grab n go place. Parking here is pretty crappy since it's borderline tenderloin and the streets here are insanely busy. All in all, this place is worth checking out if you happen  to be in the area!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Very charming location. The restaurant is low on seating so prepare to eat standing up.

My husband got the daily toast which had all sorts of fruits, mascarpone cream on a brioche bread - it was absolutely delicious! I tried to remake back at home but nothing compares. I had the tuna melt on a piece of bread which had bits of apple, 2 slices of tomato w/ cheese on top  - I'd give it a 4 out of 5. Lemonade of the day was Rasberry! It was so refreshing I had to go back and order another one to go. 

Farm Table was priced reasonably, service was fast and staff was amazing. I absolutely recommend.
author: Marta B.

description: Great convenient location prior to picking up rental car. Very tiny inside seating area and interesting quirky outside sitting/standing area. We all ordered the matcha green tea latte, mocha latte, fruit marscapone bread, bacon maple scone and quiche. Everything very fresh and great unique taste. Even though they were extremely busy, they were pretty prompt despite a tiny work area. Def a great hidden gem and local place to check out
author: Melissa I.

description:
Everyone gets the fruit on toast thing but I am trying not to eat bread because of Passover.   So I opted for the house cereal.   This was delicious and filling.   There was a perfect balance of yogurt to berries to dried fruit (I never like overdone raisins) to nuts.   

I went on a Monday morning 9:30ish.  It's a tight space but full of locals who are on their way somewhere so a space opened up pretty quickly at the square communal table inside.  

Service was friendly, fun and quick.
author: Rachel L.

description:
This tiny gem was a great place to have brunch. As we entered the restaurant/closet we  ordered one of everything, daily toast (tasty bread with marscapone cheese and sweet fruits such as kiwis, cuties, apples all sprinkled with pomegranate seeds), the croissant sammich with boiled egg and creme fraiche and ham and the savory tart. We ordered black coffee and mochas. The line was quite long and it didn't seem as efficient. We were thanked for waiting in line an glad we did. 

Pros:
-flaky flaky ungodly wonderful croissant!
-tasty coffee 
-beautiful arrangement of the fruits on the daily toast
-friendly and attentive service


Cons:
-The salad with the savory tart was a little boring, the best part were the pom seeds but the dressing was way too sweet
-Basically, the tart in general. It was underwhelming and all I could taste was brocolli
-it's smaller than my closet back home in AZ so you feel like you are constantly in the way and there are only 2 tables outside with some very artsy/annoying benches in front.

It was nice to gorge ourselves with bottomless mimosas and heavy sauces and dishes. they were delicate and we split the 3 small breakfast items. I highly recommend this place. Cheers!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Wandering aimlessly near our hotel -SFO 
looking for a breakfast spot..lo and behold.. 
A "park-let full of smiley people .. An itty bitty hole in the wall .. The chalkboard had some nice sounding dee-lites'
The vibe reminded us of our Village (Belmont Shore- 90803)
Croissant breakfast sandwich as good as Paris but better in this case cause we were served by the Owner.
Will return 
YUM
author: Patrick H.

description: I went on a quest for cereal for breakfast and found this place! It was delightful. No prices listed on the menu, which was a bit odd, but the iced tea was good and the cereal spectacular (expensive, but that was to be expected). Housemade cereal with fresh fruits and housemade jam. Really delightful.
author: Hannah D.

description: I read reviews about this tiny, tiny place with a small menu from other Yelp-ers and decided to check it out with my mom before a morning of shopping. My cold cereal with tasty filled with cereal flakes, seeds, dried cranberries, grapes, kiwi slices, runny yogurt, and a pineapple jam. The bowl was full to overflowing and left me feeling full but healthy. The honey latte was also delish. No skim milk here, but lattes are better with whole milk anyway. We were lucky to grab one of the few tables outside, but be forewarned, the cereal dish is not one that is easy to eat standing and getting a seat is not a guarantee. Would definitely return for a taste of the toast since the photos online look so pretty.
author: Ryen B.

description: I kind of feel like a tool for paying $8 for toast. Sure it was a thick hearty slice of toasted nutty wheat bread, topped with marscapone and fresh, artfully arranged fruits, but for $8 I could've bought so many other things... Sigh. It looked nice on my Instagram though.
author: Tara W.

description: Only tried their daily toast today but all I can say is GOD DAM, ITS THE BOMB! Great customer service and atmosphere was amazing despite it being a little small cafe ! Definitely coming back again (maybe tomorrow) to try the other things on the menu !!
author: Shirley G.

description:
Oh SF health department, I think you dropped the ball on this place. If cleanliness was my only complaint, I would perhaps just leave it alone, but when you pay a nice amount of money for a sandwich that is supposed to be heated, and it is STONE COLD in the middle, with congealed bechamel sauce, and you have rude workers and an owner (??) that thinks space for her dogs is more important than paying customers, you have a serious problem here. The owner certainly sets the stage for the rude, dirty behavior of her employees. 

Six weeks or so ago (I actually wrote this review the day of, and Yelp said I did not publish it, so here is it) I wandered upon this hole in the wall and they have a croque monsieur on their menu. That sounded good and I always like to see how it is done. This one said it had turkey and ham with melted cheese. Sounded good enough that I forked over $14 post tip to take my sandwich a few blocks to eat. 

First I ordered, the guy did not welcome me, he did was not polite and pretty much was ready to end his day as he called out after my order "Only 15 more minutes." I should have known then I might have a problem. I sat down on the bench, at the very small table. In comes a woman with her two dogs, I am bad at dog types but it was something kind of puggish looking, one tan and one smaller one that was black. One was a badly behaved dog, so I rolled my eyes at the entitled woman who seemed to think her dogs deserved more space than actual humans. Then this woman starts to say "Bring your cameras early tomorrow and be ready to post on your social media. I will be in early and prep. I ordered a new square today." You can see why I thought she was the owner. AT this point her dog barks, another example of a bad dog owner. The bad dog owner then says to the employee "Don't give him anything Mr. So and so lost his right to get a treat because of his behavior." Ok, I was too fast to judge her as a bad dog owner, she is actually disciplining her dog, way to go. Woman owner with dog is still talking, fast and pressured (too much of one of the "Cs"...just not sure which one). Then the counter person is getting a piece of ham out...note, it is HAM. Of course, my first impression of this dog owner is correct as she says "Oh hand it to me and I will feed them as they take my fingers off as I do it." Ok woman, you just said your dog does not get anything, now you are giving some to it while you cry out and make a big deal that the dog nipped you. Really??!! In front of customers? I truly hope you never had human children as we don't need parents around like you. 

So all of this I would have ignored, not writing a Yelp review about it but the next move as just so unsanitary that I almost demanded my money back (and should have). An employee was holding metal utensils, and went to put the dogs. Hand runs from nose to butt. Then he walks over and uses THE SAME HAND to put the silverware in the container, touching all the parts we put into our mouth. Gross. No one was washing their hands, the person handling money was handling food with no gloves and not washing his hands, which is in violation of health codes. 

I take my sandwich back to the office. First of all there is about 1  ounce of meat on it and NO HAM. The damn dog got my ham. The cheese is cold and not melted, the meat cold (at least they chill their meat), and the bechamel sauce was stone cold and coagulated. The sides of the sandwich were burnt. Too hot, too fast. Gross. The whole thing got thrown away, what I waste of money. 

Go to this place if you want dog nose and butt germs on your food. Go if you want rude humans interacting with you. Go if you want cold food that is missing half the meat. Go if you want to walk away shaking your head and realizing you have to Yelp a 1-star review.
author: Theresa S.

description:
+ THE FOOD
I had the egg croissant sandwich with a latte and it was delicious!!! Their foods look deceptively small but they're super filling. The egg croissant sandwich had 2 halved hard boiled eggs, some meat, arugula, cheese, and creme friache. The latte was amazing as well and I would definitely come back just for their coffee. 

- THE ENVIRONMENT
The place is soooo tiny. I've never seen a little brunch place so cramped and tiny. There is only one small table inside that can maybe fit 6-8 people if you sit really close together. There's 2-3 small tables outside too.
author: Cindy C.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with the food these guys prepare. The daily toast is a must, and it is always varying depending on the seasonal fruits. The breakfast sandwiches were pleasant as well, except that on the veggie one they forgot the avocado. They do have a good variety of pastries as well. The place, however, is too small even if you are by yourself. That's why I asked my order to go and took it back to the hotel across the street. Definitely a fan- will consider it next time I'm around.
author: Daniel A.

description: Homemade almond milk is so good and the breakfast goodies are excellent. Food options are small portioned but fresh and tasty side snacks.
author: Bridget B.

description:
If you're looking for a large, filling brunch meal, don't come here! This is more of a very small cafe with mostly coffee and some small bites to accompany your drink. I came here on a rainy Saturday morning and the place was still packed, even though there's only one huge table inside to sit at. 

We ended up ordering the egg croissant sandwich, the eggplant empanada, and a latte to drink. The sandwich was good, but nothing special and the empanada was just ok. This was definitely not enough food for 2. In addition, the prices of this place don't reflect the one $ on yelp; it's definitely more expensive. The only thing that was great was the coffee - I loved the latte! 

Definitely stop by here if you're in the mood for good coffee, but don't expect great brunch food.  

Tip: This place is also not great for vegetarians. There are very limited items on the menu that are completely vegetarian.
author: Malika R.

description:
We were visiting and decided to stop in for coffee and a sandwich. It was a very tight and confined area so we were trying to squeeze in as there were a couple of others in there as well. When we sat down, they looked at us like we were crazy and we kindly asked "do we have to stand in line to order or do we wait for someone to come to our table"? They just shook their heads and said "if you want breakfast then you stand in line" . When we went up there, we ordered our food. However, any question that we asked, they looked at us as if it were annoying to ask any questions. In addition, when I asked "is there ham on the sandwich, I didn't notice it said that", the man replied "uhhh its on the board where it says ham" while pointing to the board. 

Very rude and not a pleasant experience for a tourist to encounter.

However, the older lady was sweet and walked over to our table and handed us a cookie after they forgot one of our parties sandwich. 

It would be nice for them to greet their customers and point out where items are since they don't like people asking questions.

*After telling the man that he was rude and it was my first time in there , he said "lady, you've been stand off-ish since the start and did not apologize. Instead, he stool by the register giving me dirty looks the entire time in which he made me feel truly uncomfortable and scared.
author: Tyrese T.

description: WHOA - super disappointing!  I was there for a breakfast sandwich on gluten free bread.  The bread they use is from Trader Joes, also the eggs were so cooked that they were hard boiled, and the House-made creme fraiche was just plain mayo.
author: Alison h.

description:
After reading all the great reviews, we arrived there during a heavy rain.  The one table was full.  There was not place to wait in a heavy down pour.  It is irresponsible for the management not to state how many inside and outside seats they offer on the internet.

Who would think that they had only 10 seats.

Jack H
Playa Vista
author: Jack H.

description:
A great place if you like paying $5 for a non-real matcha latte (they added chai which ruined the flavor), or gawk at the foolish hipster I witnessed who payed $8 for a bowl of cereal with almond milk. Literally, $8 for a bowl of cereal.

Btw, avocado toast is easy to make and costs you $1. There's a reason SF hipster breakfast will never rival NYC $3 breakfast.
author: Crystal Y.

description: Very small but cozy place where everything is fresh and excellent quality. I visited San Francisco for 2 days and I liked it so much my husband and I had breakfast here both days. I had a latte with soy milk and it was delicious. We ordered the croissant ham and cheese and it was a perfect balance of croissant, ham, cheese, egg and creme fraiche. I definitely recommend it. There is always a line but it is well worth it. On the plus side, the price is reasonable considering San Francisco is so expensive.
author: Melissa V.

description:
BEST. TOAST. I'VE. EVER. HAD.
see all the emphasis? I dont know what wizardy and magic stuff they put in their daily toast but it taste AND looks amazing!

The shop is fairly small, can only fit 8 people in door. But they have outdoor seatings available which is really nice. 

I only ordered their daily toast so I can only review this place based on that. Daily toast $8 is basically a toasted bread topped with magic spread and fresh organic fruits.

Qs: is a toast really worth $8?
A: yes, for first time experience and craving only though! 

I dont think i'd pay that much for a dang toast you know? No matter how good and irresistible it is, its just insane to pay $8 for a toast.

I definitely recommend getting Daily toast if you havent already! Will come back to have a taste of their beautiful coffee 

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
I wish this place had a larger seating area, but given the real estate situation in this city, I can understand why there's only one central table with peripheral seating. You basically walk in, order, and grab a seat. They have a few cookies and pastries on display, a small breakfast and lunch money, and a bunch of coffee drinks.

The coffee was quite good, on par with other places in SF. My egg sandwich was really good. They actually have a hardboiled egg sliced in two in the middle. Yummy!
author: James W.

description: This place in TINY. If you come here be aware that  there is no place inside to sit. You order at the counter and then eat on benches on the sidewalk. This is more like a grab and go, not "brunch." The only eggs on the menu are hard boiled.
author: Laura R.

description: Delicious breakfast. Freshly made. The service was great. Tiny space so don't sit for too long.
author: Kate K.

description:
I absolutely adore this place. It's the most quaint little neighborhood cafe with a European vibe. The place is small so try not to come here with a big party unless you come really early and grab the one communal table that's available inside (probably fits 12 skinny ppl). Otherwise they have small outdoor seating (for 2-3 ppl) and even a small standing area. 

I am obsessed with their daily toast - the vanilla mascarpone cheese is one of the creamiest and best I've had and topped with fresh fruits like grapes, orange, apple, pomelo, kiwi and pistachios. Just absolutely delicious. The fruit varies seasonally so you'll always get something fresh. The toast was sourdough-y which wasn't my favorite but didn't affect my love for the toast (clearly). Would definitely order this again and again.

I also LOVED my matcha chai latte. I usually love matcha everything and the hints of chai added that extra unique kick. My friend got the quiche lorraine and said it was delicious. My only regret is not trying one of their croissant breakfast sandwiches which I will be back for! This is not the type of breakfast place where you will leave feeling beyond full and guilty for what you ate - instead you'll feel delighted and perfectly satisfied :) Can't wait to take all my friends and family here!
author: Andrea P.

description:
I always appreciate simple and savory menus :) Egg Croissant sandwich and daily toast with a Matcha Chai Latte. Nothing big, nothing too fancy, nothing too fatty that'll clog my arteries. My kind of place. 

Only complaint is how tiny the place is, but excellent customer service. Don't let the long lines scare you either. It almost scared us away but it goes pretty quickly and high turnover rate for seats,so you can say for here when you order. No worries.
author: Vy D.

description: Great price for SF. The coffee is amazing, personally I think the toasts are a little subpar, where my food was a little cold when it came, and I prefer my toast a little more chewy, but if you like crunchy/crumbly toast this place is perfect. The fruit toast is really good though.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I came here on a quiet Friday afternoon. There was only one other person in the small store.

I ordered the croissant with ham, cheese, and egg. The croissant was nice and flakey and all the ingredients came together nicely.  I also ordered an oolong tea and it wasn't that special. My friend ordered the fruit toast and she really liked it. 

The workers are really nice and the store is really cool looking. I would come back again!
author: Lydia H.

description: Really great coffee, fresh food ingredients, chill staff. Busy first thing when they open, but seemed to level off about half an hour later. It's a small interior, most seating is outside. Back to the food, I wasn't expecting the egg to be precooked and cool, but given the number of people lining up and how quickly they're able to get through the queue I can see why they opted for that approach. The croissant sandwich was delicious. Overall I would definitely recommend.
author: Darcy F.

description:
I really thought I would like farm:table. I wanted to like them too. An ever changing menu with locally sourced fresh ingredients? How can you go wrong with that? On this Thursday morning, I ventured through the tenderloin to find out what this place was all about.

Alas, so many things about this place were not just not good, but noticeably disappointing that I most certainly will not be going back.

I'll start with the stuff that was only mildly disheartening. The menu is not really a menu at all. They offer a toast option, which is really just butter toast with some cream spread on it and fruit/nuts dumped on top. The other option is an egg sandwich. Aside from that all that they offer is some pastries and a salad or some vegetarian dish I can't recall. So we have a subpar menu with almost no options to start.

Next I will point out that there is all of one table for all of their customers to share in this tiny spot. And it's not like you're going to be getting take out when your meal consists of a carefully balanced fruit arrangement on your fancy $8 toast. Ok, whatever, I can deal with that and squeezed myself into a seat on the table being shared with four other parties.

I ordered the toast, because the other option is the egg sandwich and could see from the other people eating it that it was nothing special, basically just a soft boiled egg on a croissant. The toast was average at best. I saw them preparing it and it was literally something you might make for yourself at home with whatever ingredients you have lying around. 

The service though... I don't even know what to say. All that I ordered was the toast and it took them THIRTY MINUTES to bring it out. When I asked the server what was taking so long she nonchalantly said "oh right, I was supposed to make your toast huh?" So she pulled out one slice, smeared some cream on it and put the fruit and nuts on top. Why did she not do that thirty minutes earlier when I ordered from her? No idea. 

What a terribly run operation. Hopefully the owner realizes that like many of the other reviews state, their employees have a bad attitude and provide poor service. I will definitely not be going back and will recommend others to stay away as well.
author: Mark O.

description:
Fun location for a quick brunch. Be forewarned, this place is smaller than your living room so be prepared to huddle at the door in line. Seating is first come, first serve and very minimal (1 communal picnic table, 2-3 tables outside, and a small window counter)

// FOOD // The menu is sparse, but each item is made with love with local ingredients. 
     + Daily toast: Thick toast smeared with mascarpone and topped with fresh fruit and pistachios.
     + Egg sandwich: Soft boilied eggs with fresh greens in a flaky and buttery croissant
author: Pauline P.

description:
Sucks that there isn't a lot of seating here and it's so popular that when we went, it was quite crowded. The items we had:
- Savory tart: good, but nothing special. Basically a good 'ole quiche.
- Croissant sandwich: this item was good, but nothing to rave about.
- Mocha with almond milk: I enjoyed this, and really liked the chocolate they used.

Not sure if this is worth the trip and price.
author: Katherine L.

description: Well sorry to say, but this place was a bust. I am not overly picky, but they couldn't be bothered to put avocado on toast and then the fruit and nuts for vegan option, even though they had it. Then my simple cappichino , they didn't have non fat or 2%, just whole milk. To top off this experience, the milk was sour, so I couldn't drink it. Really not that remarkable, other places do so much better, plenty of options in this awesome city.
author: Judy H.

description:
Found this place next to my apartment and I am loving it. 
For a weekday morning around 9, the place was packed. Keep in mind though, the space is small if you want to sit inside and outside tables were all occupied. I had to change my order from dine in to to -go
Ordered a mocha with soy, egg ham toasted croissant and a cheese Danish. I must say that I absolutely loved the crunchiness of the bread and the taste of ham with egg. It complimented each other real well. Highly recommended!
author: Neil S.

description:
:( I was so excited to come here but my entire experience was so terrible. First, my order was forgotten; they gave us food to-go when we mentioned that we wanted to sit inside; and the worst part was that the manager(?) berated us for brining in a little chair we saw by the door. There is only a small table inside that can sit 9 people or so, and we squeezed in a seat without it affecting the doorway, but he got so upset and was extremely rude about it. He raised his voice and abrasively told me that I should not move the chair from other tables outside - which I didn't even do! I was seriously appalled by his behavior and perhaps that's what made the food taste worse. 

The daily toast is not that special and overly sweet. I'll probably never come here again in my life.
author: Juliana P.

description: I had a pug & honey latte, and a daily bread. I was floored by the taste of the bread. It was delicious and now I am sad that I don't live in San Francisco because I don't have access to this deliciousness everyday. The place was cute- a bit small, but some casual outdoor seating did the trick. I got my food and latte to go anyway. I will come back next time I'm in the City by the Bay!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
