Daily Toast: Served on fluffy bread topped  with sweetened mascarpone cheese, and the fruits were beautifully placed on the toast.

So if you're in the mood for something simple to start your day, and ready to cozy up in a coat in the SF cool breeze while you're in area, this would be the place to be.
author: Natalie W.

description: Warm, friendly and delicious! We had the daily toast and the egg croissant; I would go back in a heartbeat to order the toast again. Don't skip the coffee drinks either (the matcha green tea is so good).
author: Monica D.

description: This is a cute & TINY breakfast joint that serves some toast with beautifully arranged fruit (including fig, peach, strawberry, blackberry). The toast presentation is great. I had the toast & an egg croissant sandwich. There is only 1 table inside that is large & communal. There is also 1-2 two-person tables outside. There is also a parklet with some potential seating. This is not the place to go if you're trying to grab brunch with a group of 10 friends or something. They serve fresh juice & coffee as well. The kitchen space looked cramped as there were three workers struggling to not bump elbows in the small space. They get their food from local farms & their menu changes every now & then depending on what's in season.
author: Brenda L.

description: Food is divine.. It really is. My friend and I were being extra pigs in the morning and ordered all three items: tart, toast and eggs on a croissant. There are only 4 tables total for this spot. Three outside and one inside which is shared. So sad... Wish there was more seating so people don't have to wait for seats or look like homeless people eating on the dirty streets of downtown. Service is great, their iced coffee is very tasty. I like the very minimal items for this spot. Please farm table.. Make more space. Or maybe next time I'll bring my own mini table and chair :(.. U know the camping sized ones lol
author: Colette P.

description: Great breakfast!  Croissant egg and the daily toast are amazing.  Sat in the public park area just outside the place.
author: Alexis C.

description:
Nice place, comfy. Clean, nice food and decoration. Good place if you're around the area. But I came here because yelp recommended it as vegan friendly (my gf has dairy allergy). 
There isn't a specific menu for non dairy food. You just take the cheese out of the sandwiches. So, just a heads up for the non dairies out there.
author: Cristobal K.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for a while and it totally met my expectations. 
Portion size was perfect and they even topped off my coffee when I asked for a to-go cup on my way out! 
Lovely food, lovely people, lovely atmosphere.
author: Amy J.

description:
It gets 2 stars b/c the fruit on the bread was fresh. First, be aware it only seats about 15 people & the majority is outside. The pix of the bread w/ fruit looks beautiful but it's white bread (brioche, whatever) & the marscapone is a bit too sweet. Should've opted for the house cereal. :/
Service not the friendliest but that's pretty standard for SF.
author: Tricia J.

description:
The food is fantastic. I love simple food executed well. 4 things on the menu. The cereal, egg over croissant, toast with fresh fruit, and the quiche. The quiche was good but nothing stood out for me. 3.5 stars. The boiled eggs on croissant with dill was delicious. 5 stars. The cereal with home made almond milk. Had jam mixed in and gave it extra flavor. 4 stars. The toast with mascarpone cheese and fresh sliced fruit was also delicious. 5 stars. They have some pastries on the side. Muffin and croissant were quite good.

I tried the mocha and it was fantastic. 5 stars!! Smooth, chocolatey but not too sweet.

Only drawback is the lack of space. They have a small table inside that can seat ~8 people. One other small round table outside that can seat 3-4. Have some cute "green" space outside where you can also sit but the "seats" are not horizontal, all angulated so you can't sit straight. I don't mind that at all, but beware if you have kids. Very difficult place to eat with kids unless you get lucky and get a seat inside.
author: John L.

description: Overall this was an okay experience, but our group was underwhelmed. With so many fantastic restaurants in the area, this one didn't stand out as praise-worthy. Even putting the fact that the place is absolutely tiny aside, the food was just not that inspired or impressive. We stopped here for lunch on our last day in SF, and, sadly, we had more impressive dining options in the SF airport (which has amazing dining options, btw).
author: Alina B.

description:
This joint is probably one of the best breakfast/ brunch places I have been to. The portions are small and with tip expect to pay about 30$ for 2 croissants and two 8 oz juices. Now that I have mentioned the price and the portions, the food is quality and very delicious. The food is surprisingly filling knowing the portions looked small and they come packed with delicious flavor. 

The spot is pretty nice but it is very small. The place can get packed and might not find yourself sitting down:/ or you can wait/eat in the car/walk and eat/ eat in the bus/ bike ride it home... Lol  

Sum: 
Bomb food! $15 per person. Filling although small portions. Small spot. Might not have seating available. Worth the wait(;
author: Roxanne R.

description: The most extraordinary toast I've ever had. From the perfectly toasted bread, to the creamy mascarpone, to the fresh, sweet seasonal fruits, every bite is another trip to the 4th dimension of flavor for your tastebuds. Brunch will never be the same again now that I've lost my farm:table virginity. Pair it with an iced coffee for the full experience or add an egg-on croissant if you're feeling particularly hungry.
author: Ananya M.

description:
Food was delicious, but 2 stars for price and service. Took an out-of-town friend here because of all the hype and ordered the vegetarian quiche for my friend who cannot eat pork due to religion. The servers brought out a quiche that obviously had bacon in it and reassured us that it was vegetarian TWICE both times I asked. It turned out to be a bacon quiche the third time I forced them to look at it. 

I understand it's an honest mistake but a recommendation for better service would be to put it on the house and make it up to the customer whose religious observations you almost broke and who you did not believe for the first two times around.
author: Shelley C.

description: Although the options on the menu look like simple things to make at home, I feel like Farm Table's options are great for on-the-go breakfasts. The options are pretty limited but will fulfill whatever craving you have. The combinations on each toast, sandwich, or yogurt are quite unique and are like no other place. I do recommend farm table, go! Come hither!
author: Wendy T.

description: The wait was long for brunch on a rainy Sunday morning and I was hungry. The menu did not look appetizing and so I decided against waiting. However I bought a chocolate croissant and the coffee cake to tide me over till I reached my favorite breakfast place dolce amore. I was not impressed.
author: Sonica T.

description: I'm giving this place 3 stars only because one of the employees was very rude to the customers, almost military style. The place is very small so there's a communal table. He was moving people around, telling them to not use their laptops, not stand around by the door and just very moody. People actually got up and left. I will not come back here again because customer service is not their virtue.
author: Jazmin S.

description:
Had brunch here on Saturday. It's a very very very small place in SF. Not hard to find though..
I'm a big guy so I felt extremely claustrophobic inside... I ordered their Croissant sandwich with an egg in the middle. It was bomb. 5/5. I wish I ordered 3 of them though since the portion was on the small side. It didn't come with any sides. I think sides would have helped alot. 

I ordered some kind of cocochino or something.. It tasted very bad...... For some reason it had an ashy taste to it. I don't know if thats how it supposed to taste or not but I'd def never order it again. 

Their service is excellent. Even though its a small place, the food runners are polite when trying to get by you. They make sure you have everything you need and are overall very friendly. 

I'd definitely come here again if Im ever in SF. Ill probably try another drink to see if the other stuff is better.
author: Thomas N.

description:
Best breakfast ever.. I really wanted to come a second time before leaving the USA ! 
I recommend again and again !
author: Clara S.

description:
First time here from LA!


House Cereal: honestly this had yogurt and jam which was great and they added cereal and almonds which is great too BUT for $7.95 I think it can definitely be better . 7.95 is not a lot but for what I got LOL portion of ingredients were lacking. I think it said there would be coconut but did not find it. 


Loved that the yogurt was refreshing though ! 
My friends ordered the toast with fruit on top along with the egg on crossaint. They liked it a lot . 

This place is very small but it's a cute little spot for a quick snack :)

They have coffee and a variety of espresso and coffees as well.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
This place sucks on customer service .
Sucks on space . There's no room whatsoever.
(Only a table with 3 chairs ) 
Over priced * 
And overall weird ...
Why ? Because after you order from their small room/kitchen/cafe , you don't know if stand around waiting for a table inside and overcrowd the place even more or go outside and stare at the people using the only table outside, waiting for them to leave .
*2 stars for coffe . Good , but not good enough to have such a weird experience for breakfast in such a beautiful city
author: Marylin G.

description: Review long overdue. Visited from Chicago and still dreaming about their mascarpone toast over brioche. Fresh seasonal fruits and coffee. Can't beat that :)
author: Ela O.

description:
A cute little shop not too far away from Union Square and the perfect place to sit down for a light brunch/snack or a good o' cup of coffee, just fabulous! 

Looking at the pictures, I admit that I wasn't at all expecting this mom and pop joint but it was definitely a good thing. You can tell that the employees were either really close friends or family and there's just such a good vibe in the kitchen.
 
When I was indecisive of what to order, one of the gentlemen helped with the menu explanation and even suggested which drink pairing to order.

I ended up with the brioche berry toast with an iced honey milk and they were both delicious. The toast wasn't too oily and had just the right amount of crunch, cream spread, and berries on top. While the honey milk on the other side helped wash it all down pleasantly. It had a subtle hint of honey but just tasted really comforting. I am sure this drink would have been amazing hot as well!

Overall, loved the vibe and staff here but wish that there was a little more food selection such as breakfast sandwiches or hash browns/potatoe as sides. Definitely a cute place for great coffee and to hang out but I wouldn't come here to meet a friend for brunch or something. Just seemed a bit more of a coffee shop than brunch place.
author: Luby H.

description:
The sour tart was one of the best I have ever had. That, with the yogurt, I was full the right amount. 

The place is too small. But they have an outdoor seating which is actually cute.
author: Vikram A.

description:
Really unique, hip brunch/coffee spot that will definitely offer you a one-of-a-kind experience (communal ambiance, wholesome food) that may be hard, if not impossible, to replicate anywhere else.

Food - high quality, organic/wholesome stuff that's very delicious and nutritious tasting. They have a few egg-based dishes for brunch, in addition to a yogurt/granola bowl, and several other pastry items (pound cakes, croissants, etc.) that are dense and absolutely delicious. Nice selection of coffees and espresso drinks as well.

FYI: The only reason my rating isn't a 5 is because there's a limited selection of cooked brunch items (i.e. 3-5 plates?), which makes sense if the establishment is positioned as a coffee/dessert place, but not so much as a brunch spot.

Ambiance - interesting place: there's a single communal table indoors and it forces you to sit next to people you don't know, which is not all that bad (or good if zero conversation takes place), so it just depends on your preference.  Interior design evokes bucolic sentiment as the name of the restaurant suggests, and do note that there is outside seating if you prefer to not eat by the communal table.

Service - The employees are extremely nice and seem very passionate about what they do though, which is awesome! Otherwise service is just fine; nothing too remarkable to note vs. other restaurants in this style/price band (besides the effusive staff energy).
author: Amy G.

description:
1 star for the service, food was ok. Ordered a mocha, butter croissant n toast. Requested that the croissant be warmed up.

Coffee took 5 min, but food came out 20 min later, by which time coffee had already gone cold. The croissant was also cold, so I asked if they forgot to warm it up n the lady told me oh yes we did warm it up but it has been out waiting for the toast for 15 min. No apologies :(

Such awful service n lack of respect for customers. Who boasts that the food is cold since its been ready but sitting out for 15 min. Sorry u might be popular, but we won't be coming back.
author: Ken G.

description: If you like bird food portions for ridiculous prices this is the place for you. If you are a true coffee fan forget it too. You'll get scorched and bitter coffee. I ordered a tuna melt here for 8.50 and got soggy lettuce with no dressing or flavor and one piece of bread with one slice of tomato and some sub par tuna and a slice of cheese on top. Farm to table? More like Safeway to table. Actually the Safeway deli has better food than this (yep, very sad). Save yourself time and money and completely skip this place if you're considering having a nice breakfast in the city. This place is all hype and thoroughly disappointing.
author: Jini Y.

description: This was a neat experience. We ordered breakfast here I got a quiche and the egg sandwich. We sat at a community table in this tiny little place. I also got a chai matcha latte that was really good. If I went back I would definitely get the cereal and he fruit toast... those seemed to be the most popular and they looked delicious. The people here were also nice and after breakfast we ordered a sweet role which was the best I've had.
author: Jenna G.

description: Small place but a gem for solid clean food breakfast.  I had the homemade cereal (not too sweet which I liked) with jam and almond milk.  Also,  a really good soy latte.  I think it would be great if they could offer a few more vegan options.  The place is extremely small but I sat at the one table (community table) and enjoyed.
author: Amy Y.

description: Really nice place for breakfast. Best in SF. Thanks for the perfect service and kindness.
author: Bob B.

description:
When I was in San Francisco last, I made an intentional trip to Farm:Table before my flight out because sometimes you need just one human moment when you travel for a reason that is not VACATION.

As is true for most big cities, San Francisco has strong neighborhood identities. Farm:Table is in the Lower Nob Hill neighborhood, where Tenderloin meets Nob Hill. (They have a coffee called Tender Nob, which is a nickname for this particular part of this neighborhood and which I think is funny. They also have a coffee called Verve, which could have nothing to do with the neighborhood, but could awesomely be a reference to The Verve Pipe. Remember those guys? No? Ok, moving on.)

Oh gosh. This place is so, so tiny. When I stepped out of my car, I gasped. No kidding. This should be a definite expectation reset for many of you. If you are expecting to do brunch here with a group of six, you'll be disappointed. However, if you want to have a little moment for your self and one other person, that could maybe possibly sometimes work. There is one community table inside (implying: make friends!), a ledge (do I put my coffee there? Or my bag? Or...?), and a couple of small tables outside. Essentially, you are (1) grabbing food and going or (2) you are making new friends because you are sitting on top of these strangers while eating something crumbly or (3) you are about to passive aggressively battle to the end with people you have never met before because you all just want to eat your delightful breakfast food in a little of your own personal space. Don't you want to find out which group you fall into? I did, so I decided to stick around.

I placed my order with a kind of slightly frazzled woman, who seemed to care less about me and my order than whatever was on her screen. There weren't many people in line waiting to order, but she seemed flustered and the kitchen was busy, so I ordered multiple things out of something akin to stress-and-judgment-laden-creativity (that's a thing, right?) and headed outside.

The first thing I ordered that came out was an almond milk latte. They use HOUSEMADE almond milk, which is gritty and very almond-y compared to mass-produced almond milk- and they seem capital-P proud of it. I imagine some guy spends his Tuesdays soaking almonds and using cheesecloth made from Tibetan monks to strain this mindful and special almond milk the right way. Whatever the backstory, this was not expensive for a latte. Really, everything here is not expensive (all of the food items are under $8). Yes, there are a small number of offerings on the total menu, but what they do (excuse where this is so obviously going), they do well.

As I was enjoying my HOUSEMADE almond milk latte, I started to really take a look at the food that was coming to the communal table and the tiny tables outside and it looked awesome. Ridiculously awesome. It was at this point that I praised my excellent (if not stress-and-judgment-laden-creativity) in ordering multiple breakfasts just for me. I definitely have self-congratulatory moments throughout my day and this was a big time smirking-and-head-nodding one. Multiple orders is the WAY in some places. Multiple orders is not the same as second breakfast, which is more of a time reference; as in: you eat second breakfast later in the day (a 10-10:30am situation, if you will). Ordering a second breakfast at the same time as the first one is a different situation completely. It is actually pretty baller, if you think about it.

As I was HOUSEMADE-almond-milk-latte-toasting-my-own-greatness, my first food order came out: The (Holy) Daily Toast.

The Daily Toast is a sea salt foccacia topped with sweetened mascarpone cheese, seasonal fruit and pistachio nut meat. It is like the best fruit pizza you've ever had. The mascarpone is sweet and the focaccia is crunchy and the fruit design is like art. Spectacular.

The Daily Toast was so good and filling- and I needed to head to the airport- so I had my second order, the Egg on Croissant, wrapped to go. The Egg on Croissant is a hard cooked egg with ham and Havarti on a toasted croissant with greens and fruit. It is a flaky croissant that is somehow substantial enough to hold the ham and eggs. The crumbly eggs and the tree-trunk like ham make for the right balance of tastes. Even when I ate it cold an hour later at my gate, it was still incredibly good.

I could call Farm:Table a "little gem", a "hole-in-the-wall", or give you some extended metaphor highlighting that great things come in small packages, but instead, I'll say that this is a lovely red-paneled place that, in the morning, has the most beautiful light and I'll say that you should definitely order a few breakfasts here for yourself just because. Whether you find a seat or not, you'll enjoy it.
author: Erica G.

description:
Updated: the owner reached out and was accommodating, understanding, and professional. Because of this I updated my review from 1 star to 4. 

Original review:The food was good but not a lot of options. One "entree" each and a drink was $28. A little steep. But worse the seating. There's very limited seating and the pushier and sneaker you are the easier it is to actually sit. We were waiting for a shared table when some one got up. My husband and I (I am pregnant - but not that that really matters, just the point) go to sit dow when a man sitting there nearly done with his meal told us we were not able to sit there he's saving these seats. ummm for who? A minute or two later multiple people who he knew say down without even ordering yet. The management needs to figure out how to make this easier for patrons.
author: Melissa V.

description: We had a really bad experience here and would not recommend this place to anyone. We were here late morning on October the 13th. I asked for a cup of coffee, nothing special just a plain drip coffee. The guy taking our order says "we're out" and then proceeds to shake the coffee container and says " I might be able to get you a cup". Ok, no problem. It's strange to me that a place that claims to be a breakfast and coffee shop wouldn't offer to make more coffee. Later, I go outside to put some cream and sugar in my coffee and the cream was empty. The same guy walks by and I tell him and he replies and tells me to go inside there's more there. Why not just refill the creamer. So next in line my friend orders a cappuccino from this guy. She asks if they have any flavoring. He replies and says no they don't have that and if that's what she wants then she can  go to Starbucks. Wow, so rude! Next in line is my friend who has a slight accent but speaks 100% perfect english, has lived in this country for 20+ years. She asks for an Americano. He so rudely says he cant understand her and she repeats her order, she says its an espresso. He then proceeds to turn around and grab someone to "translate" for him. She was the most upset out of the 4 of us because he treated her like garbage. He was delivering everyones food, except for ours. He sent out other people to give us our food and they were laughing as they dropped off the food. It was a really awful experience. I can't believe people like this work in customer service. This guy clearly does not belong in a job that deals with people.
author: Alison K.

description: Very cute small breakfast spot. I had a great daily toast with mascarpone and house coffee! Only downside is very limited indoor seating, though the communal table is interesting and fun. I would absolutely go back.
author: Adriane B.

description: Its my favorite breakfast spot. Very small and cozy café where you can get amazing house made egg croissant and good espresso. The spade inside is limited but you can always try to find something outside.
author: Jessie P.

description: This place is legit !!! The most amazing breakfast creation the "daily toast". It's literally a micro hole in the wall with a couple of seats outside but totally worth the wait..
author: Maria P.

description: Omg ... Their daily toast is delicious! I didn't expect it to be anything special, but the mascarpone cheese, fruits, and toast complement well together
author: Michelle C.

description: Very good food! Had the toast of the day with gluten free bread. Very good without being sweet. Sister in law had the egg croissant which was also good. Also had the Nutella latte. Have to get there early because there is a line out the door before it's open. Very limited seating. Very polite staff.
author: Christina V.

description:
The food was ok but the coffee was a big disappointment. I went to the place because of the coffee and left extremely disappointed. 
We ordered 3 cafe lattes with almond milk. After getting the order the 3 of us thought it was something wrong with the machine. The coffee was watery and weak. We spoke to the guy and he said the issue was the almond milk not the coffee itself. This is impossible because I order almond milk lattes from other coffee shops every day and this never happened before. 
He gave us just black coffee and nothing changed. Awful taste and we all ended up throwing in the trash. If you know and like good coffee don't go there.
author: Maria G.

description: The egg croissant and fruit toast are on point!!!! Definitely the best breakfast I've had in a while
author: Harry L.

description:
The service is top notch. Super nice dude taking our order and even the poppyseed cake was delish. The mocha was bland and tasteless to the point of being almost watery. Im pretty sure the fault lies within the type of chocolate being used. 

5 stars alone for the amount of awesome dogs that breeze past you while you wait on the wooded wait station area.
author: Ella A.

description:
It was cute. I had a quiche Lorraine which was delicious but I was actually hoping there would be more on the menu. The small salad on the side was really good with the cute little fresh carrots. I also got the fruit juice which really wasn't worth it. 

The place was tiny with one communal table where I eavesdropped on a girl who had left the company I so happened to work for! How about awkward......... -_-  can't help it when there's only one table to sit at! Anyhow.

This place is adorable and has a good vibe and music but seriously. Why is it so small and why is there like nothing on their menu? What they do have is GOOD though. Like I just picked it from my garden, good. Just don't come here if you are feeling claustrophobic.
author: Esther S.

description: The daily toast, which featured (beautiful) fresh fruit and cinnamon-sweetened mascarpone was very good, though I recommend ordering extra cheese, as it veered toward dry. The latté was also delicious.
author: Nanucktucktuc K.

description: Wasn't that tasty. It was pretty good! But probably won't come back.  The restaurant was very small and crowded.  And a lot of food was pre-prepared (like the eggs), so you couldn't really ask for variations to orders.
author: Tara R.

description: Beautiful, colorful, fresh food that makes you feel good about your life choices. A tiny indoor space with one communal table that seats maybe 8 comfortably makes for an environment where everyone feels like friends - employees and customers alike. Coffee so dark and smooth that I had to buy a bag of beans.
author: Christie L.

description:
I got a huge surprise when I walked in. I was expecting a semi-typical, but small brunch restaurant, but what is really there is a community table with sparse outdoor seating. The inside of the resturant is about the size of the handicap bathroom (not including the open kitchen which is equally as small). 

Parking - Difficult, I hope you get lucky. 

Seating -  6-8 seats inside, two 2 seater tables outside, with the SF community benches along the sidewalk. Lets just hope it's not windy and cold when you're there. 

Service - speedy and friendly 

Bathroom - not for customers. Bummer because that means I can't wash my hands! 

I had the croissant sandwich with a hard boiled egg, prosciutto, some leafy greens, and white sauce - it was delicious! I did pluck out the egg yolk because I am just not a fan of yolks. 

The Daily toast had some vanilla spread and lots of fresh fruit (strawberries, raspberries, oranges) on top plus pistachios. I didn't think I would like it, but the choice of bread they used (I think focaccia) made the world of a difference. 

The house juice is fresh and you can definitely taste the grapefruit, so if you detest grapefruit, don't get it. 

I highly recommend coming to try just once. It's a cute dainty brunch stop before headed down to Union Square. 

What I don't like is the pressure to tip (while paying for the bill) before services arrives when you order.
author: Jess W.

description: Ummmmmmm! Waited a long time to get to the counter in this one-table, four-menu-item restaurant. I was super excited due to the reviews. When I got to the counter, the cook was scratching her face & handling EVERYBODY'S food. I left!!
author: Tonii T.

description:
TINY spot yet big on deliciousness and freshness. 

Do you ever feel like having a GOOD breakfast, that will leave you satisfied and happy yet spare you the "I feel short of breath, need to unbutton my jeans" sort of feeling  afterwards? This is that type of place. 

Make no mistake, chances are you will find yourself making a line because the place is obviously popular, but it is worth it. My fiance had the croissant (not your regular croissant, but a super-packed yummy version), and I had the toast with fruit, which was the most delicious, scrumptious toast with mascarpone and super duper fresh fruit such as berries of all sorts and figs. Then just when you think you can't go higher than that, have a sip of their gourmet coffee, or the OH SO GOOD milk with honey, and you will have a hard time coming back down... 

If you're in SanFo do yourself a favor and start your day here...
author: Rocio P.

description: I'm gonna say it. I don't understand the hype around this place. It was very, very... Okay. My coworkers and I came here on our lunch and did not expect the wait to be this intensely long. The place is literally the size of a shoe box. There's only one table inside (which fits about 8 people) and the front of the store is an open window that has a bar style standing area outside. There's also some futuristic seating area that is really cool but totally dysfunctional (especially for my 7-month pregnant coworker). I got the toast which was good, but not $7 good. It was a thick slice of bread with mascarpone and a bunch of fruit on top. I also got the juice that they make which was good, but not $7 for a 10oz cup. I probably won't be back, but I adore the whole concept of the place.
author: Kyle D.

description:
1. Ambiance/Location
2. Service
3. Value
4. Taste 
5. Perks/Extra

1. Such a good "locals" feeling. Total hole in the wall but close enough to walk from union square. There's 1 shared table inside and the coolest oddly shaped seating outside. OR if you want to be entertained and watch people try to eat, there are 2 or 3 regular outside tables. :) I pick the odd ones of course lol
2. Service was great! they were all so incredibly friendly! 
3. Its a little pricey BUT so is SF sooo pretty normal
4. TASTES AMAZING! There matcha latte with the daily toast (I had fruit and mascarpone) was to die for. 
5. I loved how this place just made me feel calm. AND its super fresh. Coming back for sure.
author: Denelle S.

description:
Meet the home of the sandwich that shut me up for a whole 15 minutes straight. 

Oh holy wow! I believe I ordered the breakfast croissant with ham and a hard-boiled egg. The croissant, the ingredients, the vegetables, the egg and most importantly, that sauce coalesced so well together, it simply encompassed my soul. I also ordered a glass of almond milk - homemade! And I usually call almond milk "almond water" but wow, it was almost like drinking real milk (I'm trying to do this no-dairy thing and personally I think it's kinda wickity wack cuz I LOVE milk...but this almond milk was THA BUSINESS!) 

My friends ordered some lattes and they looked like they enjoyed it immensely. There is also a community table and a "parklette" where you can eat on the sidewalk. It's a great place to go people watching. The owners are soooo super sweet and nice! I love how they are a family-owned business and truly care about their work, their food and their ingredients. I wish places like this were the norm and not the exception. I can truly say that this place embodies exceptional food...no doubt. 

In the words of my good friend, after she finished her meal, she said, "You HAVE to yelp about this place!" 

Cheers to a wonderful meal that I will be dreaming about. 

OH BEST PART! No crazy SF brunch lines! We just walked in, ate, and walked out! SO refreshing! Best kept secret :) I think I may have let it out ;)
author: Leena B.

description: Sooo small, 1 table to share for about 8 people max.  Small menu, which I like.  Food quality is excellent, but small portions for the price.
author: Heather V.

description: Amazing !!!! Toast of the day is to die for. I would have it every morning if I lived in the area. Egg sandwich was good and yogurt with homemade granola is good. Honey latte is awesome
author: Jacquelyn L.

description:
LIGHTEST FORKS IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!!!

Most light weight forks I have ever held. Seriously, if heavy fork after heavy fork has ruined your dining experience, this is the place to go. Be warned though, the daily toast is not served with a fork. You are, however, free to request one from the staff and they are usually pretty receptive to it. I've yet to find a lighter fork in San Francisco, you'd be crazy not to pick one up.
author: Meredith P.

description:
Cue what Monica T. said. While the service was good and the simple food straightforward and tasty, I found the place to be too TINY and the wait too be too long. I am pretty sure I waited over twenty minutes for 1. an iced coffee and 2. some toast with fruit. 

The communal ONE table in the place had an assortment of hip folks on each side -- a gal reading a book on a tablet, a canoodling couple (male with requisite hipster mustache), two single non-associated females, and a family of three which included a baby. Two small tables outdoors were occupied, but there were also two tall counter areas from which to eat (while standing...) and a miniature park (called a parklet) with which to somehow situate yourself to juggle your food and drink I suppose. If a place could be described as borderline tritely San Franciscan, it would be farm:table.

Anyhow, the daily toast had a nice mix of salty (from the bread) and sweet from the mascarpone and fruit. The sprinkled pistachio bits were a nice touch ($7). The iced coffee was delicious - not too sweet or creamy and strong ($4).

Good, if you called your takeout order in advance while starting your walk on over...from 4+ blocks away.
author: Jan P.

description:
As read in earlier reviews, this place is TINY (but adorable). The one, communal table inside seats 8? comfortably - so I might recommend that you expect a sweet, little coffee shop instead. 

We loved it, having ordered two of the three menu options and a slice of Banana Walnut Bread (thick and in no need of butter - read: moist and delicious). The Asparagus Frittata was light and creamy - though I wouldn't say filling enough on its own.  The Ham, Egg, and Cheese Croissant, however, was perfect in every way. It was my first experience with a hard-boiled IN a sandwich and it was divine. Simple and lovely. 

Go.
author: Emily Y.

description: Great coffee and food. Limited space necessitates a limited menu (5 items) and pastries, but quality is fresh and homemade. Be prepared to get cozy with strangers if you want to sit.
author: Mila C.

description: Almond Milk with honey and spices ... A delightful comfort treat to start the day !! Staff very friendly and willing to help you.
author: Emilie S.

description: The place is pretty small but as long as you can sit down right when you get your food, you're golden. The daily toast is a must. Along with a cappuccino. I'll be back here probly like 20 times before I leave!
author: Juliana R.

description: TINY (in a way) - not much seating so you have to grab & go or quickly claim a table (or two - dependent on your "party" size). Very limited seating inside though there are a few tables + chairs outside. The food... Very FRESH! And, tasty as well! Though the portions are a bit small, and the prices are on the high side. Neat place to check out if you happen to be in the area, have time (consider waiting), and with a small "party" of people...
author: Pina U.

description:
First morning waking up in San Fran and my boyfriend and I decided to yelp breakfast places in the area. We are staying at the Ritz so this place was only about a 10 minute walk. 

We walked in and were pretty disappointed that there was only one communal table in this itty bitty place. I think there were two two tops outside but it was raining so that wouldn't work. My boyfriend and I were almost out the door but decided to order coffee to go. I ordered a chai latte and he got a mocha. His mocha was good and my chai latte was alright- it had a little bit more spice than I like. 

While we were waiting for our coffee a couple got up from the table opening up some space to sit. After we saw the food that some customers were eating we decided to just order and eat anyway and I am SO glad we did! 

I ordered the croissant sandwich which came with hard boiled egg, prosciutto, Creme fraiche and baby arugula. It was just perfect. The combination worked. My boyfriend and I shared and I really could have gone for another. We also ordered mushroom and zucchini frittata. WOW. Was not expecting that! The aioli it came with was just delicious. I asked for an extra side that I slapped on my croissant also. (Hehe). Both items were light but filled us up. I didn't have a heavy full feeling. I was thoroughly satisfied with all elements of the food. 

I know that the setting of the place is what makes this place and works for others but would be nice if there was more room. Since it's a quick bite I guess it really doesn't matter that you share a table. Overall I would definitely recommend and would absolutely go back.
author: Ida A.

description:
Great find. 

This is a perfect spot for a quick breakfast and coffee. The espresso is spot on.

Nothing fussy about the place. Just nice people helping folks start their day. 

They do what they do very well.
author: Christopher H.

description: This place is the best. Don't go anywhere else for a fresh breakfast on weekends. The only problem is that the place is very small and there's a rather long line, but once you order your food everything is fast and the taste is totally worth the wait. Their daily toast is like no other... Literally! Also try their homemade almond milk.
author: Kiana B.

description:
I had the toast and some milk and honey, all delicious! Unfortunately the portions are tiny, even on other "standard" dishes that my coworkers got. The daily toast is literally one piece of bread, which doesn't really suffice as a full meal (and I'm a pretty small person who usually only eats half of most dishes).

The place is tiny with one very small community table, so don't expect to sit and eat here. I would love to give it more stars, but the portions and the space are just not there
author: M M.

description: I almost never give five stars but this was awesome. I liked everything I ever ate and drank at this place. Nice bread, yummy coffee, small and cozy. Been here many times. Good for lunch or breakfast or any time really. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jen N.

description: Omg you can taste the freshness, love and attention their products are crafted with here. I say crafted because my egg croissant and iced coffee (highly recommended) were so flavorful yet light. My boyfriend got a mocha and the fruit cereal (also delicious)It's a tiny establishment with a line out the door, now I know why!
author: Jean V.

description:
Fantastic fresh food and coffee. Small shop so it isn't suitable for large groups (they only have one large table inside which is usually occupied, then 2 small tables outside). 

Small menu, think there were a total of 4 food options and then an array of coffee choices. I am guessing these are constantly changing and updating. I had the egg croissant and a iced latte. Perfect start to the day.

Coffee - 5* - good quality, cheap, well made
Sando - 4* - exceedingly expensive for what you get but very tasty. Quality over quantity (or 400% profit). 
Shop 4.5* - nice friendly staff, chilled music, great atmosphere.
author: Greg R.

description:
I like the theme of farm to table, but I kind of think the ingredients could have been higher quality if they wanted. Went for breakfast, had the toast and the savory tart, also a coffee. Managed to get a seat, so that works out better than you might guess.

Essentially this is food made for instagram, and I love that.
author: Chris B.

description:
Better than good. I wanted to love this place but it feels like the formulaic San Francisco/Berkeley/Portland farm-to-table-locavore-organic-bacon and creme fraiche on everything-hippy dippy...and arugula. There's always arugula. Anyhow, I just feel like places where I can buy a 7 dollar toast and a 4 dollar iced coffee are all over the City nowadays. Just once I want a place to surprise me with fresh ingredients that aren't "in" (you know, kale and such) and have me not spend over 5 bucks for a glorified snack. 

I got the egg sandwich with bacon (of course), arugula (yup) and creme fraiche (duh) on focaccia. Hard boiled egg was perfectly cooked. A bit small for the price.

I also had the milk and honey drink w/ cardamon which was very good and comforting. Service was fine. Space inside was really hot/stuffy and crowded with the communal table. I sat outside which was really nice. They have a parklette too which has some extra seating. 

Not sure if I'll be back. It's just OK but something was lacking-didn't feel welcoming or of the neighborhood somehow.
author: Semuteh F.

description: I came to farm:table twice while staying in the city. The atmosphere and food make for a great Instagram picture. I ordered a cafe mocha and the daily toast. The coffee was delicious and the daily toast was adorned with a colorful fruit spread that made my morning. The place is cramped and they only have one communal table. I sat there with my mom and we talked to people who were visiting from around the world. It was a great way to start my day.
author: Sarah B.

description: This tiny little spot was quite delightful! The pastry, morning toast and lattes were yummy. This is a great place to spend time with a friend. I would not recommend it for groups or children due to the space limitations.
author: Reshawn L.

description:
Had my breakfast here a couple days ago, I had the daily toast. And it was Ok good. 
The shop is very very small, only one table in the middle. 

I think this place is a bit overrated. It's not that good as what I expected.
author: Jie C.

description: Great local place for breakfast/brunch. The food is fresh and delicious. It's more light dishes rather than hearty meals. I got the daily toast and it was BOMB. It looks large but I recommend you don't share it. The place is super small so don't come here with a group unless you get food to go. Waited a while for food and the service was ok. The house juice is good but not worth $3. It comes in a small paper cup! I still recommend coming here if you're in town.
author: Julianne H.

description:
The food and drinks deserve 5 stars. The daily toast is worth buying once a day. 

The service is a 1 star. All the men are very rude.
author: Gabrielle H.

description: Found this place while on a trip to SF. Had the breakfast sandwich and latte. Sure the place is small but we found a spot on the shared table. Perfect for the SF experience.
author: Marc A.

description: Yummy! I particularly love the toast! So scrumptious! Eat at the parklet if u get the chance :)
author: Tony R.

description: We are here for breakfast, as it was close-ish to our hotel at Union Square. The location is incredibly tiny, and the menu is only 4 or 5 items total. There was no room at the only table in the restaurant, and as we sat outside, we were harassed by a homeless person begging for food and money. I had the egg croissant sandwich, which was great. Although their space is limited- it would have been nice to have a few more options to choose from.
author: Teresa O.

description:
Be warned, this place is tiny.  There is literally one table inside for customers to share. Very cramped and stuffy.  There are two small two-seater tables directly outside.  Most of the customers were ordering to go.

I got the croissant egg sandwich which was quite good.  The toast looked amazing, but it looked more like dessert than breakfast.  If you're craving a sweet treat, go for it!  

Worth a try if you're in area, and reasonably priced. All that being said, I will probably not return because I prefer to be able to sit down and relax for brunch rather than grab and go.
author: Alex M.

description: The coffee was delicious and so was the breakfast. Very small location. Like in many San Francisco restaurants, not a lot of seating, so you might have to stand. Prices were reasonable, and the customer service was great. They were very friendly.
author: Lyn S.

description: Loved loved loved this place. Perfect for all my hungry boys. They had large portions and huge pancakes. The wait wasn't to long and the staff was fast and super friendly.
author: Aidee S.

description:
farm:table.... faddish name, but what a great casual breakfast spot! My husband and I stopped by around 8:30am on a Sunday, and I thought it'd be empty. Everyone must be at home snuggled up in their beds, dreaming of their impending hangovers. But when we got there, most of the seats were filled, and we snagged the last 2-person outdoor table.

Husband got the frittata, and I went for the sandwich du jour. Their menu changes daily, but it's all pretty approachable, so roll the dice and stop by (or check their twitter). My sandwich was composed of a warmed piece of baguette, arugula, prosciutto, goat cheese, and pesto crème fraîche. It was nicely balanced, and I loved the spunky herbs in the crème fraîche. The sandwich was garnished with one darling little strawberry. My husband's frittata was individually baked, which was a nice touch. He also can attest to the good quality coffee (these guys used to work for Blue Bottle).
author: Meghan A.

description: Yummers! Really awesome food and the workers are super friendly. They definitely made my experience in San Fransisco all the worth while!
author: Fiona W.

description: One of the simplest things I've ever had for breakfast but one of the best whenever I am in SF I'll be stopping by for a quick visit to try something new.
author: Olivia G.

description: I was in San Francisco around Christmas and was looking for something different for breakfast! We stayed in Union square so this was about 20 min walk. What I found was the most amazing experience! I am still thinking about it! I had the green tea matcha latte and the daily toast! The Daily toast had fruit and crushed pistachio, Both were amazing! Can't wait to go back!
author: Josie K.

description: Great breakfast place. We ordered cappuccinos and the croissant with egg, which came toasted with poached eggs, ham and greens. The croissants were really amazing and the coffee was delicious. Some cons: tiny space with barely any sitting, don't get the juice, it tasted like from concentrate. The quiche looked very good and there's also a brioche toast with mascarpone and fresh fruit that looked amazing. Guy sitting next to me ordered and loved it. Would definitely come back if hungry for brekkie and pressed for time.
author: Carolina R.

description:
A wonderful little place to have breakfast. And by little I mean little. They have only one table inside, just one, plus a few outside. But this adds to the experience. The staff is there to take care of you and serve the best food possible. 

I got a frittata, which had broccoli, ham, onions - it was fresh out if the oven and was delicious. I also got their standard latte which they served in a glass and was very good. 

The menu is not huge but it well thought out. They also offer pastries. My friend got banana bread and loved it. Highly recommend this place.
author: Nate M.

description: Amazing food! Don't be discouraged by Farm:Table's limited menu. I'd suggest the Daily Toast and juice. So bomb!
author: Angela D.

description: Very small little place with limited seating.  Got their daily toast and a savory tart.  Both yummy, but the proportions were small and just not too noteworthy.
author: Lily N.

description: Super cute little crack in the wall. It's not the kind of place Togo sit and eat bc there's literally maybe 8 seats so I found that out the hard way. The breakfast sandwich was amazing tho. Just get it Togo!
author: Jami M.

description:
$4 for a smallest piece of shit iced coffee, but it was damn good. Sometimes it's just quality over quantity. 

I've had their egg and cheese croissant and their fritatta. Fritatta was kind of dry, but the croissant sandwich was delicious. Guess it's a hit or miss? Food is good, but I would come here more for their coffee.
author: Michelle C.

description: The daily toast is HUGE and fresh and yummy. The little outdoor area is fun to look at but I wish they had more usable seating.
author: Sera B.

description: I would have really loved this place if they had more seating. I really loved their cereal and house made almond milk. I have to say that was probably some of the most delicious breakfast cereal I've had. The staff was upbeat and really nice, so you can tell they enjoy what they do, and that was extremely important to me as I had just driven 8 hours from san diego and this was my first meal since being behind the wheel. Loved the atmosphere, very trendy.
author: Ahryana H.

description: This place was delicious, fresh, and inexpensive. Be a social person if you plan to stay, because there is one table in the place that seats about 10. We met people from all over when we stopped here for breakfast on an August morning. The Daily Toast (Huge brioche slice, with mascarpone chees and piles of fresh fruit and walnuts) was everything. Service was fantastic. I got a croissant, coffee, and the toast for about $14. Croissant was flaky and buttery. Coffee was warm and inviting. Just steps from our hostel. Eat here, you won't regret it. :)
author: Kelsey V.

description:
Area residents are lucky to have a coffee shop like this one. The sidewalk outdoor seating is very cute. http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/TXeL7CAylCjz0tsnuUktgg/l.jpg

The coffee drinks ($2.50-$5) choices are listed on the blackboard above the counter. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/neHLWGaZf0Y01t2-eMJ_OQ/l.jpg While the food menu is handwritten on the left column blackboard, next to the register. Most people order to go, but u can also sit at the communal table inside. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lIuSwYUYqz6jLW4D_swT1w/l.jpg

I got a special: half creamy asparagus soup, half sandwich (pickled radishes and black pig bacon) and little gem lettuce salad for $12. http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SM4qCgL5IIyQyMg5y8wDhw/l.jpg I enjoyed every delicious bite. It was a fantastic little brunch.

Drawbacks: limited street parking in this area, Cash only.
author: Luis C.

description:
In the heart of sustainability, farm:table is such a (literal) cute little spot. I stopped in after seeing the Daily Toast on Instagram and knew I had to try it. So glad I decided to go for it and also grab a loaf of banana bread and a sweet roll - both of which were delicious. The Daily Toast is a bit sweeter than I expected, but amazing nonetheless. The banana bread was super moist and would pair great with their coffee if I was grabbing something on the go in the morning. 

Don't expect a seat if you are headed there at peak breakfast/brunch hours, however. If you do snag a spot it is really wonderful. Go go go!
author: Taylor F.

description: Such a cute little place with great simple food. We had the egg on croissant and breakfast toast and they were both perfect.
author: Mandy R.

description:
I loved everything here, but the limited seats. I took one star out because of that. Other than that, they have wonderful food, friendly service and lovely ambiance. They open very early too, which is totally awesome. Very affordable breakfast and drinks. It was very nice having some Egg on Croissant and matcha drink while people watching around.
Loved. It.

p/s: sharing a table inside with other people is kinda fun too. I'd like to do it again.
author: Phuong P.

description:
Definitely recommend for the food and friendly staff!

Came to farm:table early on a saturday morning after an endless night of no sleep (jetlag). Their milk and honey was soothing to my upset stomach and their egg on croissant was delicious! 

The place is cute and the staff is super friendly. Just keep in mind that it is really small with only one table inside and a few outside. It was raining today and I live only one block away so I just took my breakfast to go, which was perfect for me.

I'll be back!
author: Rianne O.

description:
My cousin Vanessa D. loves to support sustainable local spots like farm:table so I suggested it for breakfast while we were up in SF.  We weren't looking for something heavy so we stopped here since it was nearby the hotel.  Little did I know, the menu is very limited and the place is tiny.  There's a communal space inside that consists of one table with benches all around.  It seats about 6-8 people max.  The place is a quarter of the size of a regular coffee shop and unbearably hot inside.  

We opted to eat outside just to cool off from the warm interior.  I ordered the wheat toast with mascarpone, apples, and caramel.  The toast was more like slices of wheat sourdough, chewy in texture.  The mascarpone was perfectly flavored with maple and the apples were a lovely touch.  The caramel was a failure.  I expected gooey but was met with hard candy.  I didn't like the caramel at all.  Overall, it was good and healthy.  

I also ordered a decaf latte.  They were unable to make me an iced decaf latte.  Judging from the size of the kitchen, the chef had to deal with, I don't blame her.  I'm glad I ordered the hot latte instead because after a few minutes of sitting outdoors, it became chilly again and having something warm to drink was most welcome.  The coffee seemed to be made with a French press and there were a few grounds at the bottom of my cup, not so much that it was gross, but enough to make note of.  They had raw sugar available and their food is made with fresh locally derived ingredients, hence the name farm:table.  They also offer almond milk as a substitute if you're lactose-intolerant.  I love the concept of the place, but wish there was a more extensive menu and seating area.  With the healthy options and the eco/sustainable mantra, farm:table is a neighborhood favorite.  CASH ONLY.
author: Trina D.

description:
I had a cup of capuccino this afternoon. It tasted great and not expensive. The coffee was hot, but not so hot that it's going to burn your mouth, yay. Not so bitter or too acidic, just right and suits my taste well.

It is a good place for a coffee to go, but since the place is small, it's not really good for dine in (when crowded).

I would definitely come back and recommend this coffee shop.
author: Bianca N.

description: Yum!!!! House Cereal with yogurt and berries was soooo good. Also loved the Chai Matte Latte!
author: Marisa P.

description: I haven't been there for breakfast, but for lunch with iced coffee, this was a little meh for me. Not a ton of options, and though the salad I got was decent and straightforward, it didn't knock my socks off. Iced coffee was a little bitter even with cream and sugar.
author: Jake V.

description: A very cute, cozy place with nice outdoor seating. We had breakfast here today and enjoyed some delicious food, the daily toast and the egg on croissant. Both meals were delicious and looked very appetizing! We're definitely coming here again!
author: Raphael B.

description:
I had the everyday toast with a latte and my boyfriend had the egg croissant with a mocha. Both were amazing!! The fruit on my toast was so fresh...just perfect! And the latte was by far the best I've had in San Francisco!! The place is small inside. But it's cozy. And the staff is very friendly. We'll be back!!

My only regret is that I didn't get an iced latte to go!!
author: Janell G.

description: This place is really small and has a community table.  It's not for everyone but I love it!  The dishes are small portions but large in quality.  Changing menu makes it interesting and sustainable.  Great place to stop for a bite or a cup of joe on your way to downtown for shopping.
author: Naty D.

description:
A definite favorite: whenever I want to treat myself I come here for their delicious toast with seasonal fruit, tasty baked goods and interesting coffee combinations. I do not eat meat, but my boyfriend does and he is a fan of their savory options.

farm:table typically has very friendly staff, and is communal table with some outside seating available (and I do mean seating).

Sidenote: if you prefer HUGE American breakfast this place is probably not for you, farm table focuses more on the quality and seasonal ingredients.
author: Diana B.

description: Crowded, cramped space and DELICIOUS!!! The Breakfast Toast was one of the best things I have ever eaten, slathered with honeyed mascarpone and covered with beautiful seasonal fruits. Kudos to the staff for doing what they do in this little space without totally losing their  minds- and BOOS to any customers who fail to understand and empathize because they can't sit down immediately or fail to understand the menu or style of service: they need to get over themselves or go somewhere that will not challenge their comfort zone!
author: Lynn R.

description: Love this place I wish I can eat there every day! Fresh fruit was the best. I had egg croissant it was super good. The menu is simple but the food was beyond amazing! Def worth checking out
author: Aide L.

description:
I got the toast of the day and the braised pork with a soft boiled egg. The toast was a brioche with a smear of mascarpone and "dark caramel sauce" topped with apples and pomegranates. The sauce didn't taste nor looked all that caramel-y, but it had nice flavor to it. The pork was tender, but the best part was the rapini (had to look it up, it's some sort of green of the mustard family).

I'm a little conflicted about the place. The food was good, but they charge way too much for the portion size and the service was basically nonexistent. I can pay around the same amount and get similar quality of food at a nice sit down place. I admire what they do -- simple food and concept with quality ingredients, but it's simply not worth it. Even in San Francisco, spending $35-40 on brunch and still walk out of the place not completely full just doesn't cut it.
author: Alice W.

description:
Farm:table is a little hole in the wall shop in the heart of san francisco. The shop is very cozy with not much room for seating on the inside. They do have a neat architectural sitting area right out front of their shop.

Their daily toast is awesome! MUST GET! We also ordered their croissant sandwich which is delicious--perfect amount of savory to go with their fruity toast.

The quiche was meh. Don't get. nothing special.
author: Claire G.

description: so good......egg on croissant was fantastic, everything is so fresh tasting! the place is a little on the small side but it's super cute and the food is incredible!
author: Emily S.

description:
This place is just over-the-top adorable. It's so tiny,  there is only one table there. The table will accommodate 6 people, maybe 8 if you squeeze. Great place to start a conversation with a complete stranger sitting next to you!

The people behind the counter are also super adorable hipsters. They sound absolutely passionate about their coffee and their food. For me I had a little teapot of green tea. The teapot will yield 3 cups, so the $4 you pay for it is really not too much.

I would definitely recommend it and I will go back myself to try their food.
author: Valentine A.

description:
I don't know what everyone is saying about the great service but every employee that worked here was atrociously rude to my friend and I the day we went. We were given dirty looks when we were looking at the menu and the girl asked us when we were going to order in a rude tone. When my daily toast came, it didn't come with the pistachios on top. I asked about it and the girl replied in a sassy manner: "Yeah, I'm chopping them up right now. Or do you want them whole?" No, I do not want them whole but I expected them to be already on the toast and not to come out 5 minutes later and have to sprinkle them on myself. My toast wasn't even toast; it was a baguette sliced in half. Definitely not what I expected and the food wasn't even good to warrant this kind of service. 

Funny thing, we were taking a picture on the steps and they kicked us off but then they reposted our photo on their instagram. Guess they're not so high and mighty either. Do it for the 'gram huh?
author: Michelle H.

description: Quaint and cute. There's nice seating outside so you can enjoy the city. The menu is small but everything is delicious. We had the croissant, breakfast toast and a lavender latte
author: Amanda M.

description:
This place is so cute! We walked in and expected to see a rather large restaurant based on their reviews and comments, but it is just a quaint little seating area and kitchen in the rear. I guess since we aren't from here, we aren't iaedMake sure to get here early or you will be fighting for seats! 

My fiancé and I ordered the daily toast and chai lattes. They were so good I don't ever want another breakfast again. All their food is fresh and sourced straight from the farm. What more you ask for?
author: Austin F.

description:
Communal and quaint done right. Really enjoyed our quick brunch at this rustic little shop. 

Menu is creative and the coffee is some of the best I've had. Today's fruit toast and iced coffee was light but filling enough to hold me over till early evening. 

Considering it is San Francisco, they do attract a unique bunch. If you aren't up for sharing the newspaper and your personal space with a Sheldon (BBT) type then see if you can snatch up one of the few tables located outside.
author: Julia C.

description:
This place is bomb, 5 stars hands down. The breakfast sandwich bread is to die, and the egg is perfectly poached. Perfectly. Every. Time. 
And the morning toast.. You haven't had it until you've had it here. I didn't even know what that meant, and I love toast; but this is toast on another level. On our way there again now.. Cheers to the 1000th review.
author: Bryan P.

description:
Truly, the food is quite delicious. But for fucks sake, why did it take 30 minutes just to get an egg croissant and the daily toast?? There wasn't even anyone in line when I got there, which was shortly after they opened (~8AM). 

Don't come when you're actually hungry. Service is not prompt and they're in no hurry to get your food out to you. Quality is undeniably good, price is tolerable for the quality, but nothing justifies the long wait. Nothing is even made there - there's no cooking involved! Just assembled and warmed.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: This place is super tiny inside with only one community table and a few tables on the sidewalk. However, it's definitely worth going here as the food was amazing! We had the daily toast and the egg on croissant. Both equally delicious and fresh. Feel good about eating this healthy breakfast to start off your day in SF!!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Great spot, super small but definitely in a good way! 
Stopped in for a quick breakfast and was very pleased.  I ordered the cereal, mostly because it was gluten free and the light meal I was looking for. An absolutely beautiful dish was served, which I enjoyed at the lovely table with a couple of other diners.
author: Yasemin K.

description: The restaurant is tiny, there are a few seats inside and a few tables outside, dont expect a table for 2 at this spot. The food was high quality, farm to table (hence the name:)) and you could tell they cared about what they prepared you. Its a sweet little spot for a quick bite.
author: Savannah R.

description:
CASH ONLY.  I was on the hunt to get Kouign Amann if it killed me.  They don't answer their phone which is really annoying, so I had to walk over there & just pray they had it Sun morning.  I took Bart to Civic Center & walked up Leavensworth which is a scary street in the daytime too.

Got to the tiny shop after turning Right on Post St, it's on the Left-hand side.

Saw they had Poached Pear Filled Kouign Amann $5 CASH ONLY!  Damn, didn't want to pay that much for a small pastry but I've come so far I was getting it.

I was only gonna eat a few bites & save it for later, but it was really tasty.  Still got some caramelized sugar on the bottom, flaky, barely noticed the pear.  I liked it fine.  Kouign Amann is from Starter Bakery in Oakland, not made there.

Got some flavored water FREE - on the Right side of the Cashier.

Some seating inside & outside.

Hrs:
M-F 7:30-3p
Sat 8-3p
Sun 9-3p
author: Ann L.

description: Hyped up hipster coffee shop. Run Down, coffee was blah, felt like the servers were all stoned, but the breakfast yogurt cereal bowl was awesome, and the egg croissant was delicious.
author: Ethel F.

description:
This place is tiny, like closet tiny, and somehow there are 4 people working here. 
Walk in, order from the grumpy register guy. Shuffle from side to side as you wait for your tea but other people are trying to order. 
Sit down, wait an above average amount of time for was essentially a croissant with 5 toppings. 
The flavors were good at least but I wouldn't return.
author: Steffen G.

description:
Very good food! I ordered the toast of the day and it was amazing. Place is small and price is not cheap, but my bf who doesn't usually like brunch (he says most of the brunch places serve food that he can easily make, which is true) loved the food. I take that as a huge compliment. 

It has one communal table inside for 8 people which is fun. And the rest is outdoors seating. There's a very cute parklet outside. Great experience. I'm happy I'm close by.
author: Wendy K.

description: There's a reason you always see lines out the door. Good coffee and pastries. Their daily toast is where it's at. Thick cut of toast with marscapone, fresh fruit, and pistachio. My only wish is that they accepted pickup orders ahead of time.
author: Raj S.

description: Lovely spot in the Lower Nob neighborhood. Great food complemented by friendly service. The place is very small, they only have one large table inside, but they have a cool seating outside. The place is very popular, so be prepared to wait a bit.
author: Artem G.

description: Cozy little shop with luxurious options like homemade almond milk and Yerba Matte Chai. Super friendly staff and seems to be a local favorite. They do have gluten free options as well as dairy free options but they are not vegan. The savory tart was superb.
author: Nora T.

description:
This is a cute little hole in the wall!

I ordered the egg on croissant and it was DELICIOUS. They toasted the croissant after I ordered it and omgosh it was so crispy and flaky when I bit into it....so yummy. It came with a boiled egg, cut in half....and it had cheese and ham as well.

But guys, don't get tricked! The croissant looks WAY bigger in the yelp pictures. It's the smallest croissant ever ): I was still pretty hungry afterwards. For breakfast, I think it's fine. For lunch? Good luck not chewing your hand off after. I had to go for pho afterwards.

Two of my friends tried the Daily Toast and it had a bunch of different sliced fruits on it...looked really colorful! There is also a sweetened cheese spread beneath the fruits. My friends seemed to like it and thought it was pretty good! 

Two of my other friends tried the Savory Tart but were not impressed at all. It basically felt like eating a giant quiche or basically just steamed egg with crust underneath it and some cauliflower mixed in. There's some pieces of lettuce on the side for their "salad" that had an olive oil based dressing. I don't think it's worth it at all...

Note: There is only one table at farm:table so keep that in mind! It is a really small place, so you don't plan on eating there since you probably won't get a table. The people there are really nice though!
author: Kelly T.

description: Really nice place for breakfast! The Daily Toast is highly recommended! Fresh fruits on a toasted bred with very tasty mascarpone! Unfortunately there is not much space.
author: Johannes S.

description: This restaurant literally changed my life. Eating the daily toast is a truly spiritual experience. The savory tart is the most amazing quiche you will ever eat. The breakfast sandwich will make you cry. The chocochino is a truly out of body experience. Eat this and live forever at peace.
author: Adam S.

description:
I saw all the pictures of the daily toast on Yelp and decided I had to give this place a try. When I got there and saw that the toast was seven dollars,  I was worried that it wouldn't be filling enough for a whole breakfast but I feel like it did a pretty solid job. I maybe wish I had gotten a little more food, but boy was it delicious. The one on menu that day was a sea salt foccacia with assorted fruit (orange, strawberry, apple, & grapes) on top of a mascarpone spread! The balance of sweet and salty, soft and crunchy was absolute perfection! My boyfriend got a mushroom tart of some kind, also good but not as memorable as the toast. 

My only complaint is the lack of seating. Be prepared to sit on tiny weirdly shappen benches.
author: Ashley R.

description:
Venue - SMALL. There is only one small table for communal seating. Otherwise, there are sidewalk benches outside.

Food - Very simple. Too simple for the price tag. An egg croissant, nothing special, for $7? Not worth it. Also, for a small place that only really serves 3 items, our food took forever to get to our table (about 20 minutes). 

Overall - Sure, the place is cute and the concept is nice, but you're really just buying into the hype.
author: Katrina L.

description: Really tasty espresso and really fresh house made almond milk. Tough spot for me but when I'm around will always consider a macchiato!
author: Bree G.

description: In regards to my last review, I would like to acknowledge that the owner reached out to me to encourage we go back and that our experience wasn't typical. Great customer service, we will go back to give it another try.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Great place for a quick breakfast or lunch in the TL. As we walked in, we were greeted by a nice hostess and asked us if we had been there before. She then went over the menu quickly for us and welcomed us to Farm Table. There is only one small table for about 6-8 people inside and some seating outside so if you come here, be prepared to take your food to go.

The almond and honey drink was amazing. Yeah $3 for a small cup (smaller than a "tall" at SBucks) but the quality of the drink cannot even be compared with anything available at SBucks. So milky, perfectly sweetened, was just the perfect drink to start off my morning. 


We tried two items- meatloaf sandwich and beef and butternut squash stew. At first we looked at the food and was a bit skeptical but it was love at first bite. Beef stew perfectly flavored, butternut squash and brown rice paired perfectly in the dish. Only thing is it was a bit salty (or maybe a lot salty) but I took it home, diluted the stew that didn't have much liquid in it by the time I got home with some hot water, reheated and had the perfect stew. The meatloaf looked a bit dry and unassuming but was actually really flavorful and went great with the baguette and cheese. 

I would definitely come to farm:table again if I'm ever in the TL area!
author: Gloria C.

description: Street kitchen. Food is not fresh. Had tuna sandwich - did not like it at all. Coffee was good. Would not go again.
author: Dima S.

description:
Hole in the wall! This place is fresh and you feel good after you eat here. Chai latte! Not too sweet not to strong, perfect blend. 

Defiantly coming back!
author: Mar A.

description: I think this place is more about aesthetic than taste. Love the decor and overall rustic charm of the restaurant. Our food looked beautiful but lacked a bit of flavor in my opinion.
author: Tara J.

description: Delicious food! Be warned though, there is not much seating and my fruit toast took quite a while, hence the 4 stars rather than 5. Once it did arrive, though, it was delicious! Our entire party enjoyed their respective food.
author: A A.

description: This place was so good we went back the very next day! Tried the lavender latte (was awesome flavor even though I ended up with lavender leaves in my mouth),  chocochino (amazing) and pug and honey latte (also awesome). Ate the daily toast twice (holy crap! Wow), croissant sandwich and tart with fennel, bacon and broccoli. So good!
author: Emily L.

description: Very unorganized place. Food is ok and for nine bucks u only get fruits on a piece of toast really. Line is always long and the place has a startup vibe for a brunch place. Items sell out at 10am.... I mean, really...? "Famous" matcha chai latte is no match to boba guys which is a couple of blocks away. Overall not bad but not worth it at all.
author: Monnikka M.

description:
Thank you SF Yelpers for leading me here!  I based my decision to come here soley on the star rating so I wasn't prepared for the postage stamp size of it or the 4 item menu....but luckily we were there early enough to grab a seat and their daily menu items were right up my alley.
I truly enjoyed my daily toast and latte.  My snobby friend was with me and he ordered the daily fritatta and a latte as well.  We shared the sole table with some New Yorkers but it never felt crowded or intrusive.  
I have to admit that my delight with this place may be more about the novelty of it, because I can imagine that it can get crowded or you may come here and not find a place to sit, and that would really suck.  But most of the people that arrived after us seemed to find places to place their treats and carry on.  But be warned that you will either have to give up your personal space or order to-go.
author: Lisette C.

description: This place is super cute! Instagram worthy. How do I know? Well, besides my own two eyes, a group of tourists were taking photos with their selfie sticks, iPhones, AND GoPros. My boyfriend and I stopped in and got tuna melts and a toast of the day.  Both were great. The staff was super friendly. Normally my experience with hipster employees at trendy places is that they're all assholes. Not the case here. Everyone was really welcoming, and the food is bomb. Can't beat it.
author: Renee R.

description:
Is like to eat breakfast here everyday. Fresh food. The milk and honey is great. 

Small spot but I think that is part of it being a cool location.
author: Ross H.

description: Extremely good cappuccino and croissant -- hit the spot at 7am. Friendly staff, too.
author: Richard S.

description: My favorite placeee ever. Daily Toast W/ Honey, Ginger, Mascarpone, Berries & Pistachios and an Almond Milk Latte always makes me happy.
author: Debra T.

description:
You know how some people describe a place being the size of a postage stamp? farm:table is actually the size of half a postage stamp. So tiny that you might have to go outside to change your mind. Ok, enough of the corny jokes.

The food is fresh and delicious. Good coffee. Warm, caring service. Just expect to share the one table with others if you want to eat in. There are a couple of tables  and a unique parklet just outside the door. 

Definitely not a place for vegans. Lots of very fresh dairy.
author: Delaine Z.

description: This place is a must go to if you're ever in the city. It's a small place, but the food is delicious! My bf got the egg on croissant and I got the fruit one. Both of them were delicious! We'll be back here again whenever we go to the city! :D
author: Lisa D.

description:
Farm:Table is exactly what you want it to be. Simple, fair priced, and damn good food. I couldn't keep my eyes off the menu for the morning as I wanted a little bit of everything. So what did I do? A little bit of this and a little bit of that. It felt like Mambo Number 5.

Grab a table and pull up a chair to share communal food with friends or strangers.
author: Kevin J.

description: Iced coffee was bitter, not in a good way. Tarte was cold. Pricey at $12. Service was good though.
author: Noah D.

description: This place is SO tiny but everything is so delicious! Definitely my favorite breakfast spot in SF.
author: Clelia R.

description: The toast of the day was on point. Very filling and had a variety of different fruit on it. The place is very small so it might be smart to take it to go if you're not lucky enough to find a seat.
author: Sandra S.

description: Delicious food but way over crowded for my taste. Even when taking food to go, I felt like I was in the way and the staff seemed stressed.
author: Emily J.

description: Egg sandwich lovers stop here! I had high hopes for an $8 sandwich... They were completely satisfied
author: Reuben K.

description: This place is incredible! Amazing food that's really well priced, coffee is delicious, and the service was impeccable. Friendly, fresh, and good.
author: Adam D.

description:
Very good food. I had the egg croissant sandwich. Was flames. 

Inside they only have 1 large table that everyone sits at together. Pretty neat. 

Also had a latte with honey. Very delicious. 

Overall it's a very strong yes for travelers and locals. Nothing crazy filling but very good.
author: Everett B.

description: This is an awesome breakfast joint.  You may want to get it go or squat on the street because seating is limited.  But don't let that stop you there too many great things to eat to here.
author: Grey H.

description: Delicious, everything on the menu great choice except the cereal don't get the cereal!
author: Vanessa N.

description:
I saw pictures of chicken salad sandwiches here, except when I asked about it, the cashier said "We never had them." So I went with the pulled pork, thinking that it would come in a sandwich form. It came in a bowl. And it was supposed to come with beans but since they ran out, they replaced it with beets (the bowl was literally drowned in beets/beat juice).

Their daily toast was sweet potato cream, oranges and almonds (Saturday), which was interesting. I saw pictures of others that looked better. Warm milk + honey was good, but when isn't it?

Also, this place is very small. Like, very small.
author: Christine C.

description: Small, welcoming place. As soon as I entered, they offered me coffee or tea as I pondered the menu... My entree was unique, creative and beautifully presented. I ordered the pulled pork with savory rice pudding and a poached egg. Everything was phenomenal individually and even more taste bud blowing when combined. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Scott P.

description: Coffee and food are good not great but better than most of the grab and go options close by
author: Amanda Y.

description: They got the name right: very limited seating. Service is really slow. I would have liked to taste more of the menu items. What kind of coffee shop has NO decaf! Disappointed!
author: K T.
