description: I went Farm:table a Sunday for brunch, crazy line, no place to sit, the cafe is really small therefore you have people stepping in and out while you are in line to order. Of course, I waited some time for my food to be ready. I asked to dine in and got my food to go. It's all worth it though since the daily toasts($7.95 + tax) are delicious.
author: Karla A.

description: If I could I would give this place zero stars. My friend suggested this place for breakfast before we left the city, so we thought we'd give it a try. The food was poorly put together paired with terrible customer service. 2 of the 3 workers we encountered had terrible attitudes which made for an extremely unpleasant experience on our last day in SF. This restaurant prides themselves on being environmentally friendly and wants to make a change in the world but they should first start by changing their attitude towards their customers. This was all surprising as this place has good reviews on Yelp.
author: Shiva S.

description: Had an issue. Wrote an unflattering review. Was contacted by owner via Yelp messaging about the issue. Feel much better about it now.
author: J S.

description: Great environment and outstanding food! I'll definitely visit again the next time I visit SF!
author: Christina C.

description: Sipping on a cappuccino outside while waiting for a croissant breakfast sandwich. This is place is tiny with very limited seating but worth the wait and if you don't mind posting up on a curb somewhere, you are good. And the coffee was great!
author: Kristi R.

description: Don't get me wrong, the food was fine, but I think that for the price, this place is a little over-hyped. Most of the items on the menu I feel like I can make at home for myself for way cheaper... The staff there was very nice though, despite having such a long line of customers. We waited around 30 minutes total for our food, including waiting in line to order. So I have to give it 3 stars for the good service and OK food, but I won't be coming back because I felt it was nothing special and over-priced.
author: Emily H.

description: Obscure breakfast for my pallet but absolutely delicious.  I've only been in SF for a few days and let's just say, I'm a repeat offender. Make sure you add avocado to the breakfast sandwich.
author: Tucker F.

description: Rad little spot! Really fresh food, amazing bread and creative. Seating is minimal, so need to be patient and realistic. Coffee is great, especially with some steamed almond milk!!
author: Robert G.

description:
In the mood for a quick, delicious breakfast? This spot is for you! Great, albeit limited, selection of yummy breakfast toasts and other tasty treats.

Everyday Toast - mascarpone spread topped with an assortment of fresh berries, delicious!
Egg Croissant Sandwich - I'm a sucker for ham and cheese on a croissant, this did not disappoint. 

Only downside is that it was super difficult to find a place to eat. There's one tiny table inside and a funky seating area outside, but if you cant snag either you're out of luck.
author: Mimi B.

description:
Love this sweet little place! This place is so tiny, with indoor seating for probably 6 people (tight squeeze around the table), and I think 2 small tables. The orders do come out quickly so perhaps grab your goodies to-go. I was lucky to snag a spot when folks were leaving, so yay! 

I ordered the honey milk, quiche, and daily toast. The milk was wonderful, warm, and comforting to sip on while I waited for my food. Quiche was nothing to write home about. Daily toast was EVERYTHING. I loved it. What a delicious combination of fresh fruits, wonderful marscapone spread, and on a toasty crunchy bread. I would definitely come back for that daily toast.
author: Mary N.

description: Love this place! Everything is so fresh! And looks so appetizing, from their artisanal coffees and chai to their cereal bowls and seasonal fruit toasts. Great place for a mid day snack, or a morning breakfast! They have limited siting space, but always had interesting conversations when I got a chance to sit their communal table. I highly recommend this place.
author: Yasmine B.

description: A cute little restaurant with a big wooden table to eat at :)  Delicious local coffee with a menu that changes every day!  When you walk in to farm:table, you feel like you've stepped into someone's home.  The people there are very friendly and are happy to explain the menu or shoot the breeze.  I do think farm:table is a bit on the pricey side, though, so I probably won't be back *too* often...perhaps only when I'm showing a friend around SF.
author: Brittany N.

description:
I ate tarte & sweet toast.
Both were delicious.
i have to go again to try another menu!
author: Kayoko K.

description: Such a nice and quaint spot. We ordered the tuna melt and a milk and honey latte. Absolutely the best! Will definitely be back every time I visit SF.
author: Adriana M.

description: Small space, but tasty food! We enjoyed our breakfast toast and lattes here this morning
author: Kristine B.

description: So glad I decided to have brunch outside the hostel today. Went across the street to this small spot. The coffee was delicious and fresh, and I had the cereal bowl. All the ingredients were fresh, delicious, and locally organic! Next time I'm in San Fran I will be back. I just wish there was more seating outside :(
author: Andrea S.

description: Another yelp discovery. At first glance you wouldn't think this place could be so good. It's a tiny tiny space in the front of a building in downtown and doesn't look like much although the decor is homey and the staff friendly. The menu is limited, but EXCELLENTLY executed. I had the egg sandwich and was blown away. Super simple ingredients, but it all tasted super fresh and the flavors really popped. The coffee was excellent as well. I sat at the community table (there is only one table in the actual shop) and dug the vibe. This is a place to go when you have a morning to just take it easy and relax.
author: Alex M.

description: Amazing breakfast food...  Great flavor in each items we ate...  Try the egg on croissant but ask for frittata bread instead omg!!!
author: Julian F.

description:
I have been to this place for a few years, it has been a weekend tradition for morning breakfast sandwich and coffee. For the first and last time I will visit farm table.

I placed my order and 30 minutes later, no one realized that they were making my order. I got up once, then the workers mentioned it will be out in a few minutes. I got up twice, then they asked that my order was. The third time I got up, they mentioned that they lost my ticket. 

It was not busy when I was there at 2 pm. Then I was quite upset as this was 40 minutes and 6 customers later that they served. Their attitude to me was, you could wait or have some money back. RIDICULOUS, they made a mistake and made me feel like it was my fault. Their attitude was "I lost your ticket, so what". For being in the service industry, this was not a great way to treat customers. 

My next thought was, it took 40 minutes, and my sandwiches were still not made, should I wait another 30 minutes? NO WAY! They are in the service industry and are not even polite to their customers.

My conclusion of this place is lack of service, lack of empathy for customers, and very slow service.
author: Richard H.

description: Love this little spot! Great workers and I loved the latte. Tried the cinnamon raisin roll - dry on the outside but when I got a couple layers in it was the right yummy texture. Service was quick and although I took it to go, the community table seems like a great place to hang with friends or read a book.
author: Hilary R.

description: The place is somewhat cozy and cute, although the space can definitely be bigger for a busy city like SF. I feel like the largest group can be a size of three, anything bigger will make it really awkward and clumsy. We ordered the cereal bowl and the croissant sandwich. Neither of them was special at all especially for the price. On top of it, we had to clean up the table from the last round and the round before that, since nobody was collecting the dirty dishes. Not going back again, not recommended.
author: Wanqi C.

description: Farm:Table is simple and perfect.  This Resturant has one table and three employees.  They are a drink spot,  the matcha chia was great.  The food gets me every time.  So simple fresh and delicious.
author: Rich S.

description:
first off, thank you farm table!
I am not from San Francisco and I was walking by and a was immediately attracted to the coziness of your place. 
The coffee was great with the home made almond milk, blew my boring Miami girl mind!! 
Then the food, um ok how about the best breakfast I could think of on a cold morning. It was great all 3 days in a row that I went. Everything is fresh,the menu changes everyday and some things are a little unexpected like the lintels with a poached egg on top, at first I was like um lentils for breakfast and then I decided well if they are serving it then it must be good and boy were they right it was delicious and quite filling! 
Now whenever friends say they are going to Sf I say please go it farm table it's a small place that deserves all the support it can get from locals and tourist who enjoy something special!!
author: Nicole P.

description: Calling all Aussies in search of great coffee.  Order a strong flat white and prepare to be happy!!
author: Tim L.

description:
Small shop with little seating(maybe 5 max can sit inside) but if you're walking by, it's the perfect spot to grab a coffee and breakfast.

The coffee on brew is RoastCo and they brew it well. Was delicious!

I had the egg croissant which is phenomenal.  I want to say the best I've ever had in life...I guess at $8 each it should be.  It was!  their pastries also looked really really good!

The service was also very friendly and accommodating.  I came back an hour later to pick up two coffees and two croissants for my friends.  The kitchen must have been overwhelmed because it took a good 20 minutes to get our food.  Besides that, it was a great experience.

Bottom Line - Enjoy it!
author: Food L.

description: Excellent coffee.....the menu is small and perfect..... A great place to stop in the morning and get a great cup of coffee.  A couple of outdoor seats and a table inside with a couple of benches. Leave a big group at home.  I had an egg on croissant and it was awesome.  All ingredients tasted fresh, the croissant was crispy and light.  Perfect quick breakfast spot in San Francisco.
author: Chris H.

description: Ingenoius little spot near the Clift hotel where we usually stay. This place always have simple but innovative breakfasts. No place to sit aside from 2 small tables but I love their almond latte (they actually make their own almond milk) it's the best I've had so far. Everything it's super fresh! I don't mind even queuing for 10 min to get a taste of their food! Love it! Wish there is one in LA
author: Francis A.

description: Food was at best McDonald's quality, but prices WOW. you can get a dinner somewhere else for the price of breakfast here.
author: Tomcio P.

description: The Daily Toast was phenomenal, as was the coffee. Few places to sit, but that shouldn't deter you. Fantastic place to grab a quick and delicious breakfast.
author: Rosemary P.

description:
We stumbled upon farm:table after heading to Dottie's and seeing a humongous line.  We were starving and needed nourishment, so trusty ol' yelp pointed us to farm:table.  Four stars can't be bad right?

Well, the food wasn't bad, I really just think it is way over-priced.  I have no problem with the one table, stand outside and eat concept.  I appreciate the use of local, organic ingredients, but really, after eating what we had, I couldnt justify dishing out $26 for the experience.

We had:
1.  Hard boiled egg Brioche with a tomato and herbed marscapone:  There was really nothing wrong with it, but if the highlight for a $6.75, tiny sandwich served on a tea cup plate was the yummy seasoned tomato, then that is not cool.  The brioche was ok, nothing earth shattering.  It took me 3 bites to eat this.  
2.  Arugula, goat cheese, roasted root veggies (added bacon):  With the addition of bacon, this cost $13.  No way in hell will I ever pay $13 again for a tiny dish of roasted roots and some arugula with drizzles of goat cheese.  Again, the dish wasn't bad, but no way does it justify a $13 price tag.  

The tea pot we shared was good.

Overall, I probably will not come back here, just because the the prices do not justify what you get.  I left hungry and feeling ripped off.  For that price, give us more! GIVE US MORE!

My pictures show you how tiny the portion is...look at the serving size relative to the fork and knife! Crazy!
author: Raymund S.

description: Terrible service! Just dropped into this place...Went into the shop at 7:32 (they officially open at 7:30) and they guys were rude and told me to come back after five minutes. Ridic!
author: Imran A.

description: Great little place.  No real seating, so plan to take out unless you are lucky.  I had tomato, spinach tart, which was delicious.  Coffee drinks were good, and they had some nice tea choices.
author: Karen S.

description:
I first Yelped this place and saw rave reviews and the yummy-looking pics. I also thought I have heard of the place mentioned somewhere (TV or article?) for serving fresh, organic food so we definitely wanted to try it. When my husband I first got there we were disappounted with how SMALL the place was. There is only 1 table inside and the rest is outdoor. This would have been okay during a beautiful, sunny day...but on a cold, windy and rainy day and the table inside was already full it was annoying. 

However, we were there and decided to try it out anyway and I am SOOOOO glad we did!!! The salted caramel foccacia bread with the fruits and honey spread (?)) was THE BOMB! The egg, bacon sanwhich with whatever else was just as good. Our taste buds were exploding and loving every bite. 

We also ordered the cafe mocha and I would say coffee is not their strongest point, but their blend of juices were good. 

In short, I woukd come back rain or shine. Prepare to find a place to sit down and eat elsewhere (we ate in our car) on a cold/rainy day. Otherwise, sunny days would be Delightful!
author: Maureen D.

description:
Great little place. Cozy and really good. House cereal is delicious with homemade yogurt, jam and muesli. I'm told the egg on croissant was excellent, too. Hot chocolate was creamy delicious. As was the matchla chai latte.
We'll be back it was a great way to kick off the day.
author: Jim R.

description:
The daily toast is amazing. It tastes very fresh. It's one of the best breakfast items I've ever had. I would probably be a regular if I lived in San Fran. 

The place is small, but very cute. I went on a Tuesday morning. It was not packed, but there was a steady flow of people.
author: Evelyn R.

description: Very high quality breakfast! Amazing granola and loved the, at first sight weird, egg on croissant. Crowded, but still cosy and somehow it seemed everyone found a seat to enjoy their breakfast. Disappointing the oat meal was out already at 9 when we arrived, but was happy with the granola. Good coffee.
author: Jo R.

description: Well, we got here before reaching 3 km to get for a breakfast at 7.35AM but it was closed - even it says "open" on yelp no opportunity to make a proper review of the food.
author: Denn S.

description:
Very limited but delicious menu!  Seriously, there are like 5 items total that you can order.  The menu is reflective of the size of this establishment as well.  There is one table inside and various seating around a parklette outside.  This is not for a brunch event.  This is for a fun & different breakfast stop on the way to another activity.  The food is great, but portions are conservative so don't expect a big entree platter here.  Were talking one quiche wedge or one croissant sandwich with no real substantial sides (sorry strawberry salad, you are delicious but not sustaining).  

All in all, you can feel the sense of love for the establishment in the employees.  It lives up to the name; the food feels like it is sourced from really quality ingredients.  Its a lot of flavor that comes out of that tiny efficient space.
author: Christine E.

description: Good food and relax environment! Like daily toast, fresh fruit and healthy. Favory tart is also healthy. The room is small only one table in it, but the environment is warm. I like it.
author: Dora L.

description: It's wonderful to have a pretty displayed fruit toast and a cup of coffee to start the morning. The place is small with very limited seating. Better expect some wait before getting a seat. There's also seatings out side on the streets (about 4-5seats) and some extra table at the window for people to stand there for a quick bite.
author: 智婕

description: Very very friendly cafe. The food was great. I love the eggs on croissant. There's a little hint of sweetness coming from the creme fraiche.  I personally would have liked my eggs a little more runny and not as thoroughly cooked. The coffee was from Roast Co. Can't make up my mind if I like it or hate it. It's Ethiopian so I was already expecting the bright notes. There was a little hint of bitterish sweet after taste which I didn't quite like. Nice little place to chill which is very busy. A single communal table within and some space on the pavement/sidewalk to stand/sit about.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
I'd like to be able to review this cafe, but both times that I was there, I couldn't seem to get past the extreme attitude that the employees seem to have (whether they mean to or not). The employees I have encountered there-guy in his 20s with that sort of trendy beard that screams "I am trying to be world-conscious but still want to be hip", and a girl (and I mean girl, not lady) who threw attitude my way at 7:30 in the morning-are snobs. They act like they think they are working at some hip, uber-Parisian cafe, and funny thing is that the baristas at the cafes in Paris I have encounterred are way more polite and customer-friendly that these two! 

The first time I was there, I walked in and the bearded guy said with attitude that they were still closed. Cool. No problem. But two things: 1. you might want to keep the door shut to let people know that you're still closed, and 2. you might at least pretend to be a little friendly, given that I am the customer and you are the worker-yep you ARE the worker.

The second time I was there, there were maybe two other customers sitting at the community table, and three people working behind the counter. I went up to try and order a latte, and the uptight lady told me (yes TOLD me, but with a slight attitude) "it will be a few minutes"...umm....there's hardly anyone here and there are three people behind the counter! If it's an issue of timing-that they are still opening up, then you may want to come in EARLIER so you can start the opening process EARLIER.

Other times I have walked past the place, I would look as I am walking past, and the employees seem to not have much experience working in a cafe establishment in a big city-they seem to be moving soooooo slowwwwww...OMG. Seriously!!! They all seem to just be hanging out. If I am on my way to work in the morning, I am realizing that I wouldn't want to go in there for coffee because it's really not a place to get coffee in the morning on my way to work unless I have 2 hours to spend just hanging out before work!

The over-all beef I have is the attitude. STOP with the attitude and just be nice to everyone!

Wish I could say how delicious the food and coffees are but I can't seem to get there!
author: Julien N.

description:
This place might be hyped up. I don't know. I wasn't that impressed. Be warned! This place is tiny tiny tiny! I wouldn't recommend coming in a large group. My boyfriend and I were look for some breakfast on a whim. And scanning through yelp, my boyfriend decieded he wanted to try Farm: Table. I like the concept of this place. They have a very short and simple menu: a french toast, a breaksandwich, granola/cereal, baked goods, and coffee. My boyfriend and I went up and both ordered the breakfast sandwich which was a croissant with greens, cheese, hardboiled egg, and ham and tomato. I got mine without ham. We were able to snatch a table. When were waiting for my food, my boyfriend went in to check our order and turns out they had messed up on our order. They only put in one sandwich not two. I was right next to my boyfriend when he ordered and I heard him order it correctly. How did they mess up such an easy order? I have no idea..but he went back into re-order his sandwich and one of the servers barked at him to get in the back of the line...uh wth? you messed up on our order and now we have to wait another 10 minutes in line in the tiny cramped place for you to fix it? All bad. Two thumbs down. By the time, my boyfriend got his sandwich (with a quick apology thank goodness! from one of the waiters), mine was cold and sad. I wasn't even that impressed by the sandwich. Crossisant wasn't warm, cheese wasn't melted, eggs were over cooked. Meh. Not my cup of tea. The only thing I can say was good was the coffee. We ordered a  cap with the meal and it was actually really really good. The perfect temperature and real creamy. 

Nevertheless. I would not come back here.
author: Sam L.

description: First time in SF & read about the toast.  They were out of focaccia so it was subbed with ciabatta so I passed.  I'll be back next time to give it another go.  I ordered the quiche instead & it was great.  It's a tiny spot with a communal table & more casual seating outside.  Round 2 with toast & a latte in my near future.
author: Lisa S.

description: Hip small breakfast bar with attitude. Food and coffee are good.
author: Yow-Bang W.

description:
Great place to have a wonderful breakfast. The home-made cereal made my wife happy and my eggs on croissant were amazing.
Coffee was good, but it can be improved
If you want tons of food, this is not the place for you. It's not cheap either.
author: Marcelo C.

description: 4 stars for being a friendly, quaint, and healthful restaurant. It's tiny with 1 communal table inside and 2 tables outside. Breakfast menu is small but fresh and really delicious. I had the frittata which was delicious and it came with greens. Hubs had the daily toast which was loaded with fresh fruit! It was delicious. All of our food was. I had the chai latte with almond milk that also included matcha tea, so yum! All in all we enjoyed our breakfast and the friendly service.
author: Claudia K.

description:
Phenomenal healthy breakfast in the city.  Seriously, it's the best way to start out some shopping or sight seeing while visiting.  It's a tiny (one large table inside and 2 tiny ones outside), cozy establishment with the kindest, most down to earth people working there.  I've had 2 amazing breakfasts and I can't wait for more.  On one visit I had their daily toast (with mascarpone, fruit, and honey) and another time I had the cereal (yogurt, cherries, and granola-ish cereal).  And order a pot of tea with your breakfast to heat you up on a chilly SF morning!  

So satisfying, yet so light and simple.  Upon leaving you'll question why you don't eat like this every morning.  I'd be a heck of a lot healthier if I did, plus I'd have more energy.  

I'd like to try their lunch too.  They close after lunch.      

Follow them on twitter (farmtable) and watch their menu change daily.  It's fun!  

You should go and experience it for yourself, TODAY!
author: Sheryce S.

description: The best toast I have ever had in my life. Hands down. Wish they had more seating area - but would go back again in a heartbeat for that toast. Yum yum yum.
author: T. M.

description: I love this place. Sometimes, on a busy weekday morning when there's no conceivable way in hell I'd be able to stop by for a hot breakfast, I wake up to visions of a poached egg on polenta and cheese dish I once ate here. This place is teeny-tiny but I've always been lucky enough to grab a seat and enjoy my meal. Their croissant sandwiches exceed this croissantaholic's expectations. I wish I didn't have to work (or wish I lived closer) so I could dine here more often. Eat here. You know you want to.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
1) Perfect steamed milk bubbles. 
2) An excellent mix of soft and crunchy for the Koulgh Amann. 
3) A sweet-tart fresh juice blend that makes your mouth tingle with joy.
author: Ibanga U.

description:
Solid 4 stars!  I was working from home and had to run down to FedEx for something.  On the way home, I decided to pick up a quick lunch from farm:table as I've been wanting to try it anyway. 

I picked up a yummy braised chicken sandwich - flavorful, tender chicken, loooooved it!!  Also had a salad with strawberries, cheese and balsamic dressing - very fresh, great balance to the chicken sandwich.  An iced coffee that hit the spot and kept me awake all afternoon as I worked away.  Plus a peach muffin to save for breakfast for the next day - enjoyed this!  

I would definitely come back!  What a quaint, cozy little place to get yourself a healthy meal and do your body some good - looooooved it!!  :)
author: Maile N.

description: Long line went really fast. Egg croissant was pretty good, but lemon coconut pastry was delicious! Coffee latte was both beautiful and delicious!
author: Joni P.

description: To be honest, I am not sure what's good about this place. Seats are outside on the kind of steep slope, small fragile tables, self service. No coffee refills, super small food portions with very limited options. Overall a big disappointment for a tourist. There might be something good about it which I am missing or just don't get it but I must confess all the good reviews and a high rating on yelp was very misleading. This was the first and last time I'm having food at this place.
author: Behzad K.

description:
Love, love, love this place. Very french, very local. Perfect place to saunter into. Great fresh juices. The breads melt in your mouth.

Once we went in there and sat alongside a gentleman who was reading his paper and he clearly looked annoyed that we have crashed his party table(there is only one big table). But then loyalty, he thought, came with some perks. I would be annoyed too!
author: Rahul V.

description:
**CUTE AND COZY LUNCH IN SAN FRANCISCO - LET'S CUDDLE**

There were people waiting for tables on a Sunday early afternoon.

One communal table inside.

Two patio tables outside.

Yes, extra cozy.

ORDERED:

*SHREDDED SHOULDER PORK with POACHED EGG ($9.50) 
Delicious. Homey. Flavorful. I could eat more of this. Loved the poached egg.

*FRENCH PRESSED COFFEE ($4)
Dark chocolate flavor. It wasn't strong and I wanted it to be.

We sat outside.

It was chilly.

Staff was attentive, even though it took 15+ minutes for our lunch foods to come out, they came out and apologized.

We bussed our own table.

You need patience and CASH ONLY.

RECOMMEND.
author: Betty N.

description: Their coffee is pretty good. My wife said the egg on Brioche was ok. It would be nice to see at least one vegan option on the menu. Their toast is vegetarian and not vegan (in case you are wondering). I had to ask and sub in some other items to make my breakfast vegan. They do have avocado to put on your toast which is a plus.
author: Jason S.

description:
It's the simple things done well that make life special. The two poached eggs nestled in the middle of a flakey toasted croissant with a little ham, sharp cheese and arugula - this is what makes life lovely. 

True hole in the wall - bypass the limited number of tables inside and sit on the street furniture directly outside where you can sniff the fresh mint and try to recall a world not full of big city buildings and traffic.
author: Paul D.

description: Tried their daily toast and savoury tart. One word, amazing! Especially liked the daily toast with its sweetened mascarpone cheese and fresh fruit. I like a lighter breakfast, so this was perfect for me. This restaurant is good for smaller groups and nice weather days, as there's not much room to sit.
author: Sam S.

description:
Get ready to be friendly with your neighbours in this very cozy place with a small communal table (or snag a spot outside). We arrived around 9am and were famished. Be warned that the menu is small (only 4-5 things written on the board) and the portions are on the small side so you'll need to order more than one thing unless you just want a snack. We had the hard boiled egg, dill on brioche and the beans with slivers of pork and egg. Both were cooked very well, but I just wanted more....of something. More ambiance, more seating, more food options, just more.

While I liked my meal at Farm:table, I wasn't wowed and thought it was a bit pricey for what it was.
author: Colene C.

description: The food and service here was good.  I especially liked that they had 1 common table.  Everyone was talking to each other and it was warm and welcoming.  I will be coming here more often.
author: Roberto L.

description:
Very small place with 5 menu items. But don't be scared: lack of options means that what they sell is pretty darn good. We had a ciabatta egg sandwich and the savory tart, coffee and a honey milk, and a muffin. We loved the place and since we live around the corner, we will def be back. 

But I think you have to be lucky to get a seat.. so come prepared to either eat and walk, or take-out, or sit on the little public park area right in front. But if you're lucky, it is pretty cozy inside on the communal table.
author: Miriam L.

description:
OVERALL PROS:
- What an adorable spot! My friend was happy to go here for lunch and leave the corporate feel of financial district by going just a few blocks away. She said "I feel so Californian" and I felt the same: local ingredients, a simple and healthy menu, and relaxed looking diners (mostly in the hipster/ biker crowd). You share a large wooden table inside with other diners, or can people watch on the tables along the sidewalk.
- We got a nice sampler with a half salad, soup, and sandwich for $12 thanks to a BlackBoardEats deal.
- The people working there were super friendly. They brought each of our dishes out to us. And my friend left her wallet on the seat and the girl behind the counter ran after us down half a block to give it back.
- The ingredients were SO fresh. Like literally just pulled out of the ground.
- MUST HAVES: Green garlic soup!

OVERALL CONS:
- I wish there was just maybe one more option for sandwiches and soups so we could get a little more variety. Now I have to come back to try a different sandwich!

THE FOOD:

* Mixed baby greens w/ baby carrots radish balsamic vinaigrette - The dressing on this was well balanced and light. However there was too much arugula which made it a little too bitter. There were too few carrots/radish, though everything was incredibly fresh. My friend liked the salad overall, I'm just not a fan of too much arugula.

* Green garlic soup - This was so great! Immensely tasty flavor, not overpowering. I took one sip and immediately perked up, amazed that a simple garlic soup good taste so good.

* Feta chive egg salad sandwich on pan de mie - The bread was buttery & slightly hard, yet filling and delicious. I liked the concept of this sandwich but I couldn't taste the feta as it was overpowered by mayo in egg salad. It came with this cute little radish on the side that was delicious (I never knew I liked radish!).
author: Ziyan C.

description: Not too many choices for food but the ones that are offered are good. I ordered crossant with ham and boiled eggs and it was delicious (how can you spoil it anyway). their coffee is good too. But the place is too tiny and hard to move around and sit inside without people constantly bumping into you. They have a few chairs outside but outside area is not cozy and not pleasant to have your breakfast in.
author: Terry I.

description: Ordered the daily toast and coffee. Super fresh and delicious, but overpriced for a slice of brioche and fruit that is presented nicely on top. Overall nice little breakfast joint, but with limited seating and high prices.
author: Ren L.

description: Stopped by for a quick breakfast this morning. Cute spot for a morning latte and a healthy breakfast. It seemed like a two man operation. Both very friendly and as quick as they could be. Highly recommend this spot for a quick breakfast. Seating is limited.
author: Michael H.

description: I stayed at a nearby hotel and used Yelp to find coffee and breakfast my first morning in San Francisco. I had a cappuccino that was pretty good, along with the "daily toast." The daily toast may have been the best $7 I've ever spent. It had a cardamon mascarpone cheese spread on fresh thick-cut sourdough, topped with an array of fresh fruit to include: nectarines, apples, blueberries, raspberries and strawberries topped with pistachios. This breakfast was so satisfying and special that I had to go back the next morning. I would've given it 5 starts but the coffee was pretty good and not spectacular. Give this place a try, you won't be disappointed.
author: Audra B.

description: This place was a very nice little coffee/tea shop. The menu is limited, but their food is very fresh. I got the Daily Toast and the presentation was done very nicey. It tasted as good as it looked. As for the tea that I ordered, I felt it was a bit pricey for what it was. It tasted like normal black tea. There is limited seating, so it is not very good for large groups. The workers are friendly and helpful, so thats always a plus. Overall, this was nice place to stop by for a quick morning grab.
author: Cal K.

description:
Hated it.

If you want to stand outside to eat your overpriced small locally grown or made up cereal, then by all means, eat here.  I think this place is overated, love the concept, absolutely however they could do a better job of making it an experience to remember.
author: Denni P.

description: Decent but not really worth going out of your way either for breakfast. Had their hard-boiled egg croissant, which was nice and flaky, but dunno if it is worth $7; other than the croissant, it wasn't that memorable, nor was the chai. I do recall seeing someone next to me get some nice little fruit garnish with his croissant when mine didn't though; felt a little miffed at that. Also, they take a while to wipe down the tables. They didn't wipe up the mess in front of us from the previous group until after we got our food. I had to clean up some of it myself in the mean time.
author: Linus W.

description:
I came here hungry on a Sunday morning excited to grab a quick breakfast and try out their very popular "daily toast". When my bf and I arrived, we were surprised with how tiny the cafe was, there's one communal table that sits about 8 people tightly. It was about the size of a small living room and there was barely any space to move around, but the decor was rustic and very very charming. Without the crowds of people waiting to order food, it would actually feel very cozy and quite nice. 

I tried:
   Daily toast - toasted bread with a mascarpone+honey spread topped with seasonal fruits. The bread was hot and toasty, the mascarpone+honey spread was lightly sweetened, and the fruits were very fresh. It was beautiful and pretty darn delicious, but maybe a tad too expensive for what it was (two pieces of bread, spread, and sliced fruit).

  Iced milk coffee - it comes default as a milk coffee that is very lightly sweetened (you can customize). There's also a house-made almond milk option (+$1)! The coffee was aromatic, strong, and I loved that it was barely sweetened, it was very nice.


There is very limited seating, so don't come here expecting to have your own table, there's one communal table indoors and 2 single tables outdoor. However, there is a parklet right in front of the coffee shop where you can lounge and sit, but no table space there..

The service was okay. The staff was friendly and nice, but the wait for food was very long. Not sure if they were understaffed that day or not, but we waiting quite a long time for our toast and coffee. I read a few other reviews from yelpers that experienced the same problem - there's definitely room for improvement on their food preparation time. The coffee arrived about 10 minutes after ordering and the toast probably took from around 30-40 mins. After our meal, my bf thought the daily toast was so delicious that he wanted to order another one to-go, but because we feared the wait would be another 40 mins, we decided not to order more food. In the end, we just left farm:table still hungry and sad (we wanted more daily toast) ; (

Overall, I liked mostly everything about this little cafe, but the long wait made our experience less enjoyable. Maybe we'll give farm:table another try on a less crowded day.
author: Monica T.

description:
Tendernob. 

I know, I know, it's the area where the Tenderloin borders Nob Hill, but so help me I'm very immature and it sounds like one of the symptoms of syphilis. 

But they have a coffee called Tendernob too, and lots of other coffees besides, and their their coffee is off the planet good, Australian good even, and that's saying a lot. That's saying everything, actually. They do a tiny but creative and tasty menu, too, like eggs and creme fraiche and herbs on a croissant. Servings are kinda small for the $7-9 you pay but eh, they're open Sunday and there's not much choice on the Sabbath. 

Out the front is this rad little mini-park area (think they call it a parklet?) to sprawl on and drink ya drinks.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Be prepared to wait, like anything worth it in San Francisco. I did not have the breakfast food, so I can only speak for the drinks. But with the constant line outside I can imagine the food is good. I got 2 lattes and the house juice (apple,pear, and something). I waited about 30 minutes to get my drinks. They were fine and the juice ended up being from a bottle. Not sure if drinks are worth 30 min wait but maybe food is. Another thing, the place is very small, so if you are hoping to sit down and eat that might be difficult. If you rather skip the lines and have a more spacious sit down option go to Honey Crepery that sells really good breakfast food. It's down the street from farm table on the corner
author: Natalia P.

description: If you need a place for good and quick breakfast lunch, you will love Farm Table. The venue is tiny but charming, staff is friendly and welcoming. Their egg on croissant is super, and so it is the house espresso.
author: Nicola L.

description:
Hands down to this place. Five star to the ambience. Though the place is small , it gives the feel of old rustic breakfast inn. I have been there twice and relished the Daily toast, some sort of sweet butter spread over toast and topped with strawberries, pista, orange and couple other tasty fruits I couldn't identify.

Great place for breakfast and brunch.
author: Abhinay P.

description: Nice place but not my style. Slow. Not enough seating place, small portions and not that delicious to balance out the cons. Specially when you are a tourist you don't want to waste this much time on a small breakfast.
author: M N.

description: Great food and great service. Daily toast with marscapone and fresh fruit was amazing and same with ham croissant. Everyone here was so nice!! Only drawback was lack of seating but it's SF so that's expected.
author: C S.

description: The bread used for the 'daily toast' was way too salty. Not sure if this changes daily but salt bread + apple slices (out of anything else?)  + sugary sauce should not be $7.75
author: Max C.

description:
We were looking for a fresh food breakfast spot and this was just the place.  It's a small menu (3 items when we were there) and changes daily which is great because you know they're making the freshest meals possible.  I got the quiche and my husband enjoyed the baked ham croissant.  The quiche was perfectly cooked and seasoned. And the croissant was so tender and buttery.    I also like the that they make their own almond milk which was a great addition to the housemate chai tea.

We would recommend this place to anyone looking for a quick bite that's super fresh! Be aware that it's small with only a couple tables but worth the wait. There's also a laid back sitting area outside.
author: Rachel H.

description:
a small little boutique shop located near the tenderloin, the breakfast items were delectable and unique.. Their signature breakfast item is a baguette toasted and sliced is laid flat like petite h'orderves topped with halved hardboiled eggs.. Topped with 3 or 4kinds of tomatoes... Sliced squash, doused with a bit of olive oil and balsamic vinaigrette. Lest I forget the mariscapone cheese.. It was refreshing and light yet filling..
the prices are really decent as you would buy from a breakfast sandwhich.
coffee (bluebottle) for about $3-4
sandwhiches are about $3-5

they take cash only!
it gets crowded and parking might be a bit hard. but worth it!!
author: Jay H.

description: DELISH!!! Very small place, but the food was amazing. I got the egg on croissant; delicious flavor, light, fresh, filling, perfect Sunday morning pick-me-up. My boyf got the daily toast; AMAZING, fresh fruit, light refreshing butter spread, crispy salty-ish toast. Great balance of flavor. Highly recommended. Not for large parties.
author: Brandi S.

description: Wow!! This place is a real gem!  The homemade cereal was amazing with fresh coconut curls and tangy house made yogurt and the croissant breakfast sandwich was also excellent.  We also enjoyed the daily toast and delicious lattes - really top notch! We went on a rainy weekday morning, so there was a seat available with no wait, but be forewarned, this place is tiny.  I mean, really tiny. The only thing that kept me from a 5 star review was the lack of seating.  There's one small communal table inside and a couple small bistro tables for two outside.  I found it charming and delicious, but it's not a good option for a group.  Standing ovation for Farm: Table!!
author: Amanda H.

description: Loved the daily toast! The vanilla mascarpone went really well with the fresh fruits. Workers are friendly! The only downside are the seatings outside. This place is located on a slight hill so the tables outside are slanted and weren't very stable.
author: Yanni C.

description: Come to farm:table for phenomenal coffee and perfect croissants. Flaky on the outside, soft on the inside... So good. Visited on a Sun at noon, waited in line for only 20min.
author: Aki N.

description:
The food: very simple and tasty and fresh

Drinks: Good morning coffee and a place to come meet a friend or two

Sitting: Good luck... there is only one table inside and one table outside. 

One sentence: A european style breakfast/brunch place one would like to go during the summer to people watch.
author: Sam H.

description:
This adorable cafe is exactly what I had been searching for during my stay in San Fran. It's tiny, so not loads of rooms to sit down, but if you happen upon it when it's quiet, you will be rewarded with a peaceful brunch spot.

The coffee is excellent and the brunch options are simple and considered. Offering just a handful of menu items done well, my brunch buddies were awesome enough to order everything on the menu between them so we got to try all of it. From crunchy cereal with poached fruit to a vegie-packed frittata, and a little bowl of braised beef and rice - everything was spot on. 

If you don't score a spot inside, there is a 'parklet' outside - a mini park with garden and places to perch to enjoy a morning brew. Did I mention adorable?
author: Mel P.

description:
Sorry, not a fan. Hipsters galore. Hipster here, hipster there, hipsters everywhere! 

We tried their toast, quiche, and iced coffee for brunch. Toast was ok, quiche was already cold and bland when I bit into it, and the iced coffee was not as bold as I was expecting. Maybe it was the ice, but it was too watered down. Seemed a bit pricey considering. 

There is no ambiance or seating - it's an extremely small space crammed under what looks to be an apartment complex. Employees seem frazzled. 

Maybe I'm wrong, but they claim to use ingredients or produce from local farmers (in their bio), but I saw them take salad mix out of those plastic containers you find at Costco or other markets. Suspicious?! 

Needed a second brunch since the portion was so small. I guess if you live close by and need a quick coffee and pastry, it might be a good option.
author: Katie K.

description: Shocked it serves food! But it is a small joint serving coffee. Friendly folks in this walk-in-closet-sized location.
author: Fred J.

description:
I am the king of wishful taste-making, so why are you making eye contact with me? Yet another reason for you to be on your knees.

I discovered today that I may be on the edge of relevance for the Yelp populace. What a rush, what a thrill...and how did I come upon this presumption? Well, I actually went to the place that is rated "hottest" on this site at the moment, farm:table. It actually isn't that far away from me, but it does require me to steel myself to take the 19 Polk, the passenger list of which would not be mistaken for the guest stars on an episode of "The Love Boat". More like "The Meth Bus". Come aboard, they're expecting you.

After sauntering on Post for a few blocks, I was surprised to find this to be a blip of a place. There is a distinct Gallic feeling to the decor with the red outlines, and it actually does consist of a French farm table, fully occupied when I got there. Their ever-changing menu is on a chalkboard column, so you pretty much get what they have. I was there for a late lunch, so I went for both the $8.50 Prosciutto and Pesto Sandwich on a crunchy baguette and the $5.50 Cream of Tomato Soup (see photos). Fresh-tasting for sure. The baguette was just the right texture. The soup had a dollop of olive oil, a bit on the lukewarm side but still a treat for the clean flavor of it.

Since I really couldn't sit inside, I secured one of the two petite tea tables outside in the bitter cold. I did get self-conscious slurping soup as derelicts would slow heir pace to stare at me. However, I don't fault the staff who were nothing short of  attentive and cordial through my entire experience there. By the way, I did bypass the Verve coffee beans this time in favor of their $3 glass of unfiltered apple juice (see photo). I think once they clear out the ice rink at Union Square, I'll come back and get the food and coffee to go since it's only a few blocks away.

FOOD - 4 stars...very fresh flavors albeit a limited menu and a tad overpriced (my total bill went over $18)
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a nice walk-in closet...and if you can't be with the one you love, love the one you're with
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...quite stellar and conscientious
TOTAL - 4 stars...worth the hype? (shrug)...worth a visit? oh sure...wait a minute, are you still looking at me?
author: Ed U.

description: Almond milk latte. If heaven had a taste, this would be it. The sweet rolls are mysterious gastronomic delights: they're not served warm, yet somehow maintain a soft, melty center that should be the envy of every cinnamon roll on Earth. The staff are friendly and do their best to get you helped quickly.  The no-laptop rule at the community table is appreciated and the Parklet is a perfect curb-side Eden. A lot of gripes about how "small" it is and how "there isn't much seating." I feel they have optimized the space to the best of their ability without bastardizing the sense of atmosphere. PSA: Like every decent establishment in a major city, arriving early is key. If people haven't picked up on that by 2016, it's their problem, not the establishment's. Get out of bed before 10am, folks.
author: Anna G.

description:
Small place, nice staff.

Went here cause of the good reviws on Yelp.
Was little disapointed that its the smallest place ive seen. Lucky though cause i got one of the 2 tables outside. Was here at 8.

Food was great and coffe aswell.

Nothing to complein about, should not recomend it to a tourist cause seating is difficult to get.
author: Patrik D.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday December 22, 2009 @ Noon
Crowd:  Striking Well-Heeled Expats of All-Ages Some w/ Journals
Atmosphere:  Cozy
Decor:  European Charm.  Hand-Painted Benches w/ Communal Table
Service:  Friendly Baristas
Imbibe:  TenderNob & Mocha
Devour:  Olive-Oil Breakfast Bread & Cake
Total:  $13
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I went here while visiting SF. I'm not a coffee drinker, but that Almond Mocha seemed so tempting, it was amazing!!! Not bitter like coffee usually is and not too sweet. 

I had the grits with egg and kale - WOW - yummo! I could've eaten two bowls, but it was filling so I couldn't. 

It was much smaller than I expected, but so cute and I loved the neighborhood feel. 

Be sure to not get trapped without cash, they only take cash.
author: Lana M.

description: Amazing toast of the day. The mascarpone + toast + fruits + pistachio was spectacular. Walked in with almost NO appetite and ended up consuming 3 different things. They dont have a huge menu but what they do have is fantastic.
author: vilas v.

description: Small place, ie not a place to take your out of town friends for a sit down breakfast. People working have great attitude. Slowest line/service, which was slightly annoying just to get a very simple toast and latte. Amazingly tasty food and drinks though. Would come back again for sure.
author: Tina B.

description:
UPDATE:

I still love this place hardcore. Egg Sandwich you are my everything, my all.

HOWEVER:

They no longer make their own pastries =(

Instead they use a bakery in Emeryville called Starter bakery which is good to just so so

LAMENT:

Jalopeno scones we will never forget you
author: Vince C.

description: FANTASTIC and GREAT customer service! The toast is a must. Fresh quality and delicious. Small place and worth trying. I will definitely be back.
author: Kimberly P.

description:
Delicious yet expensive. One community indoor table, in case you didn't get the message. 

If you have the freedom to go on a weekday, I'd recommend it, because it's packed on weekends!
author: E. S.

description: My friends and I were looking for a quick take out breakfast and found farm:table on Yelp. Good thing we wanted take out because the place is tiny, but everything we ordered was incredible. Highly recommend the daily toast. It tastes as good as it sounds and as beautiful as it looks. Everything is very fresh and the people who work there are so nice. Even if you're looking for a place to sit, there is a cute little Parklet right outside for some alfresco casual seating. Love this place!
author: MZ ..

description: It's a very nice place (small but nice). They don't have that many items on their menu but what they got is creative and tasty. The coffee is good too (good not great for San Francisco).
author: Farid F.

description:
Prob wont go back. But glad I went.

Only had about 3 things on the menu. Now don't get me wrong, I like limitations, too many options can be just as cruel as too few, but 3?! And all of them were bizarre, like salmon and lockes, or croissant with creme fraiche (basically sour cream). I thought it was a ok. Too hipster for me, but not necessarily a bad experience.

Worth a shot. Hopefully their specials on the day you go are better than when I went.
author: Brittini S.

description: Went here on Sunday morning for breakfast.  Ordered a croissant egg sandwich w/out ham with their house juice.  A friend got the same sandwich with ham and a capacchino.  First, the croissant came out WITH A HAIR.  I went back to kitchen to notify them and came to realize they all had hair and no hair nets in the kitchen.  Got a new one, but with ham.  The lady didn't believe I had ordered one without ham.  Hair was gross enough, but they messed the order twice.  Concept is good and food is good but potions are small for price.  Layout and decor is nice as well, which is the only reason they get 2 stars instead of 1.  They only have 1 medium sized communal table inside.
author: Diana M.

description:
Farm:Table is probably one of my favorite go to spots for a good, delicious, simple breakfast. The menu changes daily, but I've grown to really trust that whatever they decide to serve for the day. I know it's going to be gooood! I'm not usually one for unpredictability when it comes to my food either, but I'm telling you, every new selection I've had here has been very tasty. 

Customer service is beyond great. It's also nice to know that Farm:Table is all about fresh, local, sustainable ingredients. I can support cool establishments like these any day.

This place is teeny tiny and seating is extremely limited.
author: Ann S.

description: Very limited menu. No kitchen so have to order what's on the menu and it's pre-made food that's microwaved. Spent $20 on a very small orange juice (size of a children's cup), egg on croissant and bowl of cereal. One table inside and very limited seating outside.  Not worth the walk if visiting the area.
author: Angela M.

description:
We got in at 7:30 on a weekday for breakfast and had the daily toast and daily cereal. A bit pricey at $8 a piece, but the toast was good and topped with mascarpone and fresh fruit, and the cereal I think had housemade yogurt and jam amongst other things. Yummy, simple and light, and also different from normal heavy brunch/breakfast fare. There is also a selection of baked goods. Very small location, with just one table (usually shared) if you're eating in.

If I was in the area for breakfast again, I might stop by, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Mimi C.

description: Hipster mecca. Small pretty place with nice wooden outdoor seating. Perfect for your weekend morning small batch latte and overpriced stuffed croissant.
author: Alexander P.

description: Such a cute brunch place! Very homey with great quality of food and beverages. I ordered their stuffed croissant which was delicious!
author: Linda C.

description:
I was visiting SF and was looking for a farm to table restaurant when I came across Farm:Table.  This place is within walking district from Union Square.  It was about brunch time and I was craving something SF.  This place definitely hit the spot.  

Seating:
It is a quaint sized place with approximately 8 seats at a communal table to sit in.  There is a open kitchen style window  with a window sill where people standing outside can also set their food or drinks.  There was one table with two chairs outside of the door.  There is also a modern wooden bench directly in front of the door curbside.

For those of you who are not used to sharing tables and want a more intimate setting to eat at, I would highly suggest walking over to Union Square and enjoying your meal on the grass.  I am not the biggest fan of sharing space however I actually enjoyed meeting other patrons and enjoying our meals.  I felt that is what the point is of having a quaint coffee shop - neighborhood shop with your neighbors and the farm is brought to the table.  I love it!  It provided a very friendly and casual ambiance that many coffee shops are lacking these days.

Food:
I ate the croissant sandwich which was to die for!  I also had an iced mocha.  They carry other pastries there as well.  Everything on their menu is delicious.  You really cannot go wrong with whatever you choose to devour.  

Hours:
Make sure you come for breakfast or lunch.  They are closed in the late afternoon.

Go and enjoy their food folks!  It's worth the wait if there is a line out the door.  And if there isn't seating available, you can always take the food to go and enjoy else where.
author: Arlyn M.

description: This place is awesome! Small menu but everything looks amazing and it's fresh! I had the house juice and the egg crossaint. Both excellent. I wanted to try everything! I will be back to try the toast! Very small place so hard for big groups! Perfect for a date brunch!
author: Jamie W.

description: Pretty nice little hole in the wall. Wait is abit much though, otherwise an easy 5 stars. Not many options, 4 really, but quite lovely. Egg croissant was small but still nice. I enjoyed the honey and milk drink w cardamon. If you have ever had the Indian dessert Kheer, it was comparable in flavor.
author: Danielle C.

description: This is really small.  It's not really a restaurant but more like a hutch that serves food.  I had a bowl of the house cereal (which was good) and an espresso.  I was by myself so I sat down at the counter outside next to a woman in yoga pants which was my only option.  There are eight seats.  Seven others were taken.  She looked at me like I was a sexual predator and turned away from me after I said "wow... Close quarters huh?".  I think she wrote something horrible about me on social media while I read my book.  It was tense while I ate my cereal, so this is the type of place where it might be good to go with a friend.  I think I may have been put on a watch list so I don't know if I can go back.  It's too bad.  That cereal was good.
author: Greg M.

description: Great find... The menu is limited but with quality. Staff is nice but could definitely be more welcoming.  I stood at the counter for 3 mins before the man taking orders even looked at me to say hello.  When you see how tiny the interior you will understand that critique... Do NOT take a large group here, it is tiny....and only has one communal table inside that is about 4x4 and two tiny cafe tables out on the street.  Great for a single traveler stop or a cute couple grab a bite, but not to celebrate or bring a big group to unless you want to dance on Post St.  Food was quality and fresh.
author: Evan D.

description: Great find! Cute little hole in the wall breakfast spot. If you're in a hurry around breakfast time it may not be your best bet however the food is worth the wait! Daily toast is a tasty desert breakfast with fresh ripe fruit on soft brioche bread. Egg sandwich was tasty and filling. It was a little greasy and I would have preferred my eggs soft boiled but still a very yummy breakfast. I'm a sucker for house made almond milk, which they offer per request, and their coffee was very nice. Sweet simple menu, fun very "SF" vibe, glad we found it.
author: Christina C.

description: Toast was good nothing extraordinary but coffee was delish! Good quick bite although it was really busy!
author: Christian G.

description:
Very small seating area with a communal table inside and a few small places to sit outside. If you're OK cozying up to other folks, then you have to check this place out. I had a root vegetable hash with a soft boiled egg on top. It was really good. Their coffee is nice and strong. They have a special house juice that is a combo of apple, orange and lemon. Quite tasty. 

Like I said--tiny dining area :) You've been warned.
author: Theresa H.

description: Nice, small little restaurant. Short but good menu. Only gripe is that the portions weren't big enough. Friendly service.
author: Shaun M.

description: Good food. Very small menus and not much seating. Prices are a bit high good service.
author: Veronica W.

description:
I've been back here a couple times, and I continue to love the iced coffee with almond look.  I prefer the breakfast selections to the lunch selections.  The lunch items are good (a couple times ago I tried a quiche, a tuna salad sandwich) have not surpassed the wonderful simplicity of a fresh bread/nut butter/fruit/honey drizzle item I had the first time.

This last time, we tried a meatloaf sandwich, egg sandwich and yogurt/homemade cereal.  The meatloaf was quite tasty - moist, a little tangy, not too salty, nice texture.  I wish the egg were soft-boiled instead of hard-boiled, but it was pretty fantastic - quite flavorful with a homemade mayonnaise despite its simplicity.  The homemade cereal was a nice healthy option - unsweetened yogurt, cereal, fruit and honey.
author: Connie T.

description: Coffee and the daily toast are delicious. My husband and I went here for breakfast when visiting San Francisco. We went here based on the yummy looking photo of their daily toast which had fresh fruit. It was as good as it looked. You do need to know that the place is really small and when we came here the only inside table was taken by a large group of eight. There are two small bistro table outside and a large wooden bench on the sidewalk. You have to get used to the confined spaces in a large city. And get used to paying higher prices of the bigger cities. The daily toast was $8. My husband had cappuccino with almond milk, I had coffee and we each had the daily toast Total $25 before tip.
author: Debby S.

description: We read the reviews so thought we'd check this place out. It definitely was not as good as we had hoped and their gluten free options are limited to just the cereal. The presentation of the daily toast was beautiful but the bread was dry and considering they only provided a fork, it was difficult to eat. Coffee was gross.. Save your money and walk to the nearest Starbucks.
author: Courtney J.

description: Terrible customer service. Went once when I first arrived at my hotel in San Francisco and it was very busy, so not much was expected for customer service. We ordered 2 latte's and an almond croissant no problem. The next day I wanted to get a latte with a little less milk, or even a cortado, but wasn't sure about the coffee culture and their menu considering some spots in SF don't know and it wasn't on their menu. So I ordered a double short latte (all their lattes come in one size and I didn't know) and he rang me up for a latte at $6.75, which is ridiculous so I asked him why it was so much for a double short and he said "I thought you said a double" and I explained what drink I wanted and he was telling me what I wanted was not a latte so I told him I wanted a cortado and he yelled out "there you go!" And I told him how I just didn't know their menu because it was a little confusing and he just kept belittling me instead of just helping me out so I asked him to cancel the transaction and left. It's really frustrating for someone who doesn't frequent there to go in and order and if I explain what I want he should then explain to me what they call it and how much it is because even just a double 12 oz latte shouldn't be 6.75, I went in the day before and got 2 lattes one with almond milk and it was less than 8 dollars so I don't know what's going on there.
author: Annabelle M.

description: This place is a small cafe, the line is long but well worth it. The food is delicious and so healthy. I love all the fruit on the toast and homemade mascarpone. So delicious!!
author: Jazelle M.

description: Nice little place. Service was a little off today, though - they forgot about my coffee order.
author: Vladimir D.

description: Very cute hole in the wall joint around our hotel. Had a cute nice hard boil egg on brioche with  goat cheese and cucumber. Yum!
author: Keefy Y.

description: Quiet and quaint breakfast spot with fresh toast and unique breakfast options.  Great place to grab a small bite before venturing out to sight see!
author: Andrew K.

description: A toast a day, the YELPER stays happy. While I am normally not a fan of carbs, I fall in love with Farm Table's daily toast. The combination of strawberries, kiwi, grapefruit, pistachio and pecan butter was divine. The waiter is friendly and is happy to explain the dish to me and my friend. My only complaint is the limited seating inside the restaurant. Nonetheless, a memorable place for breakfast!
author: May Y.

description: Cute place to grab a latte and a quick bite.
author: Dejana B.

description:
So I'm late to the table, four years late or so. But when I'm at Post & Jones, I'm not really in the mood to eat. I'm more in the mood to avoid stepping on used space jackets & not getting sprayed down by the guy power washing the sidewalks. In fact, I don't think I've ever been to Post & Jones outside of the hours of 6pm & 2am. So, for the first time this past weekend I found myself close enough to remember that I never came over to this closet of a stand, which would easily go for say $1900 if someone wanted to live inside it. 

I fulfilled a cliche by ordering $10 polenta (the traditional porridge dish of Italy) for breakfast. Creme fraiche, cilantro, carrots and sausage justified the dish, as did the quality. The Fetco cup they had going was as good as a quick cup can get. 

The place seats about 4 inside and 4 out, but they do have a parklet which when you look at it, looks like Christian Slater drunk after a scene in Gleaming The Cube constructed it with the wrong Ikea instructions. But, there are cupholders and it's better than sitting on a curb on a wet power washed street.
author: Jon A.

description: Although this cafe is small ( only 1 table inside and 2 outside), and there are only a few items on the menu to choose from, their food is fresh and yummy! We had their quiche and the ham and egg croissant. Both were perfect! Their coffee was good too! Wish they have more tables...
author: Anita T.

description:
Please dont' be deceived by the title of this place. First of all it's 1 singular table. So if you don't enjoy being crammed around other people inches from the 'kitchen' (which is a mini convectioner oven and esepresso machine) that's your first warning. Now that we've gotten over the fact that it's a shoebox, let's first dicuss the food. 

Ok, maybe it's coming directly from a farm to their singular table, but I'll tell you what it isn't, made to order! That shit is pre made in the morning, by what seems to be an insanely stoned out/acid damaged elderly SF spirit mistress....The "menu" which was basically 4 things, sounded OK in a "yes starbucks now has a fancy SF bakery sending it stuff instead of cardboard muffins from North Dakota" way....insanely basic food...which if done right I guess is a YAY. 

This place is a GIANT nay. The scone was ROCK hard. The egg situation was a SITUATION. But I think what made this place a numero uno offender and reason for me to actually LOG back on to yelp 2 years after my last review and scream some reason into the nothingness of the internet was the price point/service.

You gonna pay for some seriously boring shit here and you are going to wait A LONG TIME FOR IT TO BE REHEATED FOR YOU, and when you get it, you will get it at their leisure, with zero friendly vibe. You can if you are lucky sit outside (in the fog and cold) and sit on a weirdly misguided city parks public grass chair spot, but you might have to jockey for a spot there as well. DEFINITELY DON'T ask for things like 'no sugar' in your coffee. 

On their chalk board they tout their "VERY SPECIAL" iced coffee, which is just an imitation of Blue Bottles New Orleans situation. A now overly familiar cold brew with sugar. I asked for it with no sugar please. 

I grabbed a scone. My partner waited 40 minutes for his reheated egg situation. AFTER his eggs, came my iced coffee, SATURATED in simple syrup. I muscle my way through the crowd (why it's crowded I have no idea) to return it politely. The acid victim looks confused. Her thinning grey hair gently falling into various plates of food. 

Acid Spirit: "You want sugar in your coffee?"

me: "No thank you, I told you no sugar please"

Acid Spirit: "So you want iced coffee with sugar, which is our specialty"

me: "No thank you, I'd like iced coffee without sugar, is that possible?"

Acid Spirit: "I guess so although that's not our specialty"
(meanwhile I had already had a bafflingly long conversation the FIRST time I ordered it about the EASIEST of requests, no sugar. 

20 minutes later....LITERALLY she comes stumbling out like a zombie and then out of nowhere this 60s spirit decides to dish up some serious passive agressive bay area righteousness to me. 

Acid Spirit: "Here's your iced coffee without sugar"

me: "thank you!"

Acid Spirit:  "let me stand here and watch you take the first sip to make sure you like it!" said with exaggeratted smile and barely veiled annoyance

I'm too cold and bored and over it to even ice her bullshit back so I just say "yup! There's no sugar, just how i like it!"

She leaves. We leave. We never go back. 

I advise you steer clear of this little turdling of a spot.
author: evan d.

description: Super good food. But be ready to pay for it. Cheaper than some more than others. If I had a place to sit comfortably it would be better. But I'm sure I'll be back. Still get 4 stars because the food is real and good. And real good
author: Tyler L.

description: I don't necessarily like communal seating but this place is worth sitting next to complete strangers. The daily toast is soooo good. And not to mention their salads and the savory tart was soooo good well worth it. I would come here again for sure also great coffee
author: Juan C.

description: A true hole in the wall! Very teeny but cozy cozy spot. Nice if you can get a seat at the table inside and enjoy the bustle of the cafe. excellent cappuccino.
author: Caitlin G.

description: I love how fresh the food always tastes here. Egg on croissant and almond milk latte are delicious. This place is small and the line can be quite long but it's worth it.
author: Irina P.

description: Loved the toast with berries and fruit, and since I can't have dairy, they substituted almond butter for the mascarpone!  It was delicious!!!  The house juice was fantastic, too, and the presentation was beautiful. I loved sitting outside on the wooden planter next to the mint to eat.
author: Emily G.

description:
Didn't expect this place to be so tiny; there is one communal table inside, but it's probably better to just grab your food and go.

I like how they have different menu items every day; I went on a Saturday and had a sandwich with bacon, hard boiled egg, and... something else that is not coming to me at the moment. Simple yet delicious, the bread that it was served on was really fresh and the sandwich had a kick of flavor. 

I also ordered the latte with almond milk because a lot of yelpers mentioned it was really good, but it wasn't anything spectacular in my opinion. I was expecting a stronger almond flavor, guess i'll be sticking to my soy latte next time i come back.
author: Angela K.

description:
I love this place and will camp outside it's cramped little vestibule for unestimateable amounts of time in chilly rainy STORMY weather for the chance of paying almost laughable amounts of money for deliciously perfect and in some cases almost microscopic morsels of yum.

I love the house made nut mylk, the awkward parklet, the little glass jars and especially the teeny tiny kitchen under the stairs that looks like it was made by elves.
author: Summer S.

description: Tiny place. The minute you step foot in there, you're in there. Awesome breakfast offerings.  House cereal is fantastic. I will return
author: Marc C.

description: Over the hill and not so far away from the Financial District is farm:table a small and quaint nook on the border of Tenderloin and Nob Hill. If you can see the cottage garden parklets at the front, you've found your cafe. Small things come in good packages and here you'll find wholesome healthy eats to line your stomach. On the morning we ventured here for brunch, I opted for the pork bowl of pulled pork, rice and more. Delicious. Filling and my favourite kind of breakfast - a non-breakfast foods breakfast. I also ordered a green tea which was a calming sip for a day of walking ahead of me.
author: Lani P.

description: Great breakfast sandwiches. And the cold cereal is a real treat. And the coffee is delicious. Seating is very limited but they have small seating area right outside.
author: Danny C.

description:
Small in size and though the one table can seat a maximum of 8, it comfortably seats four strangers. If you are feeling social, you can certainly attempt speaking with those around you.... Responses and good conversation are not always the case. 

Good coffee, better almond milk, & a simple breakfast. The pastries are good, but the daily specials are better.... Since they are special. Nothing is too heavy and it is a great place to drop by if you only have 20-30 minutes to eat too!

I am a fan of the croissant egg sandwiches & daily toasts!
author: Diana Y.

description:
It's simple: this is the coolest breakfast place in San Francisco. It's so quintessentially SF that you can't help feel proud that there are places like this in your city. Go and enjoy. 

Always ask them what their favorite item is on the list. You may end up with a surprise dish you didn't expect to love so much.
author: Mehdi A.

description: Over hyped and over priced. Super disappointed with this place. They gave us our croissant sandwiches in these paper to go plates that are similar to the ones you would get outside of a club at 4am when you get a hot dog. Super random. For the price point it was not good food at all. I got the croissant egg sandwich which was super sloppy -- my hard boiled egg fell out of the croissant as I picked it up to take a first bite & the whole thing fell apart. Never again!
author: Naseem K.

description:
I like to think of myself as kind of an egg connoisseur and farm:table's got their egg technique down to a T. Over the weekend I tried their egg on a biscuit and it literally blew my mind away. The biscuits were buttery and firm (in a good way), bacon was thick, sauce was creamy and the EGGS!!! The yolks were perfectly creamy but not undercooked. WUT. SO. AMAZING. I can't even put it into words. I have been let down many times by disappointing eggs, but literally, I have never had better.

Also, the milk + honey drink had such a complex flavor and even though I was kinda skeptical at first (felt like I could totally make that shit at home...) it was so delicious that I barted back the next day just so I could get another cup before I went home for the week! 

A must try!!!!
author: Debra L.

description:
Fuck yes.

I hate to write a 5 star review here, because I don't want bigger crowds to go to this lovely little place. I usually get the savoury oat bowl combined with some form of meat. My word, they have the best slow cooked pork in all of the bay area I've had... And I've been to quite a few meat places.

Their coffee is also phenomenal. All around amazing.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
Tiny ass space - so truly a communal experience. Which is about right bc only Stalin could drum up a worse idea. 

I kid, I kid. Food was a'ight - nothing to write home to Moscow about. It seems like most things are pre-made and then reheated in a microwave or toaster oven. I could be wrong but I doubt it. 

Coffee was ok as well, a bit gritty which I don't mind but know some ill' complainers might get their bear skin britches in a ruffle. 

Overall it was a "meh" experience at a place more driven by novelty than quality.
author: Seth S.

description:
The daily toast looked like a healthy breakfast to end a week of vacation gluttony.  The pictures hooked us so my girlfriend and I made out trek over to farm:table from Union Square.

The place was a bit smaller than we expected as there was only one communal table in the shop.  There were also some seating outdoors, but it was a cold and windy December morning.

The people were very nice and explain the menu and ordering system to us.  A lady (owner?) even help us enter our order as it was our first time there.  We got the daily toast and croissant sandwich.  I have to say the food was excellent.  The croissant was crispy and the eggs were perfectly soft boiled.  With the daily toast, we requested that the marscapone cheese be put on the side and they happily did so.  The fruit was ripe and the cheese was sweet just to my taste.

The only fault was I thought the value was a bit off.  Although the croissant sandwich tasted great it was underwhelming in size.  Another small hiccup was that they left off the pistachios on the daily toast that we saw another customer had (but again we requested the marscapone on the side, so that may have threw off the cook and they simply forgot, not too big a deal since we made a special request).
author: Tom Q.

description:
Great little spot if you're looking for delicious food in a hip setting.

Like seriously, really hip. I felt a little dumb wearing Sperry's in here. I guess with a name like "farm:table" (it's almost like it's making fun of people who say "farm to table"... so meta) I should have expected that.

I got the frittata, with fresh tomatoes, potatoes, sausage and an herb aioli on the side and an iced coffee. The iced coffee was honestly mindblowing. They use almond milk apparently, which makes it milkshake decadent while not being too heavy. In my perfect reality, I would install one of those gerbil water spigot things in my house filled with the stuff for whenever I want it. Dream big, guys. 

My least favorite thing was the seating, though. It was busy when we went in on a Tuesday morning (imagine the weekend), and we sat outside on this weird little veranda sculpture thing that was probably not made to eat frittata and drink orgasmic iced coffee on. Having just four tables outside would have made for an even better experience.

Seats or no seats, that iced coffee will have me coming back next time I'm in SF, and I'll definitely be trying what ever is on the menu that day as well. Even if it means the farm cannot literally come to the table.
author: Matt M.

description:
the egg sandwich tasted real good
very limited space and seating there however
author: Harry R.

description: We expected better given the reviews. Over-hyped. Sandwich was very good, but nothing truly special. Cereal was unremarkable. Seating was limited. Coffee was pretty.
author: David B B.

description: Delicious food from a tiny storefront. Seating is at a premium so expect to carry out or grab a perch on the curbside timber structure. Breakfast was a toasted croissant sandwich with bacon, cheese, boiled egg, arugula & herbs...just right with fresh brewed coffee. Breakfast was about $11, not bad for SF.
author: Arnie S.

description: The toast topped with fruit is simple yet out of this world. And the egg croissant sandwich done veggie style (no ham) can't be topped. The wait was kind of long for a weekday morning. Can't wait to return.
author: Ami Y.

description:
Yes... just yes to everything! 

While this place is VERY tiny, just one communal table inside, it is something you should 100% try. I have been several times and tried different things every time, ALL OF THE FOOD IS DELICIOUS! 

They usually have about 3 menu items, aside from some assorted pastries, you really can't go wrong with anything. On top of which, they're coffee is fantastic! I recommend the cappuccino, but have heard great things about their house coffee as well. 

If its a nice day, you can also sit outside. There are two small tables (just two chairs at each) and a nice little park area (basically the size of two parallel parking spots).
