If you're just looking for a good cup of coffee or some great brunch food, this place is worth the stop!
author: Jess K.

description: I really love the organic, hipster place this give. It is a little challenging to find the place however the apple toped with egg and nuts were so good I went there again. What I did not like about this area was that most of them are snooty as hell. I am from out of town and so SORRY for asking 2 questions about your menu- attitude not needed. thanks. food is good. service needs a little work. unfortunately coffee is nothing compared to blue bottle.
author: Angel L.

description:
There's a single communal square table inside with two smaller tables lining the streets that are 2-seaters. The menu is simple with 3 things to choose from along with a small variety of pastries, and a handful of coffee choices. While the menu is simple, the flavor is not lacking at all! We ordered the egg croissant and it was probably the best breakfast sandwich I've ever had! Everything tasted very fresh!

Be prepared to wait for the food as they make it as ordered, and it can take a few minutes. It's a small place, so you can see into the kitchen and watch them prep and make everything if you're sitting at the communal table.
author: Alice L.

description: Excellent mocha and milk n honey. Worth waiting in the long line. Excellent neighborhood ambience. Plan for to go food or eat standing. Definitely worth a repeat every time I come back to sf
author: Vikas J.

description: Not bad except nothing on the menu and nowhere to sit
author: Patrick T.

description: Loved the Matcha Chai Tea Latte. Small place with a communal table plus cool outdoor seating.
author: Kristen C.

description: The food is a 4 stars for what they offer but the place is a ratchet mess. The inside is very small but has a large communal table bad idea!!! The outside smells like piss and outside seating is unsanitary. This is below an apartment building in which I imagine that the chaos below makes the lives of the tenants upstairs a nightmare. The employees are crabby and I saw one sorting tip change and stacking them when the time spent should be on more pressing tasks like getting customers in and out.
author: N A.

description:
Three words: Fresh, Simple and Delicious

This small cafe uses fresh ingredients which are bought daily (menu changes as new ingredients are purchased). The food prepared/cooked is simple as it displays the essences of the ingredients used. The food is Delicious is one of many words to describe the food here. You'll have to decide what word to use after eating here.

Dishes that I ate:

Quiche - It was simple, light, fluffy and flavorful. One of the best I've ever eaten.
"--------" (Forgot the name): I'm going to describe it in the order it was layered. Sliced bacon, hard boiled egg, creme fraiche, spinach puree, on top of a sliced piece of Baguette bread and light drizzled with lemon infused olive oil.  It was so delicious and fresh. 

The service was welcoming and quick. The seating is limited as there is one communal table inside, two small tables outside (seating up to 3 people), and 3 table top bar-ish areas to stand and eat. 

Remember: Fresh, Simple and Delicious.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Teeny tiny restaurant that feels like a home. The inside reminds me of staying in agroturismos in Italy- the three person staff have warm hearts and serve up delicious treats. Prices are normal for San Francisco (food might even be on the inexpensive side). There is not much space so maybe come alone, or with one friend- coming in a large group would be a hindrance given the space. 

Food-wise, I ordered the frittata and my friend ordered the breakfast croissant. Both were amazing, but with the daily menu- might not be there when you go. Note to the wise, all four choices looked superb and were made fresh. 

Drinks-wise, the Milk with Honey and Cardamum was amazing! Definitely order that one. Their fresh juice was great too, but it was about $4 for 8 oz so I opted away.

Enjoy!
author: Ami D.

description:
Really nice little brunch spot. Counter service, so you don't have to wait to get a table. There is limited seating inside and out, but the parklet outside is a nice place to sit if you can snag a spot.

I had the croissant with eggs and a tender nob with almond milk. The croissant was delicious, the eggs were very nicely done, and the creme fraiche was amazing. The tender nob was flavorful - the creaminess of the almond milk paired very well with the dark and rich espresso.

My friend got the pumpkin polenta with chicken apple sausage. He loved it, and I tried a little bit and definitely agreed. The mixture of flavors and textures was great. He also had the milk and honey and raved about that too.

Overall a solid 5 star brunch place. I'll definitely be back!
author: Ankit G.

description:
Delicious almond milk espresso &
Home made cereal with fruit. Hoping for more vegan options but still yummy
author: Holly L.

description:
The food here is 5 stars, easy. My husband and I trekked here from our hotel for breakfast. We arrived 15 or so minutes early and sat outside at a table and watched them finish their baking and arrange the restaurant. They were blaring music and the atmosphere was enthusiastic for such an early morning.

I ordered the daily toast--today it was some sort of strawberry focaccia bread topped with some sort of cream cheese/ricotta/whipped cream type substance, fresh strawberries/raspberries/peaches and spice. It was heavenly and the portion was huge. The fruit was very fresh and flavorful.

My husband had one of the special sandwiches. It was a biscuit with a hardboiled egg, candied bacon and cheddar cheese. I tasted a bite and it was delicious and fresh. My husband was thrilled with it and talked about it the entire way home.

I had the house juice, which was a combination of apple, orange, grapefruit and probably something else. It was great! It came in a really small glass for $3, so that was a bit disappointing. That wouldn't stop me from ordering it again though...it really was good. The iced coffee was really good as well.

Seems like this is probably a better choice for carry-out as the place is small. There is one table in the corner, which is where we sat, and anyone will sit down and eat with you. Depending on the people it calls for good conversation! It was pretty busy while we were there and our food did take awhile to come out. Completely worth it though!
author: Kae H.

description: I came here on a recent trip to SF with my husband. Ordered the daily toast which was amazing!!! We also ordered the Nutella latte which also amazing. There's barely any seating at all so this is a great to-go opt
author: Khadija Q.

description:
After going through my "must try" list of food in San Francisco we decided this weekend would be brunch, and picked Farm: Table for our weekly date meal.  We walked here for breakfast on Sunday before going to walk around the city and were able to enjoy the nice weather and good food that filled us up until early evening.  Tiny little gem of a place that is nicely tucked away.  Located in Downtown/Civic Center area or what many lovingly refer to as Tendernob/ Lower Nob Hill this place brings a new life to the neighborhood.  Farm: Table is clearly owned by a very sweet family that care about their restaurant and customers and provides a homey and welcoming feel from when you walk in. 

    Together two of us shared the frittata, Hard boiled egg croissant, and the special a sausage on a baguette, with two coffees.  Total about $30 and it was well worth it, the servings are smaller than most people are accustomed to receiving at brunch, but I equate that with the simple fact you are not getting all the sides such as hash browns or bacon or toast with each entree you get what you order and that allows the flavors of each item to really be highlighted and enjoyed.  Keeping the concept simple local food for customers to enjoy while being filing and giving you a unique atmosphere. 

    I only wish they were open Monday's so I could go and try more food this morning before heading off to work!  I know we will be back soon and hope to try to make this a regular spot.
author: Jacyn B.

description: Finally got to try this place after getting up right before they opened on a weekend morning!!! It was worth it! Ham and cheese croissant, stuffed bell pepper and iced coffee... all great! Local and fresh ingredients. The big con not reflective of its food? It's a tiny place with one small communal table inside and two small tables outside. I hope they can find and afford a bigger space in Sf!
author: Leila H.

description: Based on the reviews, I expected a long wait, crowded conditions, but absolutely yummy food.  The reality, the wait wasn't too bad...it was a bit crowded but we managed to get a table outside so that we could people watch...and the drinks/food were as delicious as expected.  I ordered the honey & milk because it sounded interesting...and in truth, it was very tasty.  My husband who is a huge mocha fan found his drink to be just the right amount of coffee and mocha.  We ordered the daily toast and egg sandwich.  Though the egg sandwich was yummy, it was the toast that made our breakfast!  The type of bread and mascarpone cheese paired perfectly with the kiwi, grapes, orange, and apple slides.  It wasn't a big portion but it was definitely enough to keep us going until lunch.  I would totally eat here again the next time I'm in town.
author: Catherine C.

description: Tried their Daily toast and the Eggplant Empanadas and they were very tasty! Small spot but very cozy.
author: Jason I.

description: Maybe I've fallen victim to America's super sized portions, but the croissant breakfast sandwich here is tiny. I'd need to eat at least 2 to be full, and at over $8 for one, this place is pricey! The sandwich was well-made (flaky croissant and good ratio of sauce to fillings) but I wouldn't come back.
author: Lauretta L.

description:
I was expecting a sit-down restaurant, but once I got the lay of the land after walking in and getting their system figured out, I really liked it.  

It's amazing how many people they fit in the open kitchen.  The cafe is about the size of a postage stamp and has one communal table for eight inside, and two, two-tops outside.  Face it, if you've never been there before, it's hard not to look like a dork while you stand quietly at the door deciphering the farm:table 411.

I loved the food.  We got the egg biscuit, frittata and zucchini bread.  It was one of our best meals.  The zucchini bread ordering was my dorky moment. After being halfway through my meal I asked how much longer for the sweet treat.  The gal said, "Oh, for all bakery items you help yourself."  See what I mean? 

Halfway through our visit they ran out of most items on the list, so you may want to get their early. 

The cappuccino and iced tea were fresh and very good.

A plus for this cafe is that right out front they have one of those very cool sidewalk parks that are being installed throughout SF.  It was very hot out, so we were lucky to score two seats at the table of 8 and get some breeze from the big open window.

I will definitely be back here...and hopefully avoid my dorkiness the second time around.
author: April B.

description:
-Tiny, maybe 10 people 
-Awesome, bit random, menu
-Unfortunately small servings
-Be aware, its in the middle of SF soup kitchen district
- They also have some bakery items which were average.
author: Ryan L.

description:
This is a quintessential SF place where there is a communal 8 person table and you feel like you're having lunch with your SF family. The menu changes daily and it's tweeted every day. We had an amazingly fresh Gouda & leek frittata w chive aioli, jalapeño scone and the house meatloaf!
Everything tasted freshly baked and picked right from the farm..loved it! 4 stars because this time we got a spot to sit, but I may not get one next time..
author: Shakti P.

description:
This is an awesome little spot to have breakfast. It was a rainy weekend in SF and wanted to start our day off with a light breakfast. Came across farm:table on Yelp and couldn't stop looking at the mouthwatering pics of the daily toast. This place definitely did not disappoint!

Tried the daily toast, which was the perfect amount of savory and sweet. The frittata was absolutely mouthwatering - light, fluffy and flavorful. I also had the chai tea latte which was made to perfection. 

It's a really small spot and not the best for big parties. You need to be pretty lucky to get a spot at the table, I guess luck was on my side! This is another typical SF restaurant where you must be ok with being intimate with strangers since you could be sharing the main table with them. Can't wait to go back and enjoy breakfast here again.
author: Jen S.

description:
Fantastic little spot - a real hidden gem. The egg biscuit w/ scallion spread was delicious but the real delight was strawberry cake!

Best breakfast of the week.
author: John E.

description: This place is wonderful.  The prices are reasonable considering how much care goes into each little plate.
author: John F.

description:
Found this place on Yelp and was super pumped to go.  Reviews and photos looked great and it was close to our hotel.

It is a quaint little shop with very minimal seating.  Staff was friendly. 

Food was horrible.  Just horrible.  Normally my husband and I are members of the "clean plate" club but not here.  We ordered the egg on biscuit with bacon, cheese, and herb fraiche.  The biscuit and all its contents were cold.  The egg was actually a hard boiled egg (what?) cut in half.  The other ingredients were nonexistent - hardly any cheese, about 1/4 slice of  bacon, and barely a tbsp. of herb fraiche.  I'm not asking for a monster sandwich but for $7 what I got was ridiculous.  Maybe we ordered the wrong thing.  I won't be back to find out.  
 
Cappuccino was also lacking.  It was sour and they missed the nail on the milk/espresso ratio.  

I really wanted to love this place but it was one of the most horrible breakfasts I've had in a long time.
author: A. M.

description: Stopped in before my hair appt down the street wanting coffee but decided to get the milk n honey. Loved it. Cute lil hole in the wall place. Baked goods looked delish. Will def be back!
author: Stephanie T.

description: Tiny space but what a gem. The daily toast was sweet, toasted well and the fruits rich. The eggs on croissant had a buttery, slightly crispy outside and the filling was delicious. The savory tart was a bit disappointing in comparison. Great place to just chill out!
author: Ipsita B.

description:
Only came here for coffee so I that's all I can comment on.  The mocha is according to the board, made of 60% tcho chocolate.  How could I pass it up?  Good chocolate and coffee is one yummy mason jar glass.

The place is TINY though.  I'm not sure if I can stress this enough.  I craned my neck wondering if there was a chance that the mirror was really a trick and there was more room in back.  Nope.  There's a communal table that seats a cozy 6 and then two tables out on the sidewalk that seat 3 each.  That's it.  Looks like a lot people get stuff to go here and that's what I recommend.
author: Jean K.

description: Daily toast is epic! Lovely atmosphere with friendly staff. Losing a star because my cappuccino was teeny tiny for $3.50
author: Jessica R.

description:
I called the owner(?), the shortish guy with the beautiful blue eyes, blondish hair an ASSHOLE!! 

Why? Why? Why would a customer act that way? Well, I'll tell you. This customer believes in manners and having  service people treat their customers respectfully and not say "WHAT IS YOUR PROBLEM" when mentioning their $4.00 latte tastes like the milk has gone bad. When I first mentioned this, I had a coworker taste it who agreed. Yes the MILK WAS BAD. The barista boy made me a new one but it tasted the same. His explanation, delivered in the oh so pompous tone of those who say, 'I don't watch tv' was 'there is no sugar.' Well of course not. Don't customers add that on their own? I wouldn't know since I haven't used sugar since I was 16. This is when old blue eyes said "WHAT IS YOUR PROBLEM?!!" Maybe those who might not own a tv don't know this is not the polite response to a customer, when they complain about the taste of their order. I walked out with my sour milk latte and said, "don't worry, I won't be back." to which Mr. sandy hair man replied "GOOD!"

And thus I called him an ASSHOLE!!
author: Laura M.

description: A small spot to dine at for breakfast and a limited menu but good, expertly roasted and ground coffee and delicious, innovative dishes makes for a healthy start to the day!
author: kavita k.

description: Nice cafe. Service is very slow so need to be patient. The daily toast has nice fruits on top but bread is a bit hard.
author: Jeni Y.

description: Delicious food , pretty good staff. So why the 2 star rating? It's the damn box credit card system that they use. I paid for and signed for one meal and gave a 15% tip. I was advised that they were out of my choice. So I made the choice of a less expensive, equally fine breakfast. No "Sorry about that," No refund offered. A 2 bit difference but, c'mon...  Enough on this mini rant...
author: paul h.

description: We were kinda shocked that the place is so small: just a counter, some display, and ONE table. The menu was very small. The staff were not very nice. I ordered a scone with cheese and egg. They didn't even warm it up; it was cold! My friend had the toast, which was okay.
author: Sharon C.

description: Delicious food, friendly staff, owners on site and great cooks. Must visit for breakfast, lunch, or amazing chai in San Francisco.
author: Katie V.

description: Very fresh, healthy, friendly little restaurant. I do emphasize LITTLE. There's a single "community" table inside, then a couple of café style tables outside. It was a perfect quick lunch stop!
author: VeggieLover C.

description: The three stars are for the excellent food and coffee! I had the daily toast and I must say the spread was the yummiest I have ever had! The fruits are fresh and I almost wanted to get another one! The coffee was excellent. Had the mocha. However it's a rather small space and you might not get a place to sit on the communal table. As I was new to the place, I was rather confused by the seating and was standing by the door expecting a waiter to help me. Instead, I got a rather rude reply from the waiter and I decided to get to go and sat out in the cold and ate outside! Service was not the best.
author: Abhi B.

description:
Give me that biscuits. Nom nom nom!

The only place that has comparably biscuits is Brenda's. The breakfast here is hearty, fresh, and darn right yummy. The 5 things on their daily menu never disappoint. 

Coffee/espresso drinks are great. 

Only downside with this place, it is hard to sit outside in the winter when you can fit 6 people at the tinny table at this shoe box establishment.
author: Alice C.

description:
I've been a regular here for a long time, but there have been some changes in the past few months, and I've been continually disappointed since then. 

There was once a guy who appeared to run the place, and while he was there, the service was impeccable, and the food was outstanding. Every breakfast exceeded my expectations by a wide margin and I always enjoyed stopping by. 

Now, that guy is gone, and he's been replaced by another guy, plus some new guest-facing staff. 

The guest facing staff (the people who take orders) are now extremely rude - consistently so. And, they become extremely angry and frustrated when I ask any question at all about the ingredients of the daily special. 

More importantly, the food is not what it used to be. They used to make each dish by hand, and they were nourishing, creative, and interesting. I loved every one. Now, they've stopped doing that, and are focused on serving cold items that are pre-made. 

Where there used to be a lot of variety, now it's always the same thing. Either a cold foccacia that's been sitting outside for a long time, or a cold egg sandwich that's been sitting outside for a long time. It seems they've tried to cut labor and materials costs to serve more people, more cheaply, and more quickly. The egg sandwich and foccacia are fine, but after the first 10 times or so, they become old. I miss the warm and custom made items that had a good balance of protein and vegetables. Now, it's all about cold plain white carbs with tiny fragments of protein and hardly any vegetable source whatsoever. 

This place is a shell of what it used to be, trading on its reputation. I've refrained from downgrading for about 3 months, waiting to see if things turn around. Rather than turn around, they just keep getting worse.
author: Eater S.

description: Creative use of space. Small interior, only seating inside is a communal table. Pretty good latte here. Ordered "Egg on a Croissant" - no sugar coating this name, it was literally a hard boiled egg on a croissant with some ham, cheese and lettuce. I'm a big breakfast eater and it was Not my favorite so next time I'll just grab coffee.
author: Marshall M.

description:
I'm in love with this place.  I work down the street and come here to grab breakfast occasionally when I don't have time or forget to make my own.  I have to say, everything I've had here is delicious, fresh, and amazing.

The daily toast is to die for.  I see that there are a few reviews saying it's not worth the price, but it totally is.  Don't forget how much it costs to run a restaurant business in San Francisco -- considering there are places where breakfast can run you $10 or more for something crappy, I don't mind paying $7.50 for a delicious, beautiful, colorful and fresh breakfast.

The savory tart is also quite good and comes with a little side salad that has the best dressing.

Now let's talk about the coffee for a minute.  I am a coffee fiend, and I LOVE farm:table's coffee.  The iced coffee is simply delicious, the mocha with TCHO dark chocolate is divine, and the steamed milk and espresso takes third place in a strong lineup of caffeinated beverages.  The house juice is also quite good.

I can't say enough good things about farm:table.  Try it out, you won't regret it!
author: Alyssa K.

description:
A neat restaurant with a (very) simple menu of around four items that change daily based on what they're able to source locally. The day that Katherine L, myself, and a mutual friend met up for lunch here, they were offering a bacon apple fava green sandwich, asparagus quiche, creamy pea soup, and arugula salad with radishes, carrots, and a shallot vinaigrette.

The first two were both excellent dishes, and the pea soup was enjoyable, but the arugula salad was lackluster compared to the other dishes. I had also ordered a coffee to go with the meal that I wasn't particularly impressed with.

Cash only, but, overall, a good experience, and a place that I'd be likely to visit again if not for the fact that the two large steps at the entrance prevent entry, and thus, prevent me from ever going on my own.
author: Johnny W.

description:
A nice little respite in the heart of the city!
 
The coffee is delicious ... and served up in a warm and friendly style.  (Oh so civilized cappuccino with a delicious little shortbread on the plate.) It's European coffee meets Californian quest for localization and quality. 

The cakes and pastries are always to-die-for: rich, moist, comforting.  the space is adorable: quaint and bright with a warm and comfortable interior. 

Yay, yay on a fabulous little shop where one can have a sweet European coffee experience, step out of the street craziness for a few moments, and enjoy.
author: Heather S.

description:
My favorite meal of our whole 9-day trip in SFO & up the coast in Oregon, and we got it within hours of arriving in town. I got the daily toast and a mocha, husband got an iced coffee. We lucked out with minimal seating- a cafe table opened up just as our food came out. The was a focaccia with sweetened marscapone, some stewed (?) fruit (plums or berries, I think) and toasted nuts. Delicious! The server saw that we had to wait and/or had some milk foam to spare, so gave me it to enjoy for a few minutes (how did he know how much I love well-foamed milk?). What a great way to start a vacation! 

I love the parklet outside- but I'm glad I didn't have to try and balance a plate or glass on it.
author: Arah B.

description: Staff is nice, but Takes forever!!! But worth it, if you really want a great cappuccino. After waiting for our tart for 30 min we left...
author: Tanya L.

description:
This place was fiiiiiiine.  The juice was superb and the coffee was pretty good.  The sandwiches we got were WAY overpriced for what they were.  The hardboiled eggs had those gross green-brown circles around the yolks.  The ham was good.  There were 4 leaves of spinach which was a little underwhelming.  Cheese was good.  Croissant was good but they didn't pay much for it.  At $7, the sandwich should be MINDBLOWING.

Maybe we just have a hard time with SF prices after experiencing the bounty and beauty of Chicago.  

Also it's totally cramped and tiny but not impossible to find a seat.
author: Kate W.

description: Tiny menu, uninspiring and pricey. Definitely better options nearby. The place is pretty small too, one table and a bench inside and some tables outside.
author: Carlos M.

description:
Wow so happy I am part of the group of people who have eaten here. THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!! I was there last year for my birthday and had the most amazing breakfast. It was not to big to make me feel like crap all day or to small to where i needed more to get me going. It was just right and it gave me the energy I needed to get my day going. 

The staff seems like a very happy and fun bunch of people. The place is small 2 tables in front and one nice sized family table in the main room. It was fun to sit down and have a real conversation with people and not stair into my phone for 20 mins win I was waiting for food. The menu is different all the time due to the use of local ingredients and whats available. This place will not disappoint you. The coffee is great and I showed up 10 mins before open to a line of 3 groups luckily one of them just got coffee so we got severed fast and friendly and had some great food. 

You need to check this place out! I am flying into SF in a week and this is my 1st stop!
author: Sean G.

description:
I was really excited to try this place because of the other reviews, but was a bit disappointed. 

Me and my roommate split the daily toast and the egg on a biscuit. Everything was cold and the toast was kind of stale. The other ingredients were pretty fresh, and the flavor was pretty good...just couldn't get over the staleness.

Saw the person cutting the fruit pop some in her mouth, practically lick her fingers, and then continue preparing food with her hands. hope she wasn't sick.
author: Lilian K.

description: Being that I am not a local and have not had much to compare this spot with in regards to other places like this in SF, in general this place has good food, freshly made, with fast service and good coffee. I stopped in for a quick breakfast and was looking for more table space but as long as you realize this is more of a take out spot or a place for small parties wanting to sit at the 6-8 person communal table you won't be disappointed! I like that there are new menu options regularly. If I were a local, I'd visit farm:table more often!
author: Erin W.

description:
Finally made a stop here today and tried the infamous toast topped with mascarpone cheese and a variety of fruits. The place is just like everyone mentions-it's tiny! With only 2 tables outside and a communal table inside, this place is like Harry Potter's room. Apparently they change their menu every day and today they only had a quiche, toast topped with fruits and oatmeal. I'll admit it, I was a bit disappointed. The menu sounded boring but the guy who greeted us said everything was really good. So I took the seat outside and shared a quiche and a toast topped with fruits as well as the tcho chocolate mocha. The mocha was delicious and you could taste the tcho chocolate. It wasn't too strong nor was it too light. The mocha was perfect even with no latte art. The toast was what I was looking forward to most. There were strawberries, apples, grapes, oranges and pistachios on top. No berries, no fig, nothing fancy like the other reviewers posted here on Yelp. The toast was this semi thick toasted brown bread, I'm not sure what it was but I highly doubt it was focaccia bread. The sweet cinnamon-ey cheese was lightly spread on top-I secretly wish they added just a little more. The toast itself was about $8. Was it worth it? I'm really not sure... The drive itself from where I live was pretty far and this location is really out of the way. This place is right in the TL area which is really sketch. Parking is definitely tough. Would I come back? Only if someone wanted to go, otherwise I would not crave for this. 

However, I would like to try their boiled egg that everyone has been raving about.
author: Laura T.

description:
I didn't have time to go to Mama's so I went looking for farm:table instead.  Wow... just, wow. I LOVE this place. Yes, farm:table is TINY but it's charming and I'm kind of glad it doesn't seat 100 people just because it would take away from the aura that farm:table is trying to achieve (and wonderfully executes).  Then again, I tend to get lucky and I came in here without waiting for long and snagged the table after I placed my order.  LOVE the decor, friendly service, and GREAT(!), fresh food.

I love their soft egg and green onion on brioche bread with braised pulled pork (also comes with coffee, but I opt for the milk and honey since I'm not a fan of coffee).  Their brioche is delicious bread! It is rich, creamy, and tender. Their over easy eggs... oh, my, gosh. It is easily the best easy eggs I've ever had. The egg white was fully cooked and it fully encased a runny yolk that was just... perfect. Pureed green onion is smothered over the eggs, while the eggs are sitting on a bed of tender pulled pork... and ALL of this is layered on top of the creamy brioche. You bring your spoon in, break the yolk, get some pulled pork and slice through some brioche and you've got an amazing combination.  It is a hearty fulfilling breakfast and it doesn't leave you feeling bloated. Ah-ma-zing.

Their milk and honey is light and well, just right. It's simply warmed milk with a bit of honey.  Simplicity is good for the soul... very good. I also tried their citrus apple juice and it is DEE-LISH. It's light, refreshing, sweet, and just a teeny weeny bit sour... made up of grapefruit, blood orange, apple, orange, and another fruit (I forget). Nonetheless, you've got to try it if you're not a coffee enthusiast! Although I did have their iced coffee and it was also very, very good... Lastly, their vanilla latte -- yum! Foamy, creamy, and silky. I recommend ALL of their drinks here. 

My friends like the whole wheat bread with honey mascarpone spread and green apple bits (they change the fruit topping -- sometimes they use pear). It's also really good but I think the soft egg on brioche is more bang for your buck.

The last time I was here, I came with five other people and we took up the whole (one) table inside. We had breakfast and we were overlooking the cars and pedestrians going by through a windowless opening.  This place is quaint and charismatic, for sure.  Anyway, they change their menus slightly from day to day and from am to pm so go in for a surprise. farm:table holds a special place in my heart and I would recommend it to anyone in SF!

**Cash only**
**Be prepared to order, pick up, and eat elsewhere most of the time.
author: Jenny O.

description:
F ew seats available. A bit of a wait. Limited menu. Sketchy neighborhood.
A nd so why the heck the cinco estrellas?
R eally, it's this simple:  This charming place does what it does well.
M enu of 3-4 dishes is all you'll get -- but it's really all you'll need.

T he Daily Toast I encountered on my visit was lovely...
A  housemade focaccia with vanilla bean mascarpone, blood oranges and almonds.
B ut it was the day's Brunch Special that won me over: 
L ight serving of pulled pork, egg, carrots, parsnips, with chipotle cream!
E ach day the menu switches up -- follow the @farmtable tweets for the scoops.
author: Anthony N.

description:
This isn't your typical heavy and greasy breakfast place. Although I love me some powdered sugar dusted battered french toast, fried eggs, sausage links, hash browns, and all that good stuff, farm:table is a nice break from that. The experience here is fresh, healthy, and cozy. Between my friend and I, we shared two dishes: the hard boiled eggs persimmon tomatoes bacon baguette and the 3 cheese & rooftop herb quiche. We paired our meal with lattes, a regular one for myself, and a latte with almond milk for my friend. We took a seat at the communal table inside amongst other farm:table patrons. 

The cashier was friendly and we didn't wait long for our food. Both lattes were pretty good with my friend's latte being quite tart (still good) from the almond milk. I did not know how to eat the baguette dish. With the boiled eggs being to one side, the bacon and tomatoes in the center, and the baguette drizzled with oil on the other side, I attempted to place the egg/bacon/tomatoes onto the baguette to eat it like a pizza which was semi-successful. Regardless of how I ate this dish, the baguette was crunchy and fresh, boiled eggs + bacon served as the perfect proteins, and the persimmon tomatoes were deliciously sweet. As for the quiche, the cheese, the eggs, the crust = all perfect. I could have eaten a whole quiche dish here. It was paired with a side salad with what I think was composed of butter lettuce and more of those delicious persimmon tomatoes and cherry tomatoes as well. 

In the end, our plates and cups were empty. Portions here are smaller than your average but so am I so it was a perfect serving size for me. Because of these smaller portions, prices may seem on the high end but you are paying for fresh and local ingredients while eating in our fine city of SF. Plus, during my visit, surprisingly, they played good current R&B tunes.
author: Maya S.

description:
A friend decided upon this as a good meet-up spot when he was visiting the city. It was easy to find, and immediately I was worried that it was one of those 2-hour-wait brunch places. It was a beautiful day and somewhere between five and ten parties were hanging around outside, but luckily for us, there were only a few people actually in line. We were easily able to order (we had some sort of sausage special, he had a mocha, and I had the chai latte) and quickly found a spot in the sun to wait for our drinks.

For what I thought was a crowd, we got our drinks quickly. My latte was pretty good! It had a great amount of spice with every sip. We easily found someone to help us get a knife to cut our sandwich in half. The place was pretty small--probably hard to be a sit-down place when the weather isn't as nice, but we lucked out.

Overall it was a pretty simple spot. I enjoyed my drink, had an easy time understanding the setup, the employees were very nice, and service was quick. If I ever happened to be in this part of town looking for coffee (or a latte--I just had to treat myself to that over drip coffee, given the reviews) again, I probably would. It was a good experience--just nothing too blow-my-mind spectacular.
author: Katie V.

description:
get here early. they do run out of the food. Very limited menu, but everything is fantastic. Tiny little place, only one big community table. so cozy up and make some friends. which is exactly what we did while there on Monday, Memorial day. 

There is a very odd looking and slightly awkward to sit on, park let out front. I could imagine it would be better to chill on its grass on a nice day. 

Overall, great experience. Super friendly staff and the food was fannnntastic. will return.
author: Carlynn A.

description: I come here at least once a week and love the daily toast and savory tart. Great macchiatos too. They take a little longer but worth the wait, great egg sandwich too.
author: Allison R.

description:
I went here with my dad and really enjoyed our quick lunch. 

The space is trendy and farmy with an airy, rustic small feel to it. It is small. Luckily we were the only ones there for most of the meal. 

The menu is limited. (There are four items) We ordered three of them for the two of us. The foccacia, fritta (the best thing) and an egg and bacon thing. (would have been better with poached eggs). They did miss our third item for awhile, but all was recovered and fine at the end. 

I really enjoyed myself and if I was closer to the area, can see popping over here often for a read of the paper and a delicious snack.
author: Danielle V.

description: This rating is mainly regarding the extremely unpleasant, unhelpful, and lousy service by the young boy at the counter. It was my first time eating here so I didn't know what to order but I knew I wanted to try the Daily Toast since that's what everyone raves about. In terms of lattes I had no idea what flavors to expect since there are 0 descriptions. I asked the kid at the counter to describe the Pug & Honey and Nutella lattes, but received no help. It was rather annoying. No tip for you kid. The food tasted good, but I would never wait in line for it. The Nutella latte didn't even have a hint of Nutella. Thankfully there was no line. I prob won't ever come back, not worth it.
author: Jen P.

description: Love this place! Love their iced coffee with home-made almond milk. Also their rotating breakfast sandwiches are amazing. If you aren't lucky enough to get a seat at the single large table inside, it's still very nice to sit outside in the parklet.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Options were limited - both on the menu and in terms of seating... I expected more out of the daily toast, given the price and hype from other reviews. The bread wasn't anything special, and it overwhelmed the toppings due to sheer size. Skimpy on the cheese. What's more, it was all hard to eat (the nuts should probably be placed directly on the cheese if you want them to stay put...). 

Stop here for a simple grab-and-go pastry but don't go beyond.
author: Monica O.

description:
Great little place for a brunch!  Had the polenta and loved it - and I hate polenta!!  Small menu for food, but sometimes that means everything is good and fresh.

If I lived around the corner from this place, it would be my first stop every morning.

Good work.
author: Raymond H.

description:
Coming here always seems like an adventure, I never know what I'll see or who I'll run into. Some days, I'll see drug dealers arguing with their customers, or homeless people fighting with other homeless people, or prostitutes knocking on car windows, or people shanking people. People may follow me in their cars giving me shady looks, avoid me because I'll have my "badass" face on, or yell at me because I'm not smiling.

The food has a "luxurious" look to it. You know: fancy looking food in small portions using ingredients you've never heard of before (:

But do not be fooled! One dish is enough to fill you up if you eat slowly.

The juice is some kind of apple and citrus mix, delicious!

There are only two tables outside, and they're usually taken. If you don't feel uncomfortable with the idea of sitting with strangers, you can sit inside.

So not only do I get the pleasure of eating healthy and delicious food, I get to tread through (the safe version of) the projects and experience the excitement of not knowing whether or not I'll come out alive!
author: Elaine N.

description: If I could, I would give this place 3.5 stars. It's got a great vibe, but the food I ordered didn't turn out as good as I was expecting... it was one of their egg croissant sandwiches, but the egg is a hardboiled egg sliced in half. The frittata looked good, but was sold out. Overall, just "aight" for me.
author: Courtney T.

description: This place was a nice gem in the wall. It's super small but their sandwiches are awesome. I looked at all the reviews and was expecting a croissant sandwich. Not going to lie I was pretty disappointed that they only had it on a toasted focaccia bread. Though once I got it yummy. Also, my friend got the daily toast and we decided to do 1/2 and 1/2. I think the daily toast was good but for someone who likes savory food more I can't imagine eating the whole thing. Their coffee was also strong which I love. Overall awesome! My only thing was I think the portions could be a little bigger, but maybe that's because I'm a big eater =P
author: Catherina W.

description: Farm:table is my favorite breakfast place! The small menu changes every so often and you can be 100% that everything here is super fresh. I wish I could eat every meal here!
author: Vicky A.

description: The food was great but the seating was very limited. I'd recommend getting your food to go instead of counting on a table. Their outdoor tables were these strange slanted benches that made it difficult to sit comfortably. The servers were friendly and quick. I got the toast with fresh berries that was light and delicious. It's a little pricey, but not out of the ordinary for SF.
author: Christine B.

description: Fresh! Small menu which is nice. Cute outdoor seating with flowers. I ordered daily toast with apples, bananas, blackberries & pistachios ontop. Honestly so good. Their home made almond milk was delicious in my coffee too.
author: Bonnie N.

description:
What a cute restaurant! Ate at farm:table last weekend and loved it. Teeny tiny hole in the wall in the middle of TL. 

Here's what my boo and I had:
Baguette toast with hard-boiled eggs, sauteed zucchini + onions, bacon, and flowers - Yes, flowers. It was more like a piece of art then breakfast, but everything was cooked to perfection. My only complaint was that it could have been a tad more flavorful but nothing that a little sriracha can't take care of ;) 

Mushroom and leek quiche - Wow! Best quiche that I have ever had. The egg was super fluffy and delicious. 

Definitely a delightful experience and would love to come here again :)
author: Grace Y.

description: I rated the cafe a 5 for the coffee alone.  My latte was beautiful and so damn good.  I got there ~9am on a Saturday and it was so packed! The cafe itself is really small, probably impractical for a larger group.  Luckily they have a wooden bench area outside and I was able to enjoy my latte and almond croissant.   The almond croissant was very average.
author: AC C.

description: Oh my gosh. The Toast was perfection. No I mean really....perfection.   Perfectly crunchy brioche toast, perfectly sweet Marscapone cheese, perfectly ripe sweet juicy fruit. Only problem is I could have eaten four!! I can't wait to try another. Only bad thing REALLY SMALL inside. Like space for 4 people small. Still, you have to try this!
author: Teri F.

description: Delicious and fresh daily fruit toast but quite overpriced. The parklet outside for seating really supplements the tiny indoor space.
author: Janet L.

description: awesome breakfast, i had the croissant with hardboiled egg, ham & cheese and the fruit toast. both were excellent and hearty; my breakfast also became lunch! i took both to go; its small inside but if you get a seat its a cute place to hang. i will definitely be back when i'm in the area.
author: Anu A.

description:
tasty little spot... not a whole lot of offerings but i like there couragous here we are and this is what we do approach.
Been here once and I will come back surely when i'm nearby.
author: Adam O.

description:
Small place but...delicious! Even if you can't get brunch or lunch, make sure you get a cup of the mocha or hot chocolate to go...they put TCHO in it and it's seriously good.

All their food items are fresh California fare, and their coffee is real good. With the little interior and some tables outside, getting brunch there is certainly a great way to start the weekend.
author: Alice C.

description: Nothing looks made to order. Small spot. Juice isn't even squeezed on site. I feel their price point is off for what you get. Otherwise enjoyable.
author: chris t.

description: Decent food prepared fast. Only one table to share with anyone else there. Clear your own table style. Little expensive for the lack of space and service. $7 for a croissant with hard boiled egg and bacon? Too much. It was very tasty but just over prices in my book.
author: Kayla L.

description: This is a great little place to grab a quick bite.  I grabbed breakfast there one morning recently.  Everything is hand made and pretty darn good.  The place is pretty small so having four people in front of you in line will put you outside...not great if its raining but super great if its sunny.  This place is also the kind of place that does not really attract jerks - who knows, maybe they will be a jerk if they get a GMO banana but my point is the people in line are the kind of people who will just start talking to you and help you if you have a question about what to get.  Its a winner.  If I stay near Union Square I will walk up there again and grab breakfast.
author: Sam A.

description:
Now THIS is the way all days should be started. This small little restaurant was packed on a Friday morning but we managed to still snag two spots at the one communal table.

Thanks to their Twitter updates we knew their menu ahead of time. I was read for a hard boiled egg over baguette with carmelized onion, feta, bacon and arugula. Hold the bacon. Holy moly this was fantastic. It had that classic combo of savory and sweet (thanks onions!) that was perfect for breakfast. I also had a little milk and honey. What a great idea! 

This is a great little place to eat some quality food and feel like you are doing something great for yourself. Remember to the check their twitter for the menu ahead of time!
author: Erin C.

description: Fresh localy sourced food always wins my dollar. The egg crosaunt with candied bacon is amazing. Had a bowl of the gluten free cereal with yogurt and berries that was premo too. Quick and easy. Tasty tea to top it off.
author: Kai D.

description:
Colleen C and I headed to this place for breakfast one morning a few weeks ago when we were in SF.  We didn't realize it was such a tiny place with limited seating when we previewed it on Yelp...  it's literally tiny tiny and was extremely hot inside (read: I was sweating upon entering and I don't experience that too often).

We ended up not eating, but instead ordered iced coffees to go.  The iced coffees were awesome, and I'd totally return for a cup of joe, but if you're wanting food or an inviting atmosphere, I do not recommend this place.
author: Gabi M.

description: Overpriced, I'm just a normal person who isn't hipster or into paying 5$ for a cup of juice that is poured from some bottle. The food quality is an A but as a Texan living in California now, this is the most ridiculous pricing I've ever seen
author: Michael D.

description: It is in a nice cozy spot and right across the street from where I was staying. I got there at the perfect time as some people were leaving so I could have my choice of spots at the one table inside. The house coffee was excellent and on the menu was an egg and croissant sandwich with candied bacon and creme fraiche.  A perfect combination. I would definitely go again, but sadly I discovered this place on my last day in San Francisco.
author: Kelly R.

description: Innovative breakfast. Really tasty cereal and "toast"!, fresh bread with unique toppings. Very small with a single communal table inside and several outside. Good coffee, maybe a bit more bitter than I am used to. The pastries looked delicious although I didn't partake.
author: Mark F.

description:
The first morning in San Francisco, I stopped by farm: table. I had their special of wheat toast with cream cheese topped with amazing strawberries and blueberries. He said they called it "Fancy Toast." What really sold me was the guy there saying that the strawberries (from Serendipity Farms) were "exceptional" and boy, he was right! That part of the meal made it special.

farm:table is quite small so if you have a big party, it's probably not the best idea but I can also imagine this place being great for carryout.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
My girlfriend and I stopped by for a quick breakfast before a walk around the city.  While the location is small by any standard, I enjoyed the European feel of the communal table.  Funny thing is, we were actually seated with a group of Brits, an American, and some Germans.  Everyone was happy to share their story and carry on a conversation.  

Onto the food: My girlfriend and I both had the biscuit with egg, applewood bacon, white cheddar, and a dill creme fresh sauce.  We both thoroughly enjoyed the sandwich but were still left a bit peckish.  We split a cheddar jalapeno scone and left with comfortably full stomachs. 

I think this is a definite stop for anyone looking for a delicious breakfast and some random conversation.
author: Anand V.

description: What a neat little place! I truly look forward to visiting places like this, especially when I'm out of town. This is a hidden gem of sorts and I'm not sure I would've gone if I wasn't directed here by the friendly folks at the Prescott Hotel down the street. In short, teeny tiny place with killer food and great drinks. My colleagues and I just got off of a six hour flight, needed coffee and grub and we were extremely happy after diving into our savory tarts and matcha chai lattes. The tarts: huge size for a great price. Spinach, artichokes, goat cheese even with a side salad with amazing dressing. The latte was phenomenal. It was my first try and matcha and it was like a green tea meets cappuccino. Aside from the food and drink being stellar, the service was super friendly as were the other patrons - we're not in Kansas anymore Toto! (Aka NYC where people will shove you out of tiny cafes :-) ) Just an all around great local joint! Kudos to those who run it!
author: Ali C.

description:
Quite possibly the best iced coffee I've ever had. 

Yes, it's $3.00 per cup. And its served in a warm cup. Without a lid. And without a straw. Soooooo, perhaps not all of the iced coffee luxuries one is used to. 

But! This iced coffee is the shit. Made with a dash of cream and a bit of sweet, it's the perfect thing to combat a 90 degree San Francisco day when you happen to have packed only sweaters. 

Small breakfast offerings: The hard boiled egg, heirloom tomato, zuchinni baguette for $7 was mighty tempting, but alas with just one table in the house (this place is teeny) and sweltering temps, I bolted. 

With my iced coffee. Don't try to take it from me.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Cash only, and parking is a nightmare. Sounds like typical SF fare.

However, the food here is amazing! Fresh farm to table (hence, Farm: Table) and portions are filling but not over kill. Juice is even fresh squeezed.

Menus are set based on the day and very limited, so this place may not be for the picky eaters.  If you want fresh delicious food and are not a picky eater, try this place.

There is limited seating, so coming during non-food rush hours is advised.
author: Stef D.

description: An amazing little pigeon-hole sized cafe that serves great pastries especially their egg on croissant. Simple little dish but ever so delish! Definitely a to-go place rather than a dine in place though. Would go back and try the rest of the pastries for sure
author: Jingi A.

description: It was ok. It's s cute place with pretty simple choices but nothing mind blowing. We were pretty underwhelmed.
author: LAIKA K.

description: I just finished my breakfast which was meticulously prepared and delivered. The staff is personable and the artisan style menu is filled with goodies. The point that must be made is that classic soul music e.g. Al Green, James Brown was playing the entire time i was there. I will be back soon!!
author: Trevor C.

description:
Small shack in San Francisco.  Just a couple blocks away from Union Square.  Kind/friendly staff.

The boyfriend and I decided to stop by this place (after yelping) for breakfast before our flight back to San Diego.

Their freshly squeezed house juice is very good, wish it wasn't served in such a small cup!

There wasn't much to order from since their menu was very limited.  Everything was made to order, but nothing we ordered came out hot besides their coffee/espressos.  Everything was room temperature which was a bit of a downside, but their food was still good.

I ordered a bread/toast with sliced peaches, pistachio and mascarpone which was pretty good.  My boyfriend ordered a sandwich with hard boiled eggs, bacon, and cheddar cheese(?)... he said it was good, but it would've been better if everything came out hot and fresh off the grill.

There was just one big table inside the small shack in which we shared with a few other strangers.  We didn't mind... but it did feel a bit awkward while we were eating and they were waiting for their order.

Their staff was so nice, one of them noticed my latte was too foamy and made me a brand new one.
author: Phyllis R.

description: It was the worst place I have ever visited. Daily toast had worm in it and they said the blackberry had a problem. But I won't visit this place ever.
author: Hyejin S.

description: The cereal is a great grab and go option. I wish they had more seating! It would be great to have seating outside and maybe a parklet
author: Carly K.

description: It's a very simple place with a few choices, but the few choices are simply delicious! I had the toast with fresh fruit and a cappuccino!  The place is really small and doesn't have enough seating, prepare to eat while standing up! Definitely worth the walk from Union Square to the Tenderloin!
author: Kiran J.

description:
5 stars for the food. 

Makes me feel like a taster on Food  Network.

I had to take away a star because standing around waiting for 25 mins with no place to sit is not okay with me.

I also need to take away a star for the ridiculously huge table that they cannot fit there. I mean really...if most of your clients are takeout clients that's who you should be accommodating. 

They litterally kept suggesting I wait outside and I wanted to say  ...."Hey...tell King Henry the 8ths table to wait outside".

Lol.

Maybe it time for a bigger location.
author: Chastity C.

description: Farm table has great food but limited menu. The environment is very small but quaint. One might find it necessary to bundle up since it was an open and brisk outside!
author: Sean M.

description: This is place is really just for take-away. There are basically 6 seats and people get it and stay put. Food is great though!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Hi, I have typically enjoyed my farm:table experiences but this morning could have been way better. The quality of the food was good in the end, but we ordered to go and waited 40 minutes and when we were finally brought our order, it was incorrect. Which we didn't realize until we got home because we had to rush home with the food. I understand that it was a Sunday and there typically is a rush, but this experience was a bit disappointing as I talked the place up to my guests...
author: Elaine A.

description: Seriously I'm having a bad morning this place sucks my day back on its path of glory this may seem dramatic but the food is absolutely delicious! Warm milk and honey to die for! And this location is also a Lyft hotspot it's like the gods came together and created the perfect place!!!!
author: Nadege B.

description:
Went there yesterday for breakfast.  I had one of their three ever-changing specials: the bacon chedder quiche, with a small salad.  The quiche was amazing, my only complaint was that it went too fast!  I could have eaten a whole second piece :)  I also had a latte with almond milk.  Loved the heart shape of the foam.  It was delicious.

It is perhaps the smallest place I've ever been to (inside, one communal table that seats about 6 people, and two tables outside that seat 3 each).  Because it was 8 am on a Saturday I was able to grab one of the tables outside.  Otherwise, you should be prepared to take your meal to go.  

I took some pastries to go to share with my boyfriend and friend: got one plain Kouign Amann, one pear one, and one apple pastry.  The Kouign Amanns lived up to the hype here.  They are probably most similar to baklava, but much, much better.  

The place wasn't exactly cheap: it was about $35 for my slice of quiche, a latte and three pastries to go.  Also beware it's cash only.  

If you are a picky eater, check out their daily specials online before going here.  You really only have three choices for an entree.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Dropped in to break our fast when in San Fran doing touristy things.

Food- 5 Stars
Simple and awesome food.

Great quiche and amazing whole grain toast with goat cheese and nectarines that were perfectly (I mean actually perfectly) ripe.

Drinks- 4 Stars
Good strong coffee, a little too strong for some.

Atmosphere- 4 Stars
Hip and tight, like skinny jeans. A little too hot inside, but we just sat outside.
author: Alexi A.

description: You were my first meal in San Francisco. I love you most of all. Cheers, daily bread.
author: Tracy H.

description: Tiny little place with lots of character. The pastries are from a bakery in Oakland and delicious. I chose the cheddar and bacon scone. The Chai Tea Latte had an strange greenish hue to it and was very unsweetened. While I enjoyed the lack of a sugar spike the tea tastes odd and turned my stomach.  Overall it is a nice place to grab something quick and go.  Stick with the coffee.
author: Jeffrey O.

description:
MUST EDIT MY REVIEW.  WAS VERY POLITELY CONTACTED BY FARM TABLE AFTER WRITING THE REVIEW BELOW.  (Sarah, thanks.  That was really nice of you!  We will give it another go when we are in the city.)
What a BUMMER.  So it gets a star because the guy who took our order was really nice, and because the food was good.  And it gets nothing else because of the woman who insisted on berating us from the kitchen (head chef, owner, manager ????? Not sure exactly), was such a strangely unwarranted jerk that it took us from awesome mood to truly terrible mood in the blink of an eye. 
We got to the front of the line and asked a question about the yogurt. Now I know what you're thinking  - "oh this guy is a hold up the line 1000 question pain in the butt".  Nope, I promise. Asked one EASY to answer question. Guy behind the counter answers it right away, lady behind him jumps in with a truly confusing onslaught of breakfast hostility. Weird and a big fat bummer. 
Everything people say about it that is inconvenient is true. Long line, nowhere to sit, very limited menu (three items and some pastries that were really tasty).  It is inexpensive, it is cute, the food is good..... But to be honest, the food would have to be five star great if you wanna act like the "breakfast nazi" while I'm ordering.  Good, but nowhere near the hype. And I gotta give it a low rating because a little kindness goes a long way.... And so does a little hostile unkindness.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Best coffee In SFO!!! And our favorite breakfast place to eat too. 

A really cool little place with soul, whose owners still have a passion for food, and whose costumers are relaxed and friendly. 

Nuff said....
author: North O.

description:
Amazing food with amazing touch of decoration. The building itself is a historical building, that's already something. And the food was simply great. I had this bread with boiled egg and arugula. I like it a lot, it is a HUGE breakfast thou. And the coffee was very rich with aroma. What I like about the place the best is that it only has ONE table. And you ended up sitting next to strangers, but a lot of times you end up talking to them. It is like having sunday breakfast with family, but in this case strangers felt like family. It is a funny thing. Go try it out and you will know what I mean. :) and the staff were very friendly as well. Oh and with the one table thing, unfortunately, this is not a place to get your books read or your work done. It is just eat and go kind of place. But you gotta pick your battle, overall. I think it is sweet.


Update:
We came back a few more times after my first review, and turns out the dish is not consistently prepared. One thing for sure is that the incredient are super fresh and that's always a good thing. But the dish is certainly not delicious. it is just a cool spot. I will still come time to time, but defintely do not agree that the food is amazing.
author: Fung S. O.

description: Excellent breakfast. Great toast and muesli, served with lots of fruit on top. Cozy atmosphere. On the expensive side.
author: J T.

description: Perfect cappuccino consumed on their parklet. Guys working that morning and the croissant sandwich was delicious!
author: Sheri G.

description: Not sure why the Yelp insight says vegetarians go nuts for this place... Or really, why anyone goes nuts for this place. The portions are super small, and options are limited. There was one vegetarian option the day we went. We ordered the savory tart and empanada, which came out to $17. For the price, I expected more. The savory tart just tasted of cheese. Overall, it was a very disappointing experience. Maybe we should have gotten their coffee.
author: Diane K.

description:
One of my fave places in SF.  What a neat concept!  Not for someone who is anti-social.  They have just one big table where everyone sits around (stranger and all).  Chances are very high a stranger will be chatting up with you, so if you can handle social interaction, this might not be the place for you.  

Everything is fresh from what you've probably read snippets of.  
Pros:
- chalkboard menus with changing items everyday
- coffee is that bomb!
- meet new people
- outdoor seating on this cool skateboard ramp looking thing which is nice on a good day or with your pooch

When i visited, this was what motivated me to wake up in the morning.
author: Sammi N.

description: The concept, of course, is awesome and the food is equally good. I got the savory tart, which was very good. My friend got the daily toast and that was also amazing. I love the concept of the daily toast... hope I can find something like that down in LA :)
author: Meagan T.

description:
I could eat here every day.
Fine, fresh, organic simplicity.  
Changing menu every day.
Friendly staff.
Couldn't be cozier.
Affordable (Soup+salad+lychee infused iced tea = $17.00!)
**The way food should be**
author: Angella S.

description:
Great spot to grab a cozy breakfast when you are stuck in the vapid wasteland that is either tourist central or the crack & feces section of Tenderloin. 

Polenta & Bacon was pricey at $9 for the small dish, but the ingredients, prep and friendly staff were top notch.

Iced coffee was delish, and wife's pot of tea was worth the $5. All in all a win. I couldn't bring myself the spend the money on a small meal each week, but for a great little place with dog friendly outdoor seating in...THE TENDERLOIN...you can't go wrong.

Additionally, most items (as informed by waitress) will be gluten free unless they include bread (duh). Great for celiacs, gluten intolerant, oh, and trendy dieters.
author: Ryan A.

description: Stopped in for coffee and a quick breakfast... really wonderful. Top quality very hot coffee for morning coffee lovers. There is outside seating which is where I sat, catching the morning air/sun as I drank, ate,  and read the news. Even if the weather indicates the sun will be out, I'd likely bring a jacket if planning to sit outside during relatively early hours.
author: Ashley T.

description: Loved this quintessential breakfast spot. Ran by the owner and the service is amazing. The food was incredible. We tried the cereal, the savory tart, and the egg croissant - all were amazing! Awesome seating outside in the city. It's a must try!
author: Lindsey F.

description: Nice, small place to get coffee and a bite to eat.
author: Karen G.

description:
What a dud. We had super-high hopes for farm:table. Friends and foodies alike had done nothing short of rave about this brunch spot in the Tenderloin. It is literally one table--one table pressed into a tight corner and a chalk board menu of three, maybe four breakfast/brunch options. An array of baked goods looked good, but I'm glad we didn't waste the calories. SF has better pastries; of this I am sure.

One plus of the small table is that we could see every dish come out--each dainty and just too small. Too small because they were actually tasty and we wanted more; too small because breakfast for two without coffee was over $18 gosh darn it, and for that price you should get a hearty, filling start to your day. The food is good, but sparse, and on teeny plates that works for only the mousiest of appetites. And given the space is too small itself to excel at charming, farm:table is probably best saved for those with big pockets and small stomachs.
author: Josh L.

description: quaint spot! very cute. definitely limited in terms of seating, but so worth it. love the daily toast! a bit pricey for breakfast/brunch, but they do put in a lot of love into the food (especially with the daily toast; it's a mini masterpiece)!
author: Carol C.

description: Julien's critique of the new bozo barista confirms my own experience. I've been going to FT since they opened. It's under new ownership: A couple from northern Minnesota who know nothing about local coffee culture and insist they're not going to learn anything. The irony about the bozo barista's attitude is that he couldn't make an espresso drink if his life depended on it. I let him serve me twice. I could barely get it down the first time. The second try was an improvement: mediocre. Yes, these $15/h baristas who fancy themselves elitists are laughable, especially when they're serving someone who makes a $100k a year. This was a neighborhood place when it began. Nobody in the neighborhood goes there anymore.
author: peter V.

description:
Quite possibly one of the best cappuccinos I've had. Very tasty..milk proudly frothed...excellent beans with just the right amount of flavor. 

We ordered the Brioche with poached eggs and pesto...it was quite delish. One of, if not the most sensible meals we've enjoyed while up here in SF. 

Great place with patio tables outside and an interesting wooden architectural platform you can sit on while eating. 

Staff was all smiles and very prompt. It's small inside, but indeed cozy in an awesome way! COME HERE
author: Brian P.

description:
This place is so tiny and cozy, it's making me feel like I've invaded someone's living room. You know the feeling when you're tagging along your partner to a family event, and you don't know anyone? It's kinda like that. Everybody there knows everybody else and I was the n00b.

It's not a bad thing, mind you. That just means that the ladies working there are friendly. And they are! It's nice to be treated with a smile at 7.30 in the morning.

Regarding the small space and the communal table, I really don't mind it. As long as I get my coffee and not be disturbed while I play diner dash on my iPod.

I haven't tried the food, but the latte was delicious.
author: Ari C.

description: Daily toast - so called because it changes every day, but also because you will want to eat it every day. Not sure what they put in their mascarpone spread - maybe crack (or probably just a lot of sugar) - but holy shit it's good. Seating is limited to a communal table (great if you want people to watch you taking aerial shots of your food) or two small tables outside (great if you want even more people watching you take pictures of your food). There's also some weird angled geometric blocks on the street that I think we're meant to be seats? But try and sit on one of them and you'll realize that the sharp angles offer little support for your ass.
author: Emily L.

description: Good coffee... decent food with a limited menu. I had the egg croissant with candied bacon and ordered the daily toast to-go. Although the food was yummy, it was nothing particularly extraordinary. The interior is cute but super cramped and tiny inside. We ended up sitting outside at one of their small tables.
author: Georgia K.

description: Ehhh. It was a cute little place, but if your hungry for good food I would pass. Small menu, no options.. you can chose from three. (Toast)(croissant)( quiche). There is no seating except for a two person table outside and some weird ass benches I think we're ment to sit on, but they curve in and honestly were worthless. The service was rude and in to much of a hurry to care.
author: Taylor W.

description: Farm:Table is right across from my apartment and I go here several times a week. The daily toast is killer and they use TCHO chocolate in their mochas. So good!! They also have a really nice tea selection from Red Blossom Tea Company, local to SF. Seating is very limited, but the communal table inside is cozy and a great way to meet friendly regulars. Definitely check out this farm-to-table cafe and enjoy all the fresh,local ingredients.
author: Amanda L.

description: Stopped by here one morning while in San Fran.  What a great place!  I had the ham croissant with boiled eggs and a cafe latte.  They were both tremendous!
author: Jason V.

description:
HEAVEN on EARTH!! How do I live a block away and I just found this place?!?! 

Atmosphere... Adorable .... Little sidewalk spot with adorable tables outside and planters full of flowers and succulents. 

The service..... Impeccable. Friendly. Cool. SF people 

The food. This is my new favorite brunch spot. Egg frittata and their daily toast are to die for. Healthy, beautiful and unique!! 

I can't wait to come back!!!
author: Laura D.

description:
(See pretty pic)

Just writing an update to note that they're taking up a notch and beautify the food by adding a couple flowers onto the vibrant colour green. These people just know what complementary colours are and with the trendy flower decorations!!
author: T L.

description:
It is exactly what it says it will be. It's a micro-restaurant with a menu that changes daily. It uses fresh, high-quality ingredients mixed with what must be love. I can taste the love. Try it. When you go, take a bite and then make sure that you ruminate over the flavors slowly and then try to take some air in from your mouth and out your nose while it's in your mouth so you can sample all the notes and then... or is that wine? Anyway. I think it still applies.

You're not going to get a gut-busting greasy diner breakfast and, yes, it is "not cheap" (if you consider anything over a $3.50 plate of potatoes, eggs and bacon, or anything without a dollar menu not cheap). The price is decent and worth it.

It's very simple.

- You don't get a heaping portion
- But it is enough and it is mostly very tasty
- The space is small and sometimes you have to share
- The prices never exceed $8-9 a portion
- The coffee is good
- The menu changes
- The ingredients are fresh
- You can follow them on Twitter
- They have biscuit Sundays

THE END
author: Jess C.

description: Great little place. Not much seating but delicious food and coffee. We had the egg croissant, a latte and the lavender latte. All of them were great
author: Jonathan F.

description: I don't know what happened, but this place has really gone down hill in the last year and a half. I think there was an ownership or chef change. Anyways, the pastries aren't as good anymore, the daily items are never as good, and the service isn't as friendly and up beat.
author: Yan L.

description:
solid brunch. the hubby and i loved our sweet and savory selections: the frittatta with snap peas and a side of mixed greens as well as the strawberry bread pudding.  

tiny place but the communal table is cute.
author: Helen Y.

description: Great coffee and food! Really nice staff too. There's s cool little park thing out the front which was a really nice touch. But... There were roadworks right out front (June 10th) that were deafening. Otherwise would be 5 stars.
author: Julia B.

description: Lovely, tiny SF breakfast/brunch spot. Food is excellent and service is prompt. I wouldn't recommend coming with more than one other person as it will be almost impossible to find seating for just myself! Great little spot in the city if your looking for a tasty am treat.
author: Kaci P.

description:
Love unique little spots... you need to know.

 - it's teeny tiny. Get there early, don't go in groups.
 - There is one "farm" table inside with benches. Be nice make friends.
 - Almond milk lattes... Homemade almond milk. Only place I've ever been that offered that. Awesome.
 - They use local farmer ingredients, only 3-4 items on the menu change daily.
 - Frittata looks awesome!
 - Surroundings seem sketchy in the early morning. Walk with purpose.

One idea to improve...
 - Needs to open earlier. 7:30 isn't early enough for me, but I'm from the midwest and I understand this is a small business so that might not be possible.
author: Jessica S.

description:
This restaurant is one of the many hidden gems in the city.  It's a small, quaint restaurant that serves up a changing menu of fresh, tasty, and feel-good meals daily.  It cant fit more than a handful of people at one time, but at farm:table, that is, without a doubt, part of the charm.  It's independent operation, chalkboard menu, rustic decor, and friendly staff all earn points in my book. 

For brunch on our first day of vacation, we got hard boiled eggs on slices of baguette with mascarpone and a mushroom-onion tapenade puree type sauce.  It was delicious.  We also have the pea and herb frittata which was yummy but could have used a little more seasoning....and there was no salt to be found.  To drink, we ordered the fresh juice of the day which was a blood orange grapefruit apple cider that was unique and very refreshing.  And to top it off, they serve it in a mason jar - fun and definitely keeping with the atmosphere of the restaurant. 

At farm:table, you really feel like you're on the farm, in your family's kitchen, getting served fresh, local, delicious homemade dishes.
author: Ian W.

description: Tiny place with a tiny menu, but definitely worth it. The everyday toast was delicious. The bread and sweet mascarpone match well with the fresh fruit. This is a refreshing alternative to the typical brunch places.
author: Patricia D.

description: While on vacation in San Francisco I was on the hunt for good coffee and fresh breakfast. What caught my eye was their house made almond milk so I went to give it a try. I slowly navigated my way through the tenderloin district to find a red sign and red door greeting me with gourmet delights and superb customer service. As I was waiting in line(of which was quickly accumulating) my tongue was tantalize by the flavors mentioned daily change in menu. I proceeded to order myself and almond milk cappuccino and an order of their daily text of which included the ginger marscapone fresh fruit and pistachios. After short scenic wait upon their outside sitting area I was brought out my delicious cup of coffee and a beautiful piece of toast art museum worthy. I thought it couldn't get any better until I took a bite and was transported to heaven.  Farm and Table is AMAZING AND BUCKETLIST WORTHY :) I will be back the next time I am in San Francisco. Thank you guys for great food and superb service!!!!
author: Marcia M.

description:
I am a 100 pound girl who paid almost $10 for a sandwich with only three items (bacon, goat cheese, leafy thing) on what looked like wonder bread (I'm sure ii was super organic fancy pants white bread.) and left feeling FAMISHED.  The two other people who tagged along were also extremely disappointed and I felt bad for hyping the place up before actually trying it.  I heard the menu was small, but seriously: one soup, one sandwich, and one salad. 

It's also cash only and TINY, like less than half the size of Brenda's.  

I might come back for the coffee but don't expect to be satisfied by the food, their prices or their seating.
author: Jenn C.

description: Love this lil nook! Great coffee, small menu but solid food. Recommend: TenderNob, Egg on Crossiant, and the Tart of the day. Really small spot so on weekends especially there isn't much space to leisurely go about your morning routine w/o glaring eyes and people hovering your table or seat, so get comfortable on the oddly designed Parklet out front.
author: Asia L.

description:
Came here for a light brunch on a Sunday and had a great experience. Farm table is a tiny hole in the wall in Lower Nob. They serve a couple coffee drinks, several tea's, three main entrees (at least when I went) and a couple pastries. We arrived just as they opened so we didn't have to fuss with a line but this place quickly filled up and there was a line going out the door in no time.

The food was great, right sized portions, great ingredients and good prices. We ordered the daily toast, which is what Farm Table is known for so this is a must get, and an egg sandwich on a croissant. The daily toast switches up so it doens't make a lot of sense to review my particular version of the order but generally the daily toast is literally toast with fresh fruit. Doesn't sound like much but I was pretty pleased. Ours was foccaccio bread with homemade marscapone attoped with strawberries, apple slices, kiwi, and orange. The egg sandwich was your standard egg sandwich but still good. 

Service was good a little bit better than your standard coffee shop but don't think you're going to get world class service here. There just honestly isn't enough space for that. Which brings me to my next point. Farm table is a tiny establishment with one communal table inside and a couple tables/chairs outside. Your best bet is to carry and go. 

Overall, great place and a nice little find in lower nob. Definitely pick up a coffee/tea and a pastry if you're looking for a little treat. Otherwise treat yourself to the daily toast if you've got a couple minutes and they've got an empty seat for you. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description:
Haven't eaten here yet but had to put a comment on here.  If and when that ever happens, I might change my rating.

My BF yelped this place for a late Sunday lunch and to our surprised as well as disappointment, it was closed.  It was 2:30 and closed.  WTH?!

We live in the peninula and to drive all the way to downtown SF to try out this place is no laughing matter.  If they want our business as well as many other patrons, they need to update their website and on yelp.
Maybe also open more later than 2?.........
author: Angela L.

description:
Breakfast review...
- Sweet potato/carrot cake, soft egg and pancetta= best on the menu!
- Mocha=excellent; uses 60% cocoa dark chocolate (ask for extra hot)

Pros:
