rustic, intimate sf cafe vibe, A-MAZING food!!

Cons:
The wait, speed, and limited eating space (not practical for party's of 4 or more) 

The service, however, was very amicable when they are not too busy and they even offered a complimentary coffee due to the wait my first time there.

Overall, a must go to get a taste of SF charm.
author: Cesar R.

description: Fresh food, great coffee and tea drinks, welcoming staff. A must go if you are in the Union Square area.
author: DeeJaee B.

description: The daily toast was amazing , the mascarpone cheese was a win combination with the fresh bread and cut fruit . The iced coffee was perfect as well , not too sweet. Service was friendly , but took a while to get my order to go .
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Stopped by here in the morning for some coffee and a pastry. 

I got a latte with almond milk and it rocked. I also got a Mexican wedding cookie, which unfortunately was not good. Really dry. 

Stick to the coffee!
author: Cindy B.

description: Wonderful food, fresh delicious, needs a bigger space but that is a good problem to have. Pastries were phenomenal, I crave them still a month later
author: Chad R.

description:
farm table is so adorably cute, chill, and cozy but sadly that also lends to some major set backs if you come at the wrong time. With only one table, and a tiny one outside, it can make it super hard to snag a table. Thankfully my friend and I came right at the end of breakfast, so we were able to eat with only one other person at the table. It's cool how they switch out their menu every day, but that also makes it hard for a picky eater like myself to decide when to come or what to order. I finally settled on pears on rye minus the cream cheese. Unfortunately the pears were softer then I like, and even if it had the cream cheese, I felt the concept was kind of simple for a $7-8 dish. I also tried some of my friend's almond milk latte, but I wasn't really a fan. Especially considering its almost $5 for a tiny cup. 

Despite my lack of enthusiasm for the food, the service was impeccable, and the guy who took our order was really patient and helpful in helping us decide what to order. He even anticipated that I would want some butter with my bread which was nice. And I like the coziness of the place, and staring out the window. Maybe next time I'll just stop in for a coffee though.
author: Sarah S.

description: It was a unique experience for us.  Enjoyed the food and lattes :) Limited choices but good ones, just wish there were more seating options.  Would surely visit again if in the area.
author: Krishma D.

description: Amazing!!! This is a very small but very cute breakfast place. The egg on croissant was unbelievable (I had mine with no cheese and added avocado- yum!!) and the house juice was so fresh and delicious!! loved my meal!
author: Angela N.

description:
First note - This is a counter with one table inside and a couple of tables outside. I wouldn't be surprised if the tables were always taken!

It's a fun place, good coffee and good food - both prepared with attention and care. Well worth checking out if you want something with healthy ingredients on the go!
author: Guillaume O.

description:
The egg sandwich was amazing and I will totally go back for it. I was not a fan of the Frittata. Those were pretty much the only two options on the menu for brunch.

It took a really long to time to get one sandwich and one frittata and the portions are very small. We were lucky to get a small table outside and it happened to be a beautiful day but lack of seating is annoying as well as their serving and their service.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
Stood at a tiny table outside this place. I think that everything at this establishment was accidentally scaled down by 40% average human size. The food, the tables, the interior, the menu- all were too small for comfort. 

The plus 1 star was for the croissant sandwich, which was tasty, but not satisfying. It could be though, for someone that eats 7 meals a day. But not for average me. 

Also, I trusted Yelp and came to this place with my 2 visiting Aussie cousins. One of which was upset over the attitude and rudeness of an employee here. Her croissant sandwich had yet to show even after I was done with mine (she ordered one Aussie cousin behind me), so she inquired at the register. The employee then insisted that her order had already been carried out. Which it hadn't, obviously. My cousin finally got her darn croissant after what became a sort of heated customer-to-employee confrontation. 

In fear of bad customer service and tight spaces, I wouldn't come back here again.
author: An L.

description:
Amazing breakfast on the last morning of my mother-daughter weekend! 
Came on Sunday around 8:30am and had no wait.  Ordered the egg croissant and daily toast to share- both were ridiculously fresh and delicious!!!!  Friendly staff and even gave me a discount on coffee after I guzzled my latte!
Will most definitely be back on our next trip to SF!!
author: Kris H.

description:
The food is really fresh and the menu is seasonal. 
I knew this place is small but was taken back at how small. If the weather is poor and sitting outside is not an option, it will hold six to eight at best. I went solo, so no biggie here but you could see folks faces after they order that they may not sit. As the universe works in mysterious ways - everyone seems get a seat perfectly timed.
Great coffee too!
author: Scott R.

description: As a Seattleite, I can be very Opinionated about coffee. Farm:table is up there with the best. Add to the experience an incredible fresh and tasty cereal and yogurt, and you have a magical combination for a great start to the day
author: Zachary D.

description:
Love this place, been going here on and off for almost 2 years.  There's no place like it.  At first I couldn't justify the price for the amount but later realized that it was way worth it.  Quality over quantity.  The ingredients are yes, very simple and looks easy to make but everything is made with care using using fresh and quality products.  The last time I came here I had the hard boiled eggs w arugula, bacon, and goat cheese on toasted brioche and a latte made with their homemade almond milk= about $11 Deeeeelicious! 

I wished I could come here more often but it's ok because I know I'm always in for a treat when I do.  Plus the staff are super nice :)
This place is tiny but cozy and expect a bit of a wait, definitely not the place to come if you are starving.  You're better off going to Dottie's for a meal.
author: Lily M.

description:
Farm table?!? What a joke... Walking into the one room "restaurant," I was immediately struck by how misleading the name of the place is especially with store-bought pastries, a counter not a kitchen where the menu items were prepared...the lox and eggs were served with romaine lettuce on an undercooked not even toasted ciabatta roll did such a disservice to appetizing. And the "homemade" yogurt had store bought cereal mixed in, totally uninventive.

The squatters wouldn't even share the one indoor table so I had to sit outside in their cafe seating while dump trucks loaded garbage for the entirety of my dining experience.

I definitely don't recommend this place and want to caution those categorizing it as a restaurant... No thanks.
author: Jess K.

description: Amazing and delicious. I went here by myself to kill some time before work in the morning and ordered the toast. Ohmygod it was perfection and I can't even explain why. Everything about it was tasty and perfect and the fruit on top- sweet and fresh. Just get it. I proceeded to eat my toast on the tiny little communal table and a girl with a baby kitten sat next to me.. I started my day eating delicious healthy toast and playing with a precious little kitten. That is a first impression if there ever was one
author: Kim S.

description: Great frittata (I think it's always gluten-free). It's dense and filling. They make their own almond milk, which is great (though, sadly, I can't even do almond milk... so I kind of wish they had coconut milk, too). Tasty coffee and super-cute but tiny seating area that's perfect for a quick bite. I've visited here many times when I'm back in town playing tourist after having lived in SF for many years, and it's been lovely each time. The last star would come in for coconut milk or another gluten-free breakfast option. I'm asking a lot, I know, but I can dream...
author: Diane S.

description: Very good quality food. Definitely not the single $ as noted. More like $$ (at least) for a full meal since the portions are small.
author: Donny S.

description: Don't mind the wait, or lack of seating, or the simplicity of the menu. You came here for the taste of your food. It's worth it.
author: Yan L.

description: I'm in your neck of the woods now, farm:table, and I'm more stalkerish than ever.  I love your coffee.  Marry me.
author: Diane N.

description: Can't beat fresh and simple. I would have their daily toast and egg and ham croissant everyday if I had my way. Easily accessible from Union square with a short bus ride.
author: Jiahui Y.

description:
The Verve coffee that they serve is excellent, the place is charming (brick red and dark wood, slightly rustic) and my cookie was fantastic.  The menu is very limited and changes daily.  During my visit they had a baguette topped with eggs, cereal, and bread pudding. They also had a pastry case with a few items (Meyer lemon bread, breakfast bread, 2 types of cookies) and one tart (coffee pecan) on a cake pedestal. You can buy bags of coffee ($10 and up) and Firebrand baguettes.

* Rangur lime & cardamom cookie ($1): Thin, crispy, the right amount of sugar and salt, divinely scented, truly delicious
* Baguette w/ hard-boiled eggs ($6.50):  There were three small slices of baguette, three halves of hard boiled eggs, sautéed cold mushrooms and onions and a sprinkling of feta cheese crumbles.  The flavors were nice (and simple) but the stack of bread and egg was too tall to bite into simultaneously (very annoying), the portion was small...and the food was cold.  The crust of the bread was so chewy that you had to bite into it sideways.  For $6.50, I expect a little more effort, including not offering something so tall that you can't bite into it (and/or they baked the bread, they raised the hens that laid the eggs, they heat up the food, they add a side salad).

I don't understand places like farm:table that don't make espresso drinks with non-fat or lowfat milk. That COMPLETELY annoys me.  Non-fat milk doesn't ruin a good cup of coffee and I actually don't like full fat milk.  They're not customer friendly in other ways including how they only accept cash and you have to get your own cookie from the pastry case.  Uhh, would it be too much effort for them to get my cookie for me?  For those prices, they should get my cookie and wrap it up with a bow.  Don't expect to find a seat - there's one big communal table and two small tables outside.

Even considering the quality of their offerings, it's overpriced and customer unfriendly.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I was there on a Sunday for what the tweet advertised was "biscuit sunday" (sadly no detail description as I will give below) I do wish they gave more detail on their twitter page...as this is not in my neighborhood, so i'd like to know the selections before I schlep.

Basically they offered 3 or 4 things all with biscuits:
Biscuits with sausage gravy & peppers $8
Biscuit benedict with Salmon $9
Biscuits with goat cheese and figs (maybe almonds too I think) $8
a biscuit sampler with jelly (not sure if this was a few biscuits or not) $6

I had the biscuits with Gravy, ($9.14 with tax) I must say it was YUMMY (albeit small-ish), but, $9.14 was a steep price, as I am currently unemployed.  if I had steady work, I might not have minded for it sure was a QUALITY, if not quantity breakfast.  Also I did ask (sweetly) if it was at all possible to add a poached egg (I spied the poached egg on the benedict and it looked great but I don't eat fish..)   The cashier hesitated and almost said yes, but the lady a few inches behind her who does the cooking said "no sorry" I completely understood since the place is small and specialized and who knows what kind of mutiny the customers might have if they saw me chowing down "off the menu"  

I will be back once I have a job.
author: Amy W.

description: Farm:Table serves fresh food from a small menu and gourmet coffee/other caffeine options from an extensive menu.  The establishment is extremely small with almost no seating and is definitely one of the better coffee stops in the area.
author: Daniel J.

description: The food and place might be adorable and good, but having to wait more than 45 minutes for Toast is not worth it!!!
author: Gaurav C.

description:
Nice little charming place. I initially headed out for Dottie's but the long line outside changed my mind and I decided to try out farm:table. I am glad I did. 

I had their daily toast made of German rye, mascarpone, peach and almond.and completed my breakfast with their traditional love cappuccino.

The place is tiny and may not be able to handle large groups but if you are looking for a peaceful place to start your day in San Francisco, look no further :)
author: Sujit N.

description:
So I read all the Yelp reviews, and was craving some good breakfast. I walked to this place in the rain since the reviews were SO GOOD. I walked in and the place was smaller than my bathroom. There is 1 table (but its SF so I was used to that by then). However, the prices are pretty ridonculous. A cup of juice (like 5 ounces) was $4. I ordered a bagel sandwich...and to my dismay all of these sandwiches were pre-made, sitting as "decorations" on the counter. And no they did not microwave them. what. the. flip. Mind you, these had bacon and boiled eggs on them. Not good cold.

People were nice. It was homey. But pricey, not-so-fresh...etc.
I suggest Westcafe in Oakland for a lively breakfast.
author: Nadia L.

description: This was a little piece of heaven while I was in San Francisco on a business trip. Seating is limited, but if you are alone and don't mind a community table you will be fine. I had the daily toast one morning- it was just as delicious as it was beautiful. The next morning I had the croissant with no meat, and the happily substituted avocado for me. Also, the green matcha chai is to die for. Now that I am back home, I really miss this place. I would have eaten here every day if I could.
author: N R.

description: Best breakfast place we've been to in a long time! We had 3 out of the 4 specials and they were all equally good. Will definitely come back!
author: Teresa C.

description: The food was fantastic but just a heads up that it's not a sit down restaurant. You order at the front counter and there is literally one table inside, and 2 on the sidewalk. The menu is as short as it gets too - you basically have a choice between a breakfast sandwich or toast. But like I said the food is great. Next time Id probably hit this place on the way out of town and take it to go. Eat it in the park.
author: Danae A.

description:
Amazing little (tiny!) cafe in the Tenderloin. Reasonably priced, and one of the best toasts I've ever eaten. 

Pros:
- Delicious & fresh food
- Interesting set up
- Outdoor seating

Cons:
- Menu doesn't change often
- Can be hard to get a seat
author: Sam P.

description: Simple and flavorful menu. My breakfast go to.  House cereal is amazing if you are going for something light! Great house specialities: TENDERNOB. It's tiny inside, so enjoy the parklet outside:)
author: Cristi B.

description:
A tiny, quirky, rustic breakfast and lunch spot serving tiny, quirky, rustic portions of simple honest ingredient-focused food, prepared in a mostly capable, no nonsense way.  Arugula salad with marinated vegetables and goat cheese was just like it sounds, made special with good olive oil and very fresh tasty greens.  The iced tea was super-delicious but small, expensive, and no free refills.  A homemade pastry was delicious.  Savory bread pudding with soft egg was very naturalistic.  Fritata with camelized onions was ridiculously salty from the onion pan, and texture was only so so.  Portions are ladies-who-lunch size, you want to eat a buffalo burger next door at Pearl's when done, but mostly the prices are moderate and ingredients good so it's a square deal.

The decor is basically the open kitchen behind the counter.  Seating and lines can be a problem, there's one small communal table inside and two small metal tables on the sidewalk.  As of this writing they're building a super-cool looking pavement parklet on the street, which will probably triple the seating capacity and make it a nice spot on a warm afternoon.

Overall, it's in the neighborhood gem category, not special occasion.
author: Gil S.

description: This is a tiny cafe that serves a few delicious items. It's not a full kitchen, they cook in a large toaster oven and what they do serve, they serve well. The coffee is strong and tasty, and their smaller portioned foods are really good.
author: Jack L.

description:
Simplicity is the key to Farm:Table's success. The menu is changed daily and foods are offered and prepared based on what is locally available. What a fantastic idea!

When I walked in for lunch the menu was apple themed. I had the option of an apple salad, apple cobbler and apple sandwich with smoked ham on a ciabatta roll. Of course I chose the latter and was extremely satisfied with my decision. 

Upon ordering I sat down at a quaint little table with other customers who were dining in. Be prepared to wait for a seat because this cozy spot only seats about 8 people. 

A big clean pitcher of berry infused water was on the table for people to wet their whistles while they waited. In no time at all the food was prepared and scarfed down by yours truly. I would love a lunch spot like this in Seattle where I could enjoy great food and an ever changing menu. 

Final note: Cash only! There's an ATM down the block so come prepared with green.
author: Katy H.

description:
Nice and friendly staff, with menu updated daily on the blackboard, and twitter.com/farmtable At first I thought all the space was taken up by a big group inside, but I later realized that it was actually a communal table that everyone shared.  Cozy and inviting, though it could feel very cramped.  Menu selection was limited, but the food was decent. Egg salad sandwich was crunchy and delicious bread pudding and latte.

Speaking of communal tables, I still haven't find one that's comparable to Le Pain Quotidien http://www.yelp.com/biz/le-pain-quotidien-beverly-hills#hrid:Ggoko4qUJW1mOrr3UWQDBA (in LA) yet.  

Nevertheless, FarmTable is a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Carina N.

description: I will preface this by saying I walked 2 miles with my 5 yr old to get to this restaurant AND I was pretty hungry. I was irritated because the staff seemed nice but not too accommodating. I was trying to figure out something for my son but I couldn't stray from the menu. I also think it's important to let everyone know this is a super small space with very limited seating. I would recommend grabbing food and taking it to go. Despite my irritability, I got the daily toast and it was delicious. The fruit was fresh and I liked the mix of cheese and fruit.  I also got the iced coffee and I was not a fan but I like a sweeter coffee. If I would've been more prepared on what to expect I would've enjoyed my experience more.
author: Kelli S.

description:
On my Top Ten Favorite Cafes!

Yay! So glad my sister moved to this neighborhood because now I have a good excuse to visit farm:table. I've had some of the best lunches I can remember here. Delicate, simple, light, creative. I always think of that special treat I had, as their menu changes daily, its never the same, yet always prepared with the same spirit. Fresh, inventive, vegetarian-friendly. It only adds to their great qualities that they make a perfect cappuccino, and serve their house juice, which I highly recommend.
author: Janel A.

description: Great food, the relatively small menu guarantees that they aren't trying to do everything at once, rather they just stick to delivering several excellent quality dishes at affordable prices. Friendly staff, welcoming environment, and delicious food that is beautifully presented. Reminded me of small cafés I've been to in Europe. Coffee was also delicious. Highly recommended for breakfast or brunch.
author: Michal B.

description:
So I'm back in the city where I first started my career in banking (via North Carolina) after many years of moving around and working for other institutions.....another merger and here I am again.

I love this town....sunny, cloudy, rainy, foggy...summer, winter...blah, blah, blah...folks are nice, laid back and just feels like the south without the accents and mullets (I'm from the south I can write that one *grin*)

So after arriving in the mid morning I had a VERY fast cab ride into the city...I mean the guy was doing 85 mph...So fast I couldn't type on my blackberry.  

Though it was 11:15am, my body said 2pm NC time, so it was time to get some lunch.  I read a few reviews about farm:table and decided to ask about it at the concierge's desk at the Hilton......older gentle man behind the counter.....

"Can I help you?"
me:  "Yes, any recommendation on farm:table for lunch?"
concierge: "where?"
me:  "you know...a few blocks up on Post?"
concierge:  "never heard of it?"
me: "yes, I can see that..."
...cannot believe this guy doesn't know his own "hood" so-to-speak???

So I just headed up there anyways and was surprised...not in the fact that place is tiny just that is was a great little place to have lunch...hang out and have some tea and enjoy an hour.

On the menu today was the Fig ginger chutney ham sandwich (on a baguette).  After I ordered I sat down with my pot of tea...read the NY Times on the table which had a cute little plate of turnips in the center.  This is the one and only table and a community one at that which I adore.

The sandwich was good and as I ate it I watched one of the staff as they tweeted the menu to update their fans and their website in real time....very cool.

A great place and probably one I'll hit a few times for lunch while working in the city this week.
author: Michael E.

description: Kind of overpriced for what it is, but I guess that's passable since it's really the only breakfast place in the area. The egg croissant sandwich really was delicious, but I wouldn't pay for it again. Their cold brew is a particularly strong, bitter blend, so their default preparation (with sugar and milk) probably tempers that a little.
author: Kelisha M.

description:
breakfast

food: daily toast. the fruits were sweet and tasted fresh. whatever spread they were using were amazing. the bread was toasted enough to have slight crunch. it was kind of hard to eat though. all the fruits were falling off the toast and you have to pick up after yourself every bite.***4/5

service: it took a long time to get my order. maybe a fresh batch was made for me. who knows. for what i ordered, it doesnt warrant that long of a wait. ***3/5

atmosphere: very homey. it has a small table by the counter and a few tables outside the store front. it can get busy as i witnessed and people had to take their orders to go. ***4/5

value: a tad expensive when you think about it. at the very end, its a piece of toast with fruits. but it is sourced locally and being in sf, it sounds about right. it was tasty, but i definitely try something else next time. ***3/5
author: Andy Z.

description:
Awesome breakfast spot! 

Everything here is home-made and super delicious. Came here three days in a row before going to work. Love that they had almond milk and home-made cereal.
author: James Michael S.

description: Two words: Daily Toast. Read the reviews and you might wonder why all the hype over a piece of toast. Then you order, take a bite, and understand.
author: Todd W.

description: After seeing pictures of the delicious food on yelp, i decided to give this breakfast a try on one of my trips to San Francisco. I walked up and was shocked at the size of the location. It only had about 3 customers and was unable to accommodate my party of 3. They're was barely enough space to enter. And there was only like a couple of food options. Its probably a good option for to go orders but if you want to sit down and eat breakfast with others than not a good place. We ended up going to a breakfast joint a Couple of blocks down....
author: Mimi H.

description:
So, I'd have given this place 5 stars, because I love the interesting daily variety of options. Fruits + veggies are fresh. Staff is pleasant (don't ask, but the way they operate reminds me of those family-run apple orchard farms that sell cider and donuts; it feels local, perky, and countryside-like).

Minus 1 star for the space. Be prepared to share your table [and your embarrassing stories] with 1-2 other parties.
author: Eva G.

description: Amazing! Had the Tendernob, espresso and steamed milk, and daily toast, with fresh fruit, pistachios, and mascarpone. BF had egg on croissant. It was all fresh and delicious, staff was fun and pleasant, good service. It's made to order, so takes a few minutes for your order, but do we need to rush through everything in life? We sat at the community table and enjoyed the moment.
author: Cheryl F.

description:
Albeit incredibly "cozy" (see: cramped) the food being made in that tiny kitchen, for those tiny plates, packs some big taste. The portions look/are small, but in my mind they are actually what portion servings should be. Fresh, whole foods are always more filling anyhow. 

For brunch, I got a cream cheese frittata and my friend got pulled pork with a poached egg. Both were fantastic, complimented by the best iced coffee I have ever had. We were lucky to enjoy our food on a sidewalk table. If you feel to claustrophobic to sit inside, and no outside seating is available, never fear! Looks like a street seating structure is near completion, meaning more room for hipsters of the TL to get their grub on.

Only draw back to a place this small is waiting on the food if it gets busy. The frittata takes about 10 minutes to make, and mine was dropped before it ever got out of the kitchen. So I waited 20 minutes on my food and wasn't given anything in compensation. I was at least expecting an offer for a free iced coffee :-/
author: Raquel C.

description:
This may be the best breakfast I've ever had in my life.  The menu is not extensive, and the place is tiny (groups, be prepared to eat outside,standing up), but the food is creative, well thought out, fresh, and comes together perfectly.  

I was in SF for work and came here 2 mornings in a row (I almost changed my 6am flight on day 3 just to be able to make one last stop on my way out of town).  The first day, I had the hard boiled egg on brioche with dill cream and pickled beets.  Oh.  My.  God.  The second, I had the savory steel cut oats with soft egg, homemade pancetta, salsa verde, and some sort of shaved, hard cheese.  Both meals were to die for, as was their homemade citrus juice and delicious espresso drinks.

Farm:table had a nice mix of tourists and locals, so worth a stop no matter what category you fall into.
author: Sandy B.

description: The food here is quite amazing considering it comes from that tiny kitchen. I do wish there was more space to sit down, but the parklette (is that what they're called??) outside + the bar adds a nice amount of space. I love that the menu changes daily as everything has been great so far, I can't complain. It's a nice relaxed place to grab brunch on the weekend if you're not in the mood for the weekend brunch madness and the barrista the morning we went made a pretty great cappuccino! Definitely check this place out!
author: Emily S.

description:
farm:table reminds me of Koh Samui. Koh Samui is an island in Thailand. Like Samui, farm:table has been "discovered".  The crowds have arrived and what was once a peaceful, bucolic paradise is now a crowded, overbuilt nightmare. What was once charming is now headache inducing (and while I have found other beaches in the world to enjoy, I can't seem to find a decent cup of coffee elsewhere).

I would like to make a few (admittedly unsolicited) suggestions to the patrons of farm:table:

1) If you do not live within a six-block radius, please stay away! Getting coffee in the morning is stressful enough without newbies gawking at the blackboard and trying to get a clue.

2) Be considerate of the space; ie, if there are more than two of you, go elsewhere! It's too tiny for crowds (I'm looking at you: Marina girls on your way to Bloomingdales)

3) This one is so obvious I can't believe I have to say it but: NO LUGGAGE.  I deal with enough idiots at the airport, please don't bring your rollaway suitcase to a small cafe.

4) If you are a picky eater, you should also stay away. They have a small selection that not everyone likes.  Please don't engage in lengthy questioning about the offerings - they are what they are you and your questions waste my time when I want to be ordering myself.

As much as it pains me, I rarely visit anymore and now just make a French press at home. I still stop by once in a while for take-out, and as others have mentioned, they could improve their current system.
author: Hayesvalleygirl ..

description:
Love this place.

Pros:
Food is yummy, the coffee was some of the best I've had. 
The style of the place is pretty cool. Very Hipster.
The employees were friendly to me. 
Felt a bit inspired eating here.
I like that its very very small. BUT I got lucky and there was a spot at the table inside.
Community Table. 
Small menu. 


Cons:
Community table. (yes I have this under both). Didnt like the people I sat next to. They were bitchy and were ruining my breakfast.
Was a little bit pricey, but I enjoyed it so much I would go again. 


Bottom Line:

not a place for every one. Singles or couples would like it. Groups wouldn't. 

I loved it. 

Better seating outside or heat lamps would be rad.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Cozy little place with a giant farm table... appropriate. 

Great iced New Orleans coffee. You can tell the quality and time they spend to craft and perfect every batch.
author: Amy M.

description:
Very cute & unique spot for a light organic breakfast. You order inside and take a seat inside or out and food brought to you.
Our frittata was so good, you can really taste the fresh eggs and ingredients, served with salad. Fresh juice and amazing coffee. We also had a few cakes to go, yumm!
If you're looking for a huge breakfast and a large item menu, this is not the place for you and you probably won't get the concept.
author: Sean W.

description: The Daily Toast was incredible ! The perfect combo of breakfast flavors- fresh fruits, marscapone , salted pistachios and great toasted bread. Easy to share an order, too. Very reasonable.
author: Sarah B.

description: If you like subpar coffee with over the top snooty condescending attitude, this is your place. Dear snooty staff..You acted like you hold a PHD in "espresso" with your attitude when I ask for iced latte... However; you don't even know how to make a "DRY" cappuccino. "Dry" means mostly foam and a little milk; not a latte in a smaller cup. Mr. Professor barista, If you want act uppity you better have the skills to back it up!  The sweet roll was good but not better than anywhere else. Save your money and self dignity and go somewhere else.
author: J W.

description: This place was an experience! The only small square table available to sit at inside made us... talk to people! The food was mind blowing for how small the space is! It was unique, delicious and crafted with care. I would visit this place again and again and I would recommend it to anyone because it is a wonderful experience. To me, as a tourist, it feels like everything SF.  It's heaven for foodies and a safe place for coffee snobs. LOVE IT!
author: Tricia H.

description: Charming, but the food selection is too small to be called breakfast, as they don't have a kitchen. Literally 3 seats to sit at. More of a coffee shop with snacks
author: Cody W.

description: Visiting San Fran and found this place on Yelp.   I had a delicious frittata with broccoli, potatoes and feta baked into it. Perfect portion for a light breakfast.  I was eye balling some good looking pastries, including a chocolate croissant for which I pined but I decided against the extra carbs. Mr. Ninja was pleased with his egg croissant sandwich.  I sang some Miley Cyrus on the way back to our hotel and was inspired to one day bake a similar frittata in a casserole dish at home.  All in all, a San Francisco treat.
author: M' N.

description:
I'm bracing myself for some hate mail since everyone and their pet seems to think this place is nothing short of five stars.  I admit, the coffee and fresh food is hella good and five star material without a doubt.  The service is also as friendly as it gets in San Fran.  

But I just didn't have a five star experience eating at the one communal table and having to move twice in the middle of my meal to accommodate others (and their shopping bags) who were waiting for their espresso orders to be made.  As miniscule as this place is, they surprisingly have a restroom accessible from behind the service counter.  

I have no doubt that had I just gotten coffee/espresso to go, or when the hype on this place simmers down that the experience would be the full five stars.  If we're all lucky, this place will somehow buy out the crap cleaners next door and add another communal table for the hungry folk who want to eat their kill in peace.
author: Tommy W.

description:
This is an adorable little farm-house in the middle of downtown.  There's only one table (which you'll share with friendly neighbors), but the food is divine.  The portions are on the small side, so be sure to grab a chocolate-chip-sea-salt cookie for desert.  

And warning: they're cash only.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
Meal: Brunch

Vibe: Super homey and communal. I love the communal table (it's the only place to sit inside) and we prefer sitting inside to outside (though they're actively raising money through Kickstarter for their parklet (YAY!).

Coffee: They use Verve coffee, which is really tasty and they know how to make great espresso drinks. The owners (and main baristas), Shannon and Joe, are former Blue Bottle baristas, so they're really legit when it comes to pull shots and pouring milk drinks.

Food: Yes, the menu is only 4 items long and it's simple, but their food never disappoints. If you like fresh, local and simple ingredients, you'll love farm:table. The daily toast and egg sandwich were always our favorites when we were regulars, but frankly, you can't go wrong.

Service: They're super nice people and will be happy to converse if they're not too busy taking orders. Also, they're super accommodating and helpful, so feel free to ask questions or for tweaks to your drinks or food.

Value: It's not cheap nor expensive; If you're looking for good tasting and well-portioned dishes made from local, fresh and simple ingredients, farm:table is for you.
author: Luke B.

description: I love that this place is on my block. It classes up the joint. Tiny and adorable. Great coffee and atmosphere with a well maintained parklet outside. Great local neighborhood vibe. I'm usually on the run in the mornings but I look forward to trying more of the food. Closed at night.
author: Jared S.

description:
I was visiting the city on a biz trip and was staying a few blocks away from farm:table. SO glad I found this for breakfast! Toast is amazing. I went three times in 4 days! Great coffee too. It gets busy in the morning and the line can be long since it is a tiny space, but it is worth the wait, if there is one. 

GO!
author: Kristy W.

description: Great place - lovely staff who will make things off the menu for you. Always worth asking what they can do and what they have. I had a delicious baked ham, egg and cheese salad based on one their tarts.
author: Rodrigo D.

description:
We waited for half n hour to get 1 order of the daily toast.  
there is only 1 table to sit in this closet size hole in the wall. The couple
who ordered way after us, got there daily toast before us.  The coffee was just 
average and a little bitter and nothing special.  The almond croissant was great but it was hardly worth the wait because the service was very very slow and they were NOT FRIENDLY AT ALL
author: Myra S.

description: Don't let the pictures fool you. Walked across town to this hole in the wall that seats about 5 people to find only ONE thing on the menu? That and a snarky girl behind the counter to tell me to take it or leave it. Lol...really? Wow!
author: Deno R.

description:
Adorable place, great staff, incredible concept.

So, why the 3 stars?

I came here for breakfast with a bunch of friends and had their toast of the day ($6.25): bacon avocado w/ hard-boiled egg.  Now, I'm a detail Nazi when it comes to food; the slightest imperfection, it's game over.  So, when I got my plate of hard-boiled eggs on toast, I had to check for that ever-looming sign of miscalculation: the green ring around the yolk.  I don't mean to sound like an egg connoisseur, but I like my hard-boiled eggs just boiled enough, without the ammonia-taste that naturally accompanies an egg gone for too long of a soak.  The bacon bits were also a bit on the cold side...  I guess bacon has to be cooled down in order to be broken?  =\  Everything else was grand.  The toast was warm and moist, perfect amount of melt-in-your-mouth avocado slices, all topped off with caramelized onions.

For something that I can make in the morning for much less without freezing my ass off coming here early in hopes of beating the crowd, I'd rather stay home.
Love the concept, the ingredients, the table, but the food...  not so much.
author: Chase C.

description: The food is great but the service can be awful. For example, after 15 min of ordering my regular coffee, I asked the person if my coffee is ready. His response was: "I was too busy to give shit about it"
author: Khashayar F.

description:
Who knew eggs on toast could be such a revelation?
Who knew that service could still be so sincere?  To see a barista who truly loves where they work?  To see a chef personally plate all his dishes? 
If you are in the area, eat here.  You won't regret it.
author: Natalie R.

description:
I did a quick scan of reviews prior to picking this place out, but what I so OBVIOUSLY missed was that farm:table is literally cubby hole sized with literally ONE farm-table for people to sit around and nosh.

Some quick points:

LIMITED indoor seating around a farm style table.
LIMITED outdoor, side-walk cafe table seating (2 small round tables, to be exact) - NON HEATED 
Cash Only
Coffee is eh.
Menu is LIMITED

What we ordered:  braised pulled pork shoulder
What wasn't to be expected: the made to order food was cold, the side of toast was pre-buttered, the veggies, soggy.

The cost was actually more than I had expected.  I'd say moderate.

It was ok, but not remarkable.  Left a little disappointed.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Soo good! verages but I would defiantly stop by again. It's a very small quaint place. Glad we made a point to visit. The croissant was fantastic. A little light on some of the traditional breakfast be
author: Anthony R.

description: Food was delicious as usual.  Expect to wait especially on weekends.  We had to wait even on  a Monday morning.  Had delicious granola with home made yogurt, delicious egg sandwich and a quiche.  Can't wait to go back to enjoy more of their delicious homemade food.  We ate at a table outside the restaurant but it would be too cold to eat outside now.
author: Diane P.

description: As a visitor to SF I checked this place out based on Yelp.  If you are looking for a big traditional American Breakfast w bacon and eggs this is not the place for you. I was expecting more options but the croissant with boiled egg and ham was actually surprisingly good and the latte was fine.  This place is SUPER TINY....only one table in the place and it's probably 3'x6' so you will be seating with others (there were a couple of small tables outside in the common area that I think you can use).  No wifi so if you are looking for amenities this is not your place either.  The food is fresh and the people are friendly and down home.
author: Tom P.

description:
This place is great for brunch.  It's really small, so can get packed.
The coffee is absolutely amazing... just what you need to jump start your day.  The breakfast is usually good, but can be hit and miss.   They pick their dishes based on the ingredients they have, so there is no guarentee or consistency.  Absolutely worth taking the chance, though.
author: Ian C.

description: Small hole in the wall.....hands down the best breakfast sandwich I have ever had VERY FRESH!!!!!
author: John K.

description:
We were staying at a hotel a few blocks down so came here for breakfast.

Pros: delicious pastry whose name I can't spell or pronounce - pricey at $4 & it was gone in 4 bites (ok that's partly a con).  I could've eaten 5 of them.  Coffee is strong and makes the cons worth it.
So-so: banana muffin was dry and nothing special.  Cash only - with prices like these, I need my ATM to bail me out.
Cons: truly closet size - one large table plus 2 small tiny ones outside.  People waiting & watching you eat...you can almost read their minds: 'really, you're just going to sit there and enjoy your coffee?'  And you're thinking: 'yes, I am cause I just forked out some major $$ and I'm still hungry.  Maybe in 20 minutes my mind will convince my tummy that I'm not anymore.'
author: Vicki V.

description: The phrase "hidden gem" has already been used to paint a picture of this little place, but it seems the most apt and descriptive. It's a tiny little place with one medium-sized square table in a "cozy" room by a counter. Excellent coffee and pastries, no attitude, and about a 50% chance you'll befriend other coffeeshoppers sitting at the communal table. If that's not San Francisco, I don't know what is.
author: Sean B.

description: A great little neighborhood gem.  Great coffee, tasty food, and a cool vibe.  Love the community table.
author: James B.

description:
this place is TINY. there is one communal table that seats 8 people in there and maybe a couple tables outside.

their menu is very limited. i think they had 5 things that you can get. i think this place is more of a snack with coffee type of place.

their plum raspberry coffee cake is sooo yum. it's soft. moist. sticky. fluffy. not too sweet.

their latte is a tad sour for my taste.
i liked the 3 boiled eggs halves with cherry tomatoes and potatoes with buttery toast.  the potatoes were really greasy but it was still yum.  the portion was small so good for a light snack.

it is a tad pricey here.  i had the 3 egg snack. coffee cake. latte for 17$. and i wasn't even full.
author: Heejin L.

description: Staff did not seem interested in serving customers who are not from the neighborhood. 1. Despite asking them to not include meat in my sandwich, they gave it to me with ham anyway.  Thank you for (not) listening to me!  2. There were no forks on the table, and when I asked for a fork the manager brusquely insisted I look on the table. Not there. 3. A customer had her apparent non-service dog sitting on the very small communal bench with us. 4. Cereal was advertised as having sunflower seeds, coconut, pumpkin seeds etc. There were barely any seeds.  Mostly cereal and raisins for $7.99 (They did give a refund, thanks).  Kitchen mistakes happen.   I get it.  The main problem is the tone of the staff.  We heard them joking and laughing about previous customers after they left.  And joking about us as we walked out the door. The guy who appeared to be in charge of Farm Table was boasting about how he lies to his girlfriend all the time, she's too oblivious to know.  So if you enjoy a sarcastic staff and the opportunity to listen in on their bragging male conversations as you eat your meal in a small space with six seats, then this is the place for you.  By the way, the coffee and hot chocolate were very tasty.
author: Andrew N.

description: This place is amazing. There was a line but it went pretty fast. We sat outside on the planter box and waited for our food with our fresh juice. We prefer the croissant with hard boiled egg and a quiche. So yummy and just what the reviews had said it would be.
author: Jess P.

description: My God-son and I ate here on a recent trip to SF. There was a lot of build up about this place so I was really excited. Perhaps I did not read the reviews clearly but it has virtually no seating except a communal table. The food was pretty good. I got the fruit toast but it didn't knock my socks off. The menu is very small. The only service is at the counter and the guy taking my order and my money seemed very very rushed and perhaps a bit curt. I didn't like the coffee at all as it was way too strong. I am going to say "over-brewed" and it was as thick as motor oil. I don't think I would return unless I was already in the vicinity. And even then I would take something to go. In SF there are so many killer places to eat at that you really don't have to settle. Bottom line: I think farm:table is overrated. Sorry.
author: Mamo R.

description:
farm:table is probably my favorite restaurant in the Bay Area. The menu is small, simple, and everything is delicious. When I went, I had the quiche, the yogurt, and my boyfriend got the egg sandwich. Everything was amazing, and I loved the small feel of the restaurant. I didn't get to try the drinks (like the in house made almond milk), but I will definitely make it a priority on my next trip. 

It feels like you're at your family dinner table with friends whenever you go.
author: Cher H.

description:
I was really excited to try this place based on the Yelp reviews. My wife looked at the same and was skeptical. Wow, was she right. 

Long story, I decided to go there for tea and something small to kill a little time before a later breakfast. I asked for a green tea. Five bucks. Do I have to go on the John Travolta "Five Dollar Milkshake" Pulp Fiction rant? Five bucks for a medium cup of a tea bag seeped in hot water. I also decided to try a brownie which they sell in very tiny rectangles for a dollar. It was good but it takes a lot to mess up a brownie. So for my tiny morsel of food and medium tea I paid $6.

The customer after me asked for "coffee and cereal." Nine bucks.

I love local and sustainable. And this place is using their gimmick to outright gouge people. Any business that sells basic items at such high mark-ups is not what this movement should be about.

If you're in this area around lunch time avoid at all costs as the delicious Pearl's Deluxe Burgers is a few doors down on the same block!
author: Tom M.

description: Great place for fresh food. The scone and eggs were really good. Coffee is also good.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Really tasty breakfast.  I had a polenta dish with farm eggs.  Price was reasonable-- I'm unsure why people thought it was overpriced.  I would have happily paid more, given it was fresh, organic food.

One star off because 1-  they forgot my latte, and 2-  it was hard to figure out how to get a seat.  I guess you just order, then you wait for a seat.  It seems like they'd do better to have a hostess of some sort, but I was in on a thursday, so perhaps they do that on the weekends.

Regardless,  if I wasn't flying out tomorrow, I'd be back for a second round!
author: Audra C.

description: An adorable place! I got toast with marscapone and fruit and it was delicious. I also tried my the croissant with ham and mozzarella that my dad ordered, which also was great. It's really small with room for only two or three groups inside, but that gives it an intimate feeling. There were only four menu options when we came, but we tried three (my mom had the frittata, which she liked but was small) and they were all yummy.
author: Megan S.

description:
Frankly, I was not impressed!! This is between a 3/4 stars.
Maybe this week was just an off week for the food. It was a steak sandwich and a frittata. The Frittata was great, but the steak sandwich was disappointing. Service was great and the space is adorable (also very cozy). We came here on a weekday morning and we were able to get the whole table to ourselves!
author: Emily T.

description: You pay a lot for a little. Food is okay, nothing to rave about. I got the croissant egg sandwich thing, it wasn't bad. The coffee was tiny for the 4 dollars I paid. The staff is nice and friendly. But, the food and prices doesn't make me come back.
author: Justin W.

description: We stumbled upon this place while looking for coffee and were delighted when we saw that the options for food were all made with farm fresh ingredients. We tried the Goat Cheese Frittata and the Egg on Croissant sandwich and both were delicious. I love that the menu changes based upon the ingredients that farms have to offer that day and that if you go there often you can constantly try new things.
author: Laura H.

description:
The drinks are great, the staff is wonderful, and the food stellar.

The owners are sweet as can be, and the regulars here make it feel like home.

Anything, and everything they do oozes of quality ingredients, attention to detail, and a passion for what they do.
author: David K.

description: Best breakfast I have had in along time.  I got the Sando and a strawberry apricot muffin.
author: Heather B.

description:
I think this place is smaller than my future studio apt in the Bay, which is already pretty small.. about 500 sq ft? Anyway, the point is.. farm:table is SMALLER. There's a large table inside for seating, so you'll definitely share with strangers (or rather friends you haven't met yet). There are also some tables outdoors. I thought it was smart for them to cover the left wall with a mirror, b/c it gives the illusion that the room is bigger than it really is. I mean, it got me at first, I thought whoa, this place is bigger than I anticipated and then I realize that person I'm looking at looks exactly like me.. and uh, hello mirror reflection. 

Although the place is small, the food comes with big, bold, and strong flavors. I ordered their bread pudding with fresh strawberries and cream ($8) and iced coffee for ($4). Now, you're thinking, whoa, kind of pricey there.. and yes, I guess so. However, it was one of the best bread pudding I've had.. the flavors are rich and concentrated. Every single bite was satisfying. I also like that they use fresh farmer's market.. yay for supporting local businesses! In terms of coffee, they serve coffee from Verve, which is from Santa Cruz (and apparently, a well-received coffee joint). I think it's another plus that a couple of the baristas used to work at Blue Bottle, which gives them extra credibility. 

Anyway, it looks like their menu changes quite often (if not, daily), so farm:table tweets their menu via Twitter. If you want to know what's cooking, check out their Twitter - http://twitter.com/#!/farmtable.
author: Cassy H.

description: Super small, so either go at an off-time, or plan on grabbing your stuff to go. Besides the fact that I wish this place was larger, I don't have any complaints! I tried the tender nob espresso drink and it was perfect. Also had one of their croissant breakfast sandwiches and remember feeling pure joy as I ate it. Definitely a gem in the TL!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Once you learn your way around their non-peak times, this place is a complete gem. Grab a seat outside and enjoy the limited menu that's based on fresh & tasty items. The daily toast is always awesome. The last one I had was mascarpone, fig, walnuts, and a drizzle of honey. Epic-ly delicious and simple. 

This morning I had their kouign amann with sweet diced apple in the center. It's a pastry with 1,000 layers stuffed with sugar and salted butter. It's soft on this inside with a caramelized crispy crust like a croissant but sweeter. I'm not sure if they make them in-house or buy but it was completely worth the 3,000 calories with a good cup of coffee.  


Quick tip: To avoid hipster Ai students, come before 10am.
author: Julie M.

description:
Small small place. Extremely limited seating, 8 at the most.
The staff is not that friendly.
Food is not decent.
Agree with Denni P.  that this place is overrated.
author: Ying S.

description: This is a great place to get a bite in the morning. Check out the Twitter feed to see what they have for the day. I don't get here often enough anymore, but they have a nice variety of food that changes on a regular basis.
author: Nader A.

description:
a quick run down...

-teeny tiny
-cute set up
-super friendly dude who took my coffee order
-awesome almond milk latte with a big heart on top

it was too crowded so i'll grab food next time.
author: Sally T.

description: Such a thoughtful menu, much of what is derived from the Farm to Table philosophy- bought from Rainbow Grocery or made in house. They pay attention to detail and design which I appreciate and are genuinely sweet with customers. It is an extension of their art form- this delicious menu and farm:table dining experience. I enjoy eating here and sipping an impeccably smooth cup of coffee from their lovely little nook or comfy parklet outside.
author: Kristen S.

description: Small size and lack of seating (especially indoors) make it better for a standing meal or takeaway.  I had a kouign amman with a black coffee, both were pretty good.  I don't think I'd go out of my way for this place again, but it was decent considering I didn't have to wait too long compared to other brunch spots in the Tenderloin.
author: Richie T.

description: Really flaky croissant for the croissant sandwich. I also enjoyed the sandwich filling. It isn't everyday that you find a super flaky croissant like this one.
author: D G.

description: Love this place. I make a habit to come every time I'm in SF! Homemade almond milk latte and anything on their menu is sure to be a perfect morning combo.
author: Brooke W.

description: What a great place. My wife and I stopped off for breakfast with our small infant and were not disappointed!  It's very small, one table inside, and a few seats outside. But the food is fantastic. We ordered the Daily Toast (focaccia, fruit, mascarpone), Egg Sandwich (hard boiled egg, croissant, avacado creme fraiche, baked ham), the house cereal, and the house juice. It was fantastic. The wait was long, but the food is amazing. We will definitely come back.
author: Mark J.

description:
mind=blown. One of the best breakfast experiences I've had. The food was absolutely phenomenal. I had the quiche, and it was life altering. Their mocha was amazing. My friend had their freshly squeezed juice which was equally delicious. I loved the quiche so much that I ordered the toast, which had almonds, honey apricot (i forget which fruit)..and the spread was some sort of fromage. Everything tasted FRESH - as if they had a garden somewhere nearby where they picked the ingredients the morning of. My only complaint is that it's a bit small. There's one table inside, and two outside. So if you aren't lucky enough to get a table, get the food to go, then head over Union Square, eat, and people watch.

Their menu changes every day, so if you're not into surprises, consider calling in or looking it up online.
author: Sami A.

description: I love the ice coffee and probably the best in the city... I have tried almost every coffee place in town.  This is a small little place with a communal table with excellent bakery and a couple egg dishes for breakfast.
author: A J.

description:
If you want to bump knees with strangers all while avoiding eye contact, this is the place for you.

I imagined the table would at least be about the size of picnic table. But no, it's just large enough to cram two people on each side. There are also a pair of 2-person tables outside that looked as sturdy as a house of cards.

I ordered at the counter and was a little perturbed that I was nudged to give a tip of 20 percent or 15 percent when I paid on the iPad (I opted to tip cash after I got my food). I'm all for tipping wait staffs a fair amount, but I don't get how ordering at a counter and having to bus my own table warrants a tip of that amount.

There were only 4 breakfast food items available the day I went. However, my frittata was excellent, so that accounts for the 3-star rating. 

This place has potential, but in my opinion it needs a bigger space and a few more food offerings to be worth it.
author: C. J.

description: Went on a Sunday morning and was able to find parking on the street. We waited in a small line then finally ordered and was able to get two seats at the one and only table (holds 8 people) inside. Felt sorry for the 4 people busy working in this micro-tiny closet...a food truck is probably 10x bigger then the standing room only "kitchen." We had to wait about 15 minutes for coffee, and a total of 20-25 mins. to get our breakfast. We chose the egg/ham on croissant sandwich and the fresh fruits (mandarin orange, pear, pomegranate seeds) on a layer of mascarpone cheese. The food was absolutely delicious and the cappuccino was OK but nothing to brag about. They had 2 other items on the menu, so it appears you get a limit choice on what to order. Great food for sure but no room to sit. I wouldn't attempt to eat there again...maybe only good for take-out meals due to no seating availability.
author: Gabe F.

description:
Ate: Soft poached egg on brioche with salmon and dill cream cheese lemon and capers amazing!
Drink: coffee, great taste. 

If you like over cooked eggs, hard cold bacon, and burnt bread, then this is not your place! The food here is very good. The place is small an quaint, and has an ever changing menu. But that just adds to the charm. The food is prepared wonderfully. I will absolutely return.
author: Tracy R.

description: This is a great place to meet up a friend for a quick, light brunch before moving onto something more active.  Seating is very limited, but there is a communal table if you don't mind sharing.
author: Erica D.

description:
What a difference a year makes. I used to LOVE this place. We came here for breakfast pretty regularly but after moving to a different neighborhood its been a while.

Went back today for lunch. We ordered both lunch plates (beef sandwich & frittata)  because in the past everything has been very delicious. My heart sank when the plates were brought out because the portions have decreased quite a bit. Their previous ratios were spot on and combined with the pricing made it a very affordable option. The food itself seems to have lost some of its creativity. It wasn't as tasty as it used to be. They've always used good quality bread but the bread that came on my sandwich did not have enough integrity for the filling. The side salad was little more than a wilted garnish. The frittata was... fine, with the exception of egg shell.

Customer service is always good here, that's not the problem. Although it was strange to see the used plate/cutlery box overflowing - that can only take 30 seconds to bring inside.

Maybe this place is better for breakfast but I don't think I will make a trip out there any time soon.
author: Marie J.

description:
I ve been coming here for years for coffee; which is spot on and delicious every-time so dont get me wrong; but Focacciatable ? 

Is that a word?  If you like focaccia this is your place. Everything is prepared and made on focaccia bread now, but the quality and taste is still first rate. Fresh locally sourced ingredients make anything good even if you aren't a particular fan of foccaccia like myself. And if you are a fan of foccaccia then you will be thoroughly pleased with whatever you order.
author: Joe N.

description: Small communal table expect conversation with strangers!
author: Matthew T.

description: Hands down the best coffee in lower nob hill. I would give them 5 stars if they have better hours, but not being able to get coffee until 7:30 on a work morning proves sort of difficult. On a weekend the communal table is a fun place to post up if you are solo. Excellent customer service and the food is also pretty good.
author: Heidi S.

description: Fresh fruit and fresh yogurt were great.  Nice and small place to grab quick food. Everyone is very friendly
author: Brandon W.

description: Went here for a quick breakfast. Ordered the bacon scone, ham and egg on a croissant, and a chai tea latte. Everything was super yummy and fresh. It was a small little place so definitely not good for groups, but we needed something quick before heading out to SFO and this was perfect! Would definitely come back here.
author: Kim G.

description: Really pleasant service. Excellent juice combination: carrot, apple, grapefruit.  Oh my gosh the egg sandwhich was to die for! We got lucky with a table outside.
author: Ali B.

description: Iced coffee was delicious. Small, cute spot on Post. We got the croissant sandwich which was quite creative and tastey, and the quiche which was fantastic. The quiche was better than the sandwich, but both were pretty small portions. For $7.50 though, I wasn't complaining about the portions.
author: Matt D.

description: Love it. Not a lot of seating but somehow it works. House made granola, delicious yogurt, and fresh squeezed oj - It was perfect and simple. Menu changes regularly, just read today's *slurp*. Friendly staff. In the neighborhood is another plus.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
This fantastic little hole in the wall is a perfect antidote to all that crappy brunch that is served everywhere else in SF. Sure, they have one table so they just call it "communal" but it is worth bumping elbows with strangers, or sitting outside in the cold just to have something off their limited, but fantastic, daily menu. They clearly aim to use the best ingredients and they certainly treat them right. I rather like it when places keep their menu limited because they know that they can only handle doing a few dishes well. It is much easier than wading through a lengthy menu to attempt to find what the restaurant is good at preparing.

Try this place when you want to try something new, you won't regret it.
author: Caitlin H.

description: The egg croissant was excellent! I loved the sauce in it. It's a little small, but the food is great!
author: Melisa R.

description: Perfect, perfect, perfect. If you're an East Coaster looking for a place that's open early, fresh and healthy, this is it. Teeny tiny, so either be prepared to take it with you or sit with your new friends at the single table. Flavors were bright, fresh and clean, latte was excellent. Loved it.
author: Eileen S.

description: Seriously? Nice place, but I clearly forgot to order the kool aid. The staff is very nice, the food is good, but I would say not really worth the effort.
author: paul l.

description: I tried to take my brother and sister in law here Saturday and was welcomed with extreme rudeness.  We walked up outside, before we could get in the door he said: "you two with Starbucks can keep walking, gross".  I agree, I don't like Starbucks either, but my in laws are visiting from New York and I wanted to share a farm to table experience with them at your restaurant.  I was hoping to show them how great it is to eat fresh and local... Thanks for being a jerk, now I will never return and you have pushed them further away from learning the benefits of a sustainable food industry.  Be content with your own opinions but don't be rude to others for making different choices.
author: K C.

description: My only comment is the parklet outside of their establishment requires climbing shoes and a caribeaner.  Being that this place only sits eight people, be prepared. On belay!
author: Rosie F.

description:
My favorite neighborhood brunch/breakfast spot. 

I usually pass on the fritattas, but everything else is EXCELLENT!! If you go on a day when they have polenta or a brioche sandwich - give them a try, you won't be disappointed!  I also love their yogurt and house-made granola on days when I'm feeling more traditional.

The milk and honey and the mocha are my favorite drinks, and my boyfriend loves the tenderknob.

If you're in the area, you gotta stop by!
author: Jaci H.

description: Tiny place, be prepared to wait or eat outside. That said, amazing egg sando.. would eat it again!
author: Mario T.

description: The food here is pretty good and the place is super cute - very small and rustic with a single communal table. The staff killed it for me, however. We went at 1p and they were out of most of their menu already, so we stood in the empty restaurant and debated if we should stay. This may not have been acceptable to the employees, because we received very impatient stares/glares. We ended up ordering from an unfriendly man and felt unwelcome the rest of the time. It's noticeable when you're in such a small place and the only customers. I can excuse poor service if the food is amazing, but it wasn't THAT great.
author: Brett B.

description:
Positive: It's in my hood!!!
Negative: I don't get here quite as often as I should for living so close.

I've been living in the area for over seven years and only tried it about two years ago when my friend visiting from Canada went there while I was at work, and started raving about it.  The iced coffee really is that good.  And all the food I've tried have been super yummy, the different flavors coming together surprisingly perfectly.  It's just the perfect little neighborhood breakfast spot.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I came during lunch time (fyi their breakfast and lunch menus are different and lunch starts at 11:30am) and sat at a communal table.

[latte + almond milk]
I've been reading about rave reviews about this, and straight up this combination tastes nasty.  If I were a barista I would seriously stop my customers from ordering odd flavor combinations (thanks yelp.. listening to your reviews DID NOT help in this circumstance).

[roast beef sandwich]
At the end of the day, most sandwiches are kinda the same.  The things which distinguish it mainly are the bread or some interesting sauce.

First off, their bread is like hard as a rock.  I kinda felt like my teeth were bleeding after a while.  The roast beef had some spring mix with onions and honestly it was okay.  For such a simple menu I don't know how it can take so long.

[overall]
I definitely have to say I am not impressed with their food.  For a place which serves only a couple of dishes, their food really should be better, and faster.
author: Dan Q.

description: Worth the cost, and the wait.  A great place to order a lighter breakfast to take back to your hotel or apartment.  Very fresh, seasonal ingredients.
author: Mark M.

description:
I wanted to love this place after reading the Yelp reviews and hearing my husband's excitement about trying out the place.  Unfortunately I left disappointed.  

We ordered the goat cheese toast with padrillo peppers, and the toast with mascarpone cheese and peaches.  After 20 minutes and no food, I thought it was fishy that toast would take that long.  My husband got up to investigate and found out they completely forgot to make our order.  When it finally arrived, they brought out my goat cheese toast without the goat cheese.  HOW DOES THIS HAPPEN?!?!?  First, you forget our food.  Then, you forget a crucial component of one of our meals?  What is more, the food tasted like I could have easily made it myself in 3 minutes or less.

Iced coffee with almond milk was disgusting (though my husband thought it wasn't that bad).  Other coffee drinks (cappuccino, espresso) were just ok.

farm:table, I expected more.  Readers, save yourself the trouble and just make fancy toast at home.
author: Anna P.

description:
Petit

Communal

Sustainable

Tasty

TIP: check their web/twitter for daily menu, 3 items change daily.
author: Gibran H.

description:
They make the best iced coffee with Verve coffee beans. You have to be willing to walk in the tendernob a little bit to get there - but its only 4ish blocks from Union Square and is much much better than anything you could get at Starbucks. The places is very tiny - you have to walk right through their kitchen area to get to the bathroom.

Havent tried their food, but the menu always looks good.
author: Holly C.

description:
Awesome.

their cereal and house made yogurt and fruits are just ridiculously good, definitely the best i've ever had. i cannot wait to try other dishes.. i onlywish i lived nearer.
author: Sung C.

description: Coffee servings are very small.  Service is slow.  Toast is mediocre for the price.  The egg croissant is actually really great though! I've never had anything like it.  Only things I'd order if I went there again.  Not much seating at all.
author: Melody J.

description: Unique spot. They make there own almond milk. zero acid or burnt espresso taste.Smooth quality coffee
author: Michael S.

description: I read the reviews on yelp and wanted to try it.  One communal table already being used.  Had to wait on the rain outside for twenty minutes.  Needless to say,  we did not get the opportunity to try it. Would suggest they put in more smaller tables so that more people could enjoy.
author: Theo S.

description: Great cappuccinos, totally cute place. Can't wait to visit San Francisco again and come back!
author: Nathaniel J.

description: My fav spot for breakfast in the hood. I get the focaccia with egg and ohhh how that kick starts my day. Their iced coffee is great too.
author: Priyanka P.

description:
I've recently become obsessed with the "The Fabulous Beekman Bros" (Please watch, if only for Polka Spot). 

This obsession has lead to an obsession with farms, eating local and starting my own garden. So when I decided to skip the boring lunch I had waiting for me in the work fridge farm:table got me, if only by name at first! 

I love the simple daily menu. As an incredibly indecisive person I'd much rather you make very few or one thing delicious and then force me to eat that than offer me 20 pages of every food under the sun. AAND if that one item involves BACON, the greatest food known to man,  you've got me no questions asked.

Today's lunch: Bacon sandwich with arugula and incredibly thinly sliced apple on pan de mie. Crunch bacon, my favorite green, and surprisingly amazing bread. Soft and light with a sligthtly crunch crust.. just the crust.. the way homemade bread should be. 

I feel good eating this sandwich. And I like to feel good. 

Yes it's small, yes I unfortunately had to place my order to go (my dream was to sit in the sun), but the staff is pleasant without being overly nice (think fake) so I still left feeling happy. I'm looking forward to coming back regularly to break from my boring lunch routine.
author: Hailey P.

description:
our party of 6 lucked out by getting table seats (we basically swooped down on two couples as they wrapped up their meal). the portions are REALLY small, but very tasty indeed. the coffee was just whatever. my group complained the whole walk there (and goodness was the walk warm and seemingly long!), so i was a bit irked upon arrival. the irkedness increased when i saw the "cash only" sign, which sucked. luckily, my lovely friend covered me. said lovely friend found a giant hair in his food, which any normal person would have fussed about, but he just ate around it, and actually finished the entire thing. gross. 

i probably wont come back. i always thought myself a touch bohemian, but i think farm: table is a touch TOO bohemian for the likes of me.
author: Jan Y.

description: Cappuccino and mocha were both great - flavorful without being overpowering like some of the coffee I found in the area. Didn't get any breakfast dishes but the baked goods were incredible: tiny creme fraiche cakes, almond cookies, cheddar and scallion scone, strawberry scone. No, we didn't eat that all in one sitting - the coffee was good enough to bring us back a second time in two days.
author: Eric G.

description: If you are in a hurry, i suggest u skip..their breakfast is amazingly simple n good! Their Ice coffee is my go to.
author: Jane B.

description:
Summary: It's cute, tiny, but it's all concept/hype and not so much food.


Went here with a friend, based on the fact that it was nearby and had a really high yelp rating. The place is cute, but absolutely tiny. The idea is brilliant, but not exactly original - there's a number of higher end places that have more or less the same concept. It's not exactly cheap either.

The food? It's just not that great. A number of my friends can cook better, and having dinner with a friend after the farmer's market is way more satisfying.
author: Max R.

description: I came to Farm: Table for breakfast one morning while I was in SF on vacation.  The house juice is fantastic and the croissant sandwich I got was flaky and tasty. It's a bit pricey for the portions, but I appreciate that everything is hand-made and as close to the farm as they can get it. Like other reviewers said, it's TINY! The location isn't ideal, but it's a special hole-in-the-wall spot that's NOT to be missed!
author: Jessica W.

description: The line wasn't even long, but after 50 minutes of waiting, I had to leave because I had somewhere to be. I went inside to let them know how long I had been waiting and they were very rude and said that I was being impatient and demanding... I'm pretty sure waiting 45 minutes for a cup of coffee is a bit ridiculous. Not worth it in my opinion.
author: KTea C.

description: This place would be great if I was a local and knew the protocol. But for anyone new to the joint, prepare to be confused. Yes, the restaurant is a closet. Yes, that's the tiny menu scribbled on the wall in the upper-left corner. Yes, you bus yourself. Yes, there are only four options, but also notice the baked goods on the left and the great coffee/tea selection. Portions are small so you might want to grab a full meal before/after.
author: Kevin H.

description: When I read the yelp reviews that said it was small I figured a little hole in the wall place. This is a hole in the hole in the wall. But what it lacks in size it makes up for in character and food. The pastries to your left are amazing. Definitely try the zucchini cake, unlike any zucchini bread I've ever had! My mom and I both had the daily toast which was delicious. Unfortunately it looked like they were out of a few dishes by the time we got there (around 12:30 on a Friday) so definitely get there early. If you're in union square and don't want an overpriced touristy meal, make the four block trek to this little San Francisco gem.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Tried this many times, I love that a place like this is in the neighborhood.

The place and menu are definitely small, and with three items every day I expect deliciousness more often. It's definitely pricey and portions are often small, but dishes usually sound interesting. Ingredients definitely always taste fresh and individually delicious but execution could use work.

Their coffee is also expensive but I don't think I've ever thought it was great, just average.

Food is mixed. It's usually really simple and delicious (bread pudding, or fruit with toast) but most of the times it's just average. At $9 average for a small dish and drinks around the $5 mark the experience is easily marked with disappointment. Two people could easily spend around $30 dollars for poached egg and bread pudding with two coffees and leave hungry.

Maybe if the prices were lower or the food impressively unique I would find it better but at this point it's a little kitchy.
author: Sam H.

description:
I'm just here to share more love.  Every time I go here, I really enjoy myself.  Cambria, the resident chef, is always incredibly nice and checks to make sure you are enjoying your meal, which I always do.  

Shannon, the awesome barista is also tremendously friendly and really makes you feel welcome.  

Aside from great coffee and some really good eats (my favorite sandwich is roast beef, favorite soup is creamy tomato, and new favorite salad is the spinach with kumquats, toasted pecans and mustard dressing) is the warmth of the employees and the passion they put into their jobs.

Kudos!
author: Michelle M.

description: I had a Gibralter (basically a shot of espresso, and a shot of milk) and a steak sandwich and it was the best coffee drink I have ever had in my life, and also the best sandwich I've ever had in my whole life. Tiny interior. Don't walk directly through the heart of the tenderloin on your way out unless you wanna get asked if you know any good deals on methadone.
author: Mikhail T.

description:
I don't get all the 5 star reviews. I left farm:table saying to myself "3 stars" but upon writing this review I just could not bring myself to do it.

One communal table tightly seats 8 in a room so tiny you pretty much have to sit ass-cheek to ass-cheek with your neighbor. This did not bother me. Little does farm:table know, ass-cheek to ass-cheek is the ONLY way I like to sit. Especially if it's a first encounter.

My latte with almond milk was.... interesting... with it's cute leaf foam accent that I have never seen before (sarcasm! sarcasm!). After seeing a panda in my Cappucino in Toyko http://media2.ct.yelpcdn.com/photo/bAdjVxBG98oNZjmWJCzZDA/l, hearts and leaves seem like childs play. The Pear Bread Pudding was probably the best thing I had but it's really not saying much unless I'd drive across town to order it again, which I wouldn't. What did not go unnoticed was the friendly/sweet staff. They really seem to enjoy what they do and I can appreciate that.

The brioche bread with eggs was just way too difficult to eat. The bread was too thick and hard to cut into which made sawing it with my knife a task alone, not to mention all the nibbles on top of it fell onto the table because the plate was too small. I also wish they made the eggs over easy so the runny yolk could soften the bread underneath or perhaps a light drizzle of sauce at LEAST. Maybe then my palate wouldn't feel so dry. 

Menu changes daily. CASH only. This is an eat and leave kind of place. If you sit around after your meal you feel the stank eye from hungry people in line waiting to swoop your seat. 

2.5 stars to be more accurate or maybe I'm just being an anal bizznatch. You decide.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Great coffee, great sandwich. The price is understandable because they get fresh ingredients daily and it's not made by someone who gets paid minimum wage to stand behind a counter. Come on people this isn't Subway! You get what you pay for.

The communal table thing gets talked about a lot. It was a lot more fun than I thought it would be. The other people there were quite friendly and it really makes for a unique atmosphere. Would definitely come back.
author: Alex G.

description:
