Not an expansive menu, but that's kind of the point. When so many breakfast places in the city have 1+ hr lines, Farm:Table is a saving grace. Somehow, despite only have 1 indoor table and 2 outdoor ones, it's usually possible to have a place to sit by the time your food is ready. The 8-person communal table is pretty fun too. It always looks like everyone knows each other, even though they rarely do. 

The food is top-notch too. We had the fromage blanc on toast with fruit/pecans, and hard-boiled eggs with bacon on baguette slices. Both were great, and we only waited about 5 mins from the time we ordered before they arrived.
author: Evan G.

description:
Two words:  Pork Sandwich
I left satisfied.
This place is smallish, so I took it to go.
I would eat there again.
author: Derek N.

description: Yum!!! From the coffee to the fresh fruit it was delicious! Super small so don't be surprised by that.
author: Rhita B.

description: Awesome breakfast, great coffee but small seating area - 1 table plus few curb spots
author: Vivek K.

description: Breakfast sandwich and mocha was quite tasty, but glad I was not in a rush. Service was pleasant but slow.
author: Jeff W.

description: A friend took me here for breakfast before Outsidelands and it was pretty damn good. This place is tiny though, it only has one table and a few chairs, definitely not a place to bring a group of people. And they only take cash, the cashier told me they dont even have a phone haha. I ordered the B.L.T. (photo attached) and it was definitely the best one i've had that i can remember. I also had a latte w/ almond milk and it was good times. As i was walking out there was a guy outside w/ the meatloaf sandwich (which was enourmous) and he was just staring at it like he had no idea how to tackle it. I'm getting that next time.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Biscuit with ginger butter, you made my dreams come true! 

Full disclosure: farm:table also catered an event a couple of months ago at the shop I manage just down the street.  Everything was delicious, everyone who attended was very happy.  

I go here on a regular basis for an americano and something small to get me through the afternoon.  Their short menu (typically, a sandwich, a soup, a salad and some baked goods) changes daily.  I've gotten soup several times, and its always delicious.  This morning, I had the best biscuit I've ever eaten in my life.  The people that work there are very friendly, and even accommodated me one warm day when I was thirsty for an iced americano (which apparently is a West Coast no-no!).  

It is really small, but having worked in a cafe that was very similar especially in terms of the size:productivity ratio, I definitely appreciate how much they do with the space (milk, spoons and sugar for coffee are outside the door; pots, pans and plates hang from the ceiling.  Literally, every square inch is accounted for).  No matter how many people are stuffed inside, it always feels warm and welcoming, like the kitchen at home.  Plus, there is a great group of neighborhood regulars, which makes it even more like a home away from home!

You'll probably see me there!
author: Piper A.

description:
Had breakfast here this morning.

OVERALL: Delish! I would recommend a Sunday brunch here to locals and tourists in the area. 

SERVICE: Quick & efficient. The first woman who took our order was friendly and helped us pick our a flavor of coffee. The woman busing the tables was just doing her job, not to social (minus 1/2 a star)

FOOD: Now to the important stuff. The food here is fantastic! We had the mocha-java blend coffee. It was rich, sweet, and a perfect blend for breakfast. I ordered the brioche with braised pork and a poached egg ($9). The brioche is buttery with a crunchy crust. It was perfect for sopping up all the egg yolk. :) The braised pork was tender and flavorful. The best part is the perfectly poached egg on top (EVERYTHING is better with an egg on top!), cut open to let the golden yolk drip over the pork and brioche. It is also delicately topped with a small handful of rocket and chopped green onions. Perfect savory brunch for a busy day of shopping (or after a busy night of drinking...). My boyfriends choice for brunch was equally as good. He ordered the whole wheat toast topped with mascarpone, fresh sliced bananas, toasted hazelnuts, toasted pecans, and drizzled with a caramel sauce. It was sweet, filling, delicious! I could even imagine having this for dessert, it is that good! I would recommend ordering what ever sounds good, and then sharing this tasty treat for a sweet finale! 

ATMOSPHERE: TINY!!!!! I can not express that enough. There is 1 (ONE) communal table inside that could seat max 8. There are also 2 smaller cafe-style tables outside to seat 2-3 (minus 1/2 a star, I like to be able to rely on having a seat.). They also are a CASH ONLY establishment, so be prepared. We arrived at about 9:50 for a Sunday brunch, and just beat the crowd. If you are coming here, plan ahead, and be early if you want a seat. :)
author: Angela L.

description: Dig there's more staff (5) than customers (2).  F:t deserves all praise, proof is in the leek and mushroom frittata.  You're never gonna fit around that table if you're husky, Toughskins.  They've got a chair for you.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This is a good place for breakfast or brunch. If you happen to be in this neighborhood.

I really like the concept, from the menu based off local ingredients to the communal table. But there are basic issues which always make think twice before venturing there.

The food is hit and miss. I have had good dishes (french toasts) and very average one (polenta, breakfast sandwiches).

The service, albeit friendly, is not good. I have had the waiter forget about my order on a couple of occasions. Or asked a couple of times for a glass of water that never came. I understand that they run a very short staff but the quality of service doesn't stop at being friendly.

Also, this is cash only. Which can be an annoyance.
author: Robert B.

description:
Love the space!  Reminds me of little cafes in England.  The staff is really nice, and they are one of the few places in the area that carry verve coffee.  :)

I tried a pour over coffee, polenta with the works and an apple puff pastry thing.

Coffee and pastry were great.  The polenta was a little disappointing.  Not as creamy or flavorful as I like it.  Will come back and give this place a another shot though. Hoping that I'll like the sandwiches more.
author: beverly l.

description:
I came into San Francisco ready to get my grub on, and I almost could not find this place.  It was my first one on the list, and it is most definitely a hole-in-the-wall.  There is only 1 seating table inside, so you pretty much gotta get your food to go or eat it outside.

FT basically does what I like best about eating: it uses local produce, produces a limited menu, and makes good-tasting food.  The only disappointing thing with my visit was the extremely small menu, since I did not particularly want to between the 3 options of the day.  It was a choice between the daily toast, the hard-boiled egg and swiss chard, and the housemade cereal.

I do not eggs for breakfast, and I do not like cereal for breakfast, so it looked like toast was going to be my choice.  It had pears, walnuts, honey, and dates.  They were all chopped into little bits and set on top of some nice tangy whole wheat.

The food is not too expensive; most items are in the $7 range.  farm:table is a unique choice for a small meal on the go, but just be ready to select from a limited menu!
author: Solomon W.

description: I loved loved loved our breakfast here!  I will admit the very limited menu was not so perfect for my non-dairy eating sweetheart but they were eager to accommodate us.  The daily toast was heavenly!
author: Marie B.

description: I've never had anything bad here. Everything is really fresh and delicious. I'm obsessed with the ice coffee with lavender sweetener, I get it every time I go there.
author: Melissa C.

description: Don't even bother coming here and waste your time. Food is below average and service is BAD. They forgot our order of food and when asked nicely, they became defensive. Finally food arrived and the rude waitress threw the plates on the table and rudely asked is this what you ordered? Wasted 25 bucks on tasteless food and crappy service.
author: Natasha G.

description: Came here for breakfast after a friend raved about it. Waited in line for about 20 minutes to order then another 30 minutes to get the food. We had the daily toast and the savory toast. Honestly, the wait was not worth it. The daily toast, although was topped with very fresh fruit, was too hard/over toasted. The savory toast was kinda bland. On a positive note, the store front aesthetic is very cute and the coffee was good. But I probably won't be returning very soon.
author: S G.

description:
I have called a few times on a few days and get the message that this # is no longer in service?

Are they still in business, or not paying their bills, or what?
author: Mark H.

description: Passable. Pre-toasted room-temperature bread slathered with, admittedly, pretty decent stuff. The most hilariously tiny/cramped 'dining room'. Juice thimbles. We were drawn by the concept and Yelp feedback, but for the life of me can't figure out how this is the/a place to thrive in a such a competitive food scene. I mean, I guess the margins are pretty good on cold bread?
author: Victor C.

description: This place gives the phrase "hole in the wall" a new meaning. Their menu only has three items a day and it changes everyday (sometimes during the day if they run out of something) so it's nice to have that variety. We had the dunoc ham sandwich on whole wheat with herbed fronage blanc and tarentaise cheese served open face. At this point, we were so stuffed from eating all day but we still found the food to be delicious and savory. The salad was my personal favorite though. Soft greens with humbolt fog cheese, thinly sliced pears and some sort of suace was such as a nice complement to the sandwich. The true test to knowing if a place is good is coming here extremely full and still finding their food delicious. That definitely rules out that you found it delicious because you were starving. I'd love to come here again.
author: Diana Y.

description: Frittata was really delicious. I was worried there'd be a ton of potatoes but everything was pretty balanced with the veggies. Their sauce was good. Coffee was alright. My Indian buddy thst was visiting couldn't resist trying the chai latte. He only had a few sips. =\ but I liked it! Wish I coulda to goed his cup but then that'd be weird... kind of. I would probably stop by if I were in the area but wouldn't make a trek down there just for their frittata-- there are too many other awesome places that are closer...
author: Vicki T.

description:
Carbs - i love to hate them....and hate to love them. However, when I stumbled in to farm:table Sunday morning after quite an epic Saturday night I quickly became the biggest fan of buscuits you could ever imagine. Why you ask? Every last Sunday of the month farm:table features "Buscuit Sunday." (normally I'd opt for the breakfast option sans the carbs...so glad I just went for it this time. so glad....)

I easily had the BEST SALMON EGGS BENEDICT I've ever tasted yesterday morning....and the buscuits, which were just heavenly, played a major role in this. They were buttery, flaky, just slightly doughy with the perfect amount of texture and thickness. These buttery buscuits were topped with thinly sliced fresh-from-the-garden Heirloom tomatoes which were lightly salted and picked at the peak of perfection. The next layer was, no joke, the best tasting smoked salmon I've tasted in a long while. Thinly sliced and just melted in your mouth. Next was one perfectly poached egg with a fluffy yet thick consistency and cut about a quarter of the way through - just enough so the yolk could spill out on to your buscuit. Their homemade hollandaise sauce was salty and savory and the perfect flavor combination to the salmon and tomatoes. 

Not only was this this best tasting benedict I've had in a long time it was also the most beautiful presentation I've seen. Complete with little purple and orange flower (edible) petals. (You can imagine how upset I was when my phone died and I couldn't snap some photo's of this beautiful work of art)

This is your quintessential hole in the wall breakfast spot that should be moved to the top of your "to try" list as soon as possible. 

p.s. As others have noted - it's tiny inside! So get there early and expect to sit at their only table inside with other locals who are enjoying their breakfast and coffee. If you're not one of the lucky 7 or 8 who can squeeze around the table there's a couple options to sit or stand outside if it's not too cold.
author: Kristy M.

description:
sunday 2pm, CASH ONLY

i commend them for their honest effort in trying to make available affordable great tasting gourmet food. they make sure you're 100% satisfied and take your comments and concern into consideration. Although I'm not really a fan of their oyster mushroom frittata on top of biscuits entree, i was a fan of their well cooked moist short rib meat.  i'll visit them again to try something different out.  the place is cramped and almost impossible to eat at (they have a communal table that seats 8 people) , considering their popularity and very limited space (don't take not having a place to sit and waiting personally). plan on ordering to-go (they're very fast) or coming on a not so busy day.

their menu rotates on a day to day basis. follow them on twitter or call in to find out what's on their daily menu.
author: Katherine F.

description:
Loved the food here. You basically have 4 options written in chalk on the chalk board to the left of the register. Any choice tastes so delectable. I got the quiche for breakfast and the eggs tasted to fresh. loved it and i normally am not a fan of quiche. a couple days later i grabbed bfast there again and got the soft-boiled egg on top of toast and boiled chicken and veggies. the broth they boiled the chicken in was on the bottom and tasted reminiscent of Tynola (Filipino chicken soup). It was fantastic. the portions were just enough. 

the iced coffee was amazing too. just a bit of milk and sugar. I cant wait to get back in that city again to try something new.
author: Alexis J.

description:
I think this place has a lot of charm, character. Great for bum watching.  To be honest, bums are much more interesting than the normal Joe to observe. From them hacking their phlegm on the side of my car (boo) to their unique monologues, its never a dull day in the TL. When you walk up, it reminds me of a European Cafe with seating in the outside for people watching. Equipped with red doors, very French of them. The interior is small with one table that seats about 5. 

The brunch menu is limited to one thing per day. Follow on twitter to find out what it is today. I was hoping they'd have soft eggs instead of hard boil eggs that day but none the less, it was a pretty tasty breakfast. Complimented with goat cheese, buttered baguette, country ham and arugula. If this is what farm people eat every day, sign me up for country livin'. So I gave them 3 stars because their brunch plate. 

The coffee. Oh coffee. It's the core of my mornings. It started this morning with the Tender-nob similar to the Gibraltar at Blue Bottle for $2.75. The morning started out right. But then I needed more, so I got their latte with almond milk. And this is what made me demote its ratings. I've never been so unhappy post coffee consumption as I was that day. I need my coffee strong and its the taste that gives me a fake illusion that its keeping me up. This latte had NO coffee taste to it. None. I don't like it. I think it was the almond milk that muted the aromas and taste of caffeine. Hence, I learned I'm not a fan of almond milk. The ground almonds bothered my throat. It tasted like water. 

Conclusion: In fairness, I can't say that I can make a fair judgment on their coffee just because I made the conscious decision to mess it with almond milk (something I don't like). Based on their Tender-nob, I do believe they serve a proper grade of coffee. So I'm going to come back and try it without the almond milk to see how it goes. The food was pretty good but yet to rate this place a 4.5 stars, I feel like its over-rated. Definitely has the charm and potential to become a new fixture in San Francisco, but for now I can only give it a 3 stars. Oh yea and they've only got organic whole milk and no nonfat milk. Limits my options.
author: Wendy L.

description: I really just don't get it. Nothing on the menu was that appealing (pickled egg sandwich, toast of the day: tangerine focaccia with mascarpone and almonds or a potato omlette aka tortilla espanola. I went with the toast of the day. It was more like a breakfast food. So I ordered incorrectly. My friend ordered the egg. I think she's still trying to figure out if she liked it or not. Also the staff was rude and looked at us like we were idiots. Sorry we haven't been before and didnt realize sandwiches were self serve.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Everything about this place is nice; I love the communal table, seasonal ingredients, and the ever changing daily breakfast toast. 

Pro tip: Tired of tendernobs or cappuccinos? Try "something smokey".
author: Lion G.

description: Coffee is delicious and the parklet out front is divine on a sunny day. Tiny interior, so don't plan to stay, unless you just want to sip a cup and grab a tiny bite.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Farm:Table, I absolutely adore you and will stop by each and every time I am in San Francisco! 
Try Farm:Table out and you will not be disappointed at all. Sit at the large table, indulge in some fine coffee and enjoy yourself.
author: Liv E.

description:
I loved farm:table and wished we had one here in Austin.

It was a bit chilly and had to sit outside but that didn't matter.  The mocha with the heart on top latte warmed me right up.  

They say they have toast but nothing prepares you for what you actually receive.  Fresh fruit and cheese and honey that melts in your mouth. 

We went twice during our 5 day visit and I was able to try a quiche as well and that was just as yummy and fresh.  The crust was spot on and not oily or tasteless like you would find in a store bought crust.

We miss you already farm:table and when we are back in San Fran we are heading your way.
author: Michele L.

description:
When I first saw this restaurant a couple of years ago, I was so excited about the concept and wanted to support them. I finally made it there and was disappointed. Though the "daily toast" was interesting, it was a very tiny portion that ended up being bland (a hearty toasted bread with marscopone, apples, cardamom pods) and very unmemorable. The most disappointing aspect was not only the portion size, but the house coffee price. A tiny coffee cup cost 2.75 and additional $1 for a simple refill. I was flabbergasted. After paying $25 for more of a snack rather than a breakfast, they charge another dollar just for some more of their terrible, lukewarm, bitter coffee. My husband's sausage/egg stew portion was the size of a petri dish. We generally have small appetites and are pretty tiny, but after this so called breakfast, we had to make a stop an hour later for a real meal.. which was, in the end, considerably cheaper and actually gratifying. 
I so wanted to love this place and get excited about having it be a regular spot for breakfast.. but I will never come back. I still love the concept, but I can't justify the price for what's given in return. So disappointed!
author: Rupa V.

description:
I wouldn't sell my wagon to set up camp at this farm but if I moseyed by again, I would stop in for a almond milk mocha and a sweet pastry.  

Limited seating is one issue.  Big farm style table inside accommodates about 8 and then two tables outside as well as a high counter.  

We ordered the cereal with yogurt, individual elements all deelish but once mixed together the crunch was gone, and the hard boiled eggs on baguette hold the bacon.  My mocha was warmish, not as hot as I usually take it.

I think the grass maybe greener on the other side.
author: Amireh G.

description: When visiting SF, I have to have breakfast here. Everything is so fresh and creative! I have been inspired to make my own crazy toast at home. I just had their daily toast with pears, crumble, and mascarpone. The quiche had different kinds of cheese and it was the best quiche ever. Also had the red lychee iced tea. Refreshing for a hot sunny morning in SF! Limited seating, but something magically always opens up.
author: ReBecki P.

description:
Great place.  Really tiny but I think that's part of the charm.   They have one bug table inside and two more outside.  
If you can get one of the tables outside the view is really awesome.  

I had the home made cereal with yogurt and fruit. Super tasty.   The americano I had was also top notch.
author: Matt T.

description:
Complaining that farm:table is too small or doesn't have enough options is like complaining about a sushi joint for not cooking their fish.

It is what it is, people.  And it does what it does - very very well.

Local, fresh, real food.  And great espresso drinks.  And delightful baked goods.  And that's it.

Yes, the table is communal -- that's part of the charm.  If you don't like that kind of setting, it's not for you.  For me, farm:table is a great example of why I live in San Francisco.
author: Nathan D.

description:
Is the location less-than-stellar? Yes. 

Is there a little bit of pretension about the place? Yes.

However, hands down, this place has the BEST quiche (oh so light and fluffy flavorful with the perfect side salad) I have ever tasted in my life. I'll drive downtown on a weekend to come snatch that up any morning!
author: Ashley A.

description: I want to like this place. I really do. The service is great and I like the mission of the cafe: local, healthy, fresh... But the space is just too small. It wasn't even that kind of local, small, mom/pop feel, it was just overwhelmingly small and stuffy even with the door open. The food portions are very small but still good. The coffee was a bit too bitter for my liking but I guess that's preferable to some. The croissants are super fresh and crispy though, so I'll give them that.
author: Sejin J.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.  I tried this place when we were in SF in October.  What a treat!!!  Couple things, Gotta get there early they do sell out and there is one 1 Table INside and 2 small tables outside.  

I had a thick crostini with beautiful peepers, cheese and hard boiled egg on top.  I remember them being out of what I really wanted.

The menu is always changing so worth dropping in to get something new when you have time.  For travels staying in and around Main Bart drop this is a close walk from some major hotels.

PS They know how to make a good cappuccino
author: Emily W.

description: Nice little neighborhood spot with very friendly and attentive waiters. Although a bit on the pricey side, its worth it. I really enjoyed the banana bread and zucchini bread. I also had the warm porridge thing with veggies and meat which I forgot the name of, its greasy but I like it. The latte and orange juice are delicious as well.
author: Ying Ying S.

description: Cute little local spot that has great espresso and daily toast!  Very reasonably priced, and nice setting.  There are tables out front and one shared table inside.  The tendernob is my favorite! Only gave 4 stars for lack of vegetarian options, and the somewhat limited seating.
author: K M.

description: It's a quaint place. Very tiny, but in a good way. The coffee and tea smell permeating the shop is pleasant. The food is delicious, but the portions are small. That's the only complaint, but it is a significant one, hence only three stars.
author: Ehtesham K.

description:
finally had a chance to try this place out!  teeny hole in the wall spot with limited seating but well worth the journey out to the tenderloin.  menu changes daily with limited options.  the options for breakfast i had were ham, cheese, tarragon frittata; cranberry compote, apples and walnuts with fromage blanc on toast; banana bread pudding; and soft egg with rapini and bacon on brioche.  

i chose the soft egg on brioche and was very satisfied.  i've heard portions here are small but the dish i got was pretty decently sized and really filled me up.  soft egg was cooked perfectly and yolk ran over the warm brioche.  it came with two hearty strips of bacon and sauteed rapini (which was actually my fave part of the dish).  the dish was sprinkled with fresh parmesan and some citrus which took the dish up a notch.

i also got the ice coffee was was awesome.

definitely will come back again!
author: Helen T.

description: Daily toast is good but tiny little place made it annoying so I got my toast to go. Hubby didn't see anything on the menu so he didn't get anything but mostly because of how tiny it was inside and the one table was occupied. Too cold to sit outside.
author: Deb C.

description:
I am a little bitch about most things.  

Yes, I freely admit it. 

Now normally, if a place:

1) Had street parking only
2) Only took cash
3) Had communal tables
4) Didn't carry skim milk for coffee

I would tell that place to jam themselves with a splinter covered two by four.

So, against my "better judgment" I paid a visit to farm:table this weekend.

Let it be known, that even though I am still bitching about items 1-4 above, I will make it a point to come to farm:table every weekend from now on.

It's that good.  

This weekend they had the roast beef sandwich with horseradish sauce and cheddar on "holla!!" bread and a side salad of fresh greens and feta.  

We started by ordering one sandwich.  

We ended by ordering another sandwich.  

In my opinion, besides refueling that crack habit, farm:table is the only reason to get anywhere near the tenderloin.

Varied.
author: Archie R.

description: Found this place on yelp looking for a good breakfast spot in SF.  Food was ok, but overpriced.  $20 for a small breakfast and $2.00 to refill a 8 oz drip coffee out of a big pot.
author: Michael S.

description: I love this place.  It's cozy, barely anyone comes in with a laptop to use; instead strangers speak to each other.  The coffee drinks are just right, never bitter, temperature is great, and these coffee drinks are absolutely delicious.  The food is homemade and scrumptious. The new owners are sweet, and I love what they did with the park bench on the street.  Beautiful flowers and even a tree!  Yes, we need more green in San Francisco!
author: Patricia D.

description:
Fantastic in every possible way.  Instead of limited, I prefer to think of the menu as meticulously curated;  They make the best thing for each mood with the ingredients available.   And what spectacular lattes!  

Sitting and sharing a meal with people that are not yet your friends is a pleasure often neglected in our go-go world.
author: Neil D.

description: Was on my way to the airport and grabbed a tart which was like a quiche. I chose that because they ran out of blackberries for the daily toast. It was only 11am. Service was slow. It was a cramped space, but the tart was above average.
author: Nkenge E.

description:
The place looked cute but tiny..it also sent out a little vibe saying it's a cafe for cup of coffee more so than a lunch place. We skipped this spot the first time but ended up there the next day.

I wanted to try the coffee there but I was more than starving when we arrived and...the bill after a drink + a sandwich would've been $15+ so I opted for water which was self-serve style. Cute little glass dispenser filled with water and rosemary leaves and little jars and glasses. 

Their menu changes daily and they update their twitter with the menu of the day. Cool concept.

The menu for that day was meatloaf sandwich and egg salad sandwich.
Though I love egg salad sandwiches, I had some the day before so I ended up getting the meat loaf. The meatloaf was a bit on the dry side...but overall it wasn't too bad. Very meat-y and gave me a horrible food coma afterwards.


Very cute place with cute furnishing and cute graphics etc. but CROWDED. TINIEST PLACE EVER. There is one big communal table that seats about 7 people at the most. There are some tables outside like two. One of my friends ended up standing outside because the inside was too stuffy for him. 

OH, and there are only about three workers from what I saw. The cashier, one helper, and one cook. Needless to mention, the line & wait are long.

Overpriced. Tiny. Mediocre food. BUT 4 stars.. 
I really think it was just their quirky atmosphere.
author: IRENE S.

description:
Just went here! I more or less knew what to expect going into farm:table based on the Yelp reviews, and I was really excited.  I was aware that portions may be small, but since the menu is limited, I assumed that the items are still meant to be a meal and not just a side. But I still asked if the quiche would be filling enough, and I was told it'd be a "light meal" and was suggested a 1/2 order of the soup. 

So I got the quiche and soup, and though they were both pretty delicious, it was just not filling at all.. I honestly might need to go buy another lunch. I love that the menu changes daily and the ingredients are all fresh and local and organic and whatever, and if it was located more conveniently for me I might even stop in for a *snack* once in a while, but it's hard for me to think of this as a brunch or lunch spot.
author: Richa A.

description:
Was looking for a place where we wouldn't have to drive to find it.  Walked over to farm:table and it definitely was not what I had expected it to be.  Place is small with one table inside and 2 tables outside with a few chairs.   That was probably the only downside to this place, and why it didn't get the fifth star.

Ordered the quiche, my brother had their house cereal, and my parents had the toast.

They had just put the quiche in the oven, but i still decided on ordering it.  The house cereal had fresh strawberries, oats, and what looked like yogurt.  The toast special was topped with hard-boiled egg and what looked like grilled and roasted peppers.  Then the quiche came out.. it was delicious!  The ham added a good amount of salty/savory flavor and the cheese was not overpowering.  The crust was crumbly and tasty.  It came with a little cucumber and tomato salad ensemble that was tasty and went well with the quiche.

I also ordered their special juice, which I was told consisted of:  grapefruit juice, apple juice, and I forgot what else.. but it tasted very refreshing and a little minty.  

The guys working there were also very friendly and the food came out pretty quickly.  The food was tasty, the workers were friendly, and the food was unique.
author: Joanne L.

description:
I give farm:table props for offering a different menu every day and swankifying its small, Tenderloin space. However, I found the cramped communal table, limited choices and tiny portions disappointing. Because we didn't want to sit in strangers' laps and risk dropping crumbs into their coffee, my boyfriend and I sat at a table outside despite the wind. Both of us ordered a unique breakfast item comprising hard boiled egg halves on buttered, toasted baguettes, topped with sauteed mushrooms, caramelized onions and arugula. It was tasty but small; at $6.50, the islands of food reminded me of something you'd pick on at a baby shower. 

Plus, I didn't care for the coffee, mixed with farm:table's house-made almond milk. I found the milk gritty and overly "raw." 

Because we were still hungry, my boyfriend grabbed a piece of orange olive oil pound cake out of the case while paying. It was light and offered a faint citrus tinge. 

Other people are wild about farm:table, so I guess my vision of a delicious, hearty brunch is different from their ideal.
author: Bobbin W.

description:
My gf and I come here about once a week to fulfill our frittata craving and to sit outside, undisturbed, to enjoy our tasty little meal together. It's not hard to do here, the small staff pretty much stay behind the counter leaving you to set your own table/pour your own water/etc.  Sounds good to me, if I can avoid that overtly friendly/fake waiter builsh*t I might still have an appetite for the meal itself. 

Coffee is very good. Although, I don't understand what the big deal is..I know an "Iced Latte"  isn't technically on the MENU but give me a break...throw some espresso on ice, pour milk over it, charge me four ridiculous dollars and call it a day. 

Also, I love frittata's and all but it's been like...MONTHS!! and all I see on that menu is another frittata and some other less appealing option. The only thing that seems to really change is the type of creme fresh on the side. 

Okay, 'nuff snarkiness....sorry i just got a root canal.

Fresh food, fresh coffee. That's more than most breakfast places could say...
author: Lindsey L.

description: The coffee is absolutely absurd. So good. The servers are actually happy to be here, which is rare (I'm from New York so maybe it's not that rare here). Had some sort of egg baked into focaccia bread with chorizo. GUUUUURL.
author: Dave R.

description:
I had their pork brioche. I didn't really know what to expect, but it was really good! And my friend had the strawberry on toast with mascarpone; it was amazing! They have a rooftop garden where they get all their fresh veggies and their menu changes daily.

I wish they had more space for people to have their meal. I guess that's why it's called Farm Table. 

I recommend this place.
author: Kissy F.

description:
Went with my parents on a Sunday morning. We managed to snag seats at the inside table, had a nice time chatting with another out of towner mom brought by her son and eavesdropping on some friends catching up and getting ready for a day of shopping. Delicious coffee and mocha in lovely little glasses kept us alert while we waited for super simple, but perfectly flavorful/textureful breakfast. 

Quiche was a delight, mushroom morsels, crust - divine. Accompanying butter lettuce dressed just right.

And at first when the bread came out, Mom was a bit disappointed. It seemed so, minimal. But the tiny tomatoes were scrumptious, evoked the happy sweetness of picking the first fruit off the vine yourself and popping in mouth!

Don't expect to sit down at peak hours, don't expect super fast service, don't expect gigantic portions, don't expect a menu stuffed full of infinite choices.

Do expect simple good food in an intimate setting.
author: Leslie T.

description: Love the coffee and the breakfast. Ate here every day while in town. Even had to make a bit of a trek to it. Shit, I even got a loyalty card, and I don't even live in this overpriced, pretentious, passive aggressive town! If you have no choice but to stay in the horrible neighborhood farm:table is in, park yourself here every morning. Maybe arrive early, because there are like no seats. But it's worth the trip even if you got better accommodations elsewhere. Or even if you live here!
author: Steven S.

description:
It's super small. I honestly did not know where to go. There's a big table inside, and then outside there are two small ones. I kind of felt like the people that were there that day were people who lived in the same building or knew each other. They'd all randomly sit next to each other. Maybe they all do know each other... hmm. I know this is one of those places where you have to share your space with people, but this day I didn't feel like it. Next time I hope.

I tried this place out because I had some time, and the TCHO hot chocolate lured me here. I am a hot chocolate groupie, so of course I loved every sip of it. It was pretty small for $4, but I get it I suppose. That TCHO stuff is expensive (I think a small bar is $4, too, at the grocery store), but it's so delicious. 

I also had a salad since I didn't really want to have the sandwich or the quiche on the menu, and it had goat cheese, walnuts, and a light strawberry vinaigrette. I ordered it along with my hot chocolate, but they somehow forgot that I ordered it and I didn't get it for a while. But the lady was very apologetic and gave me a cookie to hold me over, so it wasn't a big deal. The salad was just okay, but it did hit the spot. I felt like I should have ordered something else. 

I will not give up, and I will go back next time. And I will also make an effort to sit with strangers.
author: Caroline L.

description:
In a word - small. Farm:table has one table. One! I get the whole communal sit with strangers thing but unless you are ordering takeout or arriving at an odd hour forget about a normal breakfast. In addition there's no where to stand if you are ordering out. If you do sit at The Table, prepare to get a butt in your face from people standing in line. 

The neighborhood is fine. Don't let "Tenderloin" freak you out. Just don't enter the neighborhood from the south. 

The food is quite good. That's why people go.  Nuff said.
author: Phil C.

description: I regret not having ordered more. But the steamed milk and honey with cardamom was heaven
author: Maria G.

description:
I'm kind of confused about what I ate.   Since there was only one choice for breakfast, my starving self just went with it and didn't bother to find out what it was.  

I got 3 half-eggs with a shred of ...duck?..beef? something...on it.  Anyway it was good. I liked it and took a picture of it for further inspection later.  I just didn't LOVE my experience at farm:table because of the lack of options and the awkward half-steps before realizing all the seats were taken.   At least someone finished shortly after...(small food, fast turnover)


All in all..ambiance is hipster-yuppie-ish.  You feel kind of...bougie..in a casual way ??.. after having pretty cappuccino and fancy schmancy looking food on the sidewalk.  That or European.
author: Tokki M.

description:
Oh Yelp, thank you for directing this out-of-towner here for breakfast on an early Saturday morning. I needed something simple, light, and fresh, and they did not fail. Fresh juice? Yes please. A bowl of the house cereal with fruit and yogurt? Don't mind if I do. 

It's a limited menu, I'm guessing based on what they bring in, but it was fantastic nonetheless. I shared a table with a young couple that had a more hearty plate (with eggs and bacon), and were I not watching my intake the day before my race (the SF Half) I would have pigged out.

Limited space - it's very tiny - so make sure to go early.
author: William B.

description: I like the idea of their every day menu being dependent on what's in-season, available and local.  Before I showed up in SF, my recon gathered that they usually carry two-ish daily menu items in addition to their coffee drinks.  On a rainy  morning, one of my two choices was toast topped with persimmon, pear, gruyere and mascarpone http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TcbKvh-e1lxywJuN6in5JQ?select=AAg5C3sFFY-kgWAPbjJbVQ and I jumped at it.  I had that with, what I suspect to be an organic and fair trade shade grown mocha.  Choosing locally, socio-economically and environmentally aware and responsible (the takeout box was recycled) cafes can lead to a delicious breakfast.
author: Darren S.

description:
Wow, Farm:Table really is as good as everyone says.  

I had a friend in town one weekend and I was DYING to try it so I didn't bother asking her where she wanted to go.  I told her it was a place I've heard nothing but good things about...

...ummm...but I sorta left out the part about how there might be nowhere to sit, and that there are only like two things on the menu, and that it's in the TenderNob.  

We got there and as expected there was nowhere to sit.  She looked unimpressed--but I reasoned that she's not the most animated person.  She said we could go somewhere else.  I gulped, but I insisted on staying.  I apologized, then I lied and said I had no idea the place was so small.  I felt like such a selfish bitch!  

I assure you I am not usually like that, but I repeat that I was DYING to try it, and I was too close to give up now.  

As we ordered, the staff told us we could stand at the bar outside.  I'm thinking, Oh man this is ghetto.  She's going to kill me.  

When she opened her mouth and her monotone voice came out, she stated, "I love this place."  

SCORE!  

Our food and pastries were dee-lish, and the coffee was phenomenal--so much better than Blue Bottle.  Like another reviewer said, the coffee is very smooth, it's kinda hard to describe.  Their mochas and lattes with almond milk are phenomenal as well.  I need a regular fix and will happily go to FarmTable alone if no one can come with me.
author: Kandi K.

description: 4/13/12.  Not so great diner for breakfast! Service was lacking and food was nothing special.
author: Jen L.

description: We stopped by for a quick breakfast today and it was well worth it. The dishes are very simple but the ingredients and combinations are winning!  My cereal and yogurt with golden raisins was crunchy and creamy. My sister had the hard boiled eggs on toast which had incredibly fresh ingredients but probably would've been amazing with a little more seasoning or citrus/acid and if the toast and eggs were warm. We also got the walnuts and berries and creme fraiche on toast which was so basic but so delicious. All the ingredients were perfect and hearty. We finished every morsel.
author: Robin C.

description: Love their ever-changing all organic specials and their lattes are to die for. Maybe it's my love for mason jars (that's what they serve their drinks in) but in terms of quality coffee drinks in the union square area it doesn't get any better than that. I'm still figuring out how to sit on that fancy outdoor structure mini park. Maybe one day I'll succeed.
author: Sophie H.

description:
Delicious food, fabulous staff, adorable place.  

Note to newbies - not a place to bring a group.  There is 1 table that seats 8 (you sit with adorbs SF strangers) and 2 outdoor tables that seat 2.  I also suggest coming early.  My husband got the last order of eggs, and once they're out, they're out.  I also suggest the bread pudding.
author: Erin Nicole P.

description:
Found this place courtesy of yelp and this place defines why i love yelp.

I had one of the better breakfasts I have had in months and I love to eat out for breakfast.  I wandered in early on a sunday while in town for a conference.  The place has one medium communal and 2 small outdoor tables, but since I was early on sunday i easily found a seat and took advantage of the NY Times (first star here).

I couldnt decide between savory or sweet so I had both.  I ordered the poached egg on fresh heirloom tomato and toast.  While the dish was a bit small for its $8 price tag, the taste was great as were the ingredients.   I then had the break pudding with strawberries which while sweet was not over the top, and definitely a great way to end my meal.  I also had the coffee of the day which left me with no complaints.

All in all this is one of my new favorite breakfast spots and I highly recommend.
author: Andrew S.

description: Awesome little joint to get a snack and some caffeine. We shared their daily toast which is their special creation for the day. Ours consisted of nectarine and apricot slices with yogurt or cream over a quality piece of toast, sprinkled with almond slices. Can't forget the 2 cappuccinos we had to wash it all down. I have to mention they take their caffeine fix very serious. It hit the spot, soooo good. It even has a cream design on top. This hole in the wall is a must try and u won't regret it! The only gripe I have about this place is the size, wish it had a bigger seating area.
author: T L.

description:
Why no chai?
Black tea and some type of pastry is how I go here.
Service is friendly most of the time.

I still super want to sit on the tables outside while reading a book and look super cute and stylish like those girls and boys do when I see them while walking on my way to work.

why 4 stars for an iffy review? Uhh cos I saw Adrian Grenier here. DUH
author: Amanda S.

description: Their coffee is okay, but this is yelp. I'm here to talk about their service! Look their trying to be a posh hipster coffee shop and the blonde chick said it all to me. It's my first time there u give me a bad impression and I'm not coming back! I asked the girl where the lids are and she looks like she doesn't want to be working and says under her breathe softly it's outside. And then I say excuse me where? And annoyingly says "outside." Speak up next time and nicely! I could of got this coffee at blue bottle! If ur gonna order order from the barista!
author: Daniel K.

description: I was here months ago while in San Francisco on a work trip. I STILL think about this place from time to time. I had toast with mascarpone, sliced pink lady apples, honey, and a soy latte. It's like they redefine toast. It was two thick slices of brioche, perfectly toasted so that there was a nice crunch to the crust, and the mascarpone and honey gave it the most wonderful, light sweetness. Honestly, I don't even know how you can do that with toast. Amazing. Really, really good. The place is cramped with a communal style table but I wouldn't mind eating the toast hanging upside down off of monkey bars. Its just that good.
author: Ji Hae P.

description:
we're always looking for an out-of-the-way local restaurant, this seemed to fit the bill...walked over from our hotel, and it's not a "restaurant" per se, really more of a walk-up counter serving food and espresso with one big communal table indoors and a 2-top on the sidewalk.  not a criticism, just not what we expected.  we sat at the sidewalk table, which faced a nice little wood / planter 'parklet' in the street.  nice.

all of which is a preface for...food was terrific.  my partner had the egg croissant, which was perfect, and i had the tart / quiche.  both were very good.

i don't know that we'll go again, as we're not in san francisco very often and like to mix things up, but i would recommend.
author: Matthew R.

description: This is such a quaint breakfast location. The chai tea was really tasty as well as the food! If you're looking for a cute find, this is it.
author: Alex E.

description:
Saw this place on Yelp and the reviews made it seem nommy. They have a different menu everyday, which is pretty cool too. There is a wait though because the place is pretty small, so if you want to sit and not stand, be prepared to wait a bit. They do have stand up eating areas outside on the sidewalk though. 

Almond Milk Latte. For my lactose intolerant self! It was alright, I thought their coffee was okay, not that great, I didn't really like the flavor the almond milk added and it tasted watery. But I did like how they drew a heart with my almond milk, cuz I'm kind of a sucker for stuff like that.

Smithfield Ham and Creamed Bloomsdale Spinach on top of an English Muffin. This was alright, I definitely thought the ham was overly salty but I guess that's expected of cured meats. Fortunately, the creamed spinach and English muffin neutralized the saltiness a bit. 

Lemon Curd, Strawberries, Sour Cream with a Brown Sugar Crumble. This was my absolute favorite. I think I'd come back if I knew it was served on a particular day. The sour cream wasn't too sour, definitely not like in a burrito or taco. But the flavors worked really well together, it was almost like a crumbly strawberry shortcake. NOMS!
author: Constance C.

description:
The best things in life are small, simple and delicious.  This place is truly the little gem of the neighborhood.  The quiche was silky and rich, the raspberries, cheese and honey on the walnut bread is my new favorite thing in the morning, and the hardboiled egg with mushrooms and bread is yummy. Mochas, cafe au lait etc. are rich.  
Yes, the place is tiny and you must share the only communal square table if you wish to eat inside, but how delightful a way to meet someone new over a satisfyingly fresh and delicious breakfast.  
Personally, I hope farm: table stays true to it's roots and stays small!
author: Marta F.

description:
In a nutshell, the food is pretty good, but neither spectacular nor well-presented, and the price is way too high for what you get.

Don't let other reviewers fool you with comments about farm:table's petiteness or cuteness or what not.  Yes, it is definitely small, maybe 10' x 10'.  There's one table with a couple of chairs and a bench.  But I don't pay for petite or small, I pay for food and service.

The service was pretty good, the two folks working the counter were quite nice, answered questions amicably and were otherwise attentive enough.  As for the food, it was fairly good, emphasizing fresh ingredients.  From the quite limited menu, I selected the:

  Apple & Clothbound Cheddar Sandwich
  Citrus - Cornmeal Cake
  Cafe Latte

The sandwich was served open-faced [cheese not quite completely melted on half the sandwich], two small slices of bread, sliced apples covered in melted cheese served on a small plate. The bread was very good and the sandwich overall was tasty. The citrus cake was quite nice, a nice breakfast cake which went great with the coffee.

So, what's my beef, why just two stars?  Well, for $8.50 I was expecting a bit more -- at least a decent sized sandwich, or maybe a small, even tiny, side salad to garnish the plate, or piece of fruit or, well, you get the picture. The citrus-cornmeal cake was $4.75. The single latte wasn't cheap either at $3.50.  And there you have it.  With tax my little lunch added up to $18!  

Sorry farm:table, I don't care if you are fresh or cute or whatever, your price-performance ratio is way out of whack.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Always, Always great! 
Never have been disappointed! 
If you are looking for seasonal, fresh local food- where the ingredients themselves speak for themselves, farm:table is the place for you!  They remind me of being in Greece, where for food is so simple but so fresh and flavorful.
They also are really good at combining flavors like savory and sweet, bacon and peach...
oh and the staff is really friendly, (and the guys are cute- can't beat that!)
author: Claudine D.

description:
Our lucky day. We stumbled upon this place and decided to check it out. Very small with a large table inside and a few tables outside. We were lucky enough to score one of the tables outside. 

The brioche was excellent and so was the coffee. Quality ingredients and great taste. 

I wish we stumbled upon places like this more often...
author: Jessica K.

description:
There's something about Farm:Table that makes me feel like I'm sitting outside in the streets of some scrumptous little town in Europe. Maybe it's the coffee served in jars, maybe it's the mopeds pulling up and away, maybe it's the feel of Post street with all of it's hostels spewing foreigners. Whatever it is, I adore it.

They serve a few staples here so for those that are indecisive (like me) this is a great place. We ordered the bread pudding, which there's no other way to describe as other than perfection. 

There is virtually no seating here, one big (farm) table inside and a couple of small tables outside so I imagine dining in will be hit or miss. We got lucky enough to grab one of the tables outside and enjoyed an absolutely gorgeous morning.
author: Julia N.

description:
I've been waiting for a place that's worthy of my 100th review.  Farm:table was it!

Wow, this is a very tiny place for having such a big reputation.  I wouldn't have found it if I wasn't looking for it.

A feeling of guilt is something that was missing from my breakfast.  In other words, extravagance isn't something they serve.  My "Toast of the Day" with apples, fromage blanc, and pecans was very earthly, so earthly that I also ordered a ham, cheese, and egg baguette for a little (ad by a little, I mean a lot) added protein.  The toast was superb.  The baguette was a bit too hard for me, and caused some discomfort to my single-tooth denture, haha.

Coffee (Americano) was pretty good.

Cash only :(
author: Jesse M.

description:
Cute concept, but Sooo overhyped!! (didn't try the food)
Expensive, SUPER small crowded space.
One round communal table smooshed up in the corner.

Biggest complaint- they only carry WHOLE MILK!!!?? seriously- what coffee shop only carries whole milk?? hot chocolate was $3 or $4 and Mocha was $5. If you dont' want whole milk, you can add Almond Milk for +$1. --I know SF is expensive..but this was kinda overboard.

If you don't mind the prices and the calories, the Hot chocolate was pretty darn tasty.  Not too bitter, not too sweet, not too hot, not too cold.  A++
author: Jennie Z.

description: I thought this place had a cool concept with the communal table and high quality coffee and food. The way they present the description it makes you get hungry imagining it. I was pretty disappointed when I ordered this great organic coffee to find that it is pre-made in batches (not single cup brew like most high quality coffee shops now-a-days) and the sandwiches were stale, tasteless, and about $7.50! I tried a mocha on a different day and was not impressed with anything there. I like they style of the place and the staff seems to work hard and are generally friendly but don't think the place gives out near what you pay for. :(
author: Collin L.

description: If you change your hours, you should post your new hours! I drove all the way into to city for what?
author: Tony L.

description:
It's all about the food here people!  That's it!...it's all about the food!  You'll either get it or you won't.  You are paying for high quality fresh ingredients.  They have 4-5 items on the menu.  The menu changes everyday.  They have fresh juice & great coffee.  If you feel like treating yourself have a dessert or two.
If you are the type of person who needs to get a 20 egg omelette or a Venti  size coffee in order to feel like you got your money's worth, Farm:table is NOT the place for you.
author: Kattya B.

description:
Disclaimer:  This review was written by a girl who doesn't feel comfortable dining at a table with her own family, much less a group of strangers. 

Of the two inviting options, I chose the hard-boiled eggs + chutney on very thick, hard-to-cut slices of bread.  While we ate, pieces of egg and bread crust flew in the air around the square communal table, and no diner emerged unscathed.  The almond butter + nectarines on wheat toast was a little easier to eat, but definitely still messy.  

I wouldn't bring a date here.  In fact, I ain't coming back until I'm settled in a relationship and no longer need my boyfriend to find me sexually desirable.

The service was EXCELLENT.  When I didn't get my re-fill on coffee, they asked me if I wanted to take it to-go, which was a thoughtful treat.  But great customer service doesn't compensate for the fact I had strangers watching me remove almond butter from my face and egg yolk from my sweater.   

Let's just say my poor coordination is the reason I like to eat, and do other things, with the lights off.
author: Janney B.

description:
I just spent Sunday morning on the sidewalk in the Tenderloin.  No, I didn't wake up there and no this was not the result of a tragic Saturday night I don't remember.  I went there to check out biscuit Sunday at farm:table.

This is my 130th review, and only my 15th 5 star.  The whole experience was wonderful.  We sat at one of the little tables outside on the sidewalk, and it was sunny and pleasant.  The staff was friendly and the service was great.  It was even prompt which surprised me considering the number of people there and the size of the kitchen.  

And the biscuits, oh the biscuits...  the devilish love child of butter and flour... were wickedly delicious.  I had the biscuit with poached egg and greens with mustard butter - absolutely amazing.  Everything was fresh, the egg was perfectly poached (in the shell) and yolk tied together the the buttery biscuits, the bitter greens, and the spicy mustard perfectly.  It was served with a little pickled carrot, which was also wonderful.  

I kept seeing out of the corner of my eye that several people were getting the biscuits with strawberries and honey ricotta.  Now,  one of the ways I am trying to make a difference in the world is by trying to start a trend of eating dessert after breakfast.  So of course, for the cause, and because I couldn't resist the call of those juicy, sexy, red strawberries, we ordered one of those too.  It was wonderful, and the dollop of rhubarb jam was a lovely touch. 

Coffee is usually pretty important for me at brunch because it counteracts the food coma that brunch usually induces.  But you can just come and enjoy the coffee for its deliciousness because they don't supersize the food portions here.  I guess you *can* have brunch and not feel the need to chase it with a nap.

farm:table represents a perfect execution of all the wonderful food/culture ideals so quintessential to San Francisco - the ingredients are seasonal, local, and farm fresh; the flavors are clean and refined; the one farm table fosters community around food; and they tweet their menu twice daily.  it's like eating everything great about San Francisco in every bite!
author: Linda L.

description: Sooooooo good!  Best cinnamon bun ever.  Only 4 out of 5 due to lack of seating.  Best breakfast sammich ever too.
author: Edwin L.

description:
What a lovely discovery. An itsy bitsy coffee house with beautiful delicious pastries and breakfast foods, serving Verve coffee with the expertise of ex-Blue Bottlers.

There's one wooden communal table inside surrounded by comfortable benches and big open windows, with a few tables outside. If you are addicted to photographing your food, come here some morning for the light, nice breeze, and cozy quarters in this lower Nob Hill oasis tucked among the car repair places.
author: Susie W.

description: Great americanos and breakfast sandwiches. Extremely small space and cramped space but worth it!
author: Ro B.

description:
I love farm:table so much! First of all, I was desperate to find good coffee and they are brilliant. Their espresso is so great and they make their own almond milk. It's simply amazing. I wish they opened earlier!

I love their ever changing menu. I've had a number of their quiches and they are simply to die for. They serve them with a side of dressed greens which are a great compliment to the fluffy delicate and savory quiche.
author: Sophie C.

description: Food was tasty & fresh organic but the place is very small only one table inside & two outside. Great coffee
author: Alia A.

description:
Don't get me wrong, this place is hella cute, but I had no idea how tiny it was gonna be inside.  That picture you see of the barista?  That's the whole place.  We were poking around behind the door looking for a secret room with tables or something.

We had one of the variations on the hardboiled eggs on baguette rounds with accoutrements.  The stuff on top was good, but the bread was beyond hard.  It tore up the roof of my mouth so badly, now I am not a happy camper :(

I'd go back for a cup of tea and test out some of their baked goods... those looked quite nice.
author: Meredith K.

description: Yum!!! watery frittata that took 30 min with no orders ahead of mine.  female chef with a sour face.  what a joke.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Farm:table is a one sharp little micro-restaurant. It must seat about 10 people max. The whole place seems like it is shoe-horned into the space of an average family room.

When you walk in, you are overcome by its petit cuteness. Straight ahead is the counter for ordering and the kitchen just behind. A LaMarzocco espresso machine sits prominently on the counter and to your left is the chalk board menu with a tiny list of of offerings. The owners worked for a local SF coffee company, so coffee figures prominently in the offering. Behind you is a banquette that is the entire seating area. There are a couple of two-tops on the street.

We were there for breakfast and enjoyed house-made granola and poached eggs on avocado plus crusty bread and carmelized onions. In addition, our barista made us a latte and a traditional cappuccino, all from Verve coffee in Santa Cruz. Everything was well crafted.

Since it is so small, we were able to talk with the owners at length. They explained their concept and talked about their passion for food and coffee. It is definitely a very personal place. We used to go to Canteen (they've stopped serving breakfast), but this will be our go-to place for breakfast in SF.
author: Joe J.

description:
Adorable space.

Enjoyable but not remarkable breakfast - I had swiss chard with bacon and soft-boiled egg on bread. $7.50.

I wouldn't come back especially for the food - I might come back for the charm.
author: Catherine H.

description:
I didn't get much argument about trying a new place for breakfast this morning...we were getting kind of "creped out" after 4 breakfasts at Honey Honey. Yelp directed me right across the street from our hotel to farm:table. How had we missed it???  When we got there, I knew why...there wasn't much to it other than the single communal wood table inside a room not much bigger than a closet. 

Talk about local flavor...this place was awesome! Serving a small selection of baked goods, the BEST coffee (and loose tea), and three rotating breakfast dishes (a cereal, a toast, and an egg dish), this is just the kind of place I adore. Two people excelling at a few selected creations and serving them very personally to lots of happy customers. For us, that meant a delicious breakfast and a full table, so we got our order to go and went back to our hotel lobby to savor our meal. 

One of the highlights of my trip was at breakfast here the next morning...a local mentally challenged patron came in and was treated with total dignity as he professed his love (and lust) for a fellow regular and filled the place up with his presence. If that doesn't show a place's true spirit, nothing does...
author: Janet D.

description:
I'm fairly confident I won't be returning to farm:table. I appreciate the concept, and the service was friendly, but I left the communal table unimpressed/depressed that everyone there shelled out nearly $7 for 3 tiny slices of baguette each topped with 1/2 of an unchopped hard boiled egg and a slice of bell pepper.

The food tasted alright (I didn't find my bread pudding to be particularly flavorful and I didn't enjoy the extremely tough/chewy chunks of bread) but if I'm going to pay $6-7 for a breakfast SNACK (I actually had to but a second breakfast immediately after) I would like it to be something I can't make at home due to lack of skill, ingredients or time. I did not feel that this was the case on my recent visit. Maybe you'll have better luck with a different daily menu. :)
author: Krystle S.

description: 2 coffees +  2 hard-boiled eggs + a stack of wheat toast with almond butter = $37.50.  Eventhough the food was good and the service a bit smug, I'm thinking way over priced for this hipster haven near Union Square.
author: Steve B.

description:
I absolutely hate places says "cash only". If I saw a restaurant says "cash only" at the door, I would say "Lets do somewhere else". Can anybody tell me who does NOT hate cash only places? Who would prefer carrying a bag of heavy coins and green papers in her thick wallet instead of a couple of plastic card?! 

On Sunday, me and my girl friend decided to go shopping at Union Square. So let's grab a cup of coffee on the way. Farm table sounds like a good place, I found it via yelp, and it's very close to union square. This is our first time here obviously, but wait, what? Cash only? Hold on, let me check, humm.... I only have three dollars cash... and the Latte is 3.50. My friend was like, "let me check, ah, I don't have cash either.... But I have coins..." We were at the cashier at the moment and the lady looked at us and felt very awkward. I was like, are you serious about this? I have Visa, Master, Amex, Discover, you can take anyone of them, JUST TAKE ONE please! "No, we only take cash, sorry. But don't worry about it, I'll just take whatever you have." I go "Ok, we'll just share one coffee then, one latte plz. @_@" Very embarrassed at the moment. After we ordered the coffee, my friend was keep digging her 3000 dollar LV purse and found all the coins she had at the moment, and added up to 3 dollars. She said, "Now I can order my au lait." Now the lady (she looks like the owner of the shop though) walked towards us with two cups of coffee, and said to me "here's your latte" and turned to my friend "here's your coffee, it's on us, don't worry about it." I went, "oh no plz, we just found 3 dollars, plz take it." She went "No it's ok, don't worry about it" She really wasn't gonna take it. Then later I beg her to take the 3 dollars.... She eventually took it. Hew...... What an embarrassing experience! 

Although I hate cash only places, but the lady was truly nice to us. We did get what we wanted in the end and the coffee was awesome! The shop was tiny but cozy, very French looking little shop, with red door and décor, and also wood furniture. There were also some people sitting out side the shop enjoy their espressos. I'll definitely come back!
author: Serena H.

description: Tiny little hole in the wall. Fantastic atmosphere. Great food. Amazing coffee. Ask for the honey latte. It's not on the menu.
author: Gita W.

description: Knowing what to expect makes this a great place to stop by, especially if you're touring and can hit it up on a weekday morning when it's a bit less busy.  The menu is spare, but everything is very well done.  We had the cereal and toast, which doesn't sound exciting but we were quite impressed. The cereal was included a balance of crunchy flakes, tart yogurt, and sweet fruit compote/jam. The toast was a surprisingly thick and flaky piece of perfectly toasted bread topped with delicate Marscapone and a combination of fresh fruit. I really applaud Farm:table on choosing just the right fruit because every bite was delicious without hitting a single overly tart or just-past-ripe bite. The coffee was above average, as well. Seating is limited, so be ready to share the indoor community table or balance in the pop-up park on the street. All-in-all, I'd suggest it as worth a try.
author: Cory M.

description: Was just ruminating on how much I love farm:table and how much I'm craving their homemade cereal when I realized that in my last review I'd forgotten to mention my favorite part. Not only is it absolutely delicious, quaint and wonderful, but the name is awesomely nerdy. Farm:table = farm to table (though I'm sure I didn't need to clarify that) and that makes me happy every single time I walk by. I love wordplay.
author: Maggie F.

description:
My next venture: I shall open a cookie shop that can only fit one person that is shorter than 5'3".  It will only serve a "cookie of the day" using all local ingredients...and only that one cookie.  It may be the hottest thing on Yelp for years to come.

There is a formula that is beginning to be unearthed here...

1) Business owner (most likely food oriented) has a good simple idea...which is basically do one thing and do it really well, e.g. Blue Bottle, Brenda's, Ike's, et al.

2) Find location that is impossibly small.

3) Let the rest take shape on its own.

The result is quite possibly an extended run on the top spots for "Hot on Yelp."

Farm:Table follows this exactly.  The product is pretty high quality and executed very well.  The service is charming and jovial...essentially it is a limited offering but what they do they do it well...a basic K.I.S.S. approach which I wholeheartedly believe in.

The interior has roughly 1000 CFT.  This makes it uncomfortably cramped when they have ...oh, lets say more than two customers at any given time.  Brenda's is palatial in comparison.

Therefore, some Yelpers come along...get some goodies, and rave about it here.  Other Yelpers see the high marks and like the concept and bookmark...turning into a snowball effect.  However, I really think the "bookmark to try" is more often then not a pipe dream in cases like this.

Sure, you've bookmarked, sounds great, getting there as a destination is actually more daunting than you originally figured...So, instead you resolve to try the place when you happen to be in the neighborhood.  You approach...it is impossibly small and may have an impossibly long wait.  You resolve to try next time...something this good must be worth a trip back next time.  All these people can't be wrong.

The key really is exclusivity.  Limit the number of people who try it by sheer logistics and you'll be Hot on Yelp for months on end...snowballing more and more.

If you happen to be there and don't mind reducing your personal space to basically nil then by all means go...it is pretty good.  If not, honestly, you can get the same elsewhere...like actually really...you can.  

The Emperor isn't wearing clothes...

Hypothesis proved.  Please sort by date and see review directly above on 12/31/2009.
author: Chris D.

description:
Okay, so I just had breakfast here and want to say something while the experience is still fresh.

farm:table, I want to give you three stars. You're bougie as hell and only have one table inside and two stools on the sidewalk; representatives of the proletariat might find it appropriate to smash windows, shout slogans, and distribute socialist pamphlets over the ruined hulks of espresso machines. But still. Your coffee is delicious, and there's a simplicity about you which softens the pretense.

Your sandwiches are delightful, on paper. 'Daily toast' with homemade jams and chutneys and colonialism and whatnot. I saw the hard-boiled egg on baguette with avocado (my new love interest), caramelized onion (an ex i'm still not over), and bacon (drool)...yesss, that sounds perfect. Let's try it!

I'm not a professional chef, but I know stuff and things about making and eating food. And you present me with this Rube Goldberg machine of a meal, I want no part of it! It was taller than wide, falling apart at the slightest touch and requiring careful reassembly between bites. I'm not eating, I'm doing a Jack Bauer impression and defusing this improvised explosive breakfast.

Do us a favor. Slice each of those baguette pieces in two once more. Don't put whole halves of the egg on each piece, but slice those in one of those little miniature lyres. Layer the bacon first, then the avocado as glue to keep it in place, then the egg, finally the onion as garnish.

Really, it'll be better this way, take my word for it. And I'll give you some more well-deserved stars. Do it for the people. And while you're at it...a 'cash only' sign would also be nice. Now back to labor!
author: Peter B.

description: Awesome place to have breakfast, whether you're in a hurry or not. The food is original and good, super nice waiter, offered a tea refill to go. Great atmosphere!
author: Charlotte D.

description:
Cute place. I should really give it 5 stars for its existence. Great business model, you really feel the heart of the staff in the food. Though the review is for the food, 3 star is fair.

The house cereal: GREAT flavor, just enough crunch, but was disappointed by the time I opened it when I got home. It got soggy because of the moisture from the yogurt. Would recommend divide the cereal and yogurt somehow when it's in a to-go cup.

The toast: really really bland, no flavor. Challah with thick cream cheese spread, topped with bits of fruits. Great concept but...it really needs more flavor. I added cinnamon and honey at home, it was much better. 

The sandwich: good flavor and generous portion, plus I love anything with fig in it.

Great place for a quick, good coffee, snacks. Food-wise...to be improved.

Btw...memorize the recipe so you don't have a big book in front of you, it's a tiny kitchen there...It's cute if it's at a friend's place, but not at a cafe.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
So when I first wandered in I was starving and saw a meatloaf sandwich on the menu. I was dealing with a bit of a hangover so I just wanted some water. After getting my order number (on a stick), I asked if I could have some water; this is when the place began to reveal it's essential awesomeness to me. I was told the water is on the table. When I looked at the table there were a bunch of young hostel travelers there who cleared a spot for me. In the middle of the table was a carafe of water and I fixed myself a glass. 

My food arrived quickly as I listened to these travelers chatting away about social networking websites of all things. I even drifted into the conversation occasionally as social networking is something that I have one or two opinions about.

The sandwich was delicious!!! The bread was perfectly soft and tasty. The meatloaf was in generous portion and irresistibly seasoned. There was also a delicious mini apple on the plate. 

After a little while the travelers left and were replaced with a group of regulars who sat and discussed the coffee scene in SF, which I had no idea was so complexly interesting. Everybody was inclusive to outsiders like myself and I even decided to extend my stay long enough to enjoy a drip coffee.

If you are looking for a coffee and a quick bite this place is great but it is also a good place to go if you just want to hear some interesting conversations. This place is not a laptop party so leave it at home.
author: Eric G.

description: This little breakfast eatery is located between downtown SF and the Tenderloin District. After being introduced to the goodness of the place by my friend during my trip to SF  last August, farm:table has become my go-to place for breakfast every time I am in town. This trip, I went there on two different mornings, just because I couldn't get enough. My choice of beverage is always the milk and honey. I also tried one variation of their daily toasts (there are several and all delicious), their pickled egg sandwich, and their potato tortilla. Every recipe is different and unique and I have never ordered the same dish twice. This place has my highest recommendation.
author: Joan W.

description: Finally, real coffee! Delicious coffee - honestly think the best in SF. Delicious organic food. Up most recommendstion!
author: Chamee S.

description: Just what a small, neighborhood coffee shop should be.  Outstanding, high-quality teas.  Wonderful quiche and tarts. And friendly service.  I just wish there was twice as much space--but the other customers were friendly and made room.  A little pricey but quality costs.
author: Michael N.

description: Delightful!  Just grabbed a Mexican chocolate scone and the Spanish potato tortilla.  Both were divine.  The scone was soft and fluffy, not heavy or greasy.  The Spanish potato tortilla with the aioli was creamy and highly tasteful - i recommend both.  This place is so tiny and cute and the park-let out front is super funky.  I highly recommend this place.  Ask for the daily toast!
author: Casie M.

description: Breakfast was fantastic -- had the house cereal and the daily toast. Delicious. Would no question get 5 stars if the server wasn't a jerk. When I asked for a receipt after I had already paid for my meal (I apologized first, acknowledging that I should have asked when i paid) he said "it's a little late" and walked away. Pretty unreasonable in my opinion, given this is certainly within the normal expectations of his job and even a basic payment processing system has the ability to generate receipts after the fact.. Would go back for the food but hope to not encounter that guy again. I hope you don't either if this is how he regularly conducts himself.
author: Jeff K.

description: The dish they put online they actually don't have it. I feel they are not honest on their Manu. Plus they only have one table inside. Very disappointing. When restaurant is lying about their Manu what else you can expect. They should be reported.
author: steve k.

description:
FARM:TABLE HAS THE BEST COFFEE IN SAN FRANCISCO

(ducking preposterous glances hurled from beautiful Philz coffee bitch) - i'll go back there, too, because i think bitchy is hot.

back to farm:table - this is only a review of the COFFEE and the SERVICE.  i didn't get to eat at farm:table, but it's on my short list when i get back to San Francisco...

no one with a heart and a palate couldn't love this place.
author: Erin I.

description:
Farm:table is a breath of fresh air for someone whose access to coffee is limited to Starbucks because of it's convenience and the paucity of decent cafes in the home area. Even for the boyfriend--a Starbucks zealot--the coffee here definitely impressed him if not reopened his eyes to the world of REAL coffee (he always forgets its existence). 

For 4.80 they make a mean mocha. Gritty, not too sweet, milk just hot enough, it was perrrfection. Their food/breakfast alike are actually average in price. Try the boiled eggs served on top of a baguette with asparagus and shaved Parmesan. I personally enjoyed eating my breakfast at the community table, sharing newspapers with others, and writing over an already completed Sudoku puzzle, but if you like your space take your order to go. There is maybe one more table outside that seats two, but that concludes the seating provided here. 

The friendly barrister gave me a sample of the dark chocolate he used to make my coffee and happily shared facts about their beans, though my short-term memory has failed me. I do remember we came the day before Valentine's Day so I got a heart in my foam. :) Places like this make me wish I lived in the city. Preferably upstairs to this coffee shop.
author: Alesia T.

description:
I bookmarked this place before my trip to San Francisco because it was ranked #1 on the Hot On Yelp list. If it's hot I have to give it a try, right? 

I wish I had a place like Farm:Table within walking distance from my house. I totally dig what they are about and how the do business. Some douche asked for Splenda and the lady behind the counter politely told him, "We don't do that here..." How awesome is that? 

Unfortunately Farm:Table wasn't what I was looking for the morning I visited. I was hoping that the morning crush had passed but the place was packed which meant that my scone and hot beverage was going to be a to go order. I was hoping for a relaxed spot at the tiny farm table so I could read the paper and start the day slowly. 

My scone was excellent (I think it was honey corn something or other) and since I'm not a big coffee drinker I went with the hot cider. The barista put a splash of almond milk in my cider to make it creamy and it was an excellent addition. I almost feel bad for not trying the coffee that so many people love but maybe I'll give it a go next time.
author: Britt W.

description:
