Love this place. So cozy, so inviting. Definitely a great place to go to on a weekend morning. I tried their latte (delicious) and their hard boiled eggs with pesto on a baguette...wow..it was phenomenal. Also had a bite of their chocolate cake, equally as impressive. 

In addition to their food and excellent service, what's really memorable about this place is the setting. You feel like you're eating at your breakfast nook..namely because there's only one table which every one eats at. Very cute idea. Love how inviting this place is. 

Definitely check this place out. It's a great way to start off a weekend morning.
author: Shreya C.

description:
The food is tasty, original, and seems to vary daily. The staff is very very friendly. I won't bather on about the food because I only ate here twice in my short visit to San Francisco, but I will tell you that both sandwiches were divine. I was hungry, to be sure, but their were more than just edible. Yum. Wish we had a place like this back home.

Minus one star for the price. Sandwich+coffee came to $11. Too steep to make me a regular, but a great spot while on vacation.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The staff here was super friendly and the food was pretty amazing. I had the boiled eggs and chilis on french bread....so yummy! The coffee was superb, and the place in general just had a great vibe.

Be willing to take your food to go if you need, because they only have one table inside and two small tables outside.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Ah, the new darling of Yelp. It was because of its high-rating that caused me to visit farm:table in first place. You know, time to see what everyone was talking about.

What I found was a tiny space with one semi-large indoor table, and two outdoor tables. A cafe that could sit a maximum of a dozen people. The idea itself sounds challenging, especially in a world of Starbucks and Peets that house multiple tables and are created with the mindset that the coffee shop should be your third "home" (after your real home and work, of course.) So how could farm:table do the same thing with such a small space?

I'm not sure if I have the answer, but I will say that my first visit turned out to be pleasant and quaint. As my friend and I sat at the table, a rotation of about 6 others joined and left the table. It wasn't a lounge spot, but you never felt pressured to gulp down your coffee to avoid the leering stares of people waiting for a seat. It simply was a place to be, for a moment, in a moment of tranquility.

What works to its advantage is its locale. It is a bit out of the way for many people, unless they live in the Tendernob hill area. I honestly can't see myself making the trip on MUNI simply to have a coffee and sit at this table. So perhaps it will always be a place in flux.

But to its product: the iced coffee was served in a mason jar and was quite delicious. The menu changes daily, and consists of only two or three things. The food was adequate, although a bit small for my liking. The service was quite amazing and you could tell that even though this place was a bit new to the neighborhood, its owners were establishing good rapport with some consistent customers.

A good cup of coffee and a nice change of pace, but honestly, not going to make a special trip to go here. It will be a good place to visit whenever I'm visiting the neighborhood.
author: Bryan B.

description: On a busy Sunday morning the line went quickly. Amazing, AMAZING coffee today. Ethiopian single source. Plus the food was delicious!!  If you like good coffee and real food then it's a must go in San Francisco!!
author: R U.

description: Let's just say it's liquid crack.  Iced Coffee is the best.
author: Jasmine N.

description:
I could see how this place is a breath of fresh air for anyone who lives in the area.

It's a very adorable cafe in the middle of an otherwise GHETTO part of the city.  The staff were real friendly, the food was good, and I somehow felt healthier eating there... 

Plus, the excitement of not knowing whats on the menu tomorrow... ohh the suspense!
author: Clarissa P.

description: This place was very adorable and teeny. There isn't much room for sitting and chatting or sitting and eating, but the coffee was great. I like my coffee dark and strong, so this was my type of place. It's in a great area and there's a beautiful mini park seating area outside.
author: Abby S.

description:
I loved this place! They only serve a few dishes and the menu changes daily. We went for breakfast this morning and I had the daily toast with homemade almond butter, coconut flakes and sliced bananas. My companera had hard-boiled eggs served over toasted bread with habanero chutney and feta cheese. Both dishes were really yummy (even though I preferred mine) and just right in the portion size for a breakfast that doesn't leave one full and bloated. 

The food here is super duper fresh and they way they juxtapose the contrasting flavors shows a real flair and knowledge of pairing. The coffee drinks are tasty and rich. You even get little designs in the crema of the cappuccinos and caffe lattes :) 

I had read about the one communal table in the place and I somehow envisioned a long banquet table accommodating several people. But the place is so tiny that the actual table is only about four feet by four feet. Yeah, you might be asked to get up and move over a couple times to let others sit with you but it's really not that big of a deal. It's actually quite intimate and even lends to conversation amongst strangers, which is what a big city like San Francisco can use more of now and then. There are also a couple of small two-tops outside. 

I will make an effort to go back here and try this place again the next time I am in the city. I'm anticipating they will eventually move to another location to accommodate the growing number of fans. Let's hope it doesn't lose the charming ambiance or the superb quality of the food and drinks if that ever does happen. Thanks Yelpers for helping me find this place!!  I can't wait to go back.  I love SF!!
author: Slim S.

description:
Ooh lookee, lookee! Number 800. (But after posting this it says I only have 760 reviews? wtf)

I admire this place but I cannot vouch for their drinks. Their drinks look really good; unfortunately, I already had my sugar and caffeine medication for the day (brownie/coffee). The drink menu hosts a comfortable amount of different coffees and other non-caffeinated drinks such as apple cider. Along with drinks they have a modest selection of cookies and pastries available.

Their food menu consisted of three dishes that change daily. On this particular day it consisted of a sandwich, a salad, and a soup. They all sounded really good. I choose the beef sandwich with grilled onions and horseradish gorgonzola.

The sandwich is yummy. The bread is super cashmere soft with chewy crust. The beef is surprisingly tender. Everything else in the sandwich works just great. They also give you a mini apple that is super sweet. The sandwich was really good but it doesn't justify the near $9 price tag. I think $6 would be more appropriate. Some chips or fries and a pickle on the side would have been a great addition as well. I guess this is downtown pricing?

The interior is just what the name suggests, a communal farm table with a jug of water. The table seats 8-10 people in the center of the room. That's basically it for the dining room. The rest is a small kitchen where they churn out all the food and beverages. The chalkboard menu is along the front of the cashier wall. Everything is minimal but done with a tasteful eye. Keep in mind that there isn't a bathroom. Not a place for groups or business meetings.

The staff is very friendly. There were two women and one bearded Elijah Woods looking fellow, all working the kitchen/cashier. You don't even have to pay until you're done. They clearly have a devoted following because each customer would hash up a conversation like they were old pals. This place became crazy busy in the afternoon.

The customer base looks just like the staff. Middle-aged seldom arm tattooed folk that could only originate from the Bay Area or Seattle. I witnessed: a lot of iPhone texters, a group of girlfriends complementing one's ass, a Bape-wearing couple, and a long haired skater-looking dude giving the staff tupperware for them to put his food in. I love SF.

___

More of a takeout third-wave coffee house. Food menu changes daily. Great service and attitude.
author: Michael H.

description:
Sweet, yet another business lives up to the hype, and this time it's in my neighborhood!

I came here and had the Tendernob (a shot of espresso with some cream/foam) as well as a cup of coffee.  Both were delicious, so you can't go wrong with coffee or espresso drinks.  

I also tried the sandwich, the same roast beef sandwich that Michelle M. described, and it was excellent as well.  I can't wait to come back and try the baked goods and other daily menu offerings.

Service is friendly, and the place is tiny but there's a friendly vibe to it so cozy up at the communal table and enjoy some awesome coffee/food.
author: Joseph N.

description:
It's tiny.
It's fresh as can be.
Its menu changes every day.
It's super delicious, like your best friend just made you the most scrumptious simple comfort CA farmy food for lunch in their apartment.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Probably isn't anything that I can say that hasn't already been said. The food here is great and the service was friendly. Wish they were in a bigger location but who cares when you're eating!

Ill definitely be back.
author: V L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food at this small but fine establishment. 

I like the daily menu approach because it keeps things fresh and exciting. I had the Spice Pork on Challah and it was very tasty. the pork was very juicy and flavorful and paired well with the frech press coffee of the day and the mixed greens side salad. I will go back in the future to find another tasty meal on my plate.
author: Devin N.

description:
I rolled into farm:table pretty late for breakfast one weekday morning.  Luckily, the daily chalkboard menu was still set on eggs and toast.

The food and coffee selection is awesome.  This cafe's originating idea is definitely novel.  The menu is dreamed up daily based on a few wholesome ingredients, and the seating is just one large table where strangers mingle.  Obviously with one table things get crowded and awkward, but the staff is nice enough to ask everyone to squeeze together.

On this visit I had eggs, ham, and fig/ginger chutney.  It had all the appeal of homey breakfast food, without being heavy.  I also shared a pot of green tea with my bench neighbor, though it was a very lacking compared to what I find down in JTown.  Supposedly, this is a coffee joint, which the menu supports, so I'll be back to give it a shot.
author: Sean B.

description: This was good food. Took it to go as they were steadily running out of menu items I was left to try the egg sandwich with goat cheese and verde sauce. It was delicious, the boiled eggs were cooked to perfection. The latte was super creamy and tasty. The wait was way too long for a simple to-go order of a simple boiled egg sandwich though. I live near here so likely will be back because I appreciate a small menu with fresh items and robust flavors.
author: Piper W.

description:
Having just been to Columbia this week, I suddenly had an insatiable urge for good coffee.  For the longest time, I've only been able to tolerate coffee if it was "covered" up by sugar and flavored lattes.  I never liked the bitter aftertaste.  In reality, I've learned this week that the aftertaste only happens because I've settled for crappy coffee all these years.

My first stop was Farm: Table.  The place is so tiny that its hard to assume that they would have the room to make anything, let alone some of the BEST coffee in the city. 

When we arrived, Shannon and Kate took the time to explain how they select their coffee brands, pull shots and brew coffee to make it taste unique.  Then when they served it, the coffee was sofa king smooth.  There wasn't any coffee aftertaste in the Ethiopian blend we tried...absolutely perfect!

Now don't go there expecting to hang out for a long time.  The place is pretty popular and the table at the restaurant is about the same size as my kitchen table at home.  But the coffee, their friendliness and their unique setup make it worth seeing whenever you are in town.
author: Jeff G.

description:
we had the asparagus and feta quiche and the soft boiled egg over brioche with fava bean puree, prosciutto+ arugula.  beautiful.  look at my photos.  we loved both.  great bread and combo.  great prices. look at  the pics. the quiche was $8 (little more than expected esp. compared to what you can get at tartine's) but it was still great.  the brioche was really tasty. i really enjoyed the fava been puree.

there are only a few items daily, so make sure you get there early enough.  i got the last quiche and it was about 1pm.
author: o g.

description: Tried their daily toast. I got lucky. Strawberries and mascarpone. Yum!
author: Olivia A.

description: My boyfriend and I stopped in for breakfast on a recent trip to SF. The place is small and cozy, with one tabletop for eight and a couple small tables outside. It was pretty chilly out, so we squeezed in at the big table. The environment is welcoming, cozy and it provides the perfect opportunity to meet new people. For travelers, this is a great spot to make friends and get great restaurant and bar recommendations. The staff was kind and the food was excellent. I had the house made granola with yogurt and spiced apples.  My partner had the house made bread with mascarpone, citrus and almonds. They were both excellent- light, but filling and perfect for a long day of exploring. The day we left, we stopped in for one last breakfast here and once again, were delighted with the food.  If I lived here, I would spend way too much money here.
author: Abigail Jane D.

description:
There is a lot to love about this place. It is indeed very charming and the service was friendly and fast. I love a lot of the details about this place like the central bottle of water with fruit floating around and the decorations on the wall. And I LOVE the coffee. If this was a coffee shop alone, I would have given it 5 stars. I don't usually like coffee. I rarely finish even small cups of coffee and after coming here, I realized that it's just because other places don't make it correctly. I got a large cup of mocha and downed that thing. 

I took off two stars for the food. Their sandwhich that day had bacon, avocado, and carmelized onion (yum!). But those ingredients alone could carry any sandwhich and while I felt like the ingredients were indeed fresh, there was nothing special about it. The boyfriend and I also shared a mixed green salad with shaved fennel and oranges. Again, super fresh but the proportions were wrong for me (We got about 2 orange slices for an overflowing plate of greens) and the dressing was overpowering in its acidity. 

Overall, this place was just ok for me. Would I come here again for the coffee? No doubt. But it has not become one of my essential stops for when I visit SF.
author: Kai L.

description:
This is a very small place as others have said.  Probably six people can sit inside and that's if you are all rather friendly with each other.

But, the coffee is awesome!  Only organic whole fat milk is used, so no skinny lattes here.  It's nice to grab a cup and walk around the city sipping it.

I've not tried their pastries, but they all look good and appear to be organic.

When we are in the area, we'll be here getting our morning fix!
author: Jody R.

description:
Best coffee in the neighborhood. Excellent food for both breakfast and lunch with a menu that changes daily. Early on, they had some troubles with selling out of food not long after lunch started, but they've not only significantly improved that, they're now also open until 6pm during the week! I no longer have to leave the neighborhood for a cappuccino after 4pm!

It's cozy and often packed, but don't be shy - sidle up next to your neighbors at the community table and enjoy your drink.
author: Derek W.

description:
I came in with four people, and was really pleasantly surprised by how awesome a brunch we had.  With the small space and good reviews, I expected the experience to be characterized by good food, but with a little bit of a struggle for space, etc., especially because we had a reasonably large group for the size of the place.  But aside from a really minor wait and squeeze in the beginning, it was wonderful.  Some lovely people at the common table moved over a bit so that we could sit together and not be super-cramped, and we had a brief, fun conversation with them.  The people working there were equally awesome; they were really friendly. The ambiance of the place, at least in our experience, was really cozy and friendly -- as opposed to cramped.  It doesn't hurt that it's a lovely space.

As for the food, I thought it was simple, fresh and really good.  I had the toast with cherry tomatoes and egg, as did two others in our group; the toast was a good consistency and the egg was perfectly done.  (I didn't share others' experiences of the bread being really thick or tough.)  We also had the bread pudding, which was unusual -- the texture wasn't as homogeneous as other bread pudding that I've had, but it actually really enhanced the dish, in my view.  The iced coffee was so good that two others in the group had it after they tasted mine -- even though we each had already had a coffee.  The only thing that I had that I recommend avoiding is the espresso, which I found a little thin and bitter.  

Overall, a really terrific meal without the drawbacks that other reviewers have noted.
author: Danielle G.

description:
I almost wanted to give a bad review so that I could keep this place to myself. But then I realized that would do no good.

Farm:Table is an incredible no-frills coffee house. Try the Tendernob. It's a variation on the Gibralter served at Blue Bottle.
author: Peter C.

description:
A hidden gem, tucked away in some random block in the Tenderloin, this tiny place is always bustling with locals who all to seem to know each other.

Yet this is not your standard coffee house. The real allure of this place is in the food and coffee- all locally sourced, ultra-fresh ingredients that's a step above the rest. The menu, although small and limited to about 3 items, is carefully thought out and has creative offerings that change on a daily basis.  Usually they will offer a salad, sandwich, and some sort of pastry/dessert (like apple crisp) that sounds commonplace at first, but often involves some surprise ingredient or twist (example: a chevre citrus mint vinaigrette) that makes this place worth a stop if you're heading into Union Square to shop.
author: Mike B.

description:
About two weeks after I discovered Farm:Table and its delicious lattes, a friend stayed at a hotel two blocks away. I told her she HAD to go.  The morning she planned to go, it rained. Hard. She almost didn't go.  But then she remembered how bossy I am, and how there's always a reason for it. 

So she went, and she said she was so glad she didn't settle for hotel lobby coffee.  F:T serves one of the best lattes either she or I have tasted, and has consistently delicious treats and sandwiches. The prices for food are a little high, but the food is also just that little bit better because it tastes homemade.  Well worth the occasional splurge; and the coffee should simply be a staple of every local's diet.
author: Pei L.

description:
So tasty that I deduct nothing for hipsters nor neighborhood.  Tiny and cute, not like me at all.  

hard boiled eggs with smoked salmon and dill sauce on baguette, toast of the day with almond butter, toasted coconut and bananas.  

amazing.  wish i had room for the bread pudding.
author: Poppy C.

description: They have Square! Rejoice and charge your organic heart away.
author: Sherae H.

description:
The best breakfast I've had in a very, very long time! This is seriously one of my very favorites. 

What a concept - one table in this tiny little restaurant. I came with a group of 7, and we fit at this table with 2 others at different times. What a great conversation starter. At 3 different times in 1 hour, we met a family from Orange County, a couple from long beach and another couple from San Diego. There were a couple of bistros outside the restaurant so that others could eat, of course.

The hard boiled egg over crusty bread breakfast was magical - melted in my mouth - also included were fresh tomatoes, sweet corn, bacon, and drizzle of olive oil. 

I wouldn't choose 2 $$ to label this. I actually thought this $6.75 breakfast was very affordable. This space-saving, conversation-starting, hunger-satisfying little restaurant was worth the 20 minute walk. ENJOY!!
author: Christine M.

description: Went here this morning with a friend. We both got a the soft boiled egg on brioche with dill cream and chiogga beat. The sandwich was absolutely delicious but, as many others have said, it was not very much food for $7. I'm glad that I tried the place and I absolutely support their approach to food but I think it's a spot that's better for a light breakfast instead of a more substantial weekend brunch.
author: Sydney L.

description:
Farm: Table is like coming home. I stepped in from the cold and was greeted by two friendly people behind the counter and two people dining at a large table, much like you would expect to find in someone's kitchen. The atmosphere is cozy, warm and inviting. 

The small menu changes daily and as the name suggests, is all about ingredients fresh from the farm and straight to the table. On this particular day the menu featured a potato soup and egg salad sandwich. When I inquired about the soup, one of the diners piped in and told me she had just finished her bowl and it was amazing. I grabbed a spot on the bench at the table and proceeded to have a lovely lunch with two complete strangers who, by the end of the meal, I was on a first name basis with. I also learned from the two behind the counter (who were also chatting with us throughout our meal) that someone associated with my work comes in almost every morning. 

The family style table is conducive to meeting people if you choose, or if you aren't into talking to strangers, bring a book or a mobile device.

A cup of fleur de sel hot chocolate kept me toasty on the walk back to work and was a great way to end a fabulous meal with new friends.
author: Lee H.

description:
I found farm:table on yelp and decided to check it out with a friend after being caught by the fact that they twitter their menu daily! i thought this was a brilliant idea, always changing their menu based on what's fresh and only offering three menu items!

i twittered the menu and was overly pleased with what it said! after getting there with a friend, we realized the menu wasn't anything like what was posted but it reeaally didn't seem to matter one bit. everything was sooo good, especially the coffee. they really know what they're doing back there with their artisan and beautifully crafted coffees. i even got to try almond milk in my latte which i instantly loved.

i love that, true to the name, there is just one medium sized farm table for seating. on peak times during the weekend, the table is quite full which is the only con i can really come up with. there are two small two-person table outside but when the weather doesn't permit, inside it is. people are usually more than happy to share their bench with you though so i wouldn't recommend bringing a whole bunch of people at one time. great place to visit solo or with a friend.

delicious food, amazing coffee, friendly staff, a true hole in the wall that is adorned with a farm table. wonderful :)
author: Jessica M.

description:
Finally got an outside table here at our most recent trip to the city (couldn't get a spot on our previous trip). 

The food and coffee here is incredible. Just order one of everything and you'll be good to go.
author: Erik D.

description:
Is it as good as Blue Bottle? No

Is it the second-best coffee in San Francisco? Yes

Is this 5-star coffee? Absolutely
author: Mark A.

description:
Not being a breakfast person,
Not being a morning person,
Not being a "sweets" person,

I was surprised to find myself craving their toast a day after first trying it.  And then, even though the toast was different the next time I went, I still find myself craving it on a regular basis.  The toast, along with the rest of their menu, changes daily, but the core philosophy behind it stays the same: excellent bread (usually pan de mie from FIREBRAND bakery in Oakland) with a very pleasant, light, subtle mix of a cream-like substance (sometimes a mascarpone cheese spread) with very fresh slices of fruit on top.
author: Peter L.

description:
Reasons why this place is the bestest right now:

1) farm:table - can't get any simpler than that

2) SMALL menu that changes daily. You can follow them on twitter to find out what's on for that day

3) biscuit Sundays

4) cool, nice people that work there

5) they obviously don't need tweezers or eye droppers to finish off and sauce a plate before serving it to me

6) house made almond milk

7) Firebrand bread
author: cora j.

description:
Rodney got one for ya,

Farm:Table, first was the weird colon... don't get it don't care.  My colon is pretty happy no matter what, after I passed these delectables from this outer tenderloin gem.  

Like a broom closet filled with exotic models forced to create the most perfectly digestible delights my lips have laid witness to.  Try pairing it with a $4 iced coffee dream.  Sweet and solid!

After getting all to aware that a fall from a 14th floor cineplex escalator could not only mangle my dangle but scar some delicate inner abyss, i realized the small moments can still benefit from a sip of delicious brew.

Glad that the trivergence effect is forming slowly as I become aware of my fellow Farm:Table feasters, I can only gaze into the galazy of new taste consultants and trust they will fill my denizen complete.
author: rodney k.

description:
Simply amazing coffee. The staff (owners?) are really friendly, and always have a bunch of coffee speak to throw my way. 

I'm spoiled working across the street: no other coffee stands up!
author: Brooke B.

description:
Stopped in on Halloween today where Farm:Table was having a biscuit special. Got a nice biscuit and a cappuccino.

Biscuit was served with apples, bacon and maple fromage blanc (the delicious spread). The biscuit was great, flaky wonderful, but I found the overall taste a little too sweet. I think I would've liked their other more savory concoctions and I intend to write a second review once I stop in earlier in the day.

Cappuccino was good, not out of this world, but good. Mocha that my friend ordered was good as well.

Would definitely try again.

TL;DR: Fresh yummy biscuits were had after a long pre-halloween expedition. Slightly sweet, but delicionable.
author: Joshua G.

description: Tried to eat at Dottie's this morning, however 1 hour waits are not my style. Luckly i checked to see what else was nearby and farm:table came up.  Tiny cafe with a few selections of hot breakfast items, bigger selection of pastries and definitely lots of coffee. Was a great find. We ordered at the counter, sat down with others at their one table and enjoyed a nice breakfast.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Great place. Very good food and coffee. But it is tiny and they only have one person preparing the food. If you see a large group inside expect to wait 15-30 minutes. Or just get coffee and pastry. But if you have the time it is worth the wait. 

Note: There is an overflow space outside (one of those San Francisco sidewalk garden thingies) which accommodates more people if they are willing to squat.
author: Ara K.

description: Great coffee and a modern parklet for Post street.
author: Nate M.

description:
Best iced coffee, EVER! 

I moved into the neighborhood about 9 months ago and this little spot is probably the best thing about living around here... Maybe the only good thing about living around here...

The food is always tasty, and the staff is always super sweet and friendly. And that iced coffee ... I daydream about it!! I've brought 6 different out-of-towners here, and they all tell me how much they miss the iced coffee. 

A few things before you go...
- The space is teeny tiny so I'd try and go during the off hours. 
- On that note, they keep somewhat small hours. So be sure that they're open before you trek over here. 
- If you're eating there, they have you pay after you finish. This always seemed strange to me because I'm sure I'm not the only one who's almost forgotten to pay before I scooted out...especially if I'm sitting outside. 
- The prices are a bit more then I'd like to pay, but for a special treat every few weeks, it's definitely worth it! 
- And it's cash only! But, there's a liqueur store a few shops down that has an atm with a pretty low fee.
author: Francesca Z.

description:
This place is a gem!! Owner/Chef is very nice and sweet. 

Haven't had such a great cup of cappuccino in a while. Hard boiled egg with red/yellow pepper, and feta cheese topped on a baguette was awesome!! Chocolate bread pudding was very delicious!!! Quality food. 

oh... pet owners: there is outdoor seating and grab a dog biscuit for your doggie. 

We'll be back...
author: peggy c.

description:
Astonishingly fresh choices, and an inventive menu without being crass or cutesy.  The toast was amazing, with locally sourced fruits and bread.  And the service very friendly and welcoming. 

I am a big breakfast person, and a bit averse to trying new spots, but I was very very pleased when a close friend brought me here.  The Coffee I hear is excellent and the tea selection is incredible.
author: Richard A.

description:
There are only few items on the menu but it doesn't matter if they are done very well! The ingredients are really fresh and just bursting with flavor and colors, you can check out their daily menu on twitter.

The boiled eggs on sliced toasted baguette, topped with prosciutto tomatoes and squash was simply lovely

we also shared the figs on toasted wheat bread with marscapone and topped with pecans which was also delicious.  

The mocha with soy was ok. I personally don't like grittiness of their coffee but that's just me. 

I would come here all the time if I lived in the city. sigh.
author: Annie c.

description: Wow, what a treat. This place has lovely dishes that change every morning, great place for a cup of decent coffee and interesting twists on breakfast. I had slices of a toasted baguette topped with a cold hard boil egg, caramelized union and bleu cheese sprinkled on top, it was simply great. Great place to break the monotony and have a unique and simple breakfast. I follow them on twitter and get to see interesting concoctions almost daily which makes me want to go back even more. It wasn't too busy when I was there, but don't count on getting a seat without waiting for a little, very limited space. As you can tell by my review and others, this is a great place to grab a quick bite in the morning.
author: Blake O.

description:
Two cups of 1950's French Pressed Coffee...
Meatloaf Sandwich on amazingly fresh wheat bread...
Honey Panna Cotta (topped with honeycomb from the rooftop bee hives "down the street")...
Good friend to share Saturday night stories...
And you have one perfect little Sunday afternoon.
author: Katie L.

description:
I'm not a black coffee/espresso drinker.  If I were able to drink milk, I would order a super delicious latte like my husband always gets, but I end up getting their regular coffee with almond milk, which is just... regular.  

They always have yummy little tasty baked goods.  They have a changing salad, soup, and sandwich each day.  They're all homemade with the highest quality ingredients, but can be hit or miss as far as flavor.  

To summarize this is A VERY QUAINT COFFEE SHOP WITH A FEW LOVELY FOOD ITEMS.  You order at a counter.  It is a very small cozy room with one shared table.  There are a couple outside tables for two.  Everything is first come, first serve.  

I hear they are doing a "brunch" on Sundays, which is why they are closing early (2-2:30?).  It seems their closing time varies a bit, so be aware.
author: Dina A.

description: I want to like this place more than I actually do. What a nice idea, and so well-placed right in the tendernob. Whenever I check their twitter feed I think the food sounds great, but whenever I'm actually there, the options don't seem that appealing. As has been mentioned, the only milk available is full fat, which I think is a bit of a shame. I like coffee with a lot of milk, so the coffee has to be strong to start with, and I find full fat milk to be too creamy in such a combo. The first time I went I got a cafe au lait and it was really quite bad - the coffee was bitter and weak. Since then I've stuck to espresso drinks, which are good. My hopes stay high, although I'm not sure why.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Creative, but very limited menu.  Only four items available on the day I visited- all that I could have readily prepared on my own.

The biggest downside- there is a single square table indoors that can't seat more than 8 people.  This means that, in the event that you get an unpleasantly self-centered verbose involuntary dining companion, that person will be totally in your face.  My chatty neighbor was so busy regaling her friend (and by extension, everyone at the table) with the tedious details of her personal life that she managed to knock over her coffee, which poured right onto my lap.  Rarely have I been as happy to make a quick getaway from a restaurant.
author: Mark T.

description:
I'm not one to knock Peets or Starbucks. They serve their purpose, and they're, for the most part, clean and well kept. 

But even I have to admit that there's this feeling I get when I sit down at a Peets/S-bux to read a book... it's a kind of ho-hum "I'm at yet another Peets that looks like a Peets and has the typical Peets customers ordering the typical Peets drinks" feeling. You know what I mean? It's a lack of inspiration... and I guess it's to be expected when the decor and layout is so studied.

farm:table, on the other hand, couldn't be a more perfect example of what it means for a space to have personality, charm, and warmth. It's refreshing to stop by a place as a first-time customer, sit at the one and only communal table, and feel like you're welcome. The simple decor, the friendly staff, and the coziness of the space embody what most people want and appreciate in a local cafe. 

The coffee tasted rich, the baked good I purchased was a nice complement to my drink, and I was able to read my book in a pleasant atmosphere that lacked pretension. 

I'm sold.
author: Brian K.

description:
It should be noted upfront, just in case you missed it in all the other reviews -- this great find is in a very, very small space.  A few tables outside, a single common table seating around 8 inside, and just enough room to squeeze around it to order.  If you're looking for a place to lounge and stretch your legs, this ain't it.

If you're looking for phenomenal, hand-crafted, locally-sourced and amazingly good food and coffee, however, this is the mother-lode.  Menu changes every day, serving just a couple things at any given time, and the food is indescribably good.  Especially if you can catch the place at an in-between time and avoid a rush, you're in for an amazing experience.
author: Asher K.

description: Bread pudding so good it should be illegal.  Few seats on a quiet street, great for Sun light Brunch or a coffee break
author: Mrim B.

description:
I am not a coffee drinker, but I love the food. All the food  is made in that tiny little space, which does not include a rice cooker, as some reviewers have stated. I think it's a brilliant use of space to be able to prepare such a variety of food day to day. 

I understand why some people wouldn't like this place. It's small, it isn't cheap, it's cash only. But the food and coffee are not cheap. The pastries are not "store bought," and the cereal (not from Whole Foods) is toasted and mixed there every morning.  I have always had a fresh, filling, flavorful meal at farm:table. The staff has always been able to tell me exactly where the food is coming from and it's pretty impressive. Also, I've never had a problem getting water when I needed it since it is in a dispenser right out in the open within arms reach of the table. 

I love they are putting in a green parklet right there in front. The Tenderloin could use it.

So why people are flat out lying in their reviews I will never know. This place it great and it's run by really great people.
author: Krystal T.

description:
Seattle might have invented coffee shops but San Francisco's farm table has perfected making coffee.  

farm table is a tiny neighborhood cafe with just a farm table.  I ordered the latte and hard boiled eggs on baguette.  YUMMY!

The latte was just perfect.  The expresso can be overpowered by the foam milk if it's not done correctly, but at farm table they got it perfect.  You could taste the coffee flavor all the way through the last drop.

I need to go back to SF in a couple of weeks, and you bet I'll pick a hotel close by just so I can go get my coffee at farm table.
author: Bo T.

description: I was in San Francisco for one day and found farm:table when I yelped for brunch spots near me. I chose the day's special of sliced boiled eggs, wilted swiss chard, feta, golden beets, and rye bread, and I was very impressed -- this was one of the most creative and elegantly prepared egg dishes I've ever encountered in a cafe. The ingredients worked beautifully together and the portion size was just right. Why don't more places think outside the box when it comes to eggs? There was quiche on the small menu, too, and it looked delicious. This place is super cute, and the staff provide a truly great farm to table experience.
author: Lucy B.

description: Simply a wonderful place to eat and read the paper.
author: Alice W.

description:
This is a very cute little coffee shop, locally owned and perfect for a small cup of mocha. I always see a lady with very cool tattooes on both her arms! She has San Francisco cable car tattooed on her arm. 
The servers are always friendly. 
Mocha is pretty delicious.
author: Miss C.

description: Best chicken salad sandwich I've ever had IN MY LIFE. they only serve a couple items per day, which means that each one is done artfully. love it.
author: p.c. m.

description:
First off the food at this little (not to be taken lightly as I am sure my bedroom was bigger) establishment has a delicious and creative menu that will spark your tastebuds.  We had toast with goat cheese and candied pecans with a demiglaze which was fantastic. Coffee was also good. If you are into big plates of french toast with loads a grease, this is not the place.  I would also not go here if you don't believe in birth control and have a family of more than 4. 

-very small
-creative dishes
-cheap and very friendly staff
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
This place is simply charming. A cute and quaint spot with one little table and a couple tables outside. 

The concept is brilliantly simple and pure - fresh, seasonal food with a homemade kiss. And as annoying as it may be that they don't carry non-fat milk for their coffee drinks, you have to give some credit for staying true to their values through and through. (a little whole milk won't kill ya.)

I enjoyed a warm Appalachian cheese and dijon sandwich today. Nothing fancy schmancy - but lovely and wholesome. The bread is exceptionally fresh - warm and soft on the inside, crunchy and wholesome on the outside. I also stole some bites of the farro salad with root vegetables, that was amazing as well. Crisp and savory. 

You can't help but like this place. It makes the world feel like there's lots of good people and things in it.
author: Erin M.

description:
I moved away from SF about 9 months ago, so on a recent visit I was thrilled to see farm:table pop up on my Yelp.  I'm definitely a fan of small businesses like this.

I swung by on my way to the airport actually.  I gave up coffee awhile back, but I wanted to get some beans for my boyfriend.  I saw they offered almond milk substitution, so I decided to get a hot chocolate with almond milk for myself.

The female employee who made a bean recommendation to me was on point.  The BF absolutely loved the Verve beans I brought home to him.

Now, I know that this might sound tacky, and I'm not usually one to be all like, "Meh, this cup is too small."  That would be way too New Jersey of me.

....having said that, the cup that the hot chocolate came in was, in my opinion, too small.  Either that, or the price was too high.

I paid $4.75 for it...  Minus 0.75 for the almond milk, we're still talking $4 for a small cup of beverage.  And YES, I get it, the hot chocolate wasn't just your regular run-of-the-mill hot chocolate.  It was smooth, flavorful, decadent, rich.  If it was made in larger servings, maybe it would be "too much".  Fine.  Drop the price a dollar!  It really was delicious, but it was accompanied with just a small feeling of, "...awww man."

I guess if it was at least the same size as the Blue Bottle hot chocolate cup I'd have felt better.  

Anyhow, the staff is great, it's a cute spot though very tight inside, and they have an impressive menu which they change often.  I'm sure I'd go back, and hell, I'd probably order my $5 Hot Chocolate again, still grumbling of course.  :)
author: Jess R.

description: This review is totally biased. I love everyone and everything about farm: table. And they like me and they like my dog Jackson. I stop in daily to get my afternoon cappuccino - and always check to see what's on the menu, on the pastry shelf or sitting at the communal table. Don't be shy about saying Juanita sent you - you'll get an extra big smile with your freshly brewed coffee for sure.
author: Juanita M.

description:
The people who work here are really nice.  I stopped by during work today and one of the servers explained their menu and concept to me.
As I had already eaten, I only wanted a coffee.  I got the iced coffee which was good, BUT IT COST $4.  I don't think that's a realistic price for a iced coffee - that's like half a sandwich.
author: Yin L.

description: Teeny tiny casual drop-in kind of place.  Food of excellent quality focused on limited menu & yummy pastries.  Gem in the neighborhood.
author: Jayne H.

description:
I love this place. I had one experience here where I didn't like my breakfast sandwich... It was way too rich for me but maybe someone else would have loved it...

I love the idea of a scaled-down menu... and I love the menu selections as well. Friendly people!
author: Claire b.

description:
Amazing coffee and espresso drinks. In a world being taken over by blubobblers, it's nice to taste coffee from another, equally delicious roaster. 
The service is great and food is delicious looking (I have yet to try it). 
Limited seating, both inside and out, but I'm not complaining. It adds to the charm of the place.
author: Joe M.

description:
It's a small space, but the food and coffee are fantastic. 

I stopped by early in the day and ordered coffee as well as hard boiled eggs, melted fennel, and bacon on toast. They brought me coffee very quickly. The coffee was fantastic - very flavorful. My food was up in short order as well and I was not disappointed. Everything was fresh, flavorful, and well presented. 

I was so happy with the food that I grabbed another cup of coffee and a muffin to go. I can't wait to get back to San Francisco to go back to farm:table.
author: Jeremiah P.

description: The food is really good, its one of san francisco's hidden jewels. I love it!
author: Hayfa A.

description: They have Verve Coffee beans from Santa Cruz, and make one of the best mocha's I have ever had, using local TCHO chocolate. They change up their menu everyday. We had the pork shoulder brunch item which was pretty good, but their quiche was incredible, and I normally don't like quiche. Their is limited seating in the form of a community table inside, and a couple tables outside.Tasty.
author: Mike C.

description:
I love you farm:table!

You are the American dream. A cute couple doing what they love in a meaningful way.  Your food is delicious. Your coffee is next level.  Your decor is homey and inviting. I will even sit by a stranger and read the paper. Keep it coming!!
author: Danielle W.

description: This place is amazing.  Opened right @ 7:30.  They change their menu daily based on what they get at the Farmers Market or based on whatever they bake.  I ordered the Hard Boiled Egg on Brioche with Heirloom Tomato and Marscapone.  AMAZING breakfast sandwich.  Also had a pear cake which was real good but would of been better warm.  Had the 'milk and honey' drink with cardimum - also really tasty.  GREAT Service here, very cool atmosphere.  Overall,  very very cool spot.  Im staying in SF one more night and i WILL Be going here tomorrow again for breakfast!
author: Russell K.

description:
My favorite spot in the Tenderloin... well, Glide too.  This place is an absolute gem.  They serve up the Verve beans from Santa Cruz so you know that you are getting premium coffee.  You're also going to get premium service from some of the friendliest folks.

Smile!  Life is good.
author: Kevin F.

description:
4.5, but I'll round up to 5.

The coffee was excellent, and keeping in stride with the insurgence of single drip cups.  At least it tasted like it was a single drip cup, i didn't actually see him making it.  It did come out startlingly fast, I have gotten used to waiting for a cup.  

The cups were small, and not just in the volume they hold.  I couldn't grasp the handle with my paws, so I had to cradle it.  

One incredible nice thing is that the cup f coffee comes with a free refill.  Yeah.

Food...  I had a half squash filled with bacon, roasted corn, and a few other items.  It was good, but a tad overpriced, but I have no regrets.  In fact it has made me start thinking of a few new recipes that I might try.

Anyway, the store feels young and fresh.  ....and charming I think they have something, and I wouldn't be surprised at all to see a few more pop around the city.

I wouldn't go hear if I wanted to hang out and read a book though.  Too small, and the vibe doesn't feel like they are trying to promote that type of thing.  Not that they discourage reading, only that they don't have a lot of space.

Oh, ...one more thing.  Friendly staff.  I was in pseudo business attire today while everyone else was in pseudo hipster wear.  I got no attitude, only friendly service.
author: Travis S.

description:
Loved it! We had the "morning toast" with marscapone cheese, and fresh fruit, fresh baguette with boiled eggs, heirloom tomatoes, and greens, and almond milk cappuccinos....all fabulous:)
The place is small, and there's only one communal table, but it was fun.
author: Gina C.

description:
We stayed in the city for the night and were in the mood for a big bacon/ eggs etc. breakfast.  This was not that place.  
I stuck my head through the doorway, looking for the rest of the restaurant... it wasn't there.  We did find "THE" Farm Table, the only table inside.
We decided to give it a shot.
The menu is VERY short.  Pastries and a couple of hot items and lots of coffee.
Now, on to the surprise.
We ordered the recommended Costa Rican coffee.  It was great and there were refills.
I had the hard boiled eggs over ham on French bread... somebody has had training!
The presentation was great, serving was small but filling, definitely French style meals.
If I had the big camera with me I would have requested a picture of the great vintage MUNI tattoo on the girls arm behind the counter.
If I lived around the corner they would see me alot.
author: Will M.

description:
OK, so you can't not notice that EVERY SINGLE PERSON THAT HAS REVIEWED THIS PLACE THUS FAR....

....HAS GIVEN IT FIVE STARS.  


For a reason.


This place is uber-cute, with an ambiance you just want to take home with you.  It's super-small, it's the only one of it's kind, especially in that neighborhood....


The coffee is amazing.  And I am a coffee snob.  It's the only place I've found that does my wet capp with extra foam as well as Peet's.  

The only offer 1 sandwich and 1 soup daily (or at least they did when I went), but it didn't matter.  The sandwich was so good, the guy I came with got 2 of them.

The gave us little apples to eat with our food.  Oh, yay!  I told our server, "Thanks, Mom!"

They have cute outdoor tables.  And purdy plants.  And hipsterish staff that are open and not jaded.


Two words:  A gem.
author: Lopa V.

description: Delicious, simple food in a really comfy atmosphere--this place has become my favorite restaurant in the city, (especially breakfast)! The meal always balances delicately on the line between the comfort grandmother's home cooking and the excitement of a hip foodie favorite. The coffees and juices are always perfect, (especially if you like your espresso drinks made Italian-style!) This place feels like discovering the dive bar with the best food and cheapest drinks, whose jukebox plays the perfect songs and whose doors stay open 'till the sun comes up! Only it's not a dive bar...
author: Zephyr J.

description:
I love the tiny space, large communal table, and neighborhood-y feel.  The coffee is good and strong, and I always want to try everything on the (small) menu.  I came here a couple of times in their off hours and chatted with the guy behind the counter about the different roasts.  It was like talking to a coffee sommelier.

The dishes could be hotter.  And their milk options are limited to whole and almond, which is slightly annoying for someone who is mildly lactose intolerant and allergic to nuts (yay!).  But everything else about farm:table completely rocks.
author: Sarah C.

description:
If I were to open a small tiny cafe one day, I would plainly copy this place. Even just the idea of twittering daily specials that change everyday and that feature seasonal ingredients is a big plus for improving customer satisfaction.

The cappuccino was great and the food was fresh when we were there. I wish we had a branch of them down in LA.
author: Volkan S.

description:
I was on my way to Pearl's Burgers when I saw this new gem of a cafe looking all pretty and shiny amidst gloomy Post Street.  I decided to stop in and was shocked to see that they served Verve coffee!!  I haven't seen this since I visited my friends down in Santa Cruz and went to the Verve coffee shop!  

The two people behind the counter were sooo nice and helpful.  No emo college kids working here.. Just down-to-earth people who know their stuff about coffee!  I told them how excited I was to find a place in SF with Verve coffee, and they mentioned that this is the first cafe in the city to sell it.  It's incredibly drinkable coffee that is, in my opinion, better than Blue Bottle: sweet, clean, and smooth... Yes, this is your cue to go there NOW and try it!!

The table space inside is limited to one large community table (love this idea) and a few small tables out on the sidewalk.  As for the food, I've only tried a lemon scone with my coffee so far, but I will gladly come back and work my way through all of their delicious treats.  I am so happy to see this little spot on Post Street where its presence is well-needed!
author: Christy L.

description: I kind of feel like I would be missing out if I were to return to SF without the opportunity to have breakfast at Farm Table. Fresh ingredients, and an imaginitive menu that changes daily. I'd try to get there early if possible because seating is very limited. A great place to have a light breakfast that won't make you feel guilty afterward. Sitting outside with some daily toast and a cuppa coffee with my GF is my idea of wonderful.
author: Garylee W.

description:
Tiny with few options, but what options!  Fresh dishes made from local produce.  Delicious, strong coffee.  Friendly staff.
Communal seating!

Can't wait to go back.
author: LJ H.

description:
Latte = Perfect
Vibes = Great
People = Nice
Service = Fast w/ Good Quality and good service (TIP!, you cheap ass) 
ATM = FAIL! (it's okay thou, ATM at liquor store near by)

I wanna try their sandwiches/food, everything looks tasty.
author: David C.

description:
AMAZING coffee--check!
Tasty bites--check!
Awesome staff--check!
Cool space--check!
Farm Table is, hands-down, a delightful cafe with all the perks!  Go there, now!
author: kyle w.

description: I was really excited to go to farm:table with my boyfriend for Sunday Brunch after a friend raved about it, and while the food was fresh and tasty, the serving sizes were small and a bit pricey. I am glad that I went once to try it out, but I don't think that I will go again. The place was also pretty small so there wasn't anywhere comfortable for us to sit.
author: Anne M.

description:
I was told (not suggested, but TOLD) by my dear friend Tony Nash to come in. He raves about this place, so I figured "What the hell", right? I come down here for a late breakfast, and was completely impressed.

The place is a bit small, but do not let that fool you! The taste and quality of the food is completely amazing, and the service is insanely kind and considerate...totally not what I'm used to in this town, ya know?

Let's review...coffee was delicious. I mean...YUM! I ended up getting a slice of their boysenberry proud cake or coffee cake. Whatever it was, it was so good. Freshly made with a big scoop of homemade cream and a giant scoop of boysenberry preserves. AH! Heaven!

If you're in the area, definitely check it out. And if you're not in the area, get your ass there. You honestly will not be upset!
author: Nicolas H.

description: My boyfriend and I were looking for something quick but authentically local with great coffee and breakfast- this place hit the spot. We were lucky to grab one of the outdoor tables for two. My dirty chai latte with whole milk was a perfect blend of spice and sweet. We couldn't decide what to order, so ended up getting the daily toast (whipped marscapone, strawberries, and pistachios on focaccia), the croissant sandwich (boiled eggs, bacon, mayo, greens), and the frittata (asparagus & ham), and shared all three. I wish we'd thought to ask for our eggs soft boiled, but the croissant was flaky and delicious. The frittata was perfection as well, a light almost creamy puff of eggs with the saltiness of the ham and asparagus, and it was served with an absolutely glorious aioli. We saved the daily toast as our "dessert" and it was a tasty lightly sweet end to our breakfast. The softness of the cheese, pistachios, and strawberries melded perfectly with the crunchiness of the toast. Both of us were totally satisfied but not overly stuffed.
author: Jade R.

description:
After a gluttonous night of drinking and being up to no good, twin and I needed some sustenance to get us through the morning. We pulled up Yelp, and it led us to farm: table. Maybe we just ordered poorly? I dunno.

What I loved was the super friendly neighborhood vibe. There is one (tiny) communal table where diners can share newspapers and chat it up with their neighbors. I also loved the strawberry infused water and mason jars that served as water glasses. The boys who worked here were so friendly and we felt very welcome. 

Unfortunately, there were only three items on their chalkboard menu. The first item was a series of three slices of rustic bread topped with pulled pork, a hard boiled egg and roasted vegetables. Sounds good, right? It was just ok. The vegetables were a little soggy, and the combination with pulled pork just wasn't right. And it was cold. 

We also saw a delicious chocolate bundt cake and cherry pie, but did not indulge. I wish we did!
author: Caroline A.

description:
This place makes my day - anytime I can find the energy and time to drag myself down the street the three blocks, I am ALWAYS satisfied. Yes - the place is tiny, but I have yet to find it without an available couple of seats and the patrons who do frequent the place are friendly and accommodating.

The staff/owners are nice, friendly folks, too - and more than happy to provide you with help in placing your order.

The food is as advertised, fresh, unique, innovative and mmm, mmm good. The Verve coffee is tremendous - try the TenderNob for their version of a Cortado.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
boo. you suck.

i met my friend here for breakfast on a lazy friday morning. 

it was not busy. i ordered my breakfast and coffee, tipped in advance and sat down at a table. 
10 minutes goes by - friend gets her food. 
5-10 more minutes go by - my friend begins to eat, still no food. i ask someone working, they say its probably on the way. 
10 more minutes go by - my friend is finished, still no food. 

I go inside, the girl working has no clue what's happening or probably what day it is. I explain the situation, she just gives me a blank stare and says "well I guess we can refund you the money"..um YES that is what you should do and then some. So I am refunded for my breakfast BUT she does not give me back my money for the coffee or the tip. WTF. There was no record of any food orders so no way to keep track of what happened - if my food was made, given to someone else by accident, or yet to be made....

No apologies, no offers to make the situation better, no offers for another meal/coffee/pastry.  

Honestly, worst service ever. SF has too many halfway decent places that deserve my business over this place. But what would they care since they got my tip anyway.
author: Kerry F.

description:
A tiny gem of a place that I feel lucky to have stumbled into (onto?).  Warm, knowledgeable staff brew up some exceptional coffee (complete with hearts in foam).  Want to know more about what your beans have been up to?  Just ask!  They know!  Top this off with a moist decadent scone (or any other tasty treat they serve- they have a couple of awesome house-made breakfast items), a cosy community table, and a large open window and you have an exceptionally happy customer.  

Worth taking an extra walk just to be there.
author: Danielle Y.

description:
I really enjoyed the milk and honey. The milk was not too hot and the honey was not too much. That was the best part of the meal. I wanted a snack so had the romano beans salad with goat cheese on toast with heirloom tomato. I believe eight dollars. The romano beans were way, way, way too undercooked barley blanched so they did not go well. Plus there were maybe three or four tiny little pieces of them. Lots of salad that was overstuffed on the plate. The toast was on some kind of hippie grain bread that IMHO did not go well with the rest of the salad. Thank god for the goat cheese. It was well seasoned and I really wanted it to be perfect. I love the local ambiance and it's teeny tiny space and hipster vibe.

I would go back but only on off hours.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Excellent breakfast sandwich - hard boiled egg, goat cheese, lettuce, and bacon on brioche. Phenomenal goat cheese and perfect texture on the bread. Only 3 options that day - the sandwich, a frittata, and yogurt with apricots and granola...all fresh ingredients. 

Ambiance was quaint. Only 1 small communal table, so it is an eat-and-go kinda place. Still worth it and highly recommend for a quick breakfast.
author: Clarissa G.

description:
Loved our lunch at Farm:Table. 

Sunny outdoor table+Badoit+creamy tomato soup+stone fruit salad+ham and cheese baguette+lovely Kate= best lunch ever

So glad we finally came to visit. Can't wait to go back have more tasty snacks. 

They also have amazing coffee and handmade treats.
author: melissa n.

description:
This place is just simply super fabulous!

The atmosphere, the FOOD, the staff- it's great. I'm new to the area and discovering this place was a god-send! I feel cozy and welcomed every time I'm there. And sitting at a big table with other customers makes me feel so much more a part of the community (as compared with individual tables at chain coffee stores that blast awful music and rush you in and out). This place is communities are all about! And the ever changing menu is something to look forward to! always delicious and creative!!
author: charis s.

description:
OMG! I can't stop laughing at the reaction of my friend when we walked into the closet-sized restaurant this morning. We could not believe the place is SO small. We had to poke our reflections in the mirrorred wall to make sure there was no dining room, and what we were looking at was our own reflection. However, it is not the point.
I tried hard to find the menu, but I failed. So asked the person taking the order where I could look at the options. He pointed at the wall on my left where I found 2 items: bread pudding and a toast with mascarpone, hazelnuts, bananas, etc. 
REALLY?  I would never imagine myself coming to SF from the East Coast to a place with two items on the menu!!
I decided to be rude and ask for eggs. Oh, ran out...
O-K...
So, my friends and I grabbed the table. LITERALLY, THE TABLE, as there is only one, and it is really small...and decided to try both menu items...you know, just for the hell of it!
The bread pudding was runny and gross. I can make better pudding with saltine crackers and water. 
The toasts came out with a 20 min interval: the first one had a ton of mascarpone and honey. I had to catch the pieces of banana sliding of the bread  all over THE table. The second toast had no nuts on it, although the recipe was promising hazelnuts and pecans. They must have run out of nuts...and had to come up with a quick substitute- pecan shells! By the way, both "toasts" were not toasted...

The latte I ordered tasted pretty good though- two stars for that, but I have to take one back for CASH ONLY policy.

Oh, to all yelpers who gave the place and its food  5 stars: even a 5 year-old can pull off an egg on pork and leafy greens or an untoasted toast with mascarpone and sliced banana for $8. Get a cook book!
author: Iryna B.

description: I had the apple bread, which was very tasty. The coffee was good, but not hot enough, so I am saving the last star for my next visit...
author: Bogee B.

description:
Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes.  Everthing here- unbelievable.
Staff, espresso, food, ambiance... everthing.

Go.
author: Shelly L.

description:
Excellent but pricey. 
Changing menu.
Communal table. Not tables. One. Big. Table.
Outdoor seating in funky furniture/structure.
Very cool.
Definitely worth experiencing, but not really for me as a regular place. (Try Brenda's, Dottie's, or Show Dogs.)
author: Frank W.

description:
Awesome.  

This may have been the smallest coffee shop I have ever seen, however, it was so quaint and full of character that it didn't even matter.  I ordered my regular coffee, extra hot, and it was so delicious.  Was it as good as Blue Bottle? No, but it was a very close second and on my way to work, making this a place I am beginning to frequent. The pastries always look delicious.  I did try the ginger cake and it was tasty, though not amazing.  What was over the top incredible was how nice and friendly the staff was.  This definitely makes me want to come back on a regular basis.

If you're in the neighborhood, stop by!
author: Cara D.

description: This place is TINY.  There is one communal table inside where you can squeeze 8 people, 10 if you reallllly squeeze.  There are some standing room & tables right outside the restaurant.  We came because we heard about their farm to table menu which changes daily.  There's usually only 3 items on the menu so it changes pretty regularly.  We got the 3 things there was that day, but let's start with the coffee.  The ice coffee was phenomenal, and their ice chai latte was even better.  We'll definitely be going back there when we come back to SF
author: Cheryl N.

description:
Had the hard boiled eggs with rainbow chard and golden raisins- loved it! The things that made me happy were the plumpness of the raisins and the perfect amount of moistness on the bread (not overly drenched with oil). I also had a grapefruit/watermelon juice and found it to be an unusual but tasty addition to my breakfast.  Nice to find a place like this in TenderNob (I guess that's the correct lingo used by city dwellers).

Thank you for your creativity Farm:Table it works!
author: Sonal A.

description:
This place is just really cute.  Verve coffee, I'm a believer.  Its just better than all our local roasters(these guys are santa cruz, so its still all good)... blue, ritual, 4 barrel.  I mean those guys are all amazing, but those guys just got it going on.  The staff is rad.

Try the tendernob. delicious.
author: kevin p.

description: I had a pretty good quiche with a few pieces of dressed beats, cherry tomatoes, and couple slices of cucumber for almost $9, plus $3/hr parking = $12. That was an appetizer. So I have to go elsewhere for a full meal. Overpriced, tiny portions, tiny place, nice staff
author: Pixie G.

description:
I may have a new top-five favorite espresso spot in town.  Farm:Table uses beans from Verve, a roaster based in Santa Cruz that rotates its blends (the one they're using is called "All City") on a seasonal basis (i.e., whatever is good and fresh, they use).  It was a spicy shot, pulled short & thick, but without the syrupyness of your average double Ristretto.  (Eliciting warm-fuzzy home in Pac-NW feelings, where the spicy Hairbender blend from Stumptown has always been a personal fave.)

I'll be back for the coffee and for what looks to be some fantastic lunch fare (daily rotating seasonal menu, all looking gorgeous in that simple and un-fussy but meticulously prepared way that focuses on quality of ingredients.)
author: Lulu W.

description: I went once & ordered a latte ... was excited because of all the Yelp reviews ... there was something weird with the milk - I usually like nonfat milk & a splenda.  They didn't have either (on that day, or ever?), so I went with soy & it was a disaster.
author: Kelly C.

description: Feeling groggy on a Saturday morning and desperate for some caffeine, I stumbled upon this place and was delighted to taste some of the most delicious espresso I've had...anywhere. I'll be back!
author: Josiah M.

description: Let's just say if I had not waited until my last morning to eat here while visiting, I would have probably eaten here all three days of my trip. farm:table is fresh, unique, smart, all about great food and ingredients, and makes me feel like I am missing something in my life now that I am back in Seattle. With my daily toast (pink lady+ambrosia apples w vanilla caramel on pan de mie-the toasted pan de mie had a thin yet oh so satisfying and almost cookie-like crust), a pastry (croissant dough with a chocolate ganache-like filling) and cafe au-lait in hand, I walked up to Huntington park to earn those bad boy calories and savor the yummy deliciousness and sun. I love farm:table. Wherefore art thou?
author: Kaley H.

description:
Best lunch that I have had in a while. 

I had a spicy tuna salad over mixed greens with kiwi-strawberry juice, apple cauliflower soup and finished with a latte and chocolate hazelnut tart. 

Everything was amazing, fresh and healthy. 

If you're looking for a large place with a big menu, fancy ambience - a place to socialize and mingle - this is not it.

this place has one table and 3 new items everyday on the menu.
author: Kunal S.

description: The house juice was okay. The bacon, burrata, and greens sandwich was good when hot (the half I kept for the plane ride was dry but still ok). I was willing to pay $12.50 for these two items, but given the small dining space and small size of the sandwich/juice glass, I can't help but feel a little gypped. The ladies at the counter were nice and I get the sense that there are regulars who love this place (note to first-timers, it's cash only). All of that is great but I do think the prices for drinks and sandwiches run a bit high for what you get.
author: Jolene S.

description: Delicious, organic, hipsters place. Tiny restaurant with one group table. Awkward, took our food to go. Had roast pork, lentil salad, field greens, and a poached egg. Pretty damn good but for 11 bucks I want some more of everything. Only 3 food items on menu so check out their offerings before going in. The coffee and mocha is sooo creamy and flavorful.
author: Kasey H.

description:
Charming and warm with a hint of metropolitan fervor, this much needed addition to the TenderNob has got me buzzing. Farm:Table is offering smooth espresso drinks stamped with clear signs of a hearty, yet balanced selection of roasted coffee beans. Couple that with the loving hands and well seasoned virtuoso baristas/owners Kate and Shannon, and you've got a winner.

In addition, check out their food menu! Local and seasonal ingredients utilized to their full potential. I had a bowl of their Curried Zucchini Soup, and WOW! Very Nice! As I described to the Chef (Kate) sultry and electric!  Go get some!

I will definitely be returning for their scrumptious food and irresistible coffee.
author: Garcia S.

description: Farm to table maybe. But not bakery to table; I nearly broke a tooth on their bread this morning!   Yummy food on day old bread = bad idea.
author: Mike R.

description: Only 4 items on the food menu - you'll want to eat all 4, two times over!  They have other baked goodies but didn't try those.  Absolute gem!
author: Amit P.

description:
Sweet little one room location that has a down home feel on one of the best blocks in the TL. 

Everything is made fresh as you order (even the whipped cream!) and the flavors are amazing. I had the carrot soup (vegan) which was soo yummy, I practically licked the bowl.

We had no problem with street parking, on a Saturday afternoon, which was a major bonus. Cash only.

You must try it for yourself. 

Service 5+
Food 5
Local Sustainable Feeling of Goodness 5
Ambiance 5
Thinking it would be good for 3+ people, or when you're in a hurry 2
Coffeeee 5
Overall 5+
author: Leslie F.

description: I think this is an adorable addition to the neighborhood.  Inside, there is seating for ten people, max; outside, there is seating for four.  I went on a gray Friday at 11:45am, and it was pretty quiet.  Got a seat without a problem, had a delicious tuna salad sandwich.  And let me be clear.  I don't actually _like_ tuna salad.  At all.  I hate it.  Always have.  And this was a _delicious_ tuna salad sandwich.  These people are magical.  I don't know what they did, but it was tuna salad, and it was delicious.  The bread it was on was fresh and delightful.  My accompanying pot of tea was quite pleasant.  All in all, this was a highly satisfactory lunch.  Also, the people who work here are just amazingly nice.  farm:table is awesome.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Best ice coffee, ever. 
Cute spot on the sunny side of Post st. 
Super friendly, great cookies, I'll be back.
author: Ryan R.

description:
thanks to the SF chronicle's cheap eats, i found this place.  i love the look from the outside in.  super small little place with a large farm/communal table inside and two small tables outside.  

i ordered the "toast of the day" which was outstanding a now a fav @ home.  two thick pieces of crusty wheat bread, cream cheese, thinly sliced green apples and pomegranate seeds.  

my latte was on point too and beautiful to the eyes.  friendly staff.  i'll see you again on my next visit!
author: Jen S.

description: Since my review the hipsters seem to have really picket it up. A new barista nd the shots are short and flavorful again. The other day i think i had the best shot they ever produced..seems they have responded to the criticism, and i can only thank myself.
author: vivace K.

description: This place is truly unique. Staff was super friendly. Coffee is perfect and the food is amazing.
author: Sage W.

description: Coffee is a really small serving size, refill of coffee is ridiculously priced especially when the original serving is only half filled. The older short woman is rude.  If she had originally served us I probably would have left before placing my order. I understand your busy but have a descent attitude especially when breakfast is $30 and I tipped 15%.  $2 for a coffee refill is ridiculous. Next time I will probably eat there but buy my coffee elsewhere...
author: V C.

description: We ate breakfast here while honeymooning in San Francisco.  It was delicious, and I frequently daydream about the savory bread pudding.  I love tiny ever-changing menus.  Especially when based on the season and ingredients at their peak.
author: Monica B.

description: A bit on the pricey end.. but really delicious... it just happens to be close to a friends apt.. so i'll probably end up going again.  got the quiche, the fresh juice, and the iced coffee.. all were yummy.. wish i had seen the pastries on the side table before we paid though.. i probably would have gotten one of them.. we had to wait a tiny bit and i watched the guys in the kitchen mix of the quiche liquid and pour it into the pie tin... then it went into the baker thing and came out into my to go container... i know i got it to go.. but i was eating it as soon as i walked out the door.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I came here for lunch, and the first thing I noticed is that this place tiny, charming and adorable.  The second thing I noticed is that the restaurant has an extremely limited menu.  I soon realized that the chef chose to focus on just a few dishes each day -- and to do them well.

On the day I arrived, there was just 1 sandwich, 1 soup, and 1 type of oatmeal to choose from, along with a few pastries, coffees and house-made drinks.  I ordered the bbq pork shoulder sandwich and the white bean and ham hock stew.  The sandwich was delicious -- tender, flavorful bbq pork, topped with coleslaw and paprika aioli, and complemented nicely with a pickled carrot and pepper.  Smoky, tangy, and spicy!  The white bean and ham hock stew came with a poached egg (with runny yolk) floating on top and was pretty good, but a little bland.  But it wasn't something that a dash of salt and pepper couldn't fix!  After that, the soup was great.  

I arrived 5 minutes before closing, so it was pretty empty inside.  I could see how the experience might have been frustrating, if I came during a busy meal time.   

I noticed that they have a trail of giant ant stickers on the wall leading up to the pastry area.  It's not the most appetizing thing to look at, while you're sitting there eating . . . 

Overall, I had a very good dining experience.  The staff was so nice.
author: Candice J.

description:
I've walked by this place repeatedly in the morning before they open or in the evening after they're closed but since they're open at 7:30AM I had the chance to stop by for breakfast today. They serve Verve Roasters coffee and it's excellent, definitely a break from the typical "cup o' joe" you get at most of the neighborhood coffee shops. Considering that I've probably tasted the worst cafe coffee at other joints in the neighborhood, I'll pay extra for this quality brew. 

I had a delicious breakfast, toasted baguette with almond butter, bosc pears, and dried currants. It was a bit pricey but for the size of their space (VERY SMALL) I understand why. It's a cut above. 

Sitting in the space was a bit like sitting in someone else's kitchen. Everyone seemed to know everyone else...except me. It got crowded quickly (maybe 8 people) but that's part of the ambiance. I'm going to keep it in mind and go back when I don't have to be at work right at 8 so I can see what else they cook up. I like that the menu changes regularly and it's always imaginative. I'm not sure I am up for chipotle pepper jam at 8AM though.
author: J.J. P.

description: Stopped by on a Saturday morning ~9am. This place is SMALL - it looked like seating inside for 4-6 people if you were willing to get cozy, and a couple seats outside. I ordered a scone and coffee, the scone was fine, coffee tasted burnt. Boyfriend ordered some kale-hardboiled egg thing that looked (and tasted, I sneaked a couple bites;)) AMAZING. He did have to wait a while for it - had to remind them twice to get it. So - good food, bad coffee, and so-so service. I'd go back if I was in the area, but not worth going out of your way for.
author: Pooh C.

description:
perhaps my most very favorite thing about this place is not the coffee or food, but the last time i was there. this chick at the table kept complaining about not having her cappuccino right when she sat down and the barista responded with, im a human not a machine. the chick shut up and waited patiently after that. awesome.

farm:table is where i take myself on little weekend morning coffee dates before walking down to the farmers market and to pretend that im a funtioning adult. 

super amazing espresso drinks, tantalizing pastries and baked goods and amazing food. HIGHLY recommended.

now, if only their coffee could ACTUALLY make me a functioning adult...
author: Ameigh F.

description: We were only here once about  2years ago when in SF, but I will def go back if in the city. Yes, it is a communal table inside. When we got there folks moved around to make room for us which was a nice experience.  I saw other folks noted it was hipster-y, but it was a mix when we were there of ages and types.  Folks working were very nice too (as we didn't know what was up as new-comers). There were 2 choices, we both had a sandwich which was very good. LOVE the idea/philosophy of the place. Hope it is still there when I go back to SF.
author: Aly G.

description: I am an espresso snob (I don't even drink regular coffee), so I was really excited to try Farm Table. But my experience did not match expectations. First of all they only use whole milk, which doesn't sit well with me. So I declined my cappuccino, but was still going to try the food. Then when I tried to pay with my debit, I was told they are cash only (I didn't see a sign). That's fine, except that the woman who was at the register was so rude and holier-than-thou when she informed me about these two facts, that I just left. I prefer my breakfast without a side of judgment.
author: Lauren L.

description:
farm:table is proof that good things come in small packages. 

A homey little coffeeshop with a couple of fantastic breakfast items. I got the toast which changes daily, fresh bread some yummy frommage, bing cherries and drizzled with honey paired with an almond milk cappuccino. I was a happy girl. Boyfriend got the hard boiled egg special and it was gone in a blink and a half. 

Overall really cute little place and the perfect start to our day.
author: Aimee K.

description:
A great tiny place that's big on taste! The coffee is excellent, and the food was tasty.
