It's coffee shop-esque so I really can't comment on the service (it's hard to screw that up), but all of the staff were really friendly and nice. Great not to have more disaffected art students making my coffee any longer.

Also, this spot is tiny. I've very glad that they went with the one large community table approach instead of trying to cram more small tables in there. Socialize, say hi to your neighbors, whatever.

A great spot I just hope that Yelp doesn't ruin it. Damn you Schrodinger!
author: Richard H.

description:
Better than Blue Bottle.  

There, I said it.  

Now stop crying and go get yourself a Little Smokey or Tendernob with some daily toast.

Kate and Shannon have jump-started many of my late mornings with some killer coffee, delectable breakfast cakes, and friendly conversation.

Thanks you two... you rock!
author: Kyle F.

description:
Great coffee, great sandwich. The price is understandable because they get fresh ingredients daily and it's not made by someone who gets paid minimum wage to stand behind a counter. C'mon people this isn't Subway! You get what you pay for.

The communal table thing gets talked about a lot. It was a lot more fun than I thought it would be. The other people there were quite friendly and it really makes for a unique atmosphere. Would definitely come back, probably to try the breakfast.
author: David K.

description: I loved this tiny little restaurant in San Fran.  I wish I could duplicate it in Atlanta.
author: Tina H.

description: This was a perfect place to take friends from out of town to show off what San Francisco food culture is all about. Its small - in fact, there is one table. The food is high quality, unique and delicious - there are four seasonal things on the menu and all sounded (and were!) delicious. The coffee selection is robust - more coffee than food options, and your various choices of coffees can be made any of a number of ways. The service is heavily tattooed but beyond friendly and helpful. The price is right - breakfast for 3 was about $35 with coffees.
author: Gregory P.

description:
Love the concept and look of this place.
This place uses fresh, local ingredients so the menu changes everyday, and there are only 4-5 choices each. The place has a sense of coziness too since it's literally one communal table for 8 inside and two tables outside. 
They serve Verve coffee here too. It was my first time trying it, so I went with a latte with almond milk. Pretty pricey (nearly $5 since the almond milk is $1 more). It was okay, but not my favorite since I felt the coffee wasn't strong enough to my liking. The almond milk added a bit of a gritty texture to the coffee, which was interesting.
I got the hard boiled egg with prosciutto and arugula. It was good, but nothing I felt like I couldn't make at home for under $8 (the cost of the dish). 
I totally support farm:table for what they do and support, but I guess I was a little disappointed by the simplicity of the food. I'd go again, but not if it's out of the way. Actually, I'd be back to try their desserts, since they get them from Black Jet Bakers!!
author: Jen T.

description: I LOVE this place! I wish the space were slightly larger to allow more seating for those folks who don't LIVE there. I swear, the same bike-dude is always there getting his latte on! They always have yummy yummy food to eat but it hurts the bank account a bit. I don't care...I am so happy to have them!
author: jacyinda b.

description: Cash only! When we dropped in, they had two servings left of a delicious nettle and feta fritatta served with spring greens. We also ordered espresso, and a nicely poured, velvety latte and a mocha made with real 60% chocolate were brought out in cute mason jars. We ate at the only table inside, with two other groups sitting there also. It was a tiny space but felt cozy and communal more than cramped, and there was more seating outdoors (3 tables?) even though it was windy. It was so great to see such an awesome little spot turning sustainable, local food into gourmet, healthy food.
author: Erika E.

description: This place is a gem! Coffee is small and overpriced, but the food items are creative, comforting, always changing around, and always delicious. The parklet outside is such a nice spot to enjoy your food, a conversation with friends, or to feel the grass and enjoy a book.
author: Slippery P.

description: Based on the phenomenal Yelp reviews and great price tag, we wandered down to farm:table for breakfast. No trouble with seating at 9:30 on a Tuesday morning and the food came out quickly. We both got quiche which was fine but nothing particularly special. It did taste like it was a day or two old - not a deal-breaker for quiche but not a virtue either  The coffee was strong but not as smooth as I was hoping. Overall it was a pleasant place with adequate food but I'll probably search for other options next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Diane R.

description:
Neighborhood Coffee Shop as good as it gets.

They specialize in a handful of daily dishes, all of which are specialties. The Coffee is outstanding, as is every item they sell. It's all natural perfection. A daily egg and baguette dish, a daily sandwich, daily toast--each one a real treat. And the staff is as friendly as they come.

This is exactly the kind of place San Francisco is about. Unique, memorable, tiny, and local. Don't just try it once--try it every day for a week. You'll never go anywhere else.
author: Mitch H.

description:
Excellent service. 

Small with 1 communal table.

3 dishes a day.

Everyone here seems happy.
author: Jamie Y.

description:
There may be other places in the city where you can start a meal with Badoit and end it with a Bustelo Cool, but I haven't come across them.  Liikewise, there may be other places in the city where the spot goes 2 for 2 on good lunches, and combines that with outdoor tables that (at least in Summer) face the sun, making for a great spot to eat, drink and watch traffic (including some pretty intrepid skateboarders) head down Post towards the square.  But again, I haven't found one.  And even if I did, Kate and Shannon wouldn't be there and neither would the awesome lattes in the glasses rather than cups or paper which allow the foam to rejoin the coffee ensuring a delicious drink to the bottom.

So, give it a shot.  And if you sit outside, make sure when you're remarking about how good everything is, you say it just a bit louder when folks not in the know are walking by.
author: Joe N.

description:
Yummy food. Lovingly prepared coffee drinks. Super accommodating staff.
We couldn't decide and so they let us order breakfast and lunch at the same time. Definitely a tender spot in my nob for this place.
author: Stewart F.

description:
I was going to give this 4 stars and bitch about the small space, but then I remembered that one of the folks behind the bar walked over to the table and cleared out a swath of their regulars so we could sit, so the space was a non-issue.  "They like it when I boss them around" is what she said.

There is one table full of hipsters, one bench along the wall, and two tables outside.  The coffee was awesome, the bread pudding was delicious, and I got to show off the new Yelp monocle to my hip tablemates, who were very impressed.  A fine way to start the day.  Hope they do great!
author: Cassio P.

description: Simple but creative, fresh food. Good service. Seating is limited and mostly one communal table.
author: Aaron R.

description: My hubby and I stumbled across this tiny cafe, GREAT COFFEE and they have fresh homemade ALMOND MILK for those avoiding dairy. Food looks good and I must try...
author: Katelyn D.

description:
This is a special little cafe, and every person I take here gets hooked.  My little sister goes to school in Portland, and almost every conversation we have begins and ends with her asking whether or not we can ship and/or bring Daily Toast (one of their breakfast dishes whose ingredients rotates) up there.  Seriously, the girl's obsessed.

But I'm obsessed, too.  Obsessed with the delicious food, the rich coffee or outstanding espresso drinks, and the quirky location filled with friendly, wonderful people.  I try to come here at least once a week on a standing "breakfast date," and I plan on keeping that tradition up for a long time.
author: David N.

description: I go there for their coffee, currently they are serving beans from Verve Roasters & Roast Coffee Co. and they are tasty. I've gone back 3 days in a row. Their menu changes daily, check twitter each day for the menu. Had Frittata Friday, Yummy.
author: Adelle C.

description:
What a neighborhood treasure!  We were staying at Adagio around the corner and stumble upon this place.  Great local atmosphere (complete with local eccentrics ;) ), INSANELY great coffee, and great food.  

I had the bread pudding with was very nice and mellow and perfect bite to start the day.  My wife had the boiled egg on baguette with cheese and intensely flavorful micro-greens.  

Everything was made fresh and with great care.  Friendly staff and great one-table setting that creates a cool community-like atmosphere. 

They serve Verve coffee from Santa Cruz made with a french-press that was really great.  These guys KNOW and REALLY care about their coffee.  I was thrilled.  WIll hit up again next time we are in SF.
author: Patrick G.

description: The best food in San Francisco- whimsical, interesting, and delicious. Each dish is its own thoughtful melody of light but distinct flavors. The mindfulness of the chef is very evident in every thing they do. I wish they'd open a place in NYC!
author: L R.

description: All I can say is, WOW! Found this on our recent trip to San Francisco. My daughter is a big fan of fresh, locally grown products....so she yelped a breakfast restaurant near Kensington Park hotel. If I could drag this place back to Pittsburgh, I would. I am seriously craving their daily toast and bis quits with egg/cheese. We also sampled the almond milk addictive.  The only drawback is limited sitting. It was pretty cold when we visited so we'd grab a seat outside......and eat quickly. TRY IT..........fresh, delicious won't be sorry.
author: Sharon C.

description:
I actually disagree with the "hard bread" posting (it must have been a fluke). One of my favorite things about farm table is the ciabatta that they use for the meatloaf sando and steak sando. I am always weary of ciabatta, but I find farm:table bread to be like biting into soft pillows, with golden toasty edges for a nice textural contrast.

Oh, and the coffee is probably some of the best in SF. Seriously.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Such a cute tiny place where I can count the number of seats on my 2 little hands.  If you're shy about sitting by strangers, this may not be the place for you.  Its about 2 things here, fresh ingredients and great coffee!

Portions aren't huge, but they're not tiny either.  Daily toast was really good (I feel awkward just saying that, toast, really?) Coffee, superb - roast beef, delish.  One of the best brunch places that I've been to in sf, just wish that it was a tiny bit bigger!
author: kristi j.

description: Great food with fresh ingredients. Really small seating area (mostly outside on the street). Cafeteria-style ordering.
author: Blanco N.

description:
An excellent SMALL little cafe from some former Blue Bottle folks, it seems (I say this only b/c I recognized the 2 people there from the Hayes Valley BB kiosk). Good coffee from a Santa Cruz roaster, a handful of freshly made savory and sweet snacks, and one table in a tiny room. 

It's the kind of place that is good depending on your timing. If you happen to get a comfortable spot at the table (and are not particularly misanthropic), then you'll probably have a pleasant time. If you arrive to find the room crowded with no spots, thus forcing you to wait and sit outside on a cold winter day, you may leave disappointed.

Good food, serious coffee, though.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
I walked in to this place and was shocked to see how tiny it is. It barely seats 8 people in a shared table. There are 2 small tables outside for a party of 2 each. So the seating is limited. But the food is to die for. I had one of the best Lattes in my life. By the time we got there, they had already stopped serving breakfast. So I ordered a roast beef sandwich and a mixed green salad. They did not disappoint. 

The service was spectacular and very welcoming. The food was fresh and delicious. Everything was priced very reasonably. As for the seating, it ended up working out. I really didn't even notice the other people that I was sharing the big center table with. I was too busy enjoying my food. The menu is very limited, but well worth it. 

I will definitely come back.
author: Stephan T.

description:
Shannon really knows his stuff. He assisted me in finding the perfect light roast for my foodie bf, and could helpfully compare them to Blue Bottle as he had worked there in the past. (He is also super nice and adorable.) 

Too bad it's not in my hood, but then, if it were, I'd be living in the 'loin. ("Not that there's anything wrong with that.")

I sampled a little coffee there, and also got the bread pudding to go. I can't wait to come back.
author: M A.

description: If you like fresh organic ingredients then you might like this place. The down side is the menu changes every day. I spent $35 for biscuits and coffee for two and left hungry. The coffee is wonderful though and I would go back for a cup of joe and maybe a scone. But I think I'll skip a second meal there.
author: Mike Q.

description: J'adore!   I led my partner & teen on a wild goose chase to check this place out, and I gotta tell ya, I LOVED it.    The french pastries were to die for.  The cortado I had spun me out.  The place was packed, so not enough room for us to really hang out & enjoy the space much, but I love(d) it and will definitely keep on my list of return destinations when I'm in town.
author: Lori M.

description:
My favorite place in the world (that's right, the world) to get coffee / espresso drinks and yummy food. 

The lattes are the best I've ever had. The iced coffees are perfect for those rare warm San Francisco days. And the food is always delicious, inspiring and made with love (courtesy of Kate!) Don't be intimidated if it looks crowded inside, everyone if always very friendly about making room at the table!

You can check them out on twitter to see what they're serving for breakfast and lunch each day. Oh, and the homemade caramels are just to die for! I love love love farm:table.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place. Very small menu that changes daily which means more love into each item. Hint: follow them on twitter to get daily menu.

I am a big coffee bitch. I am amazed that starsucks sends their baristas to barista school and yet they can never make a quality cappuccino. It's about froth silly, not foam. Get your spoon and thermostat out of the milk. Put your hand on the side to feel the temp and use the air pressure to spin the milk until the bubbles and the milk form one consistent frothy delight. But I need not tell this to the baristas at Farm Table because they know how to make a quality cappuccino. I was disappointed to see that they didn't use oak roasted Mr. Espresso, but the beans they use are local and packed full of flavor.

I love the European concept of a family dining table for strangers. All my favorite places have these. Sure I don't like to be thrown into a space with people I don't know and forced to engage when I don't feel like it, but I am a life-long people watcher and eavesdropper and these tables are great.

Keep up the good work
author: Kane M.

description:
OMGOMGOMG! 

THe daily changing menu keeps you on your toes, and the am/pm menu keeps you on your game. The flavors are clean and well seasoned and the coffee is perfectly concocted. For the quality of food you're getting, the prices is right! Perfect portions, tasty grub, and fresh juices, OH MY! Plus the crew is a dime. 

If I lived closer, I'd probably start each day with a little F:T, but until then, I just follow their tweets and dream of eating there on the regular. 

Thank you Farm:Table, nos vemos.
author: C. G.

description: Love this little place!  Baristas are super nice and are really energetic about the new pastries they have.  I had the almond milk mocha- pretty awes, and bostock - super awesome almond pastry!  Great neighborhood joint and I can't wait to try other items on the menu!
author: Kristin D.

description: This tiny hole in the wall cafe has great food, a menu that changes daily, and blue bottle coffee. What more can you ask for?  It's tiny so you'll have to be ok with sharing one large table with others, but everyone is friendly, and lots of times there are newspapers and magazines left for you to browse through if you like.
author: John H.

description: Everyone has their own granola but farm:table had home-made yogurt and cereal which we thought was pretty cool. Coffee was pretty good but we they wouldn't accommodate a third shot for a triple tall Americano - this was confusing to us but we are from  Seattle so we are very picky and this seemed to be a coffee house rule in San Fran...overall a good find.The baked goods were great and they had gluten-free options. You can tell they made their own baked goods. Fun experience and atmosphere. Tiny space but that is part of the appeal and charm. Good to go with a small group, the place would be hard to accommodate a large group. Perfect for a stop to get some coffee and breakfast on the go or to hang out and enjoy a moment  before starting your day.
author: Tasha O.

description:
I've given it two tries but just don't get the appeal of this place.
First of all, it is SMALL.  And I mean TINY.  Last Saturday at 10am when the line at Dottie's was out of control, we swung by to get some coffee and carbs.  
Their menu changes daily depending on what's fresh.  We had bread pudding and some other carb-heavy dish involving cheese and bacon (I forget the name).  Also had a slice of apple pie because it looked so good sitting on the counter. 
Everything was a-ok but nothing spectacular and overpriced.  I think it's more of a gimmick than anything.  
I asked for some nonfat milk for my coffee and I was politely told that all they have is "organic whole milk."  I know you're trying to be all fresh/locally-sourced/organic/whatever but come on, can't a girl get some 2% for her coffee?  Ehhhhh.
My biggest gripe about this place is that there is NO WHERE to sit.  So they have a 'communal table' inside that could seat about 8 but when we got there it was full of 6 people, one of whom was by themself, done with breakfast, and sitting there sipping coffee and reading the paper.  I mean, really dude, REALLY?  Can't you see that other customers who just ordered food need somewhere to sit and eat??  There are two small tables outside, which would be your best bet at having a normal breakfast, if you're so lucky to be stalking the table as the previous customers leave.  I like my coffee and bread pudding without a side of I'm too-cool-for-school-hipsters, thank you very much.
author: Maxine S.

description: Super cute tiny place for breakfast/brunch. The staff was friendly and the food was fantastic.
author: Katie V.

description:
Environment: Place is small, cozy and unpretentious. There is a square table that fits about 6-8 people and a couple of small cafe tables outside. There are also a few small bars so you can stand up and eat. 

I live about 2 blocks away and went with a friend around 9:10 on Sunday and all the seats were already taken! 10 minutes after they opened! We managed to snag a table after waiting for our food. We found the secret: around 10:00 all the tables were pretty much empty.

The food: I ordered the toast with cream cheese and fruits and a coffee. My friend enjoyed her yogurt. I'm not a gourmand and am not going to try to expiate on the flavors. But it was tasty and filling. Probably not worth $8 for toast either. That said, I might go again and would recommend it to others who are curious.
author: Jenny T.

description: Not bad.. Had their latte and wheat bread meal for breakfast. It was a bit pricy for the portion, but the wife told me to portion control so it's good if you're petite. Otherwise I recommend coffee cafe on Taylor Street.
author: Dan M.

description: Great espresso drinks ! No Soy here, so go for the Almond milk.All the beans are so fresh and the people working there are friendly and very nice.
author: Lisa M.

description: House made almond milk latte was just as good as the other reviews said.  Loved the cups there were served in.  Went on a Thur morning around 9am and didn't have to wait more than 10 minutes for my meal, but had to sit outside and it was a little chilly.  Ate the bacon, cheddar, chive quiche.  Perfect portion with a little lightly dressed side salad.  Delicious!
author: Julie A.

description: Artisans of the coffee world work and own this uplifting little spot.  I can't wait for the parklet that is being built here soon.  Sometimes the music is turned on while the window is open while drinking your pristine coffee, reading the paper, table decorated with edible chive blossoms, and strangers sit next to you at the small communal table.  These are some of my favorite things.
author: D B.

description: Lotta bread, little egg juice and little smoked salmon, sprinkled with a few sprigs of arugala.... Left me unsatisfied and out 20 bucks for two plates. :( hopes dashed. Up the valuable portions of the meal and I would have loved.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Fantastic!!

We live in LA but if we lived nearby we would absolutely be regulars. 

Not only was the daily soup, salad and sandwich excellent but the 2 owners couldn't have been nicer. 

I will absolutely be back the next time I'm in town.
author: steve M.

description: Stopped by farm:table just for a cup of coffee.  The place is tiny and very cute.  I was tempted to try their toasts but we had way too many places to eat that day.  We went back on Sunday before our flight back to Orange County but they were closed for Easter.  I'll be back. :)
author: Lanna K.

description: What a cute little place with great simple food.  I really liked their latte, toast of the day, and the breakfast dish with the egg and sausage.  You can taste the freshness of every ingredient and the creativity in each dish that is so incredibly simple.  Only thing I didn't like was the kitchen staff that looked a little unsanitary (?)  Well, you know what I mean if you ever go there.  I wish I had a neat little restaurant like this in my neighborhood.
author: Sana H.

description:
excellent, excellent, excellent

awesome service, friendly atmosphere, and fresh food.

Could not be more happy with this place.
author: Josh E.

description: The coffee is very strong and bitter. If you are use to American style coffee you might opt for the tea. The food was good especially the daily toast.
author: David K.

description:
i enjoyed their latte so much, i had one there and got one to go.  first thing you notice when you enter farm:table is it's small...really small.  thankfully they have outdoor seating (although limited to 2 tables with 3 chairs) and it was a beautiful san francisco morning.
unfortunately i wasn't carrying cash on me, but my friend graciously paid for our lovely meal: toast with avocado, poached egg, bell peppers and fresh spinach, and toast with a mascarpone spread, apples, pears, etc.  i believe their menu changes daily based on the fresh ingredients they get for the day...fresher than my t-shirts during t-shirt time in nj.
author: Todd O.

description:
1st off Yelp, Farm Table is in Lower Nob-http://www.city-data.com/neighborhood/Lower-Nob-Hill-San-Francisco-CA.html
not Civic Center/Tenderloin. 

Cash only, teeny weeny inside, but thjere are a coupld tables outside on the sidewalk. Food is fresh and yummy. Their kouign is Ahhhh-mazing!!! Great coffee. Love their take on dressing up hard boiled eggs with pork belly and rapini. Menu changes daily which is nice.
author: Penwa N.

description: super cool morning place... love the Tendernob. Friendly staff.
author: Matthew S.

description: A bit pricey, but very delicious. I tried a few things during this visit: coconut milk, mushroom and kale soup, house coffee and the house juice. All very delicious and artfully made. I look forward to going back for one of their breakfasts.
author: Lauren J.

description: The food is pretty good and changes daily, so they should be able to perfect the couple of dishes they make. The atmosphere isn't a restaurant, but more appropriate as a food stand. If you're not the first to grab the one table they have inside, and the weather's not good enough to sit at their two tiny tables outside, you're SOL.
author: Amanda S.

description: I loved going here for lunch with my bf. The food was great: tasty, appropriate sized, and well seasoned. I had the quiche with salad which was fantastic followed by a ginger cookie. Whoa! That was a good cookie!  My bf had some meaty sandwich (can't remember which one) and he really enjoyed it and he's a picky cook, so that says a lot. I'll definitely be going back for breakfast. Above all, I like what this place offers: good fresh food with a touch of sophistication in a tiny adorable nook of a place. Oh, and the service was wonderful. :)
author: Kate L.

description: We stopped in after a shift at Glide, so it  was pretty early in the AM on Saturday. We got lucky and found seats at the one large table they have inside. On the menu that day was a swiss-chard, feta cheese and hard boiled egg on a baguette, drizzled with lemon olive oil. Oh my, just writing out what it was reminds me of how good it was. I love the simplicity of the dish and all of the flavors stuck out. Oh, and my mocha was really yummy; i liked that it wasn't overly sweetened.  I will return again farm:table!
author: Trina A.

description: Primarily a (very skillful) cafe, but with a sturdy wooden communal table for deceptively simple but delicious breakfast/brunch.    Table forces you to interact with your fellow coffee patrons, which is a good thing.   Coffee - expresso based or drip - prepared exceedingly well (giving my favorite Stumptown a run for  the money...)
author: Tyler C.

description: Best breakfast/lunch/coffee I have ever had! Absolutely amazing! Fresh, organic, high quality food like you've never tried before. The only downside- parking and seating space is extremely limited.
author: Lena T.

description: Had a fantastic breakfast in this tiny little café.  There's a reason it says "table" and not "tables" - it's really, really tiny. My hard boiled eggs over a baguette with rapini and Duroc ham was delicious and just the right size - and the coffee was not ordinary - it had a taste which made me say "hello!".  All in all, I highly recommend farm:table.
author: Jon M.

description: Followed yelp reviews and was very disappointed. Like other folks my egg on biscuit was cold and didn't look fresh. If you're not a local don't bother, this is a place to get a coffee or pastry but not a meal.
author: Katarine Q.

description:
Great rotating menu.  Fresh and delicious.

They also make a mean cappuccino.  

Cozy space with a laid back feel.
author: Allen K.

description: Great food, friendly service, wonderful coffee. Restaurant is very small so when its crowded, its VERY crowded.
author: J K.

description:
i always feel crazy reviewing spots with as many stellar reviews as farm:table, but i love them so much i can't not throw in my glowing review.  

easily the best coffee in the entire neighborhood if not the whole city.  i'd take a cup of farm:table over ritual or blue bottle any day.  it's light, and flavorful and will put a spring in your step.

as with most of my cafe experiences, I deal with the folks at farm:table in my most ragged and bleary-eyed states and they're always total gems.  they manage to engage me despite being only able to keep one eye open and reply in grunts and are always happy/amused to do so.  having been a barista, i know how easy it is to be irritated by oafs such as myself at such an early hour, but they're always sweet as can be.  

if you haven't been to farm:table (why the hell haven't you?), scoot on in asap.
author: Tom T.

description: eclectic little coffee bar just off union square. they did not have french press coffee as there ads stated but they knew how to properly prepare a red eye.  coffee was good but not Peets or Starbucks quality. Food was the hit though. Daily toast was  really creative and tasty and the foccacia was delicious. staff was friendly and fast despite the tiny space. Seating inside is really just one medium size table and a few small tables on sidewalk so not real comfortable.
author: Kelly T.

description: Latte with soymilk, pretty darn good.
author: Sara L.

description: Farm:table is best for coffee to go.  They do serve food, however there is only one communal table inside and a few tables outside (which are on a hill, so u must be careful) so eating a sit down meal might be difficult here.  I didnt eat here, so this review is solely for the coffee.  For their lattes, they do not have flavour shots, which is a must.  I know purists frown on them, but a splash of vanilla or caramel compliments the coffee so well.  Instead, i had a coffee, for $2.25.  There was nothing wrong with it, it was just really fruity.  Some people are into that, but i am not.  Farm:table is right near Dotties, so you can go there for breakfast and then walk here and have a coffee or tea.
author: Amy D.

description:
farm:table; a haiku.

love for the iced tea
bright plate full of vegetables
one table for all
author: Heather W.

description: This place is the coolest breakfast spot in San Francisco right now, it is also the tiniest. This is one of the reasons I like living in the TL TK exciting things are happening. I visit and have their mocha with almond milk, wish more places served their coffee with almond milk, tastes better than soy and you don't grow man-boobs from it. The aren't many options on the menu, this is excellent. Keeps you from ordering the same stuff all the time. I love Farm:Table hip hip place, delicious but this place has such good taste both in decoration and food. You've never had toast like this.
author: Jaime V.

description: I loved the alternative vibe of this place, even though it made me feel like I wasn't cool enough to be there! Being lactose intolerant, I'm a huge fan of dairy alternatives and couldn't wait to try f:t's homemade almond milk, which I ordered in a double latte. The barista added a nice leaf motif onto the top of my almond milk foam; I asked for it to go and placed one of the hip black and red covers on my off-white cup so I could drink without spilling *and* in style. The almond milk was delicious--light, slightly sweet, and subtly nutty--and served as a good foil to the well-brewed espresso. I brought the Boy here a few days later and he also swooned for the almond milk lattes; we are looking forward to our subsequent visits!
author: Annie M.

description: Definitely as good as it gets for the area of town....Really awesome coffee.  Superb food, despite there only being a single sandwich and cereal option each day.   Fine by me, since they've chosen to do one thing really well rather than just pile up a menu with so so stuff.
author: JOHN C.

description:
Whenever I've eaten here (twice) I feel transported to a small town or city in France. It's not (as the staff member I said this to said) that the portions are on the the small side. It's that the food itself is so different. 

The English language is inadequate to describe their dishes in the space allowed by the menu chalkboard.

Take the pear cardamom bread pudding (don't you dare -- it's mine, all mine). Okay, what you might expect is a bunch of tiny, soft pieces of bread in pears cooked to a pudding-y mush. What you actually get is slices of baguette in an scrambled-egg-pieces-of-diced-pear such that the edges of the bread is soft and the juice has soaked in a bit but the bread retains it's crusty chewyness. Five stars, and the trip to France is included.  After two visits, five stars for the food is not out of the routine for this place.

Alas, beverages have been a two-star experience for me. The house juice, while interesting, was slightly bitter. And the hot chocolate, while creamily-dreamily smooth, seems to this spoiled-by-Mexican-hot-chocolate hot chocolate lover to suffer from a near-absence of chocolate. 

So, I will definitely go back for the food. But, as I don't drink coffee and rarely drink tea, I suspect my potential drink choices will get fewer to non-existant.

BTW, I'm cool with the communal table (or turning the outside tables into one with a polite request if they're really busy). Just emphasizes that French experience.

(Full disclosure: I've never been to France and rarely set foot inside a French restaurant, so any transporting or allusions to French cooking is purely in my imagination.)
author: Charles B.

description: Extremely limited sitting- pretty much a joke for a business. The food had good flavor, but would have been better if it were hot. My husband was very disappointed with his hard boiled egg sandwich. My toast was good, but how can you put sweetened marscapone on toast and go wrong?
author: Julie H.

description: Small is an understatement to describe this place.  This place in minuscule!  The menu changes daily is what I was told.  I tried the pear bread pudding and the hard-boiled eggs with fennel today.  It was decent, but the portions were small so a few hours later, I was starving and needed to get a bite somewhere else.
author: Spencer K.

description: So good. Love their almond milk, love the coffee, and love Shannon & Kate who own the place.
author: Olivia G.

description: Very small, but charming SF coffee house. We sat outside and enjoyed the neighborhood. We didn't eat there, but the food looked very good.
author: Bill S.

description:
We were determined to go to either Dottie's True Blue Cafe or farm:table. Dottie's had an insane line so farm:table was our breakfast experiment!

Date & Time:  12/27 10 AM
Crowd: Younger Crowd, Half Tourist, Half Locals
Atmosphere:  Very cozy, one table to share, everyone friendly, but this place has maybe 7 feet by 7 feet for its customers. 
Decor:  Half kitchen, half restaurant, nice decoration, feels like like you are somewhere special and you are. The menu is written in chalk on the wall and apparently changes everyday. 
Service:  Very friendly and patient. Great service!
Imbibe:  A pot of Oolong tea all to myself. Very good! Very hot!
Devour:  I got the toast which was on delicious bread and slathered with almond butter and topped with slabs of sweet banana and coconut shreds. It was very good. This place focuses on as simple and as fresh as possible, but with little twists. Like the cereal which my aunt got which had some dried fruit and walnuts was all toasted with almond oil before they put the plain yogurt on top. Little things to make the food extra yummy!
Total:  ~$10 each for breakfast with beverage and tip
Helpful Hints: Two small tables outside, one medium sized table inside, be patient to get seated, but overall really fast service.
author: Tyler G.

description: FANTASTIC espresso, over-sweetened ice coffee, great fresh juices and baked goods. beautiful local & seasonal menu, and absolutely no place to sit. cash only, and make sure you communicate with the cashier or you might get a surprise.
author: Y K.

description: Their menus are always different and it never disappoints. Small but full of personalities. I have had their pulled pork dish and frittata several times. It's pretty consistent and portions are just about perfect. I think they grow their own garden on the roof and there is a recently addition of street side man made little garden for extra sitting area -- not proper sitting, but good enough for being in the middle of the busy city. Highly recommend.
author: Cate M. Z.

description: This was a great discovery for a quality breakfast. Fresh produce and skilled preparation made the meal visually wonderful and tasty. This is my new hot spot in SF for a yummy meal. It's urban so finding a seat inside is difficult but worth the trouble.
author: Jed d.

description: Tiny place, lovely staff, great coffee. 'nuff said!
author: Gavin B.

description: What a treat to find this tiny little espresso bar tucked into a very unlikely Tenderloin neighborhood.  These folks really know what they're doing, they pulled a perfect shot of espresso which was so good we kept going back for more. The next day, we trekked 2 miles from our hotel to enjoy it again.. no, it wasn't a fluke this place is the real deal for espresso afficionados.  Better than Blue Bottle, better than Four Barrel, better than Ritual.  I bought a lb of beans to take back with me to San Diego to see if I can recreate the magic at home.
author: Mishel F.

description: Awesome granola, beautiful foam art in almost every drink, full of grups and a very communal atmosphere. Love it
author: gino a.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for awhile. Finally made time for it...a lot smaller than I thought! Menu changes daily but while I was there...I had a little tomato, hard boiled eggs type benedict. It was really yummy and just a quaint little spot. Great place for dining by yourself or just 1 other person since the space is very limited.
author: Lola D.

description: Ridiculously high prices, small menu, tiny portions. My wife and I had frittatas for breakfast (one for each), an ice tea and a small orange juice. 28 bucks and we left so hungry.
author: Jack C.

description: Wonderful attentive service, great coffee, nice breakfast fare that changes every day. Try the almond milk latte. It's different from a usual latte, but once you get used to it, there is no going back.
author: Antonella P.

description: So tasty! We got the daily toast topped with mascarpone, apples and graham cracker crumb AND hard boiled eggs over sourdough baguette with shitake mushrooms and arugula.  Both were excellent! The staff was helpful and the coffee was great too!
author: Christine D.

description:
ok - so there's 1 table in this place.  maybe you can get about 2 people per side and then 2 extra sitting adjacent.  That's it.  But if you're looking for something different and a unique experience for breakfast, this is it.
It's not in a super glamorous part of town - but close enough.  You're not going to have table service - you walk up to a counter and order from a short list of 3 or 4 things.  And you're not going to find your standard breakfast specials.  But what you will find is an adventure into another world of eating.  And if you are finicky like me, you just don't ask what is in it - or think about it too long - and you just order one of the 3 selections available and you sit and enjoy it.  And enjoy it I did!  First we had some egg thing where the hard boiled eggs were balanced on crunchy toast, then we had their version of a cereal and finally, amazing coffee!
This place feels like it is on the cusp of something new and exciting.  The collection, preparation, and presentation of food in this place is first rate!
author: Ted S.

description: A darling little place that's thoughtfully designed and also happens to serve some of the tastiest coffee in the city alongside delectable, house made snacks? Thank you! To top it off, the owners, Kate and Shannon, are warm and kind. A more perfect addition to the neighborhood I cannot fathom.
author: jessica b.

description:
love having my cereal and fruit and my iced coffee here every morning. 
really really amazing iced coffee. tiny happy place.
author: coffeecake j.

description: We regularly make the trek from Noe Valley on the weekends, toddler in tow, bypassing closer (and wonderful) options like Ritual and Four Barrel - that's how good farm:table is.  Best latte perhaps anywhere, lovely baked goods (don't miss the brown sugar butter cake), and the egg dish on offer always seems to hit the spot.  We usually get there promptly when the doors open and have the table to ourselves for a good half hour.  Extra stars for always having the NYT available.  I wonder if there's any way to convince the ladies to open a branch in Noe Valley...?
author: Katy M.

description: simple. delicious. great coffee. stop there weekly on my way walking to work for the to-go bfast sandwich (crusty baguette + hard boiled egg w herbs + meat or cheese or both). for those that complain about seating/credit cards/price/neighborhood/parking -  might i suggest ihop - buttermilk pancakes and your kids eat for free.
author: Daniel W.

description: The coffee is AWESOME, the daily toast is INCREDIBLE, the people are way NICE. This place is tops.
author: Brittany L.

description: An ever-changing menu - my dream place!  My LLC is called On-A-Whim...this place fits right into my idea of a chef-owner that knows how to do it right!  You sit at a "farm table" with people who have a shared interest in daily specials and believe that food is love.  The prices are a little high but you get a unique meal in a unique atmosphere that makes you feel like you're part of the family.  Homemade desserts, soups, and daily specials...yum!  Now open every day for lunch too!
author: Brooke C.

description:
CUTE CUTE CUTE!
and A cup of coffee that could compete with Blue Bottle or Four Barrel. Delicious HOT cup of coffee. not hand poured by the cup like the two previously mentioned cafes, however I always feel that my coffee is not hot enough for my liking from BB or 4B. Farm:Table can claim to have the hottest best cup of Joe.
The cafe is very small, just one big table with benches in the seating area; kinda makes it feel like someone's dining area. there are two tables with chairs on the sidewalk so if it is a nice SF day..and you have a puppy. have a seat outside and enjoy your coffee in a ceramic cup, with a free refill. 
Yummy baked items...although my friend noted that their sandwiches were a bit pricey....around $10.
My Lucy really enjoyed the free doggy treats that looked yummy enough to be people food. 
Bonus: PARKING....right in front. although it is metered...there appeared to be ample parking right on the street.
author: Kelle K.

description: God bless these guys. I'm so glad they're here. Verve coffee, varied breakfast, lunch and treats. A few tips: cash only, inSANEly tiny, few milk options and a small menu. Don't go with a group of picky people.
author: Catherine C.

description: Great local coffee shop. The staff is knowledgeable and they all whip up a mean cup of coffee (or tea). I'm always 100% satisfied with my beverage when I leave here! They are a little pricey, but it is truly the best tasting coffee in the city (and I've tried them all). I've heard refills are included, but I've always gotten mine to go so I can't confirm that. Either way, if you enjoy a strong cup of joe this is definitely the place to go!
author: Anne A.

description: Great Cappucino other coffee drinks. The inside eating area is about 8 ft by 8ft, so it is pretty quaint. There is one table inside that people share and a couple of tables outside. The woman inside who helped us was very nice, and I give the barista Five stars!!!
author: greg w.

description:
I love this place!  It's a bit like you are eating at a friend's house; it's very personal and inviting.  There is only one table and enough room for 6-7 people to eat on it and a bench to the side that could seat 2-3 people that just want to sip on coffee. So expect a wait if you want to eat there.  The tiny space and the communal table is what makes it extra special for me because it forces you to interact with your neighbor, something that most people have forgotten how to do.  I have been there a few times and I always end up meeting some interesting locals or tourists with great stories...I love that!

The food:

The menu rotates daily and they use fresh, local ingredients, which is very important to me.  FYI, if you check them out on twitter you can find out what they are serving that day.

The simplicity, portion size and presentation of the dishes is very nice.  I always leave very satisfied and with a giant smile.

1- I am super picky about my coffee and Damn! They make a great cappuccino, so perfectly creamy and strong, just how I like it! And the regular coffee is just as good.

2- I've had the baguette with swiss chard, cheese, topped with a hard-boiled egg and slightly drizzled with lemon olive oil.  Yum!  Simple and amazing.

3- The barley soup was flavorful and perfectly cooked.

4-The cereal with yogurt and cherries was also very tasty and filling. Very fresh and so good!

*Prices range from 6+ for food and I have never seen anything over $10.  Cash only! *
author: Angelica F.

description: This is the sort of place that causes you to reconsider and regret every big, semi-national chain restaurant you've ever visited. Tiny, cozy, friendly, and incredibly fresh. It's just good, good, good. Lovely.
author: Drew F.

description: Farm: table is delicious in every respect. The perfect hang-out: warm hosts who are so connected with what they do, inventive simple meals using sublimely fresh ingredients, casually creative ambience reminiscent of NY before the 2000s boom - with poetry books, Marx, New Yorker, etc. - and the urbanity of spontaneous communality. I do find the portion size to be small for the price, and I'm not a big eater, but the drinks are reasonably priced. Note: If one isn't in the mood for strangers asking questions, it might then be better to skip farm: table. I twinge with embarrassed guilt about my cold demeanor towards a man with whom I was sharing a small bench; at that hour I just felt like reading, not chatting about the book I had in front of me - unrealistic of me to expect a modicum of personal space in such a tiny restaurant.
author: Eliza S.

description:
i get coffee here every day almost and their coffee/lattes is great and their tasty pastries are excellent. the almond cake is the best stuff ever. people who dont like sweet almond flavor are pussies with zero clue.

they have the best coffee and they also have the 2nd best coffee to-go cup lids. 7-11 has the best coffee lids.
author: christopher a.

description: As the four-stars say, "yay! I'm a fan." I come here just about every day for a delicious cafe au lait.  I stare longingly at the PM specials when they come up on my twitter feed, but alas they are located a little too far from work to truck over here during my lunch break. I recommend trying their soups.
author: Sarah T.

description: Great use of a small space. Loved the communal aspect, housemade yogurt and sugary breakfast cereal. Delicious!
author: L S.

description: Great breakfast. Great coffee. Super atmosphere. Wish they had more seating so we could share the splendor with more of our fellow man.
author: Jon D.

description: With all the 5 star reviews, I came here expecting a lot.  I was a little disappointed.  The coffee was stellar, as most of the other yelpers noted, but my piece of vanilla bundt cake that I had was bone dry.  It had good flavor--you could taste the vanilla, but I had to use my coffee to wash it down.  My breakfast companion had toast with sheep's milk cheese and sliced strawberries, which was a nice combination.  Perhaps I didn't choose well...but overall I thought it was over-priced for what you got.
author: CJ C.

description: Delicious quick fare. Recommend pick-up over dining in
author: Lilia M.

description: I love this place.  I don't know how they make their eggs taste so damned good.  Almond milk lattes are the bomb too.    Amazing, simple food.
author: Jeff W.

description: VERY small but quaint. great coffee and its nice to share a small table with whomever. but the place is literally one table that belongs in a farm home.  the food is extremely fresh and simple but great.  you don't feel heavy or hungry leaving.  just not really a place to expect a long meal where you sit and chat.  or else you'll be cramping the place.
author: Scott N.

description:
i love this little spot! it's tucked in the tender nob, and tiny, cute and quaint as ever. there are a few tables in and outside to dine at, and otherwise you can do take away, or find a step at the surrounding buildings or a curb to perch on. i do fancy menus written on chalkboards, and farm:table lists the breakfast, sandwich and soup de jour daily. i like how they only have 3 things to choose from daily, and what they serve is simple yet scrumptious. last time i was there they had hard boiled eggs with bacon and a fig chutney on a baguette, and a creamy cheese topped with tomatoes and chives on a baguette, and soup of which i forget. 

i hate to say that i detested my coffee. i ordered an almond milk latte, but something about it was all wrong. i couldn't even try to drink it. i should have trusted my gut and ordered it with regular milk -- the next time i will do so!
author: Sheri N.

description: Very cool place to grab a casual bite for breakfast or lunch. The place is very small with only 1 table to seat everyone who comes in.  I personally like  personal space and feel uncomfortable looking at strangers eating-- so I wasn't a fan of the community table.  However, the food was delicious and very fresh.  I ordered a roast beef avocado sandwich and a mocha.  Unfortunately, my pet-peeve is hot drinks in glasses, but the mocha was very good--not too sweet.  My friends ordered the homemade cereal that uses yogurt instead of milk.  The staff was really friendly.  Warning-- they only take cash, but there is an atm in a liquor store a few stores down.
author: Leslie C.

description:
i understand that they have blue bottle coffee here, but like i came here for coffee on monday and on tuesday went to actual blue bottle in the ferry building and it was like. . .so much better here.  what do they do to their coffee?

i'm slightly sad about farm:table because i came for breakfast at like 10 on a weekday and they were basically out of everything so i just had to wistfully look on while other people ate their bacon avocado hard-boiled egg halves perfectly resting on little baguette cylinders.

also, while those hard-boiled eggs looked pretty good, like. . .why is this place famous for serving only one thing. that's so weird.  like, are they planning on some day upgrading to two things? or is the one thing part of it.  like the fact that it's only one thing.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I like...Folks were friendly n they pay attention to detail from the drinks, the flowers on the table to the mini goat cheese n pistachio tarts ...it's cozy and I like that you have to share the one table that they have inside - transgressing American notions of personal space. Thank you for easy afternoon...
author: liza g.

description: 25min wait for food.   sunday 1145.  don't expect hearty man portions,  but food is very tasty
author: Felix Y.

description: farm:table is a dream come true. Yes, it's small, and no, there isn't a lot of seating, but they do what they do exceedingly well. The food is fresh, organic, and delicious, and the coffee is tip-top. Owners Kate and Shannon couldn't be sweeter and I really don't think they could be using the space any better. Everything is well-designed and visually pleasing right down to the sugar bowl. Plus, they have tables outside the often open storefront.
author: Andrew I.

description: Great little place to grab a quick bite and an outstanding coffee drinks. Awesome staff.
author: Marco M.

description: DO NOT EVER COME HERE TO EAT!!!! I was lured in here by all of the high reviews on yelp..but DON'T BE FOOLED! Farm table has less than mediocre food at outrageous prices. Almost nine bucks for a Slice of quiche...i can buy a whole quiche for 14 or 15 at the local grocery store and it would probably taste better. Farm table boasts of organic this and organic that...as i was waiting...tired of standing as there are no provided chairs to sit on, i walked to the liquor store to buy sugar substitute for my coffee...farm table had no sugar substitute...what about people who are diabetic??! Are they not entitled to sweeten their coffee?! The lady who worked at farm table was shopping at the liquor store for supplies for the restaurant...hmmm organic???  Anyhow...they totally forgot my quiche and after about 30 minutes remembered...and served me a lukewarm small slice for $8 or $9 bucks...I think people come here for the hipster vibe...but I like to go to restaurants for good food.
author: Cookee L.

description: Excellent brioche sandwich with hard boiled egg, marscapone, arugala, and bacon.  Amazing coffee cake muffin.  Good coffee too.  They literally have one tiny table and a few outdoor tables, so don't expect to be able to eat in if you come with a large group.  The two of us fit just fine.  The staff was really friendly.  They have a square reader hooked up to an iPad so I was able to pay with credit and get a receipt emailed to me.
author: Matt M.

description:
amazing coffee, and even better service. a day with farm:table involved is always a great day!

Farm:Table- see you tomorrow!
author: Elliott G.

description: seriously awesome coffee...i ordered a macchiato and was expecting it to be a coffee, similar to what you get from the commercialized starbucks. instead it came in an espresso cup and i have to tell you that i did not even put any sugar or milk and it was the best tasting coffee i've ever had. i also got a slice of toast with goat cheese and cherries and it was tasty. this was a great way to start the day, i hope to come back soon.
author: Marjie T.

description:
I really like this place. 
When choosing a place to eat, I'm all about the vibe and the ambiance of the place and this place is great. Yes, it is really small, 1 (kind of) big table inside, and a couple small tables outside, but what they lack in space, they make up for it in the food and the vibe.

I always look for new place to have brunch and I just added this place to one of my go-to places. Despite not having that many food to choose from, the ones that are there are delicious, so I'd definitely recommend the place.

I only give it 3 stars because even though their customer service is good and they are really friendly. It's one of those places that kind of feels like everybody there knows everybody else, which is find by me, I just need my food. 
It's just after a while it gets kind of annoying when I have to wait for them to finish their (sometimes) loud conversation for me to order my food, or when I have to wait for my food a little bit longer because they are finishing their "friends" order who came after me.
author: Dee S.

description: I like the idea of a changing menu based on using fresh new ideas and ingredients each day. However, the food on the day I visited was mediocre at best for its prices and it lacked creativity. What really ruined everything for me was the staff! There was only one girl in there that was actually polite and smiled. The other 2 servers were rude and uninviting and made my experience even worse! Not worth it to come back to this place...
author: jen c.

description: I love this tiny place! The iced coffee is pretty good and I like that the menu changes daily. Everything I've had so far has been very fresh and delicious and everyone who works here is so sweet which makes this quaint little place even better.
author: Lucia V.

description: Cute little place, very reminiscent of blue bottle....hmmm.... I wonder why? Because the owners used to work there before they decided to go do their own thing. The coffee, I must admit, is still not as exquisite as blue bottle, but it's fulfilling. I really love the fact that they make their own soy milk and other delicious treats. Ask for their secret menu, you might find something you will love.
author: Seema H.

description: Excellent simple breakfast. Great coffee. Very friendly service. However, forgot to bring me juice and I asked twice.
author: Caleb C.

description: Frittata was light and delicate and the coffee was fantastic with a small community table.  A great stop if you can fit in.
author: Chris H.

description:
A good idea - even great one - badly implemented. Coffee in small teacups so gets cold quickly - I'd rather have one mug that stays hot than a free refill that is cold by the time it hits the cup.

Suppose there was farm-fresh food, but very little of it. A morsel of strawberries in one dish and an egg-and-a-half in the other - with loads of white bread as filler.

It may have been good white bread, but lots of people aren't eating wheat, and certainly white bread is one of our more unhealthy habits. Plus, it just looks cheap.

Again, nice idea, but especially in the tenderloin there should be some healthy food involved at a reasonable price. This place perpetuates the idea that healthy food is way too expensive and you don't get a lot.

May try another time or a different meal but won't make a point of it.
author: Outdoor O.

description: I had breakfast here on the first morning of my first ever visit to San Francisco because I had read such rave reviews from other Yelpers. Wow was it fantastic. Not only was my hot chocolate deliciously rich and decadent but they had chocolate bread pudding on the menu. Are you kidding me? Chocolate and bread pudding for breakfast? I was so happy when she brought it out to me that I hummed while I ate it and not in a quite happy way but in a loud and 6 months pregnant kind of way. The bread pudding was rich and velvety and well perfect in every way. The gals working were really nice and gave my husband and I a ton of recommendations for other places we should try on our visit. Thanks farm:table for starting our visit out on such a high note. Can't wait to go back!
author: Alli B.

description: Just lovely!  I had cafe au lait with 1/2 and 1/2 (my standard) and 3 hardboiled eggs on baguette slices spread with burrata and served with pesto (basil pesto?) and sauteed white onions of some sort .  Fresh and so tasty.  We shared (well, Larry got a few bites anyway) a breakfast coffee cake and a cardamom palmier.  Excellent.  Larry had a cherry bread pudding.  Yummy!  Tiny place.  The medium sized communal table was pretty full, but we were able to snag one of the two or three 2 top tables outside.  (This visit was a month ago, so my memory of it isn't as detailed as I'd like.)
author: Karen K.

description: I really like this little spot. I always walked by at night and was frustrated that it was only a daytime locale. The coffee is very good and the sandwiches are always delicious. It's got a great feel to the place, everyone sits together at a table... farm table.. but also the name implies that they use local sustainable ingredients. It's a nice addition to a grungy street.
author: jen w.

description:
actually it should be 6 stars. at least! hands down, shannon and kate make the best latte in the nation! no kidding, i get around a bit and check lattes everywhere, but none is on par with farm:table.
and the food is incredible! how do they do this? such a superb quality and consistency. 
and here are few more stars! why? remember your last visit at 'that' or the 'other' coffeehouse? so cool, so hip, so arrogant, so snotty! ...
well, the nicest people you can find on hondas and at farm:table. especially behind the counter.
author: bmwcafe c.

description: Well, this restaurant was the highlight of my trip to San Francisco save the saxophone player beneath my window blowing for bucks til past midnight... The food is magnificient.  Fresh. Perfectly seasoned. My cafe au lait was absolutely phenomenal.  I'm from New Orleans.  That's no small feat to me.  I chose the quiche and cleaned my plate.  My meal plus drink was $12.  I tipped $5 just because I appreciate great food.  They were very busy even though I went a half hour after they opened on Sunday morning.  The service was good but not great.  I wasn't familiar with the process of ordering at the register... so I dare not take away a star for my lack of knowledge.  I even asked the guy who was apparently the head cook/chef a question because he was passing the table.  How was I supposed to know... ? LOL!  He was a bit unnerved but he answered anyway.  I've been a waitress.  I know that tone... Nonetheless, it pays to ask the people at the table what to do and leave the 3 guys behind the counter working their magic to doing just that! CASH ONLY.  Leave your plastic at home.  Take a stroll down to farm:table and enjoy the best meal you'll get in San Francisco for $12.
author: Yvette F.

description: I was very reluctant when I first walked in to see how tiny this place was, there is one table that people sit at and a register to order/pay, thats it. This place was the size of a restroom but I decided to give it a shot, My boyfriend and I ordered their carrot cake cupcake, almond cake, hardboiled eggs on toasted bread with a coffee and green tea. Let's just say I was blown away, the egg dish was good, but the cakes were amazing, melt in you mouth good. I will definitely be coming back to this place on a regualr basis for their pastries and a cup of coffee.
author: Sadie L.

description: Cute little coffee shop and very local.  The previous place was OK, but farm:table is much better and fits the neighborhood vibe. Getting a seat is tough, but if forces you to make friends with strangers.
author: Lisa R.

description: Cute. Tasty. Awesome. Cool staff. Excellent food. Excellent caffe latte and hot chocoalte.
author: Bjørn R.

description: Food is super delicious and the coffee drinks are top notch. Kate and Shannon are sometimes a little surly, but still are nothing short of the best!
author: Ian M.

description: The coffee is perfect every time,,,,it really spoils you.  They have breakfast and lunch choices that change daily and peak your curiousity,,,,thank you for the great service too
author: Nicole q.

description: A lovely wee spot with fresh baked goods, excellent coffee and superb soup (the day i was there i had the curried zucchini soup - delicious with a nice spicy bite).  can't wait to go back and relax at the large table - perfect for sunday mornings or any other morning for that matter!  owners are very pleasant and relaxed - the day i was there my favourite brazilian music playing the background...go check it out!
author: Alison M.

description:
Saw this place on Yelp and thought I would try it out. YUMMMMY!!!! The best coffee we had in San Francisco. We went back and took some home to our "dogwatchers." 

I ordered a Latte and their "toast" which was more than just that. It had the huge smashed dates, walnuts and was drizzled with honey. It was delicious. Like the reviews say, this place is small so be prepared to sit with some unknowns at their only table inside, hang out on the chairs on the sidewalk, or grab it to go. we had no problem with any of the above as the place has a great feel to it.
author: Chick M.

description:
Friendly staff
quality espresso on a street you don't expect it
free house NYT
tiny/cozy eating area
author: Troy B.

description: Absolutely enjoyed our experience. Very good service, nice people, excellent coffee and food. It made our San Francisco experience, so glad to have been recommended to visit them. It's so nice to find a small place where service, quality still matter in this land of franchises.
author: Ben L.

description:
The setup at farm:table is much like their product offering - simple and no frills. If you want a place that is going to overwhelm all of your senses, look elsewhere. I like the daily menu format since it keeps things interesting but if there isn't something that you like on there, and you haven't checked ahead, you'll have to go somewhere else.

So, small space, small menu, quick meal = good or fine by me. Small portions, hit or miss menu = hungry or sometimes meh.
author: Don L.

description:
Charming place, and we had a delicious soup, not to mention the excellent macchiatos! The house espresso is fab - a custom blended roast that's caramel-y and chocolate-y all at once. :) 

I feel *incredibly* lucky to have such a delightful cafe in my neighborhood, and love the sweet touches here, like little greens growing in the flower boxes outside. Will definitely be back often!
author: Dido H.

description: Great service. The meatballs w goat cheese were amazing.  My boyfriend said it was one of the best cups of coffee he's had in the city.  But the one table inside was too tight.  Hope the best for this place, so they can expand into a bigger location : )
author: Jennifer O.

description: My partner and I have gone there a few times and loved everything about it.  Yes, it's small....but it's also really cool to share a table with one or two people you don't know, and talk about the various things you are eating.  The coffee is incredible, but the food is always changing, always amazing.
author: Ken R.

description: These guys have mastered putting simple ingredients together in a fantastic way. In addition to a great breakfast, we got to sit at the inside, community table and got tons of other restaurant tips from locals. The coffee was great, as were the folks who served us, AKA the owners. Follow these guys on Twitter to drool from afar. @farmtable.
author: Marjorie A.

description: I've been here for breakfast/brunch a couple times.  The coffee is great, and I like that they include a refill in the price.  The menu is unique and well though out every time.  Nothing is ordinary, but it's always delicious.  I also like the outdoor seating.  The whole place has a do it yourself, kind of vibe, including the communal table, and the carpentry on the folding tables outside.  I'll definitely come back again.
author: Idin K.

description:
only cafe around the tender-nob area that really cares for their products. the people are friendly and are knowledgeable about their products.
the place is really tiny and there's a large table that takes up about 2/3's of the dining. farm:table is very warm and homey.

support your local shops, forget starbucks!*
author: Jeorge J.

description:
it cant get any more san francisco than this! fresh organic gourmet food, it is an experience. good for take out/ very quick bites since the restaurant has very limited seating. 
smaller portions, okay price, good food & latte.
author: Jyl L.

description: This is just the place we were looking for. Our first day in SF and we were looking for a unique coffee place. Not only is the coffee amazing- the food was beyond awesome! Unique and delicious. The 2 young baristas were super friendly and patient while we looked over the hand written menu. We took their suggestions and were very impressed. they were also very helpful in suggesting local places for dinner later that night. I think we may go back each day we are here. :)
author: Katie L.

description: Tiny (literally just one table), not cheap, but EXCELLENT.  I love that they have a limited choice, but what they make is fresh and very tasty.
author: Matthias J.

description:
I found out about this place after asking Gabe (who makes blue bottle coffee, and whom I consider a espresso nazi), if he ever trusts anyone else when it comes to making him coffee. He suggested this place. 

I was surprised at how small and quaint this place is, but that just adds to its charm and character. And Gabe was right, the cappuccino was off the hook. I then read the awesome food reviews on Yelp, so hit this place up one more time with my good friend Shan. She appreciates these sorts of places, and I KNOW she didn't leave disappointed. We both ordered the hard-boiled egg on the toasted baguette, with tapenade and goat cheese. I never had anything like this, and the combination didn't sound too tempting...but BOY was I wrong. Because it was absolute decadence in my mouth! Salty, creamy, chewy and tangy, all in one scrumptious bite. I even attempted to make it when I got home, but big surprise, it wasn't nearly as good. 

So do yourself a favor, check this spot out. Whether it's for coffee and/or a bite, you'll leave absolutely satisfied.
author: Kanani M.

description: Please do not come here if you really care about how big a cafe is and how much room you need to sit down away from other people. The food is the best. THE BEST! No other place in the city can prepare and serve food with these ingredients up to these standards. Everything is fresh and real. So please do not come here if this amazing oasis is too "tiny" for you.
author: Marisela V.

description: Love, Love, Love this place. Went there yesterday because my husband and I heard they served Verve coffee and also got lunch. We shared an insane delicious BLT  which was made with love. The coffee was great and the homemade salted Caramels are sooooooo great. All the people that work there have such a friendly and nice spirit about them. What a tiny and fab little secret spot to take friends for a coffee and lunch. Bravo!
author: Elise P.

description: I love farm:table! Have been going there for years and the food and coffe have always met the deliciousness of the very first taste. Sometimes it gets busy and I have to wait, but I seriously do not mind. It is good to see a small business, like this, doing well.  Thank you farm:table for making delicious breakfast and lunch and coffee for me!
author: Lisa O.

description: This place was fantastic a year ago.  Sadly, the staff changed, the prices increased, and the food is a little worse--it's more meat oriented.  It's too bad the prices went up and the quality went down.  Still, I'm giving them a 3 star rating.
author: Bob J.

description: small and sweet with beverages from heaven.  i did see something rather odd, i witnessed the barista put pieces of bacon in some girl's coffee, I'm hoping this was just a special request as it was rather disgusting though the human drinking it looked happy.  i left quickly.
author: Noel J.

description: we were waiting in line for dottie's true blue cafe on sunday. we thought we support a local coffee shop and made it a point to visit coffee shop. what i ended up with was paying $10 for two overpriced pretentious coffee. not everyone likes almond milk, nor does it make a good latte. my drink had loose bits of almond milk while my partner's drink was also not to her liking. "it tastes weird". a real waste of hard earned money. its fine if you want to have your vision of version of a coffee shop, but at least make coffee that is palatable.
author: Sun K.

description: This place is great.  I live fairly close, and I love that they twitter their daily AM and PM menus so I always consider their menu before thinking about my other options.  The food that I have had so far has been amazing.  The portions are a great size, and the prices are a bit expensive for my budget, but not for what you get in terms of quality food.  I'm the type of person who loves to find a favorite item at every restaurant I go to, and stick with that one dish.  Farm:Table isn't really a place where I can do that, but I'm ok with it because their food never lets me down.  The coffee is REALLY good too, however, it's expensive so I don't get it regularly.
author: Lizzy G.

description: dish was whatever. two eggs with mushrooms around some really hard toast that cut my mouth. taste was bland.
author: Jenny B.

description: I get my coffee to go on my way to school/work.  I never have to wait and the coffee is amazing.  If it was a little less expensive I would come here more often.
author: Drie C.

description: After reading all these reviews I thought I was going to sit down for a great breakfast BUT there is only 1 table to share with the whole tiny place and 3 things to choose from to eat.  Cereal, fruit and a sandwich--so please don't go hungry. It's a great snack stop. I had a green tea which was great and the services was very friendly.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Went there on a Friday just before the change to the 11AM lunch menu for breakfast, based on favorable Yelp ratings.  The atmosphere of this small, intimate and friendly place was quite nice.  The food (green pea and english leek quiche, poached eggs, ham and toasted bread) were good, though not great.  Chiefly, $60 for breakfast for four seemed a bit steep for the quantity and quality of the food.  To be fair, the meatloaf sandwich for the lunch menu looked generous and superb.  FYI; cash only.
author: Mark T.

description: great little local cafe with limited eats. but i like limited because i'm simple minded and i like not having too many options to ponder over. todays daily toast was goat cheese with nectarines, blueberries and toasted coconut. although it'd be easy enough to make at home and for a lot cheaper (it was $6.75 for two toasts), it's nice having someone else come up with the concoctions and let me enjoy them. plus i love their iced coffee.
author: Regina C.

description:
I have been a fan of Farm:Table from the get-go- although, I am not able to be a regular (wish I could)... the couple that mainly run it /own it are great and know precisely what they are doing.

Coffee is super fantastic when dark haired guy is working the machine. The food is tasty and worth stopping in for.  Always creative, healthy and satisfying.  I stopped in the other day and got a latte and a chocolate cardamon cookie- the latte was not as good as when guy is doing his thing.  The cookie was too hard and dry, more like a dog biscuit texture than what they were aiming for.  My friend had the "morning toast" and loved it.  I still remember a piece of Lemon Meringue pie someone brought me from there last year, will that come back again? and then there were those tiny chocolate shortbread cookies in a jar...  I have also had the various soups, super delicious.  Most sandwiches made here I would drive out of my way to have.  In the past I had a most delicious chocolate layer cake and some tasty breakfast cakes, I have the feeling the owner is not baking these any longer. Overall, so super worthwhile.
author: margot R.

description: There are several things that make this place special. Namely, the service is impeccable. There is no coffee service with a scowl or 'f*#! you' for trying to get something to eat here (you know that attitude that seems to poison so many san francisco coffee houses). The service is always pleasant. The cloth napkins. The food. The coffee. The community table. Everything just seems to work. Making a leisurely mid-day visit to farm:table is like getting a massage, going to therapy, and returning home to the excited greeting of a loved one all wrapped up in one. The prices seem just right for the quality of the food and drink. I wish I could visit daily.
author: David H.

description: Funky little organic eatery. Nothing fancy, pretty communal, but had a great local feel and my breakfast turned out much better than I expected. Cheap eats, quality food, little selection.
author: Jud V.

description: To make a long story short, good coffee, excellent juice and over priced food in relation to the portions. The day's special (hard boiled eggs over baguette with zuchinni) is impossible to eat with fork and knife without everything flying over everywhere, and the toast with strawberries that is consisted of two slices bread costs 8$...   Good atmosphere though and very kind staff.
author: Carl-hugo B.

description: Truly what I'd like to give them is 3.5 stars, but Yelp doesn't let you do halfies just yet.   In any case, this review is really just a partial review, as I haven't had a meal there just yet, just coffee and a breakfast cake/muffin, etc.  I stopped by a few times in the last week or so to get a cup of Americano to go, which is very very good.  Their coffee is delicious, and I love the little fixin's bar just outside the door where I can add my splash of housemade almond milk.  The orange olive oil (?) breakfast cake slice I had was incredible also.  Why only 3 stars? 1) $2.50 for a tiny cup of Americano and $3 for a  2 x 3" slice of sweetened bread? Pricey!  2) staff has a little attitude and my only chance for a smile is when I actually hand over my money; 3) it's super duper small in there, so if there's one or two people before me, the wait is long and unpleasant because I'm standing over other people who are sitting and eating at a large corner table.  I do plan to go back and try the food though, because it looks very good and if the quality is even close to that of the coffee, it's worth a shot.
author: Kate C.

description: Excellent espresso, nice locally source food, homely. Need I say more? Loved it.
author: Jason L.

description: This place is perfect. High quality ingredients, personable staff, and best barista in the tendernob.
author: Chuck D.

description: I'll admit that I was a bit weary going into farm:table.  It seems as though the expression farm to table is giving gastropub a run for its money as the most abused term in the food industry.  Regardless, I was curious to see why farm:table was so hot on SF Yelp.  I was quite surprised to see how small the space was.  The dining room consists of one large table.  They also have two small bistro tables outside the front door - and since the inside was overrun with hostellers and the SF chilly winter morning feels practically tropical in comparison to Denver's winters, we were happy to sit outside.  The kitchen is also tiny - and very crowded with three employees busting out food and drinks.  The coffee menu is standard, with high quality coffee served just about any way you want it.  The presentation of the coffee is fab, with mason jars, beautiful mugs and heart shapes carved into the milk foam.  The food menu is simple.  They don't serve gut busting, food coma inducing, greasy breakfast here.  Just simple variations of toast with super fresh ingredients.  We got the daily toast topped with hard boiled eggs, mushrooms, and chevre.  It was simple, but it exploded with fresh flavors.  We also split their breakfast sandwich of the day, a mix of eggs, ham, and pesto sandwiched between a crusty baguette.  Double yum!  Powered by coffee and a light breakfast, we were ready to rumble around SF for the day.
author: Thomas S.

description: When they say it is small, they mean it. One oversized table. Very, very small menu selection but well-chosen and thoughtful menu.  Very good food, hot chocolate is just OK, bread is delicious, and nice servers.
author: aller f.

description: farm:table as cappuccino:tummy. if this were a GRE question i'd probably get it wrong but as it's yelp it makes perfect sense. my sister and i had many a great cappuccinos and macchiatos in italy and france, where non-fat versions do not exist. such is the case at farm:table. the cappuccino is good--very good--but i'm not sure i buy into the hype of a place which ensures an almost fail-proof cappuccino by only offering a full-fat, organic milk version. by hype i mean waiting in a ridiculously long line to get food/drinks, then waiting some more for a table or seat in their small space. haven't had their food yet, but next time i feel indulgent maybe this will hit the spot..
author: Dee C.
