description: Lovely fresh breakfast. Good price. Coffee was really good. Small and cosy setting. Had almond butter toast with pear and coconut. Very fresh and tasty? Perhaps not a perfect place for kids but certainly a place where you can introduce them to new and interesting taste sensations!
author: G P.

description: Just been to Colorado for 2 weeks, not a good coffee in sight. First day in San Fran, thank god for Farm Table, great coffee.
author: Todd T.

description: great fresh local food. they have a parklet in the works which will provide more outdoor seating! this is one of the best breakfast spots in sf!
author: Grant B.

description: This place is so damn cute. I was visiting SF last week and didn't want to eat another hotel restaurant meal. So I turned to my Yelp iphone app of course and fell in love with the picture of that boiled egg sandwich at farm:table. So I strolled two blocks uphill (always achy calves in SF) to this little gem. It's tiny. I mean tiny - one table tiny. But it's a farm table so you all sit together. Cute. The guy and gal working there were so nice and cool. I was alone and I'm a little shy but felt really welcomed. They made me up that egg sandwich with shaved asparagus, parm and olive oil. Oh man! It's heaven. The baguette is toasted and it's a little hard to maneuver - I bent the fork trying to cut into it. It's a beautiful dish, totally form over function but once you get all the right stuff on your fork - and you actually get it into your mouth, it's bliss. I was alone so I couldn't get all "Mmmmmm," you know?  My farm table neighbor had the toast with mascarpone and strawberries - hello, I loved my dish AND had food envy. I took a pound of their coffee home so when I attempt to make that mascarpone toast in my Brooklyn kitchen, I'll have their coffee to bring me right back to that little table in California.
author: Modemme X.

description: My new favorite destination coffee spot. Excellent coffee, warm and inviting interior, a communal table with the NYTs, a carafe of lemon water and fresh flowers... and the tastiest toast ever - today's special - whole wheat walnut topped with fromage blanc and fresh cherries and a sprinkling of brown sugar. Delish! Kate and Shannon were wonderfully welcoming & friendly. If you're in the 'hood, check it out.
author: Carrie M.

description: Excellent espresso and very friendly, knowledgable staff.  The brownies are also really good.  The space is a little small but that's part of the charm.  Great place to meet fellow coffee lovers.
author: Adam B.

description: Great coffee, nice people, good food. They seem to only have one major sweet dish and one major savory dish for breakfast - but they've been pretty consistently good in my experience. I just wish the place was a bit bigger (but that's a good problem to have!) :-D
author: Neal P.

description: farm:table is a great place to enjoy awesome coffee and tasty vittles, listen to a bunch of skinny 20- and 30-something web 4.0 dudes talk about twitternomics, and watch girls with ipods and big sunglasses walk by. highly recommended.
author: Sarah B.

description: Food and coffee/tea are outstanding. Space is very tight!
author: M P.

description: Tiny, cozy and comfortable. The coffee was delicious and exquisitely prepared with gourmet treats
author: Amy L.

description: I was a little intimidated by the hipster community table at first, but I'm glad I got over it.  It's like the Boulette's Larder/Cane Rosso of the Tendernob.
author: Vose S.

description: Coffee and treats are outstanding! I finally tried that hard boiled egg thing everybody always orders! I did not like it! Yuck! way to much butter on it! I felt sick after. I dont suggest the hard boiled egg thing in less you are a huge fan of butter.
author: mandi r.

description: Okay, so if you asked me about a year ago I would have said 10 stars. I don't normally write reviews but due to the fact I have gradually lost interest in going, to the point I no longer desire my daily coffee here, I feel the need to write about how sad I am they are no longer what they used to be. I used to love the same familiar faces which included the awesome owner, Kate. Super friendly down to earth people who knew how to perfectly craft coffee/espresso and make deliciously salivating food. As time went on, farm:table started getting more and more crowded as it seemed more people discovered just how great this place was. Things began to change. It started with the constant meatloaf sandwiches on the menu, smothered in ketchup. I could somewhat deal with that by just not ordering it but then a whole new staff came in, only to see the faces I knew so well only here and there. I'd order a coffee I would always order on a warm day in the past only to be told they had something else instead. Even my usual latte is not as silky sweet as it once was. I've stopped going but the past two times my boyfriend has gone, he has left feeling sick from the overtly rich and oddly spiced soup. Perhaps the soup doesn't suit his stomach, regardless, I'm sad to say, the new chef is not so great. And I really don't understand why this meatloaf deserves it's very own day. I just hope the next time I decide to give it a try, just for kicks, it's as good as I remembered it to be.
author: Samantha S.

description: this is my favorite type of cafe: unpretentious, excellent coffee, neighborly, simple menu so as not to overtax the am brain. wish one was next door to my house like this.
author: D L.

description: farm:table is amazing.  The wonderful Kate and Shannon own and run this sweet little joint.  If you like Blue Bottle, you will love this place as the coffee is just as good if not better.  The food is DELICIOUS.  Had the best pulled-pork sandwich of my life - and I'm from the south.  Thanks Kate.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Garen S.

description: Walking down Post St is not my usual route, except when I remember that Farm:Table happens to be on it!!!  Super yummy coffee, amazing pastries, and people who really know and love their stuff!  So happy to have a wonderful cafe in my work neighborhood.  I look forward to drinking many more coffees and putting on the pounds from their sweets.
author: Jennifer C.

description: finally things are starting to look up for new establishments coming into the City, and FINALLY they are not all located in neighborhoods like the mission or hayes valley.  i get it, you want a nice hipster/yuppie market/clientle because they will always be filling up your space, but some of us foodies don't live in those hoods or want to always go to the same area for a quick lunctime snack with that crowd.  strollers, handle bar mustache's, and constant taps on the iphone can really get on ones nerve when wanting a relaxed atmos' for a bite.  i have admit, i'm a born-again-iphone-tapper.  sustainable and organic goods by the season for the downtown lunch hour, with a mixed clientle, and a comfortable setting.  get there soon and early if you want the lunch special which usually is vegetarian.  otherwise, for us veg out there, you'll be stuck with just a cookie and cup of joe.  that i can get at my famed spikes.  don't come in starving because it's not a gut-bomb type of place.  welcome to the City farm:table, you sure are a treat.
author: Boho H.

description: a great place for a coffee and a piece of toast.  not much more to eat there than that.  but i liked it a lot.
author: Benjamin C.

description: i used to be a barista in Seattle for a micro-roaster/espresso cafe. this is by far the best latte i've had since moving to San Francisco, the only other place I prefer is ritual roasters. they even do latte art! the only bad thing it's also the most expensive latte, at $.50 more than any other place, but it's sorta worth it if you enjoy good espresso!
author: Melissa C.

description: the coziest of all.  tiny is the word.  the kind & generous staff did not mind my friend & i staying for over 3 hours to chat, despite their 1 treasured table available.  we were even given two complimentary breakfast entrees when the server forgot to tell us the kitchen was fresh out of bread pudding.  as we were in no hurry, the gesture was most appreciated.  the coffee is scrumptious.  the food was very good.
author: therese a.
